Whether thats a fair comparison is fair to debate, but either way... Not close.. but good.
Bottle. Smells like wine.  Opaque dark cooper color. Tastes like a very good wine. Hits all the places on your tounge. An amazing beer.

On draft @itap. Pours dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is malts, yeast  and dark fruits. Flavor is sweet malts, dark fruits and a bit of alcohol. Medium to light bodied with medium carbonation. Pretty good beer.

Small bottle poured into a Trappist glass, dark brown with generous foam.  Great aroma of brown bread, molasses, caramel, and maybe a little fruit and cinnamon.  Flavor doesnt disappoint either.  Starts sweet and bready, with caramel, and toffee.  Some bitterness, spice, and alcohol dryness in the finish.  Great flavor, great balance, great beer.
Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels, Belgium august 2011. Dark brown, big creamy head. Malty, yeast and floral aroma. Tastes sweet and malty. Realy nice beer :-)
Hazy dark brown color with a nice dark red glow coming through, off-white head. Nice smell and taste, like this better than Westvleteren 12. Very nice quadrupel.

This is quite popular at bars around Madison.  Draft at Jacs.  Huge, long lasting head..not unlike Guinness.  Thick, burgundy brown body.  Rich fruity aroma, devoid of harsh alcohol notes.  Super smooth body, light and draught like.  Rich and fruity, super creamy.  A top notch example of a Quad, really clean and drinkable.  Approachign nutty, lots of smooth Eastern European chocolate tones as well.  World Class.

pours dark brown with lots of yeast sediment, a lasting thick off-white head and plenty of lacing.  aroma is plums, licorice and caramel.  body is full with a slight alcohol burn.  taste is rich with sweet, overipe fruit notes some floral elements as well, possibly lavender or jasmine.  finish is more bitter but retains the rich sweetness of the overall experience.  a strong, lovely beer.

This is "my favorite beer in whole wide world." Seriously, it is. Im biased. I spent a day and night at the brewery in March this year. Ive had this at the brewery itself, in bars in Belgium, in bars in the US and at home. I love it.

The aroma ia the only category in which I didnt give it a perfect score. I gave it 9 out of 10. The aroma is pleasant. Their are hints of fig, malt, goodness. Only Rochefort may have a better aroma.

This beer pours a brown, hazy chocolate like color. The head is off white and stands an inch high. The head lingers and coats the glass on its way down.

The taste is heavenly. I get figs, sweetness, fruity (but not too much so) and malty. Very limited alcohol taste for such a high alcohol brew. It dances on the tongue and is warm going down. The entire mouth regals with pleasure.

I love this beer. Its the overall most wonderful beer in my beer universe.

Im drinking this in a glass purchased at the brewery and the beer is bottle conditioned. Ive had this on tap only once, in Philadelphia. And I didnt like it. Something was lost in the kegging. Or, this bar, which I wont name, had bad keg lines. It wasnt as good as Im used to. But since Ive had it at the brewery itself, maybe Im more familiar with it than most.

Dark brown pour with fluffy off white head on tap. Aroma of malt and caramel. Taste of plums, raisins, caramel and dried fruits with a nicely balanced hop finish. Sweetened up abit as it warmed to room temperature. Very good beer but slightly overrated.
(Bottle 20/08-2011) Medium beige head, dark brown color, medium co2, round and well balanced taste.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 Pours dark brown, bit of reddish tinge. Big cream foamy head, which dissipates quickly. Nose is very good. First theres citrous fruit, then chocolate, then dark fruit, yeasty overripe fruit. Prune, raisons, black grape,  Taste has a nice fruit hop kick to it. Citrous, then chocolate malt, then dark fruits, bit of sugary fruity sweetness. Not as good as Orval or Rochefort 10 though. Re-rate comparison Abt 12 tasting 17/01/14. Very effervescent out of the bottle, lots of bubbles, dark brown beer thats almost clear, with a big off white foam head thats almost gone after a minute. Nose is rich and bold malty, ripe fruit, banana, prune, raisin and sultana, bread, rye bread. Taste is tangy ripe fruit, dried fruits, prune, raisin and sultana, fruit cake, bread, rye bread, spiciness, cocoa-cola, fruity and a noticable alcoholic kick. Im comparing it to Westy 12 and the St. B is definitely fruiter and more cola-ish, slightly more watery. Westy is much more malty and subtle, the alcohol is more hidden. Updated rating from 3.9 to 4.1.
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2011 Bottle. Outstanding. Strong fruity aroma. Nice dark brown colour. Full of fruity flavour with abv hidden. Nice lively palate. Truly great beer.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2011 I was a bit let down by this one considering its fine reputation.  The smell was very faint.  It reminded me of Nag Champa incense, bananas, figs and a trace of booze.  The sum of its parts are pleasant, but Ive sniffed much better.  No, really.

The taste was good, but I didnt think it was outstanding:  medium bitterness, slightly spicy, slightly boozy, slightly funky.  I didnt taste much fruit or sweetness in this ale.  This is a hearty, robust Belgian ale.  Very manly.  Haha.

750mL corked bottle poured hazy deep brown which when held up to light brings reddish hues.  Massive off-white head with great retention and fine lacing.  Aromas of roasted malts and yeast.  Well balanced rich flavors, very smooth, hides the alcohol very well.  Nice feel of carbonation on the tongue and medium to full body.

Appearance is murky dark brown with khaki head and good retention, small head.  Aroma is mainly dried fruit, raisin, plum, spice, yeast, dough, caramel candy.  Taste is spicy, fruity, slightly boozy. Stings the tongue.  Body is light, effervescent, slick, and finishes very spicy.  Overall, a good beer but not my preference.

Bottle.

Dark brown with a large head. A lot of dried fruit in both the aroma and taste, also yeast. The taste was sweet and quite complex. An interesting beer that I would like to try again.

Pours deep chestnut brown with reddish purple hue, big cream head which keeps. Aroma has banana, caramel toffee and prunes. Taste has bananas, spices, caramel and dark fruits. Finishes well. High abv undetectable. Good stuff

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2011 Pours dark. Lots of sweet, fruity aroma. Nice carbonation, interesting slight tanginess on the back of the tongue. Deep, rich flavors of plum and raisin, but not overwhelmingly sweet. Pretty balanced. A unique, great beer.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a clear and dark amber beer with a firm offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel, sweetness, yeast, dark fruits and notes of alcohol. The flavor follows the nose with additional pepper and cloves. The palate is sweetness with notes of alcoholwarmth. Overall a really good and well balanced beer.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 Aroma is sweet malt and sweet dark fruit with a hint of alcohol. Appearance is quite dark in colour with a nice creamy head. very nice taste similiar to chimay red.to be re-rated at a later date.

Murky brown and orange.  Nice, full brown/off-white head.  Toasted malt, dark fruit, light raisin, sherry, merlot.  Dark fruit, toasted malt, sherry, some cider, raisin/plum, biscuit.  Tastes well-attenuated and not overly sweet.  Alcohol that is apparent only after-the-fact.  Beautifully smooth.  Very nice.
Dark amber color with a ok fine head. Malt aroma. Flavor is slightly fruity and delicious Belgian quadrupel.
The expected heavy belgian aromas of raisins, dried fruits and some alcohol. taste is raisins, earth and some tobacco.

Well, really, what hasnt been said about the Abt 12? Pours spectacularly to a full head. A combo fruity (as in those candies that come in Christmas breads) and malty aroma with a hint of alcohol. The taste ts sweet but not overly so. The nice, full body is well worth rolling over your tongue a few times before you let this go down to enjoy the long, sweet finish.

Appearance:  reddish-brown pour, tan head, decent lacing.   Aroma: raisins, plums, dark brown bread and brown sugar, with notes of cherry and booze.   Taste: dark, syrupy fruits, yeasty spices, a hint of malt liquor/doppelbock.   Finish: surprisingly crisp, sweetish and a little tart.   Notes: Interesting beer.  Almost like a fruitier Chimay Red.  Pretty good carbonation to offset the rich palate.  Alcohol was well-hidden for such a big beer.
Dark brown pour with a good sized light brown head. Perfect carbonation. Taste of molasses, fruit, spices, and quite sweet. Alcohol very prevalent.

Dough, dough, dough, did I say dough? In a good way. More like roasted dough. Heady and lively on the pour and pretty heavy on the alcohol taste depending on time of day I have it and thirst level.

Also has some staying power on the palette and lingers on the finish. Fairly fizzy as well. Raisins and dates come through in the middle.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 Aroma: Similar to Westvleteren 12. Spices, nuts, candy sugar, flower garden, oranges, cherries, yeast. 

Appearance: Dark brown. Big rocky off white head.
Taste: Quite like Westvleteren again, but not quite exact. It lacks the refinement very slightly....but its still quite good.  
Palate: Creamy, fine carbonation. Alcoholic. 
Overall: If you cant get Westvleteren or wish to get it the "proper" way the monks intended, this is a definite substitute. The irony is, at times, this is better than the "real deal"...very consistent whereas Westvleteren has some variance. Plus you get that silly character on the bottle. Dont study it too closely when drunk, he has shifty eyes and might pinch your nose.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, alcohol, fruit, spices and dark dried fruit. Flavour is caramel, alcohol, dried fruit, spices, pepper and clove.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Originally rated on 14.5.2009. Good, well balanced quadrupel. 8-4-8-4-16 = 4.0

Re-rated on 31.12.2011. BBE 18.05.15 - Pours dark brown with a large foamy and bubbly head. Aroma has notes of plum, raisin, dark fruits, malts, yeast and spices. Taste is quite strong and sweet with a lot of malts, dark fruits, raisin, plum and hints of spices. Finish is warming and slightly sticky and sweet with notes of fruits and alcohol. Quite well balanced, but could still use some more aging.

It poured a dark reddish brown with a light tan head, left some lacing, very attractive beer, just what I had hoped for. The aroma was OK, smelled of dark fruits, raisins, figs, dates etc. with a bit of chocolate and a bit of alcohol, smelled pretty damn sweet. The taste was similar to the nose, alcohol was hidden well but it was a little sweet for me, dont get me wrong it was tasty but it didnt blow me away.
Palate: Oily, medium bodied, not too bad.
Overall this beer was pretty tasty but a little too sweet for my liking.

Great stuff.  Pours dark red/purple with a large creamy head and plenty of lacing.  Smells like good champagne.  Taste starts with a lot of grape and dark fruit.  Finish is really quick and shockingly refreshing for something this strong.  Doesnt taste like booze at all, I could probably give this to a kid instead of juicy juice and theyd like it, but that would be a waste and a crime.    FYI I aged this one almost 2 years.  X date on the bottle is jan 13, 2015, whatever that means.

Appearance - St. Bernardus Abt 12 has some carbonation on the initial pour. Carbonation will stick to the sides as it is poured. Appearance was dark brown and pleasing to the eye. Some dark yeast specks could be seen floating near the bottom of the glass that I poured it into (had a special St. Bernardus Watou glass for the occasion).

Smell - The smell of the beer is quite sweet and full bodied. I smelled raisins and plums. Very malty aroma. 

Taste - The beer was a little bitter when it first hit my tongue. The bittnerness mellowed out into a faint sweetness as it passed to the back of my mouth. I could taste raisins and plums as it went down. 

Mouthfeel - Pretty heavily bodied. The beer was very smooth though and pleasing.

Overall - This beer was quite good. It was not as good as a Rochefort 8 that I had, but it was still exquisite. A very well-brewed beer. The only reason this was not rated higher was the bitterness that I tasted when I first drank the beer. I personally enjoy more of the sweet notes in the beer as compared to any bitterness.

This is certainly one of the best trappist beers available. Pours a dark brown with a large fluffy head. Lively carbonation levels. Body is full, quite thick. This is a big beer. Caramel, figs, brown sugar. Alcohol is quite noticeable on this beer...which is a good thing.

11.2 oz bottle served in a pint glass at home.  Creamy mouth feel and really foamy upon pouring.  Tastes a lot like a super sweet banana.  There is a slight burn while you are drinking.  Very well executed, just not my favorite style.

33 cL bottle from Beers of Europe into a Westmalle glass.  Very dark brown with a lively but gorgeous head.  Fine, rich aroma, fruity and very abbey like.  Tastes very mild despite the high alcohol, and very fruity and sweet.  Dangerously moreish!  Its a bit liquoricy, with a brief intense roastiness.  Excellent stuff.
Lively carbonation out of the bottle, fast fading head. Brown sugar, ripe fruits and spices. Warm and boozy and deliciously silky. Long finish.

Deep russet brown carrying a voluminous off-white to creamy white head. The nose is predominantly fruity with dehydrated apricots and guava. Theres also cocoa and nutmeg present. Fresh alcohol aromas make themselves known as the glass warms in the hand.
There is no one overriding falvour upon tasting. It has chocolate, nutty toastiness, ginger, glace fruit all at once. Then theres a tangy juicy fruitiness. It is one of the most complete palate I have experienced. This is a very special beer.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 Beautiful brown beer with a tan, fizzy, quickly-disappearing head. The aroma is has an assertive alcohol presence that spoils an otherwise superb bouquet of dark fruits, yeast, spices, and caramel malts. The taste follows the aroma notes, with an equally boozy feel, but with more of a sour, citrusy note that I like very much. The palate is a bit thin and significantly carbonated, which makes for an easy-drinking brew that can be sipped but doesnt have to be. Going back to the abv, you DO feel it throughout, though it NEVER deters you from drinking on. Its quite easy to drink large quantities of this and you wont know youre getting drunk until you are. This is a very good beer that, in my book, lives up to its reputation. Its widely available, so theres no excuse for not giving it a try.
Update: I tried a more aged version and the alcohol edge has smoothed over wonderfully. Its a really drinkable beer, with an excellent fruity flavor and the yeast coming through spectacularly. I think I also detected a hint of anise, or otherwise something herbal and delicious. Ill have to bring the score up three notches.
Very smooth. Some spice and dark fruit (fig perhaps). The usual brown coloring of a quad. Obviously a top notch beer... you dont need me to tell you that.

Finally had this on tap tonight at Tapwerks in OKC. Pours murky dark brown with some rusty hues. Aromas of dark fruits, raisins, caramel, and bready malts. Flavors of bread, yeast, dark malts, spices, and dark fruits. Mouthfeel is smooth but lack the complexity I was expecting. Still very nicely done.

Date: July 3, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Beer Tasting, Bloomington, MN Appearance: Opaque with slight amount of head Aroma: Fruity, hint of fig Flavor: Consistent with aroma and I got some slight carbonation

Poured from corked and caged bottle into tulip glass.  Pours a rich Mahogany much like Ron Burgundys apartment.  Tons of beige head, too much carb?  Taste is raisins and other dried stone fruits like prune.  The right amount of Belgian yeast smell and taste in there too.  The alcohol is not noticeable.  A great beer.

Rating #1100. 330ml bottle. After a huge struggle to ease without cap without losing 1/2 the contents, it poured a deep, dark & murky brown with a small, loose & bubbly beige head that took a good deal of agitating to generate. Boozy, sum-soaked raisin and prune aromas, with molasses & a Belgian yeast backbone as well a lighter notes of caramel & toffee. Rum, raisin, Belgian yeast & some fruity tang on the tongue, a bit of choccy fruit, mild roasted malt notes, light bready tones & a demerara sugar sweetness. A bit lifeless on the palate due to the initial eccentricities of carbonation. Warming & boozy in the throat, medium in body, softish mouthfeel with a medium length, rummit bitterness & fruit skin finish. Very drinkable given the ABV.

Pours a caramel/mahogany color. Big off-white head that stays about the same height the entire drink, and leave ample lacing behind in its wake. Smells of vanilla and caramel immediately strike me. Follow that up with raisins and malt. Tastes of raisin juice, kind of like the newest Westy Ive had - but better. Sweet and creamy. Nice overall flavor and body. Nice easily obtainable beer from the folks who used to brew the Westy.

Bottle 750ml, pours very dark brown with loads of off white foam ! aroma is dried dark fruits, alcohol, bread,nuts......the flavor is very nice! creamy, dark fruits, hops, bitter, rom resin :) ..... I like this beer! very Belgian......
First time I had this I absolutely loved it. And it is one of the rare ones my husband and I agree on.  Though not my usualy suspect, I thouroughly enjoyed it again tonight!

Poured into my trapist glass. Pours dark radish brown. Aroma is very fruity, like dtied fruit. Flavour is very nice as well. This is a great trapist ale, and if your going to try one dont cheap out, go for the best!
A dark beer pours with very thick rich head; aroma sweet and deep; taste has a very fruity flavour with rich yeasty body; very good
UPDATED: APR 28, 2013 Retasted this beer again yesterday and I have to give it more points then I did before. Quite a strong beer but still very balanced. Easy to drink, fruity, tasteful, nice.
Pour is deep cola brown with a a slightly off white head. Nose is of dark fruits and and sugar. Taste is light ans very sweet, not at all indicative of 10% abv. which is a nice change of pace.

In bottle. Poured a dark ruby colour with a fair light tan head. Lots of belgian candi sugar on the nose and to taste balanced  beautifully with the fruity, raison flavours. Lingering spice and some co2 prickle. A very well crafted trappist.
Splendida quadrupel che è perfetta da bere prima di infilarsi a nanna... Lunico problema è che ci vorrebbe la bottiglia da 75, perchè da 33 si finisce in un attimo...
Dark colour,great head. Fruity aromas with some yeasty carracter. Sweet taste with fruity carracter. Excellent beer

I take special care and caution as I try this highly acclaimed special bottle of expected goodness.
Will this match the expectation that is put upon it? Shall it be worthy of sharing this as I admire my best girls glorious butt-cheeks and the very best of Louis Prima vintage recordings on wind up stereo for thick records?
I pour and let the minimal head settle The aroma is sweet but not overly so. The color is of a fine Brazilian woman I was with years ago that remains a sacred memory of love and devotion; She had the most glorious butt-cheeks that held the same deep color that this St. Bernardus has. Yes the color of both the beverage and butt-cheeks was especially blessed.
I take my first sip and telling from my heart, this is quite delicious. Very complex with a medley of flavors such as the fine Louis Prima song The Music Goes Round and Around. Wonderful throughout the entire consumption I wish for more and the second sip is better than the first. The head remains velvety and smooth - such can only be compared to one of my best girls glorious asses, Vera - so very smooth with the texture of beautiful butt flesh cared for with the caution of the Hope Diamond.
The remaining portion of the glass represents all that is well and good in the world of beverages, music and fine women. Incredibly tasty, never to tire of and craving more and more Should I take but a few of each to an island for my remaining years, I would include this fine liquid along with the treasures of Louis Prima and my selection of best girls  this ale is worthy of such love to accompany the best things in life.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2014 11.2 oz bottle. Great beer and one of my favorite quads. Pours a mirky lighter brown with a decent off white khaki head. A thick beer with more than can be noticed quickly finishing with a warm alcoholic finish that fronts most of the flavors. Dense bready yeast permeates everything with bits of fruitiness poking through and some spice. A bit of dry grass is in the finish but mostly a good warmth. Light touches of cinnamon and some clove with red and sweet green apple flavors, grape skin dryness, so rich but so tasty. Gets good at 1-3 years in the bottle, and probably lasts for 10+.
Pours a dark color with lit head, but very fruity aroma. Nice flab or and alcohol content.

750 to chalice.  Pours dark amber with big off-white head that laces to the last.  I get bread, apples, dark fruit, a hint of citrus and a little hay--pretty complex.  Taste is sweet, something near molasses.  Very creamy and smooth mouth feel, but a tad too much carbonation.  I get no aftertaste, just a warm alcohol finish.  A very good beer.

Dark brown color, big brown creamy head. Plum, alcohol, yeast and berries in aroma. Flavor is strong cream and toffee with a sting of alcohol. Also malts and yeast make their way through. Lovely product with a nice long roasted aftertaste in the throat as well as creamy toffee in the mouth.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2013 Pitch dark brown body with an off white head. Complex and sweet aroma of plum, brown sugar, caramel, apple, blueberries. Flavour has fruits, chocolate, alcohol and spices. Great beer. (8/5/8/5/18)
Very dark brown body, medium rocky off white head. Excellent complex aroma with plum, brown sugar, licorice, apricot, spices and berries. Amazing warming flavour with chocolate, licorice, bread, dark fruits. Really great.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2012 33cl bottle at home. Dark brownish red with a nice off white head. Cloudy with some floaters. Lots of fruits, raisin, caramel, spices, and alchohol. Moderate carbonation and slighty syrupy texture. Delicious.

70 cl btl.: Pitch black, very lively with fine head. nose is Sweet nose with fruit figs, sweety mature banana, raisins. a massive nose that evolves and keeps you sniffing for new fragrances. fullbodied with fine length. Lively - almost to much co2!. Taste is sweet, but welballanced with kandis, fruit, brown sugar. A lithg dry bitter exit ruins an otherwise perfect impression. But this is still a very fine though heavy beer.
Love the complex flavor, high alc % and the surprising fruit finish. I cant stand fruit flavored beers but this one was amazing!
Cest une bière exceptionnel qui a une belle apparence et qui a un goût parfait
Bottle 33cl. Amber colour with a light beige head. Fruit and malt dominate the nose. Very rich taste where the malt & alcohol is noticeable. Sweet finish, which last long.
This is probably my favorite quad.  I prefer it to any of the trappist beers (havent drank my westy 12 yet).  Taste is caramel, dark fruit, raisin with a delciously sweet finish.

Maybe too old, maybe not old enough (it was a gift).  Either way, minimum head, no lacing.  Taste is of figs, prunes, molasses, and caramel, but in an underwhelming way.  Little carbonation (it wasnt flat), and slight bittering near the finish.

Rating #700, on tap at The Malt House in Madison, WI, poured into a trappist glass, pours a dark amber/brown with a nice thick head and lacing through out the entire glass, the aroma is full of dark fruit with plum and a hint of booze, the flavor is loaded with dark fruit and with a slight finish of booze, the flavor is extremely smooth and enjoyable, I could drink this all night.

Pours a slightly hazy deep brown with a huge off white head that slowly dissipates to a cap as it sticks itself all over my glass. Smells of dark fruits raisins prunes fig come to mind. Also has a sweet dark sugar and molasses aroma as well. Twinge of alcohol evident too. Taste is sweet with dark fruits, molasses, brown bread, melanoidin and alcohol. Carbonation is high, mouthfeel is full and sticky sweet, body is thick. I liked this one, but I thought the alcohol was a little to present. Good, but maybe needs some age to mellow it out a bit. I also would have liked a bit less carbonation.

Great brew. Strong and smells yeasty with a light tinge of alcohol. Although 10%, this beer is not overly alcoholic. Pours a dark brown - same color as the bottle, and has a beautiful thick brownish white head that remains.
A beer so good it goes above and beyond my humble, debauched tastes.  Heavier on the beginning than the aftertaste, strong taste of alcohol.  Drank in a bottle on a misty mountain in Taiwan
Eccezionale Quadrupel Belga, 10,5 gradi, complessissima ma incredibilmente buona . una delle migliori al mondo, a mio avviso.

Bottle. Pours a dark amberish brown with a bubbly tan head.  Smell of ripened fruit (grapes, plums, lemons, orange zest) with the doughy, yeasty notes as well.  Tastes, wow, just wow -- its almost like a port wine or an after dinner liqueur.  The flavors are so complex with the taste of candied fruit, raisins that explodes in your mouth.  Pretty sure I took about 40 minutes to enjoy this one.  Throughout it opened up to chocolatey and caramel flavors.  The high ABV is so well hidden with only an after affect of warmth.   Truly fabulous beer and I am glad this is widely availably in Georgia.
Sublime. NO body payed much attention to this and suddenly tghe shelf was empty. I wonder in what meassure is it my fault. Nuce features in every way an sweet alcoholic.

This is one that explodes in your mouth. Lots of taste, dark chocolate, caramel, candi sugar and dark berries. Thick mouthfeel, strong, longlasting taste. Nice, foamy, frothy head that last long and leaves little lacing on the glass. This is one to try more often and that gives you a different experience everytime you try it. It looks good in the St. Bernardus goblet, wich is a thick glass.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Bottle @ home. Pours a very dark brown appearance with a fluffy brown head. Candy sugar, dark malts, dark fruits, plums, Belgian yeast, chocolate, caramel in the nose. A very full, sweet candy flavor. Candy sugar, lots of caramel, chocolate, Belgian yeast, and sweet dark malty flavor. Well carbonated. Excellent caramel, chocolate aftertaste. The booze is almost completely hidden behind the candy characteristics. This beer really got me into Belgian beers and in particular, Quadrupels. One of my all-time favorite beers!

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 Bottle pour ---> Trappist glass. I think this is the 5th bottle (non-consecutively) Ive had. Pours a very deep hazy brown, with a nice pillowy head, and and coming down to trails of lacing. Aromas are complex and rich, with dark fruits and malts and sweet yeast to follow. Undertones of light chocolate, coffee and alcohol fill the nose with promise. The flavor was extravagant, full of fig and malts - very sweet overall with a very fruity and complex finish. The aftertaste was of spices and had the warmth of alcohol. Truly a fantastic brew, and it should be at the top of your list.

Like Westvleteren, yet much easier to obtain. Brewery used to brew according to the original recipe till the time came that the monks had to take it back into their own hands. Strangely enough, rarity does add to the appreciation.
Dark reddish black, with creamy tan pillowy  and lasting head. Aroma of malts, caramel, candy sugar, ripe fruits, some liquorice. Flavour of sweet powerful malts, caramel, candied fruits. Alcohol gives a warm depth to the flavour. Full sweet mouthfeel, OK bitterness.
Beautiful trappist that cant be called one. (from 33cl bottle)
schiuma lunga color mogano, al naso lieviti, uvetta, cioccolato, al palato cè molto equilibrio tra il malto, dolce e caramellato e il lievito, molto speziato. grande birra
750 ml bottle pours an brown amber colore with a big off white head.  Aromas of caramel, raisins, and yeast.  Full bodied with a great mouthfeel, truly on of the best
Like anything needs to be said about this except that goddamn its amazing, and this is the 2501st rating!
One of my favourites! Multi-flavoured with no bitter aftertaste. Will try again and again.
Bottle in de paas, pours brown with little head. Fruity with raisins and a slightly sharp aftertaste. Lingering flavor with alcohol warmth

Bottle @ Home. Pours deep brown with a offwhite head, that setles to a thin layer af foam. Aroma is sweet fruit, plums in front, yeast, nuts, marzipan, ripe apples, caramel Taste is fruity and sweet, caramel, plums, raisins, chocolate, yeast, alchohol is very well hidden. Full bodied, soft silky mouthfeel, low carbonation ( not flat ). Yummi beer, soft and sweet, full flavored. 280411

750ml bottle. in chalice. pours deep brown with a murky look to it. nice thick, tight beige head that lasts forever and leaves tons of lacing on the glass. aroma is sweet and fruity, with alcohol and caramel malts. taste is sweet yet a bit acidic, molasses, caramel, coffee, loads of dark fruits and a delicious yeasty aftertaste. mouthfeel is incredible. like velvet. full bodied, not much carbonation. this beer is intense. absolutely spectacular.

bottle, bought in Watou, caramel, coffee, grass, amberdark , stable brown foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, average carbonation, thick feel, slick feel, long finish, yeah lovely beer
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: So far I have had two different offerings from St. Bernardus. Both were spectacular and completely different. While the Wheat was very easy to drink and actually drank more like a cider the Abt. 12 had a ton of complex flavor. Poured a deep deep brown with a thick head. Strong smells of alcohol followed by fruits, cherry, raisins and maybe even banana. Though I could smell the alcohol strongly it was well hidden in the flavor. Slight hops flavor and mild malt. This beer had a lot of sweet flavors but not sugary sweet. It was very pleasant. Cherry, chocolate, raisins, bread and yeast. And nicely carbonated to give it just the right fizz.
dark brown pour. medium head. fruit raisin bread.  dark well balanced beer. same fruit taste. good hops at end. flavour lasts and is very pleasant.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 pours deep redish brown with a brown head. On the nose I got lots of sweet dark dried fruits, plums, belgian yeast, bready notes and caramel. Taste add a weak tart profile from the yeast along with some chocolate, toffee, ripe fruits and hints of alcohol.

11 April 2011, bottle. dark hazelnut colour, very hazy. looks promising! nose is big alcohol w/ lots of cherries. when i get accustomed to alcohol i can smell some tart hay and raisins and the faintest of bananas. full/med body and moderately fizzy. big alcohol and dark or warm cherries. lots of dark fruit balanced (almost overwhelmed) by big alcohol. yeast is prominent but i wouldnt call it yeasty. slightly tart nutty finish. gorgeous!

33cl. Pours chocolate/chestnut brown with some head, though it doesnt all hang around - a little bit murky. The nose has chocolate and plums. The taste is rich and plummy with more chocolate and a hint of liquorice. Lovely palate - big structure, lovely creamy texture and then a long refreshing zingy finish.

Yummy and wow.
Aroma is slightly hops, little malts with notes of citrus 
Opens with a slight pop, pours clear light amber into a tulip glass develops a nice froath that leaves a small lace at the rim.
taste is slightly hops, light malts and citrus with a little alcohol
Palate feel is smooth, starts medium to a slightly dry feel, no creaminess but finishes wonderfully with a staying taste of a GREAT beer.
Overall my wife and I really enjoyed this one and will revisit it often.

I have been looking forward to trying this highly rated classic for a while.  The label pictures a cheery, shiny abbot against a deep blue sky.  Dark and foamy pour with russet hilites.  Malty and tangy aroma with peaches and raisins, also touches of clove, leather, and alcohol.  It is malty and fizzy on the palate, with a lingering tingle.  I detected flavors of cocoa, prune, coffee, tobacco, and stone fruits, also yeast and dark bread.  This is one of those beers - I am sure we all have a few - that I think well of and am giving a high rating to, but...somehow something doesnt seem quite right.  Maybe Im just not getting it somehow - could it be because there is so much going on in the flavor?  Still, the aftertaste is very nice, and the alcohol is well cloaked.  All right, I take it back.  This is a first rate brew, and I will reach for it again.

A - Pours an opaque ruby-brownish color with a thick two fingers of frothy off-white head. The retention on the head is very good and leaves behind lots of lace on the glass.

S - Aroma is a mix of some dark fruit sweetness and also some more sugar sweetness. Some malt and spices make up a backbone to the nose. Touch of yeast and some lighter fruits.

T - Starts off with some building dark fruit flavors and some deep caramel malts. Little bit of spice in the background. Through the middle some sweeter grape flavor comes through alongside some cherry flavor. The finish has a blend of dark fruit, some roasted malt, and a touch of apple/cherry flavor that lingers nicely. 

M - Medium bodied with moderate lively carbonation. Feels really smooth and crisp, even with a lot of flavor hitting the palate. Finish is just a touch dry and very nice.

D - Very drinkable. Lots of flavors that stay really well balanced, and also dont make the beer feel too heavy. The 10.5 abv here really stays in the background and makes it almost a bit dangerous.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2012 Bottle from Mane Liquor. This is one massive belgian. Pours a very deep brown with a fairly big white head after a bottle pour. The nose is full of dried fruits and brown sugar. Raisins, plums and fig come to mind. Has some lively carbonation. The flavours combine to produce a smooth complexity of dark and dried fruits, sweet malts and brown sugar. This beer is fantastic

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2011 have tried both the larger corked and the smaller capped version.  It pours a merky light  brown color with an off white head that leaves a little layer of white bubbles at the top after it subsides.  The smell is sweet an some what yeast.  The taste is strong and boozy up front full but then evens out with a sweet dried fruit finish.  Nicely balanced and an over all nice Quad.

Im generally not a fan of belgian beers but had to give this one a try because of its rep.  Had it on tap and it was very good.  Smooth, malty, fruity and noticable alcohol.  Tried it in the bottle a couple days later and it was a bit too carbonated for me.  Great beer overall though.

Poured from a corked bottle without a freshness date into a St. Bernadus goblet. Beer is brown, high haze, white head made up of smallish bubbles, lacing on glass, carbonation mild.

Aroma is very weak and subtle. Some sweetness a little alcohol, no hops or roast.

Beer is full bodied and smooth. Yeasty flavor, tons of malt, some sweetness from the malt / alcohol. This is a really good beer. It is not as good as I remember though. I feel like Ive had better quads to date. I will try it again and review it again in the future, even though Im giving it a good review now, it didnt live up to my memory.

Serving type: bottle

Nose full of raisins and brown sugar.  Medium on the tongue with hints of cinnamon, brown bread, and lively carbonation.  Head is billowy and white.  Hint of alcohol on the finish.  Well balanced and delicious.

St. Bernie 12 is one helluva Belgian, a delicious quadrupel that for some reason calls itself a Dubbel on the label.  Who cares what you call it, though, because this beer tastes divine.  Convenient, what with the monk on the bottle and all.  Bubbly, beautiful, and oozing with dark, dried fruit and a surprisingly dry yet mildly hopped finish...I find it easy to forget how good this brew tastes.  NOTE #1:  This bottle is at least two years old, and, while it does still have some heat, 24 months makes for  quality bench time for this brew.  NOTE #2:   "Abt 12" is one bastard of a term to define.  "Abt" refers to "Abbot," the highest ranked dude at the monastery, and thus the guy deserving of the most specialest beer ever.   The meaning of the "12," however, was debated for centuries, causing much anger and spite between the Nine Houses Of Belgian Strong Dark Ales, or NineHoBelgoStroDarAle for short.  It wasnt until legendary bartender and beer explorer Massachusetts La Toose uncovered the Flemish Red Sea Scrolls that the true meaning of the 12 was found.  After nearly dying from the sheer awfulness of the pun in the scrolls title, La Toose translated the scrolls from his recovery bed, and uncovered the long sought-after truth:  "12" was, in fact not a 12 at all, but a poorly transcribed uppercase "R".  We still have no fucking clue what the "R" means.

Aroma is grapefruity, and grape like  appearance is dark brown with a white head, first taste is highly carbonated you get some slight fruit and doughy yeast flavor very hard to find flavor in this beer, feel like it is lacking flavor big time for the style very disappointed and it is not at all worth ten dollars a bottle

Pours the color of strong tea with a white, tightly-bubbled, three-finger head.  Good lacing.  

Rich, yeasty and fruity aroma.  Banana bread or apple cake with clove and pepper spice.  A fermenty mash of pantry staples.

Taste is rich and complex.  Toffee and bread, caramel, raisins, dates, pears, and tea.  Creamy, earthy, and rich beer.  Delicious.

Pours cloudy with ruby Red highlights. Fairly big head after a bottle pour. Aroma of bread and yeast and vegetable smells that made me hungry for a pizza. Palate is thick and warm with bIg spice notes that deepens as it warms. Fantastic!

12 oz. glass poured into a Trappist glass. Pours a dark, hazy brown with a thick, beige head with speckles of sediment. The aroma is amazing... Dark fruit, caramel, maple sugar, and full of spice. Flavor is caramel, raisin, fig, Belgian yeast, and a slight booziness. Such smooth and complex character. Palate is like drinking liquid velvet.... my tongue is practically making love to this beer. The aftertaste is an alcohol warmth with a lingering sweetness that begs for more. Overall, one of the most exceptional quads out there. It has definitely earned its rank among the Rocheforts and the Westies. Anyone who thinks otherwise, stick with your Fat Tire and shut up!
Very good beer. Mild fruity undertones along with a smooth hoppy taste. One of my favorites.
Bottle. Pours brown with a nice thick lingering white head. Aroma is dark fruit. Flavor is earthy fig and raisin. Delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: pleasantly surprised by this one given my lack of excitement about their other offerings which I tried before, tasted of sweet malt, overripe fruits (not in too overt & compliment in this one) including grapes, dark fruits, caramel, brown sugar, bitter aftertaste, plenty carbonation, medium bodied, bottle around 3 weeks old ///////////////// Had again a couple of more times, most times bottled + 2 * draft. Should take proper notes. I still find this one to be too light bodied & weak tasting compared to similar offerings. Overrated in my opinion.

bottle poured into tumbler. dark brown colour, ample head. Aroma of brown/maple sugar, berries, fruit, yeast. Taste is sweet, yet superbly balanced. I really got a lot of berry taste; blueberries and cherries. Fantastic beer.
This beer tastes like burnt honey and soy sauce. I did not lik it, its not good.

Cloudy dark brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, dried fruit, yeasty and a little alcohol. Flavor is rather sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish with warming alcohol. Full bodied, soft and smooth. Excellent balance. 120510

This quad poured a cloudy brown colour with a fizzy, creamy, light tan coloured head. To the nose there are scents of brown sugar, maple sugar, alcohol, ripe fruit, and caramel. First sip was smooth and only slightly carbonated. Flavours of alcohol, caramel, hay and a little wine are most prodominant.Finish is warm and malty with a slight bitterness libgering.
This beer was the highlight of our beer tasting. From the laceing and color to the smell and taste. Hands down one of the bests.
A dark beer with a nice fruity flavour. Pretty good stuff. Ill have another.

Bottle into trappist glass.  Pours a deep, dark, murky brown with an off white, 2 finger head.  Appears nicely carbonated.  Leaves nice lacings on the glass.  Boozey aroma.  Taste is a boozy warming and belgian yeasty goodness.  As I let the glass sit, it becomes less boozy, however.  Medium carbonation, medium body.   Very good, but I much prefer Chimay or Rochefort in regards to this style.

330 ml bottle in Germany. Big dense white head, Red-brown color. A real nice looking beer. Birch beer aroma (sweet), natural, slightly smokey. Flavor is sweet but of tobacco and chocolate, not much in the way of a fruit flavor. Hops play a nice part at the front of the tongue. Plalte is very clean. Alcohol becomes apparent as it warms and has great mouthfeel. A great great brew

From a 330ml bottle on 27/2/2011. Bottle marked best before 1/12/14. Pours a cloudy very dark brown, with a good head. Has a moderate aroma of dark fruit, Belgian yeast, hazlenut praline and alcohol. Flavour wise, dark fruits dominate, but there are touches of citrus fruit as well. It has a slightly peppery spiciness, with some caramel and toffee notes. The carbonation is mild and the bitterness modest. This is a nice, high quality, warming sipper, but as has been the case with a number of other big Belgian ales with massive reputations, it just doesnt quite have what it takes to thrill me. Perhaps its just a style thing.
One of my favorites...you can smell the complex flavors wafting off its head.  Enjoy it in the proper, goblet-style glass.

On tap at the Map Room Chicago. Pours a deep ruby brown with a fluffy off white head. Aroma is soft and delicate, but nicely complex with dark fruits of pruney  raisin and plum, nuttiness, some candy sweetness, earthy malty notes. Flavor starts with a great roasty character with some soft cocoa and a woodiness, a nice creamy nuttiness, a touch boozy but in a good way. Great medium to medium full creamy body and a soft carbonation. Very well rounded complex and yet easy drinking.

33cl bottle. Rating #2400. Deep mahogany brown with a billowing cream head; the aroma has yeast and some fruit; smooth and soft in the mouth, with jammy fruits and thick dry treacly malts; the finish is sweet and plummy and the alcohol is warming but well hidden. An assured and well executed Abt.

Opaque brown pour with red tones, small brown head.
Aroma is huge- fruits, raisins, yeast, sweet malt, alcohol and a woody whiskey-like character after sitting for a bit. Flavor is sweet, dried fruits tempered by a bitter alcohol presence. Big finish. Mouthfeel goes from initial creaminess to a sudden rush of carbonation.

Pours a very dark orange.  Nice light tan head.  Nose is yeast, dark fruit, spices and alcohol.  Taste is much the same but the less on the alcohol.  This beer feels great on the palate.  A very good Abt Quad and the best I have had from St. Bernardus.

330ml bottle, best before 07/09/2015 (6 months old). Pours dark hazy amber/brown with high carbonation, 1 finger head that settle to a light small bubbly lace. The exact big belgian yeasty aroma you expect - not many do it better - what a snoof! Highly carbonated in the mouth, sweet and yeasty with a some fruit and alcohol. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel, yeast and fruit with some sweetness. What a great beer!

Nose of fruity belgian yeasts with a very complex malty palate that complements the yeast flavors. Usually I find that the malts are bland or the yeast is overpowering, this is the perfect combination

Fairly fresh 750ml - Pours a burnt orange with a thin, but fluffy off white, tan.  Aroma is fruity, yeast, spices, cloves, cinnamon, figs, very slight alcohol buried on the backend.  Taste is basically the same, slightly more fruit-forward, a bit of citrus/orange peel, plums, pears, etc, and a tiny bit of alcoholic bite on the very end.  Overall, an incredibly complex and balanced beer - definitely would improve with age on it.

Cloudy brown pour.  Most of head dissipated quickly, but remnants lingered.  Aroma....  Lots of flavor: malt, cherry, maybe dry apricot (not too sweet though), almost a scotch ale feel in there as well.  The flavor lingers and is good for the duration.  Very nice.
Agreable a boire grace a un gout tres equilibrer, legere presence darome fruite.
Really good Dark Belgium strong beer.  Has great odor with some touches of coffee and a bit of chocolate.  Taste the coffee most prevalent and chocolate second.  Very dark in color with a dark head.

Dark cider/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, yeast, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums & apricots), caramel, raisons, and spice; Slight alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, doesnt quite measure up to Rochefort - but still very good.

Large Bottle served in trappist glass. AWESOME BREW! Aroma consisted of heavy fruits such as plum, raisin, etc. Head was nice and thick off-white with a decent consistency. Flavor was heavy fruit and sweetness like candy. One of the best brews Ive ever had.

Pour fizzy very dark almost opaque brown with creamy finger thick head with minimal lacing. Aroma dried fruit, raisins, plums, hard candy, sugar, and yeasty notes. Taste wow big fruit taste all dark style fruits, a nice boozy taste, yeasty esthers, and a touch of spice. Mouth feel very carbed prickly fully body with good mouth feel. Overall a very dark tasty and complex beer. I can hardly wait for them to age out this was still a new bottle not even close to mature at all and it still was excellent. Cheers a well deserved top 50 brew.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 11.2 oz yellow/baby blue labeled bottle. The hype on this beer is really high, I will try not to think of it in this review.

Gushes slightly when it is uncapped, but I sniffed the initial whiff (tropical fruit blast) and poured it before it over flowed, it was just a very slow gush. Pours with a nice 3 finger off white head into my Duvel glass. Head stays for a little while before receding. A blanket of foam still covers the liquid. The thick, creamy lacing/head has little specs in it.

The beer is a very dark, murky brown. There is a hint of red. Tons of little things, yeast and more, are floating around in there.

After letting the oxygen mingle with it for a while I give it a smell. It smells very rich, almost creamy. Has a ripe banana/plum/peach/dried apple scent, along with some bubble gum twang. Theres also some spices in there including clove and pepper. I can also smell a faint bit of chocolaty roasted malt and a kiss of hops. You can pick up on the alcohol a little bit, it prickles your nostrils ever so slightly and warms them.

The carbonation is really biting and I like it. Mouthfeel is utterly superb, some what thin at first but with a thicker, stickier smooth finish. This aids in the taste of a million flavors. Nice sweetness, though not too cloying, and the alcohol shows up just a bit, warming as it does down. Some nice roasted bitterness in the aftertaste. A massive flavor.

Overall, this is a great Trappist style ale, and for a quad it isnt too sweet. This is one you sit back, sip, and appreciate what the brewers have done.

Pours a thick, thick head of off-white paradise.

Dark brown liquid with a nose of yeasty esters, sweet.

Deep, fruit, sweet candy heaven.

Exceptional beer!

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2016 Bottle: 10% alcohol.
Very light brown to dark off white colored head on top of a deep red brown colored beer (ruby colored when held in light).
Smell dark fruits, yeast, toasted malts, hints of oatmeal, sweets and spices.
Taste is a very well balanced mix of dark fruits, raisin, hint of prunes, soft but present taste of liquorice, brown sugars, toasted malts, caramel, yeast, spices and barleys.
Aftertaste of medicine, liquorice, warmth (alcohol), malts, spices and grass.
Low carbo, full body and soft silky tingly mouthfeel.
-----
After drinking it several times recently and during a blind tasting, I must admit the flavour has become less fascinating than it was years ago... Hence the 4, which is all the times I drank this beer combined together...
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: UPDATED: DEC 12, 2015 Complex maltiness to it, a very good Belgian Quad, although not sure if it could be considered the best.

Pours a dark brown with a thick white head. aroma is sweet wheat, dark fruits, banana. taste is pretty good, pleasant fruit with grass and maltyness. palate is heavy but clamy and sticky. overall a solid beer, but perhaps a bit overrated.

Pours slightly murky deep brown with billowing bubbly head.  Aromas...plums, other dark fruits, funky earthy yeasts.  Touch of toast?  Maybe a hint of soy sauce(or miso)  Honestly if I worked at it I could probably pick up all of the aromas on the suggested list on the side...theres a lot in there.  Mouthfeel is the first thing that hits - effervescent, almost champagne-y in its bubbles but a lot thicker!  Up front mostly a sweet breadiness mixed with alcohol.  Then bring in the fruits!  Plum, raisin, etc.  Mouth-tingling alcohol on the finish (that lasts forever.  I feel drunk after 4 or 5 sips.

The Pinnacle of Belgian Ales. Love being able to have it on Draft over the bottle. The only reason I dont give this a perfect score is I think the Rochefort 10 is slightly better... but thats like saying the Lamborghini drove a hair better than the Ferrari.

Pours a dark brown with a nice white head that reduces to a light carmel color ring. slight fruity aroma with a hint of rasin and hops and light herbs. heavy cloying sweetness, lightly sour, The finish is smoth without revealing the high alcohol content.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2011 Fantastic beer. The pour is a murky muddy brown with a thick finger and a half of dark tannigh head. Aroma of spicy yeast, fruity esters and toasty malts. Dark raisin and plum taste with a burnt toffee caramel flavour. Beautiful caramel malt and slight alcohol burn. Overall, a great quad.

no more words to say. The score should speak of itself.
One of belgiums best!

Had this wonderful abbey quad last night...draft....during the super bowl.  took beer pizza and wings to a new level...haha!  this is one of my favorites.  wonderful malty fruity aroma.  the taste is not overly sweet like many quads can be.  delicious beer...i may have to go back to get more while its still on tap.

Very dark amber-brown with an off-white head. Aroma of raisins and other dark fruits, belgian yeast, caramel and some hops. Moderately sweet and alcoholic with a slight hop presence. Mouthfeel is a little fizzy, alcohol warming, and somewhat full. This is a really nice beer that is not overdone in any way.
Strong Quad, full bodied, strong flavored well-rounded Belgian.  St. Bernadus Abt 12 could set the standard for Quads.

330ml bottle sample purchased at the LCBO. Pours a dark brown with a nice white head that recedes to a ring. Some minor lacing left behind. Aroma is of raisin and alcohol. Taste is of dark fruit and alcohol, a little bitter. Really nice brew that I will have again.
the nose is really complexly beautiful.  lots of malt....caramel, nut, coffee...etc.  the quad benchmark.

One of the greatest Belgian beers in the world.  The aroma is nice and clean - a little hops, lots of roasted malty caramel, a little alcohol.  The taste is strong dark roasted caramel, with subtle ripe dark fruit notes.  There is also a sweet, pastry like base for all of these flavors.  This is a masterfully done beer, a definite must have.

750ml bottle in a St. Bernardus Trappist glass.  Pours dark brown with some sediment and a thick, lacy, beige head.  Aroma smooth of caramel malts, light hops, Belgian spicy yeast, and alcohol.  Has a syrupy flavor, rich of the malts, a little hops to balance it, and the Belgian yeast and alcohol on the finish.  Thick smooth texture.  An incredible beer.

Sötétbarna színű, zavaros megjelenéssel, piszkos világosbarna habbal. Illata és íze nem sokban tér el egymástól, gyümölcsös, likőrös édesség, kakaó, karamellszirupos tejeskávé (röhejesen hangzik, de a Mars reggeli üdítőitalhoz hasonló, de persze annál nemesebb). Testes, olajos, nehézkes sör, ami nagyon összetett ízvilággal bír, a likőrös jelleg végig megmarad, alig szénsavas. Egy kiváló, nagyon különleges sör, amit alkalmakra kell tartogatni (én pl. felejtőnek, a szokásosan nem túl fényes vizsgaidőszakom végének ünneplésére tartogattam). Azért a Rochefort 10 egy lapáttal rátesz....

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2011 12oz bottle from the LCBO. Pours garnet brown with a very fizzy orangey head. Aroma is pears, caramel, and much malt. Dark fruity flavour with some banana. Very understated and soft on the palate. A velvet drink of subtle density and substance.

A wonderfully complex balance of spices, ripe fruit, & sweet malt. The gold standard of Belgium quads, and one of the worlds best beers period.

http://www.billysbeerblog.com/2010/02/m

Bottle: Very deep amber coloured, hazy with a great number of floaties, small off-white head with a good lace; solid sweet-caramelly nose, walnut-oil detectable; moderate to solid sweet-bitter flavour with an acidic touch, almost full bodied, soft and creamy; lingering  sweet nutty-caramelly finish, increasing delicate hoppiness in the aftertaste. Devilishly easy-drinking Quadrupel......

Oh my god!
Bottle 33 cl.
Aroma: dark bread, chocolate, raisins, yeast, malts. 
Taste: caramel, sweetness, yeast, malts.
Aftertaste: slightly bitter. 
Texture: full.

330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a brownish dark orange colour with good-sized light tan head, some retention.  Aroma is fairly mild but nice - yeast,  Taste isnt overpowering (although not as mild as the aroma) but is quite rich and has a lot going on - apple, clove, cinnamon, yeast and a hint of raisin.   Absolutely amazing how subtle the alcohol is at 10%.  Medium-ish body.  Delicate mouthfeel.  A winner.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Dark brown coloured true legend from West Flanders, great spicy taste, warm feeling in the mouth and the roasted malts/caramel taste. An true persenol favorite, and at last rated.
OK head. Brown red colour. Clear. Really yeasty smell. Strong and over all quite sweet. I find some malts and lots of alcohol. In theory this should be good, but for some reason Im not cheering.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2011 The color was the biggest treat of this beer. Oh and the toasty taste that lingered on past the first sip. Very pleased and would recommend to everyone. I am still trying to distinguish different aromas and all the many flavors that beer has to offer, but this one made my nostrils twitch like an anteater searching through leaves for a meal. There is an earthyness to this clouded  amber creamy delight.

Very nice beer, love this one! Nice small to med off white head. The aroma is of bread, caramel, nuts, spice, an earthy room, some alcohol comes through. Depending on light, dark brown to a red-brown tint, clear with no sediment. Taste is an absolute joy to drink. The flavors I get are.. bread, caramel, banana, lightly toasty malt, hint of hop-spice, butterscothch, CO2, kinda acidic, clean, refreshing, a little fruit at the beginning-fig, raisin, there is alot goin on in here and I like it. The fact that it is 10%ABV beer, I give it a 10 on taste because in my mind I think all of the qualities that they get into the brew with that amount of alcohol, I think youre going to taste some alcohol but its not crazy, around what it should be. Palate is clean, fresh, acidic, lingering fruit and bread remnants. Overall this is one of the best beers I have tasted, complex, high abv quad, lots of flavors, balanced, this beer will without a doubt win you over and have you thinking the whole way through. I think more beers should strive to be this fantastic. Damn delicious, St. Bernardus is my new favorite saint!

poured a heavy brown with a large bubbly/frothy head. the taste of yeast stood out as well as some sort of soft fruit, maybe banana. i was surprised by the drinkability of this beer. this was a exceptional brew, wish i had bought more than one.

Appearance: Opaque brown-black, frothy thick head. No visible carbonation. Aroma: Complex. Lots of scents here: banana, cloves, chocolate, vanilla, malt, bubblegum. Mmm. I can just sit here and smell it for a while :) Palate: not as thick as expected - medium bodied. Leaves a pleasant feeling behind. Little carbonation, but doesnt feel flat at all. Taste: more sour than expected, very savoury, a bit sweet and a bit bitter. Amazing beer. Makes me as happy as the monk on the label.
Fantastic beer. Beautiful aroma, full taste, great poor. Nothing at all bad to say here.

33cl bottle. Poured hazy, dark brown color with a head that is frothy and bit soapy. lasting lacing, very nice looking. Aroma is sweet, malty and fruity, noticeable yeast also. Flavor is sweet malty, some yeast and plums. High carbonation. Bit rough on the edges, as this is quite young ( BB 2015). Alcohol well hidden, warming finish. Beer is very enjoyable and well balanced.

330ml bottle pours dark deep brown-black with ruby tinge. Light tan, well developed and supported tight head. Aromas, light green apple acetaldehyde, bread, inviting complex yeast with a touch of caramel and zesty spice. Medium carbonation, well balanced complex flavours; banana, custard,  caramel; touch of sour and phenolic yeast - flavours just so balanced and intricate its tough to detect the flavours here - they work so well. Finish is sweet, complex and near sour. Very satisfying Belgian ale.
dark ruby color, massive frothy head, lively carbonation, fruity and funky, very enjoyable

The color is black brown. As expected, the foam is high and dense, but the carbonation is slightly lower than the other Belgian beers i had.
 The scent contains notes of prunes, raisin, caramel and licorice.
Same notes in the flavor , but there is also a note of green apples and a light grapefruit-like bitterness. Body is bold and rich. Alcohol is clearly marked, but in a pleasant way, like with port wine. Complexity is average, its not a bad beer, but i had expected something more.
really strong carbonation and strawberry/apple/cherry. coffee, chocolate, jack daniels and brown sugar in the back.  best balance and overall flavor ive had yet.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a goblet.

4.0 A: Murky dark brown color. Two fingers of frothy off-white head with average retention and minimal lacing.

4.0 S: Dark fruits including plum and raisin. Slight graininess. Nuts, caramel, and some mild peppery spiciness.

5.0 T: I wasnt really too impressed with this beer until I tasted it. It is incredible. Flavors are much like the smell, just in overdrive. Plum, raisin, tobacco and a touch of over-ripe banana. Not as nutty, but lots of caramel and touches of pepper and clove.

4.5 M: Medium-heavy body. Bubbly carbonation and perhaps a tad too bubbly. Smooth finish with the alcohol hidden really well.

4.5 D: This is one hell of a tasty beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-14-2009 02:22:30

From the bottle....Super Belgian Quad.  Dark brownish color, pours with highly carbonated but thin head.  Spicy and fruity tones accompanied by Belgian yeast and candy sugar.  Pretty sweet, even for Belgium.  I really enjoyed this and will drink again.

Bottle 33cl, dark-ruby color, an almond  fruity taste that is not overwhelmed by the high alcohol content. Head dissipates quite rapidly after lots of carbonation produced when pouring it. Warming, tasteful aftertaste. In a nutshell a fantastic complex taste, thus a fantastic beer!

Deep brownish red, with huge head which dissipates quickly - typical for such high ABV.  Aroma is not as complex as I was expecting, mostly Belgian Yeast and alcohol, some fresh baked bread, and apple cider notes. Body is full with high fizzy carbonation. Taste is similar to aroma - apples, yeast, and yes, a whole lot of warming alcohol. Maybe a hint of anise or fennel from the complex yeast. Long complex finish with moderate hops to balance the sweet malts. I prefer the Prior 8, Pater 6, or Triple to this. It is so heavy and cloying that by the end of the 12 oz. bottle I was sick of it. I guess quads are not for me.
another axcelent beer from st.berbardaus strong tast pours dark brown sort good belgian beer

Pours a beautiful dark reddish brown color with ample head. Smells bold, of raisins and many other fruits, slight smell of alcohol present. Tastes fantastic, with a nice balance of fruits and malt, caramel specifically. Rush of carbonation to go with the strong flavors in the beer make the feel on the palate exceptional. Despite the higher abv is very drinkable and goes down easy from start to finish; a great belgian beer.

pours dark hazy brown with a beige head. very fruity, not just red fruits but like fruit salad, big and malty, full bodied. micro-carbonation. a sweet edge at the end that hides completely the ABV. very good grassy long hoppy finish. excellent!

Nice pour, lots of foam, smells of yeast, bread, and spice.  Takes a few minutes for the beer to settle down and become drinkable, dark murky brown in color.

Tastes very complex, nice yeast flavor, some hints of chocolate or toffee, some bitterness to it as well, slight bitter aftertaste, also tastes sweet and somewhat fruity.  ABV relatively well hidden, can only pick it up slightly at the end.

Very complex and good beer, one in a sitting and you are good, but I could get used to drinking this, it did live up to the hype for me, I want to try their Christmas offering.  One of the better beers Ive had in a while.

Una de las mejores cervezas del mundo con diferencia, fabricada con la misma receta que la gran Westvleteren 12.
Si esta es casi perfecta no me imagino como será la otra.

33 cl bottle. Red brown with a small beige head that laces quite well. Yeast, roasted malt and fruits in the aroma. Lots of carbonation. But still a soft feeling in the mouth. Yeasty and fruity taste with a hint of caramel. You gotta love this beer.

Bouteille de 750 ml. Arômes de caramel brûlé, de cacao et de fruits secs. Belle robe rousse foncée, belle mousse qui disparaît cependant rapidement et effervescence active. Bien équilibrée en bouche, les fruits confis (raisins secs, cerises) sont bien expressifs et accompagnés de chocolat et dun caramel foncé. La bière donne une impression de sécheresse agréable, ce qui est probablement accentué par la forte effervescence. Lalcool est très peu apparent en finale. Très bien brassé, mais je mattendais à légèrement plus, considérant la réputation de cette bière.

(25.4 oz bottle)  My first Beer club selection for 2011.  Wonderful aroma of yeast, bread, fruits and alcohol.  Darker complexion than expected.  Lingering fluffy head.  Alcohol well noted.  Slightly heavier than other Belgian Quads.  A nice selection for winter.
June 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Complex beer with multiple dark flavours of caramel, toffee and other mysterious things! Very tasty.

This is one of my favourite Abt beers. The intense fruity flavour makes it very appreciable. Its the classic beer to be tasted very slowly in winter period, also because of its alcoholic graduation. The major tastes I can feel are resin, banana and fruits in general. It is complex enough. Excellent.
Nice beer, I was expecting alittle more flavour then what was there, hides the alcohol well. Pretty solid beer

Hazy brown coloured beer with small off-white head, floks of yeast visible and some nice carbonation. Malty caramel fuity aroma with hints of yeast and hop, all nicely balanced. Full sparkling and creamy palate. Finish is malty yeasty sweet with a bitter ending. Rather soft finish nicely balanced beer. Top beer quality!!! (@WE)

Aroma is floral with a brown, hazy color and a frothy tan foam head.  Taste is slightly carameled with medium bodied soft carbonation and a light metallic finish.  Overall, a very drinkable beer  not as good as their Christmas Ale.

Dark brown beer with big, long lasting and beautiful beige head. Lots of dark fruits in the aroma, also raisins, plums, some syrup like sweetness, bananas, hints of milk chocolate and some alcohol that is disappered when the beer is warmer. Full bodied and high carbonation, but still ingredibly smooth to drink. Taste is rich, full of dark fruits, raisins, bananas and some drying herbal bitterness. Ingredibly complex, dark fruity beer that can only be falling loved; classic!
The aroma is clean, the appearance is a deep amber / Brown.  the taste is wonderful with an strong finish.  Overall very nice to ring in the new year!
Hazy dark copper with lingering fluffy head. Smells of raisins, candied sugar, dark fruits, spice Belgian yeast and slight alcohol. Taste is YUM! Sweet with a hint of alcohol. A true classic.
Awesome appearance! Great body on this beer with a lot of intense flavor with very little hints of alcohol.

Big body. Nice subtle carb with pour. Alcohol couldnt hide in this flavorful brew like a Roch does. Another premium ale from Belgium. Only downfall is the price! I guess you get what you pay for! Worth every penny!

Pours hazy dark brown - lovely colour - with a very nice tanned head leaving very nice lacing. Full bodied malty, bready, dark fruits, caramel, floral jasmin aroma. Even full bodied crisp mouthfeel. Acisy, alcohol, well carbonated, raisins, malts, fruits and hoppy flavor. Mmm so good. Acisy lean fruity palate. Finishes dry fruity and tart hoppy. Very nice.

Poured from a 33ml bottle a dark brown with a nice frothy off white head.Aroma is of dark fruits, brown sugar and raisin. Flavor is full bodied and very complex. Flavor of malt,raisin and friut. Palate is also exceptional and leaves a wonderful lingering aftertaste. A truely exceptional brew!!
Dark brown with thick white head, nice lacing.  Earthy alcohol aroma.  Smooth malty flavors with a buttery alcohol aftertaste.

33cl bottle from Cask & Kitchen. Pours very dark brown with foamy beige head. Nose; sweet caramel malt, dark fruits (figs, plums), medicinal and some bubblegum! Taste; smooth start, caramel, cinnamon, raisins, figs, bubblegum, wood, well hidden alcohol, complex, but very well balanced, One of the best.

Tumman ruskea, hieman punertava olut valkoisella vaahdolla, jonka alta huokuu hedelmäinen, lakritsinen, hieman hiivainen ja alkoholin sävytteinen aromi. Maku on se osa, jossa tämä olut loistaa - lakritsia, luumuja, omenia, mausteita/yrttejä, anista ja mallasta. Mukavan hapokas ja täyteläinen olut. Tilaisuuden tullen ostan ilman muuta kaappiin lisää tätä belgiä.

Poured a cloudy brown color.  Medium head.   Head stayed. Sweet aroma of fruit, raison, spice.  Med sweet taste.  Med body, ave carbonation.  Has a littel bitter finish with some spice (or is than alcohol kick?) This is a complex beer.  Like it.  Like it alot.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2011 Awesome head forms quickly on a beautiful dark red/brown/black slightly transparant but murky fluid.... nice, very nice
Aroma brings you malts, and malts and then some fruit, cherrys and dark, sweet fruit, almost rotten... 
Taste is sweet and malty, fuit again, some bread, chocolat, caramel, and again a slightly sourness as in a yeasting apple.. great
Finish is long and sweet and full and a bit warming (the only thing you notice of the 10.5%)
Body is medium to full, beer is very lively...
Drank this one many times... definitly one of the great belgian beers... hell... one of the best beers all over the world even

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2011 Re-rated on a horizontal-ish tasting of this and the Specisl Edition Abt 12. Nuts, cheese, figs, earthy and light alcoholic. Very fitting for the style. Very slightly sticky. Balanced. Medium carbonation. Never quite got the Westvleteren comparision - this isnt anything as smooth or rich. Still very good and better than the Special Edition with its fresh funk.

Original rating: Nuts, caramel, red fruit, earth. Loads of flavour, yet still quite smooth. Sticky sweets. Taste develops after drinking through the long after taste. Complex and satisfying. Give it time and dont drink too cold. Absolutely brilliant. (On bottle in Poperinge.)

Bottle. Dark brown, average and mostly lasting dark brown head. Moderate malty and sweetish fruity aroma. Some herbal spiciness and licorice and also some alcohol. Body is medium to heavy, malty and sweetish flavor, some herbal spiciness and alcohol. Finish is average, malty and sweetish with alcohol. Medium bodied sweetish strong ale with lots of alcohol in the flavor.

Taster at Whole Foods Coddingtown. Clearish amber with small, disappearing yellow head. Unreproachable sweet strawberry, honey, grainy aroma. Sweet, spicy, syrupy, smooth, balanced, and dangerously appetizing. Finish is ever so slightly anesthetic. Lives up to the hype.

Dark caramel with a red hue in the glass.  Clean and healthy white head.  Smells great.  Candied sugar, dates, plum, raisin, cinnamon, dough, and a whisp of alcohol.  Taste is a little bitter/harsh up front (not sure why) but opens up quickly with what I anticipated on the aroma (i.e., cinnamon, dough, dates, raisin, etc.).  Somewhat numbing in the mouth but, on the whole, quite enjoyable.

33cl bottle poured into a Chimay Trappist glass.  Dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is fruity, bubblegum.  Flavor is the same with slight alcohol, very smooth.  Full body, high carbonation.  Finish is short and sweet.  Nice brew.

11.2 oz. bottle from Johns Grocery, Iowa City
Served around 55F in my Trois Pistoles chalice.

Ar: Very complex aroma.  Notes of boozy raisins, burnt sugar, and figs.
Ap: Pours an incredibly murky very dark mahogany brown with a big 1"  cream head.  The head diminished rapidly, and left little lace, which was a surprise.  Huh.
T:  Huge boozy sweetness up front reminds me of macerated raisins or figs.  The finish has a tart bite to go along with a moderate alcohol burn.
P:  Extremely lively carbonation.  Thick, sticky body.

O:  Dont get me wrong, this is a very good beer.  It just didnt live up to my expectations.  Im sure Ill give this brew another rate some day soon.

500mL bottle in a Trappist glass.  Dark brown heavy pour with lots of frothy head.  Not as aromatic as I assumed it would be.  Rich malty flavor.  Easier to drink than a lot of comparable high ABV quadrupels.  Very enjoyable beer.

750 mL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a Trappist glass. Pours clear reddish brown with a tall, frothy tan head. The head remains to the end and leaves a moderate amount of dense lace. On the nose, there are aromas of molasses, candi sugar, raisins, roasted malts, yeast, dark fruits and a hint of hops. The flavour is intensely sweet throughout, complex with lots of candi sugar, fruit and molasses. There is a hint of hop bitterness towards the end, but the malts are dominant overall. The finish is long and malty with slight hints of yeast and hops. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and biting carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent abt. It is sweet, with a beautiful malt complexity, lots of molasses, raisins and candi sugar. There are ample fruity notes and only a faint hint of alcohol. Very well assembled. Not quite at the level of Westie 12 or Rochefort 10, but very, very nice. A perfect choice for a cold winters evening. 2010-11-26

Bottle from summer secret santa. Thanks! Pours a dark reddish brown with a fizzy beige head that fades quickly. Aroma is sweet. Vanilla, dark fruits, some booze sweetness. Something almost cheesy or meaty. Thats about it though. Taste is definitely on the sweet side, with a warming finish. Something metallic lingers in the back. Not impressed. People seem to put this up against Westvleteren 12. Wasnt impressed by that either. Maybe these kind of beers arent for me. Then again, I adore Rochefort 10.

Ive been sitting on this 11.2 oz bottle since last January, and now I remember why I saved it for Thanksgiving. Poured into a chalice, it raised an ample head that laced the glass above the ruby reddish liquid. Aromas and flavors presented molasses, pears, honeycrisp apples, and finished with thick brown honey. Heavenly indeed.

0.33l Bottle.  Pours a dark brown, almost black.  Aroma is extravagant - heavily floral with distinct notes of yeast, dried fruit, and citrus.  Taste is dominated by the malt flavors, mostly yeast and raisins, but also a touch of banana.  But, the beer doesnt stop there.  Flavors also bleed into a very firm base of citrusy hop bitterness that carries over into the finish.  Wonderful beer.

Draught served in a chalice. Pours a murky dark brown with a rocky head. Aromas of sweet caramel, dark fruits and yeast. Flavors are much the same as the aroma but with some nice bitterness as well. Love it.

G: Poured into a Chimay goblet.

A: Dark brown color with a slight haziness to it. Very nice lacing. 

S: Plenty of yeast leaving behind spices and lots of dark fruit.

T: Lots of sweet malt backed up by undeniable Belgian yeast; some alcohol is present in the taste.

M: Very smooth and heavy-bodied. Fairly low carbonation.

D: Fairly drinkable; definitely a sipper. Not everything fits together perfectly, but a very good beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-29-2009

Cloudy brown, with a small, but very lasting head. Sweet aroma of caramel, raisins, yeast, sharp alcohol. The mouthfeel is smooth, almost silky. Subtle carbonation. The flavor is smooth, beginning with notes of dried fruit, caramel, malt and ends with hoppy notes with a wave of alcohol warmth. A sweet and satisfying beer.

Pour is brown and cloudy with a kahki head that dissipates to a film on top. Aroma is sugary malt and dark dried fruit with some roasted scents. Taste is more dark fruit and sweet malt with a nice blend of spices. Palate is sticky and finishes dry.

20-nov-2010
33cl bottle at home. 10% ABV. This was the last beer in a tasting session. It was not as impressive as I wouldve thought. Sweet dark beer with a huge head. Nice long finish. Im glad I have another bottle at home, so a rerate is on its way.

Nice dark brown pour with slight head. Nice sweet aroma slight citrus smell. Delightful taste that attacts the tounge with a bubling grape hint. Great beer, this was a rough weekend for me with my Imperial/ Double IPA trials, but I couldnt ask for a better beer.zChampange of beers almost literaly. Highly recommended.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2014 Re-rated higher on Jan. 9, 2014.  From the 25 fl. oz. corked bottle. The pour is a handsome looking dark amber tone with about a three inch puffy beige head.  There is some wheat in the aroma but this is not the main ingredient.  I also get a bit of mellow malts along with plum and dark fruits.  No spices per se.  The foamy head tickles the lip. The taste is on the bitter side with a powerful although muted alcohol sensation.  A bit of bitter hoppiness at the end that cleans out the sinuses. a very likable Belgian style ale.
This is a fantastic beer.  Fantastic on the palate and gets better as it goes down.
Dark brown with a white rocky head, Aromas of prunes and cocoa in the nose. Very nice texture, but a bit grapey in terms of taste. Like the Prior 8 much better.

I guess I just dont get this one. Ive tried it warm, cold; aged, fresh; yeast in, yeast out, but its not my thing. Looks and tastes "muddy" to me, not balanced and a bit all over the place. Its not like its really bad tasting or anything, just tons of beers id rather spend my money on than this.

Bottle. Dark brow, tanned head that leaves a nice lacing. I find the aroma quite subtle for this heavy beer,  some roasted maltyness and a little alcohol and something that reminds me of figs. Taste is quite sweet with a hint of chocolate and raisins+caramel. Also a hint of alcohol. Well balanced and a nice palate. Good finish, long and with a tiny hint of smoke/peat. It does not blow me away with anything in particular, but the overall impression is very good.

Glass poured from the bottom of the bottle. Somehow this glass tastes better than the first couple from last night. Sharp alcohol nose is evident. Very dark purple-brown color. Good carbonation. Flavor is sweet and muddy. Warming finish. Fruity-prune-raisin notes. Very chewy.

Une fois versé, le liquide dévoile une robe brune.  La mousse forme un col mince mais tenace.  Présence dune dentelle sur le verre.  Le nez permet de découvrir des notes maltées moyennement fortes et riches : à travers la levure typiquement belge, le caramel est enveloppé par des fruits bien mûrs qui sont gorgés dun alcool parfumé de fleurs et de sucre.  Au goût, le liquide permet de définir davantage son malt : pratiquement comme un morceau de toffee qui fond sur la langue.  Le caractère fruité est aussi imposant, avec des pointes chaudes et rondes de raisins et de figues qui me rappellent un bon vieux rhum.  Le fort degré dalcool se fait aussi sentir : sa présence freine judicieusement la douceur du malt et du sucre.  En bouche, le liquide est rond, très enveloppant, avec une effervescence propre au genre et un texture crémeuse.  En finale, les quelques notes douces qui apparaissent se font rapidement talonnées par un alcool qui réchauffe avec finesse.
decent as fuck. tart thing going on. not too dark, more of a brown. fruity. grapes!.. not bad.

Once upon a time, I was all about this beer.  Now, the fruit flavors are less notable, the sweetness is in-check, and the malt flavors arent as great as Id hope.  I dunno if my tastes have changed or the bottle Im drinking is less great, but Im certainly not as in love as I once was.
Aroma of dark roasted malts, caramel, fruit.  Deep complex malty flavor ... so much to take in.  Malt, coffee, caramel melts together in an amazing combination. So so good.
Great beer with a high alcohol content. Enjoyed this very much, and would drink again and again.

I cracked it open and poured it into a trappist glass.  I must have done something wrong here because the head of my beer went away fast.
