Pours very rich and silky, with plenty of peach and caramel flavor.  I had not noticed the high alcohol content until I really searched for it in some of the alcohol burn.  I was surprised to find a good amount of carbonation flavor in this beer.  Mouthfeel is very silky and very honest exactly what I like in a good beer.  Flavors are toffee malt, caramel, peach nectarine, apple, and some banana.  Mostly sweet with a light dry taste of hops but for the most part an afterthought.  By far the best Belgian to date.  Will probably need a re-rate for more accurate description.  This beer wont blow you away when you taste it so that you find yourself jumping around exclaiming expletives.  This beer is the old man speaking calm wisdom rather than the younger phenom trying to outplay you.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bottle. Aroma has yeast and toffee. Taste has sweet caramel, dry hops and some sweet dried fruit. I can only compare it to Rochefort 10, which I found to be slightly stronger and more complex in taste. RE-RATE: 30.12.13: Small bottle. 10% (instead of the 10,5% it was before?) Murky brown body, medium off-white head. Aroma has yeast, brown sugar, some dried fruit. Very typical Belgian. Taste is plain and thin, mostly raisins and high booze. Tongue-numbingly overcarbonated, the subtle flavours that might have been there are now completely veiled by it and the thin mouthfeel is certainly not helping. This beer might have been great in the past but at the moment it is not. Ive had bottles of it that were 4+ but recently it has not been very good. This is not the first time I am experiencing quality control issues with this brewery, hence my lowered rating.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2011 375 ml bottle poured with much anticipation in chalice. Muddy brown apearance with a slight tan head. Smells of raisins, bananas and yeast. I could also detect the alcohol. It was hidden well but it was there in the finish. Tastes of spiced rum cake with a somewhat harder mouth feel. A very well balanced smooth brew.
Dark, smooth, fruity carbonated taste. Lacking in aftertaste but makes up for it in flavor.

one of the most well balanced and amazing beers I have ever had. The malt has esters of dark fruit and a soft grainy sweetness. The yeast kicks up more esters and a well attenuated profile that carries the malt through to the finish. The hops are rounded and fruity.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 Foam came bursting out of the bottle as I opened it. Absolutely amazing appearance. Not much aroma, slight malt. Taste is quite sweet, like malt candy; and lof dark dark fruit and belgian yeast. Very good beer.

Poured from one of the small bottles into a St. Bernardus goblet that looks like an oversized wine glass. Muddy brown dubbel/quad appearance with excellent foam retention. Ill give it a little time to warm up - on this warm October day, it shouldnt take too long.

It smells like an enormous malt bomb, massive aromatic slabs of deep caramel, overripe plantain and rum raisin. Malt for miles and miles. 

While it smells very sweet, the taste has more going on than just pure sweet malt. It is moderately sweet up front, which is entirely appropriate, the sweetness of a rum-drenched dark banana bread. It is a little spicy, though perhaps not as clove-heavy as some of the other Belgians. Alcohol, while by no means overbearing, isnt afraid to poke its nose in at mid-palate and let you know its there. Dry-ish finish with a raisin aftertaste. 

While this is a full-bodied beer to say the least, it achieves the heavenly cloud-like Belgian mouthfeel like few others of this strength not named Rochefort 10 or Westy 12. 

In fact, I think this can stand with the above as one of the finest quads available. Personally, I am not in the mood for quads very often, but when I am this is easily a go-to. 

Heres a prime example of one of the worlds great beers just sitting on your liquor stores shelf at an affordable-luxury price. Go pick one up today.
profumi di frutta secca e datteri in bocca corposa morbida ed equilibrata, forse leggermente  poco persistente

This was my second bottle of abt 12, however I did not take notes for the first one and so I wanted to have another before I rated it. Off the bat, the first bottle had a much stronger Aroma that captured my senses the instant the bottle was opened. Secondly the first bottle had a thick thick huge light BROWN head which I thought was awesome. 

This second bottle was poured into a trappist glass. Abt 12 is dark brown with a light tan head with tight bubbles. The aroma was spicy, earthy, malty, and fruity. I got pears cherries and figs. The taste was malty figgy and sweet. For the palate the abt 12 had a feel that reminds me of coca-cola and a finish of stingy spices.

This is a great beer. one of my favorites. Although I wish it was a little more consistent
Aroma/Malty-toasted, Appearance Head/Initia-huge, Head/Color light brown, Body/Hue-murky, Initial Flavor-bitter light Finish Flavor-bitter light Palate/Body-medium to full, good beer
330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy very dark brown with no head.  Aroma is raisin, caramel malt, prunes and figs.  Lots of caramel, lots of dark fruits.
Excellent beer - I really cant add anything to all the great reviews already on this beer.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 Anyone who is big into the craft beer scene knows Westvleteren 12 - a Trappist beer made by monks in Belgium and sold exclusively at the monastery - is the most sought-after beer. Most of those people have likely heard that St. Bernardus Abt 12 is either a "clone" or a very close replica of the famous "Westy 12." Having drank both beers I can tell you they are definitely different and the authentic Trappist brew is definitely superior. However, Abt 12 is still a very good beer in its own right and a lot easier to come by.APPEARANCE AND AROMAI poured an 11.2oz bottle into a Trappist chalice. I was amazed this beer produced a huge, fluffy, tan head. It was slow to dissipate and left nice lacing on the glass. The color is that typical Belgian shade thats not quite brown and not quite maroon, but very hazy.The aroma is also typical for a Belgian strong dark ale: alcohol, perfume, and dark fruits. Not nearly as aromatic or as inviting as an authentic Trappist, though. In fact, its surprisingly mild. TASTEBefore I comment on the taste, it should be noted that the bottle of St. Bernardus Abt 12 I drank was fairly fresh and had not been cellared. Beers like this age like wine and its almost a bit unfair to drink them young. That being said, theres still a lot of flavor to experience here and its still pleasantly satisfying.Much like Westy 12, St. Bernies is a fairly complex beer. The overall taste is a mélange of dark fruits like plum, apple, cherry and fig. Theres also a noticeable dryness to the finish and in the aftertaste due to the high alcohol content (and the fact my bottle was rather young). The palette opens up a bit as it warms, but only slightly. Its funny how a beer can have seemingly a variety of flavors, but the actual intensity is a bit muted. Its like listening to a symphony with the volume turned way down.DRINKABILITYBelgian strong dark ales tend to be an enduring experience of drinking due to their unbridled energy in the mouthfeel. Yet, Abt 12 was an amazingly easy beer to drink. I was surprised and delighted by the pillowy softness of the mouthfeel. Beers like this tend to act like Pop Rocks, but this beer slides across the tongue with amazing grace. Surprisingly, it is only a medium-bodied beer and has a lighter mouthfeel than youd expect.At 10% ABV, St. Bernies should be a beer to handle with caution, but the drinking experience would indicate otherwise. While there is definitely a sharp, dry, alcoholic presence to the taste, this isnt the kind of beer that must be sipped, nor is it the kind that overwhelms the drinker only halfway through. FINAL THOUGHTSSt. Bernardus Abt 12 is a beer that has pretty much everything going for it, including a reputation for being so similar to one of the worlds most revered beers. I almost want to give a perfect score, but I cant due to the absence of a true "wow!" factor. Maybe if I try a vintage version Ill change my mind.
Figs, Black raisins, honey.  All sorts of dark fruits.  Very fruity and complex.  Nice and thick beer.  Very drinkable

Kibontásakor egyből kiigyekszik a palackból a sötét réz/barna színű  ser, melynek krémes, bézs habja vékonyan megmarad a tetején ill.a nedű üledéket képez a kehely fenekén.
Illata igen malátás, aszalt gyümölcsös, pici csokoládét is idéz.
Csípősen indul, teste telt, szirupos.
Malátás, édes aromája karamellás, enyhén citrusos/finoman pörkölt és aszalt gyümölcsös hatásokat hordoz magában, íze mazsolás, aszalt gyümölcsös, akár kalácsot is idéz.
Befejezése citrusos, kesernyés, alkoholos és enyhén száraz, mely egy árnyalatnyi fanyarsággal kísért gyümölcsös-pörkölt utóízt hagy maga után.
A magasabb alkoholtartalom jól el van rejtve, emiatt könnyen iható a főzet, mely összességében egy nagyon élvezetes íz-és aromaélménnyel szolgált.

Pours dark brown, excellent high head like the rest of its St. Bernardus compatriots. Aroma is a plethora of barley and alcohol, dry fruity notes, red wine almost, dry maltiness. Taste is heavy on the barley and alcohol, slight fruity barley notes, dark burnt barley malt grainy finish. Very good, but could be better, it was as though it was all there but just not in the right proportions as the right time.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2010 Bottle. Dark brown/red with a small beige head. Aroma: dried fruit, alcohol, red wine. Taste: dried fruit, perhaps dried figs, caramel malt, toffee, some sort of hard candy, sweet, the alcohol is hardly noticeable. Full mouthfeel. Complex, but goes down dangerously easy.
The week after I had the bottle, Reza put on a 3 year old draught, so heres a comparison:
The alcohol in the aroma has almost disappeared, instead I get more port and some hard candy. Huge licorice taste, everything I got from the bottle and more, very complex. This is quickly becoming a favourite.

Decided to try one of these for my 250th rating.  I have neglected purchasing one for awhile now.  Big 750, corked and caged.  Poured with a good bit of carbonation, dark murky orange pour with a big frothy white head.  The head faded down to a thick half finger after a few sips, good retention and left a lot of lace.  Aroma was lots of rich malts, some fruitiness from the yeast, grape bubblegum and caramel.  Hard to pick through all of the complex aromas.  Flavors started out with a fruitiness, then a big malt presence although not sweet, just big and malty with a subtle bitterness in the finish.  Had a fruity finish too.  This stuff is one of the smoothest drinking brews I have some across.  I didnt detect alcohol anywhere in this which was quite unreal.  Its amazing drinkability while being huge and full flavored is reason enough to try one of these.  Excellent.

Large, slightly off white head. Can definitely smell the yeast, the bread scent is very strong. This beer is creamy and sweet but definitely not overwhelming so. There are so many subtle flavors in this that I dont know what to say other than a perfect Belgian Abt.
Dark and murky with a off-white head.  Very flavorful. has a sweet after taste. not too bitter ... definitely one of the best beers i have had.

A deep brown pour with tan head.  A very nice dark fruit aroma of plum, raisin, and caramel.  The taste is soft and sweet with those dark fruits really coming through.  The finish is somewhat sticky with a soothing alcohol warmth.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2011 Dark red-brown colour. Big White beige Soft head.Aroma: roasted nuts and hazelnuts.Roasted malts and dry fruits,dry figs and alcohol.Taste:Roasted nuts,hazel nuts.dry figs,some coffee,chocolate with nuts and cloves.The taste reminds me a lot, the traditional greek nuts pie.Full creamy body.Very long lasting finish, sweet metallic and alcoholic.A complicate and delicious beer.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2011 Ive had this beer twice now in the last six months, and while I dont have explicit notes to record here, I think I still have a good enough recollection, particularly from the second of the tastings, to post a review.  I have a bad habit, particularly after sampling several good beers, of taking note of whether or not I liked the beer, but not of why I liked it.  Because of the shortcomings of my recollection of my first tasting, I paid extra attention during the second.  So for a quad, I recall this being on the medium-dark brown end, with a healthy dust-colored head.  It looks beautiful.  As for the flavor, yes there were raisins and dates, but these excellent expressions of maltiness were comfortably shrouded by a somewhat more explicit simple sweetness, probably the result of a dark candi syrup.  On top of this, there is just a hint of spicy hop flavor and bitterness on the back of the tongue.  It is oh so pleasant!  Thanks for a great beer, if only I could have it more often!  UPDATE: On tap at Shadys.  This version is slightly less sweet and slightly more roasty.

Pours brown with a ton of sediment and just a brief brown head. Nose is fairly weak and a combination of brown sugar and fruit. Flavor is the usual rich abt fruitiness/ dark maltiness with a very big dose of brown sugar and spice on the backside. Finish is sticky. Alcohol is fairly well hidden. Very good stuff.

draught at capital ale house.  pours a like red color. Aroma, sweet apples, cinamon spice, apple cider like with booze that burns the nose in the back.  taste:  spicy apple cider, some hop presence, caramel, dry, booze is covered by sweetness, great brew

Bottle, served at the brewery. Pours a lovely, deep hazel brown body with a voluminous tan head. Nose is classic quad: figs, raisins, port wine, candy sugar. Taste is similar, with an important twist: a strong element of a distinct sweet nuttiness (found throughout the entire dark abbey ale series of St. Bernandus, but here amplified through added sugar and fermentation) reminiscent of a well-known Norwegian bread-spread named "Hapå" makes this a truly original quad. Full bodied and rich in texture and taste complexity, blended magnificently. Thumbs up for St. Bernandus, once again.

Served into a Westmalle chalice

A: beautiful brown almost like an ice tea with a 1 inch frothy head beige in color, high carbonation with a bubbly lace.

S: Sweet brown sugar, some grape aroma, alcohol, fruity (banana?), i got an weird faint smell of condensed milk.

T: Sweet bitterness, astringent, warming (not rochefort warming), ripe fruit.

Overall very good beer but not what I expected, will give a try again, felt a little bit flat in flavor.

Serving type: bottle

330 ml bottle @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio. Rated @ 17.6.2009.
Pours a dark brown colour with a small creamy white head. Rich aroma of dark fruits, malts, brown sugar and caramel. Very nice flavour of caramel and malts with raisins. Alcohol is well-hidden. Rich on the palate with full body, very smooth carbonation and creamy texture. Awesome.

Tap, pours a deep, hazy brown nearly chocolate but light filters through around the edges.  Less malty than the bottle.  Barely perceptible bitterness, aroma of raisins, hazelnut.  Smooth, somewhat creamy mouthfeel and clear finish.

33cl bottle.  2 years old from my beer cellar.
Started to foam a little too much.  But a very good beer which has benefited from aging 2 years.  I will open another one in a year or 2.

chocolatey and very malty, very dark brown color, caramel colored head, heavy sweetness, full body, creamy, a sweet finish, alcohol

Overall:  This beer is so rich its like eating a chocolate bar!  While thick and creamy isnt my personal favorite way to have my beer, this really is a must try for all beer lovers.
Brown, hazy colour with an off white head. Very nice aroma but I cant place the source. Lovely creamy texture with a warming sensation. Bitter flavour. Cracking beer.
Medium-dark brown appearance; off-white head. Pleasant aroma with dried fruits. Medium-to-full taste, complex with good fruity flavour. Sweet, yeasty finish.

On Tap : Pours a Dark brown into a St. Bernardus glass with a nice off white head here - Smell is a little earthy, fruits, it seemed a little bitter at first, but slowly as the brew warms it starts to reveal itself - The head is creamy, and i would certainly agree that this one is smooth overall - Flavors are Caramel, Dark fruits, licorice, booze, dough, I was frankly a little disappointed - Yes , it was my first Quadrupel .....
From a 750ml corked bottle. Dark copper almost brown, beige head, good retention, spices, some roast. Good sweet taste of malt, round, some alcohol. 8/10
Rich beer with a lot of aroma. Nice colour and texture. Slightly disappointed by the finish that is, by my taste, too short.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 2008 bottle. 
Lovely orange amber with floaties and lovely lace. 
Root beer and chocolate, licorice, plums, raisin. Super smooth, full body. Wonderfully integrated, with sweetness subsiding. Excellent. 
(old rating 4.2) 
330 ml bottle. Big soft caramel malts with chocolate and something like rum. Sweet and fruity, and almost in balance. A great, sweet, abt.

11.2 oz. bottle from a mix pack. Ive been saving this one for last, and all the others have been excellent. Ive had it before, and I hope its as amazing as I remember. It pours a dark opaque brown with a medium tan head. The aromas I get are caramel, dates, apricots, and hints of vanilla and coffee. The flavor is mainly sweet, with a bit of tartness and a slightly bitter finish. The palate is very heavy, with a sticky film that coats your mouth. The alcohol content is noticeable, but not offensive. Overall, a great beer, delicious, but restrained.

Bottle. after a year and a half in the cellar, it was time to try this one out.  Pour was syrup like with plenty of carbonation.  Color was a deep red with yeast hovering, not settling.  Smell is fruity, but also a bit boozy. Flavor of candy fruit and yeast with the booze blended in very well. I will have to get more to cellar.

Bottle wee, consumed 2010-08-13, La Grande Motte
AR: caramell
AP: dark amber brown 2 cm beige lively rocky foam
F: loads of carbonation, vionos, caramely fudgyness, alcoholic warmness, chocloate, round soft well brewed beverage
The best beer of its kind. Sweet caramel and candy sirup smell with a rich flavour.

(on tap at Joels birthday party).  Pours opaque brown-orange with thin off-white head.  Candied sugar is prominent.  Taste is sweet and slightly hopppy. Full bodied and oily texture.  finish is slightly bitter and smooth.  Excellent beer, but a shade below westvleteren 12.

Rating #414, bottle from Kvickly  

Wow, this is overrated. I really dont see why this beer is so hyped. I have tried only a handfull of Abt/Quadrupel until now, but this has certainly been the lessest complex and most boring example of the style.  
It starts out quite well as a dark brown beer with a dense head. The aroma is a dissapointment, though, only being berries with alcohol and some anonymous hops. Flavous is wood, alcohol, and traces of berries; impossible to select which. Medium palate. Dont get me wrong, this is not bad but it is not a world class beer, either.

Shared a bottle with Dinoistrad in Ohio and another with the lovely RebeccaGlynne in Nashville (along with once on draft at the Beer Engine). The bottles pour a bit lighter than the draft with a dark golden appearance, along with a pale white head and some good, light carbonation. Aroma is a fine, bold blast of dough. Taste is all sorts of malts... a bit of caramel, a bit of roasted nuts. Super smooth mouthfeel. Goes down real easily, with only the slightest hint of alcohol. One of my favorite beers as of late.
Shared bottle with thelizard. Deep copper color with a pale white head and a malty aroma. Nutty, full-bodied, not bitter with a smooth finish. Overall delicious. One of my favorites.

Botle. Makes me happy I have a mouth. Complex dark fruits with well balanced hops to round out the rich slightyl sweet raisin with a smooth bitter. Very satisfying and slight gas. Well deserved ranking
UPDATED: SEP 26, 2016 If you dont think youll get a chance to try Westvleteren 12 this is not too far off, approaching almost as good, but much easier to come by.  Yummy. Serving: Bottle and tap

Bottle thats been sitting in my cellar for a year and a half - Pours dark, opaque cola color with a big fluffy off white head. Aroma is lots of toffee, caramel, and bready malt, with a fruity booziness. Passion fruit, apricot, and plum. Taste is smooth and malty, with lots of depth, raisin and plum, with a smooth alcohol burn and a bit of bitter snap on the finish. Some dark chocolate lingers. Way too smooth for 11.5%, with a velvety body and perfect carbonation. This is a ridiculously good beer. Bravo, monks.

Poured into a frosted glass. Very thick creamy head that is very much situated on the top of the beer. Brown in color with reddish hues. Aroma is of fruits and malty caramel. Taste is very similar trouble the smell but the wine nature of the abt style begins to come through. The palate is where the 10.5 % abv makes its appearance but only subtly. I am very impressed by this beer and will definitely have another soon.

75 cl bottle, pours dark with a creamy head, aroma of malt caramel, brown sugar,dark,fruits and yeast, taste is malt, brown sugar and dark fruits, super smooth and very nice overall mouthfeel, fairly long finish, fantastic.

11 oz bottle. Very dark appearance with a tint of red. Thick head that dissipates to a thin top layer fairly quickly. Aroma of plum and raisin and malt. The 10% ABV is completely hidden in taste and in aroma. Somewhat fizzy as it hits the tongue but completely smooth finish. If not for the premium price in my area I would drink this beer far more often.

Ive had this multiple times now, and its great every time.  Pours a cloudy brown with a slight tint of red.  Off white head thats very large at first,and shrinks rather quickly.  Fruity and spicy,  maybe thats the plum /raisin flavor I read about so much.  Very smooth,carbonation is pretty mild,almost just slightly fizzy(?).
33 cl bottle from Ølbutikken. Dark color with nice offwhite head. Some taste of fruit, a bit of alcohol. Has a lovely finish.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2010 A sublime ale.  Fruity, bready, malty, hints of clove, banana, cherry.  Smooth palate.  Just enough bittering hops to prevent any cloying impression.  This beer needs to be quaffed at temperatures only slightly cooler than ambient to be fully appreciated.

Bottles always available and drafts from time to time at Monks, St. Stephens, Belgian Cafe, etc.  

My go to Belgian.  Simple as that.  Amazing beer.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2010 Sampler at Canal Street pub the ale had a small, off-white head with reddish-brown body.  Aroma of molasses and dark fruits.  Flavors of raisins, plums, cherries, and a hint of raspberry with a very light hop finish.
Bottle poured a cloudy dark brown with small off white head.  The taste is dark fruit, spices, heavy carbonation, alcohol, roasted malt, and molasses.  The nose is faint dark fruits and alcohol.

Not sure about the bottled date. Drank 08.01.10
Good lord...cap off and the contents shot out everywhere. Tried to capture it but only got 2/3 of the 11.2 oz bottle. After everything settled, it appears to be ruby red/brown with an enormous tan head. The nose is spicy, dark fruits (fig, raisin, plum), dark caramel malt, and mild hops. The taste is very rich, dried dark fruits (fig, raisin, plum), a sweet caramel, bready malt,  and mild hop presence. The lacing was thick and sticky on the glass. Great beer!
What can you say.  This beer is not for the light at heart.  It is a full taste that fills you mouth with every flavor.  This is a fantastic beer,  it is as good as they come.

poured from a single bottle purchased.  unable to decipher the freshness date "13 C1 15".  Oh well, no big deal.  This is one mighty fine beer.  Pours a hazy dark amber with a thick off-white head.  an aroma of malt sweetness with caramel, dark fruits, and some alcohol.  The beer is smooth on the palate with some alcohol bite at the end.  bready maltiness with plenty of dark fruits, plums, raisins, etc.  Im liking this

We believe this particular one was bottled in 2006. Freshness date 140710. Incredibly enough, even though this bottle is 4 years old, it poured a lovely dark brown with a thick, three finger creamy head. Yeast sprinkles on the head looked almost like cinnamon. The only affect that age seemed to have on this, is in the aroma. Very slight, almost imperceptible scent of dark, sticky fruits. The taste was phenomenal! Heavy malts, dark, sticky fruits (almost like fig newton filling) with subtle spices and a thin, refreshing mouthfeel. Age has only improved this wonderful beer!

2009 Bottle in my hotel room in DC - Pours a hazy dk amber with a large sandy head...aroma is dark and fruity, raisin, figgy, sweet caramel and very light spice...the particles in the lacing left on my glass looks like cinnamon to the point where I almost taste it...aroma is similar, dark and doughy malt, dried fruit, yeast and vanilla, light alcohol bite...holds its own against any quad as far as Im concerned...

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2011 Poured from a 11.2 oz. bottle (dated 26 05 14) into a Chimay goblet.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown with reddish tint. Has a 1-2 finger off-white foamy head which dissipates fairly quickly. Decent amount of sediment floating around. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Strong smell of raisins and dried fruit. Very sweet malty aroma. Smells absolutely delicious.

Taste: Complex flavor which combines the sweetness of dried fruit and roasted malt with a nice bit of spice. Strong alcohol flavor is apparent throughout. Very nice warming finish with just a hint of bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a high amount of carbonation and a distinct alcohol bite.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability; however, you dont want to drink too many because the high ABV will catch up to you.

Overall: An excellent beer all around. For the price of $4.49 a bottle, Ill definitely be buying more. I would highly recommend seeking this one out. This is just a great beer.

Smells like biscuit malt and sweetness. Nice head and great lacing. very thick, a lovely light burnt brown looking drink, hazy. This is amazing in the mouth. Soft and warm, it builds and then flows down your throat. Amazing, I whish I could drink this all the time.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 A: Dark ruby-brown with a substantial off-white head that leaves behind wonderful lacing

S: Complexity is key here... figs, raisins, a hint of softer fruits, a touch of alcohol all accent a lovely herbal-roasted malt presence

T: The taste certainly follows suit... typical candy sweet belgian fruits with yeast are followed by more mellow raisins and grapes before giving way to the malts and yeast that balance out the flavor and give more subtle earthy tones

M: Medium bodied with a perfect amount of carbonation.. a nice presence on the palate before subsiding

O: The complexity is almost too much.. the tongue gets tired after a few and something less alcoholic and less flavor full is needed after 2-3 or these... this is not to say that this is not a most magnificent beer!

500mL bottle, courtesy of Donfardz64!
The smell is sweet malt, and full of Belgian yeast. Esters of banana and bubblegum mingling with a raisin-ey malt and a mild fruity hops.
Flavours have a bit of autolysis with the bready yeast, nothing unpleasant. The malt is light, yet dark (?) and has a lot of peppery spice. Very full bodied - nothing is done lightly. This beer is huge, and very Belgian. I like it a lot! :)

Bottle.  Pours dark amber with a creamy off-white decent head.  Aroma of fruit, malt, caramel with a bit of alcohol.  Tastes of fruit, malt, spices and a touch of chocolate.  Very complex.  Hides the alchol content (10.5%) very well.  Smooth and warming.  Excellent !!

Amber brown pour light tan head ... aroma of dark fruits and spices .... taste of plums, raisins, molasses and spices with a warming finish ... lots of fruit flavor with a good balance and spicy bite .... very complex and excellent
UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 Delicious .Sweet, malty, caramel, honey. Tastes thick, but doesnt look thick. Alcohol scent. Dark mahogany color.
Colore scuro,schiuma poco persistente,nonostante la sua alta gradazione alcolica e facile da bere ,almeno la prima;).Un aroma fantastico.Una birra da provare e riprovare.Fantastica

Grabbed a bottle at Mint on walk home.  Pours a plum brown with large off white head.  Aroma is abound of apples and spice.  taste is spicy of apples, cherries, yeast, and malt.  lively carbonation on the palate with nice finish.  great way to start the weekend.

Poured a blackish-brown with a full-sized off-white head.  Great fruity aroma of grapes and apples.  Also Belgian yeast and caramel malts.  Taste is very sweet and fruity.  Flavors of cherries, yeast, brown sugar, raisins, plums.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  Aftertaste is smooth and sweet.  Fantastic beer!

Oh yeah. 12 oz bottle pours into a snifter a ruddy brown with dark red highlights; foamy, loudly fizzy tan head that sticks around for a bit. Nose is very malty, with apricots, fresh green apples, earthy, wine-like notes. Taste is incredibly clean and fresh. More apple, strong, healthy roots, mild spice. Mouthfeel is gentle, lively. Alcohol is extremely well-masked, and you WILL get pleasantly light-headed.
UPDATED: JUN 27, 2013 Nice reddish brown color with a long lived head. Good spicy aroma. Nice sweet taste. Not bad.

Rating #200, finally! The moment I cracked this open, 1/3 of the beer gushed all over the floor of my apartment. Gotta love this... Anyway, heres what I wrote down after cleaning up:

Murky brown appearance due to all the CO2 being released, thin off-white head. Pungent vinous aroma, mild alcohol, plums, dark cherries and just a hint of lemons and green apples. Pretty caramelly as well. Soft and creamy mouthfeel, but not cloying at all - I was even a little surprised by the fairly "thin" mouthfeel. The alcohol is definitely beneficial in balancing the beer with dryness. The flavour is fruity as fruity as the aroma, malty (Munich malt?), slightly caramelly and yeasty. Very little bitterness. Overall, Id say this is a really nice sipper, but it didnt overwhelm me.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2010 Had this at Cheeky Monk in Thornton, CO.  Very nice establishment with a ton of great brews.  This was the only beer I tried only because I knew of its quality through this website.  As complex as any brew Ive had.  Lots of flavor with that hops bite I look for.  Great mouthfeel and appearance.

A bit of a gusher this one.  I cellared it away for a few months, handled it with care, cooled it down to the serving temperature, but I guess it was just really happy to see me.  Lots of swirling yeast dancing around the bottle and glass - but hey, its Belgian.  Its a dark mahogany with a yellow-white head.  Aroma is more fruity than what is to be expected from a quad, or rather more lighter fruits here; apple skin, green grapes and unripe banana.  There is also a complex and wonderful spiciness.  Taste is a brown candy sugar, apple, cinnamon, a little bit of bready yeast and a tingle of alcohol.  It is amazingly well balanced, superbly so.  Its only let down is that the mouth feel is a tad thin.  Finish is cinnamon, sugar and apple - so very much like a rich apple crumble.  A classic.
smells of apples and yeast. Balanced mouth, with orange peel, fruit, and sweetness. No strong alcohol taste. Pretty tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 33 cl bottle.  Pours a brownish amber with a small white head leaving a small amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is yeasty, raisins, and light cherry with a bit of alcohol.  Initial taste is sweet raisin and caramel.  Light alcohol in the finish.  Light-medium body.  Low carbonation.

Deep brown body with creamy white head. Aroma of dark fruits. Very sweet with notes of dark fruits, vanilla and banana. Full bodied. Sweet, lasting finish that had a strong kick. Not as good as their Wit but very nice nonetheless.

750 ml bottle from Kellers IGA.  Pours a cloudy ruby-amber color with a big, rocky beige head that leaves some light, sloppy lacing and settles into an uneven cap on the beer.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, caramel malts, bread, plum, raisin, spices, licorice, and alcohol.  Flavor is not far off the smell, with plenty of yeast and caramel malts, bread, plums, raisins, brown sugar, nutmeg, anise, and alcohol.  Medium-bodied, with a yeasty mouthfeel, moderate carbonation, and a lot of sweetness.  Pretty smooth.  Complex, and a good sipper.  A bit of a letdown, though.
Pours a beautiful dark cloudy brown with a light brown head. Aroma is of fruit and bread. Nice full bodied mouthfeel and taste with notes of fruit, bread and spices. Fantastic beer.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with Vinny. Pours a sick hazy chesnut with a full, frothy off-white head. Aroma is delcious; figs, barley, tart cherries, banana, sweet malts, caramel, toffee, and bready-notes. Full bodied with a sweet, velvety smooth palate. Finishes with a brief, yet satisfying warming. Excellent Quad. Cannot believe I had not rated this guy yet.

Served from bottle into a Chimay goblet.  Poured a nice dark brown with a two-finger white head that subsides to a minimal amount slowly.  Lacing was excellent throughout.  The aroma was comprised of fruit, alcohol, and malt.  The flavor was filled with fruit, nuts, alcohol, and a spice note.  It had a medium feel on the palate with high carbonation.  Overall this was an excellent brew with a really nice flavor and aroma.  Actually very smooth for a quad as well.  I would and definitely will buy again.
33 cl bottle, Brussels, Belgium. Deep hazy auburn, musty barnfloor aroma. Sweet port flavor followed by a bitter hit that mellows to a warming spice finish.

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brown beer with a red shine on it, foamy white medium head, lacing ok. Fantastic aroma of dark fruits, sweetness, malts and some spices. Taste is caramel, chocolate, dark fruits, malty, light sweet on the background, even light hoppy at some moments. Every gulp you take the taste evolves better and better, giving you all the different tastes each on their own, fantastically flowing from the one taste to another. Top quality beer, best of the series, can stand next to the Westvleteren.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2010 Poured into a Duvel Tulip.

A-  Deep brown/ ruby red with a rich tan head and nice lacing.

S-  Complexity with molasses, caramel, orange. An earthy yeast, avg/hvy alcohol with figs.

T- Delicious!  Malty sweetness with a touch of bitterness, great balance, depth and complexity. An exceptional beer. 

M- Nicely carbonated, creamy and incredibly smooth.

D- Another dangerous brew. Goes down smoothly and hides the high ABV wonderfully. I could easily drink this all night.

Excellent beer. Another must have on hand.

Bottle, 33 cl.  This is a pretty damn delicious quad.  I wish it was a bit creamier in the mouthfeel but damn nice!  Aroma is boozey with hints of dank fruit and a little apple.  Taste is smooth, chock full of fruit and delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2011 12 oz bottle from Blaine G-Will.  Deep brown colored pour with a big plush light tan head.  Aroma is caramel & a little spicy, flavor is sweet with more caramel and dark fruit notes.  Finish is also sweet with bit of spiciness as well.  Fantastic beer.

Bottle @ Den Tatoverede Enke courtesy of gunnar. Dark clear mahogany with an off-white head leaving good lacing. Aromas of dried fruits, caramel, alcohol and perfume. Sweet, alcoholic, light bitter and spicy in the mouth. Medium to full body with a syrupy texture. Yummy!
Big spicy sweet aroma with some banana and bread. Tastes of a balanced sweetness of belgian sugars and spicy hops. I would love to sit down and enjoy this again with some aged cheeses.

The beer pours a hazy medium brown color with a tan head. The head appears very fluffy and soft. The aroma is alcohol, dark fruit, brown sugar, yeast and candi-sugar. The beer smells great. The flavor is a lot of dark fruit (plums and raisins) with some brown sugar, candi-sugar, yeast and alcohol. Medium-thick, very creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. This is what a quadrupel is supposed to taste like.

355 ml bottle.Pours a dark ruby with a thin tan head that stays around the sides of the glass.Nose is traditional of yeast,bread and many fruits.Taste is very smooth and drinkable with lush fruit throughout. Really nice beer but Ive tried many other American interpretations of the style I thought were considerably better...
Brown color with lots of head! Fruity aroma and taste, but sweetness previled. Fine brew, but if you want "fruity" there are many USA ales, at lower prices.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pungent grassy aroma. Very dark brown, beige head. Very strong sweet malty aroma. More like a fortified wine. Not for me.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 Malty with chocolate and fruit notes. Wonderful aroma. Its one of my favorite quadrupel.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2013 bottle. really dark brown with tan head that disappears quickly (Ive had this beer explode on me before so Im surprised it didnt this time) and of course the sediment floats on top.  Aroma is cereal, roasty, bread, coffee, and woody,  taste is medium sweet.  palate is creamy, full body, average carbonation, and has a super long finish. For some reason this beer tastes worse than I recall, but I know that in 20-30 minutes I will change my mind.

Bottle @ Den Tatoverede Enke, Copenhagen. Pours deep ruby with a thin off-white head. Aroma is quite complex of yeasty dough and sweet malts. Taste is a complex mix of sweet malts with notes of dried fruit especially raisins. Full body with soft carbonation. Dryness and a noticable bitterness emerges in a long and memorable finish.

head : normal, beige
colour: dark brown 
smell: candy sirup , hops , alcohol , wineous note , spices 
taste: strong alcohol and hop punch that floats away nicely in a spicey slightly anis and fruity flavour ... very nice ! but i think when aged and mellowd its even better !!
A chewy raisiny, doughy beer with lots of dark fruits and a fair bit of sweetness as well. Extremely smooth too easy to drink and too delicious.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2011 Bomber. Pours dark cloudy brown with small fizzy head that quickly dissipates. Spicy, bread-like flavor thats a little bit acidic. Smells a bit like leaves. One of my favorites.

pours a very deep brown like weak coffee. with a nice rich colored head that depletes quickly .the aromas are of dark stone fruits  black cherry and  plum, with  hints of caramel and coffee. which the taste mimics well i would  even stretch to say there is  some deep underlying  flavor like soy or Chinese  black beans...this beer  is good and executed well , just not amazing or unique

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2010 330 ml bottle. 10%. From Poperinge, Belgium.
Dark brown colour with average sized ever-lasting sand head and some yeast floaters. Aroma is complex with fruit, porridge, malt, tea and yeast. This really is something. Extremely fruity flavour with yeast, malt and lots of alcohol warmth. But where they hide the alcohol aroma? Flavour is genious. Very rich and smooth. Hallelujah this is great! Im so so so pleased I have 750 ml bottle of this excellent stuff waiting in my "beer cellar".

Bottle(0,75l) shared with boyfriend spkevin. Pours a hazy dark brown beer. Nose of yeast, alcohol, raisins and bread . Nice full mouth-feel. Taste is sweet, licorice, caramel, yeast, dry and slightly bitter ending.Long lasting aftertaste. Excellent brew, really enjoyed it!

Bottle shared with friend on the greens of our first golf outing of the seasn. Cloudy dark brown with some red highlights and plenty of floaties.  Nice rocky tan head with moderate lace. Nose of raisin, peach, spicy yeast.  Taste is quite balanced and no alcohol flavor is very pleasing. Taste of raisin, sweet bread, candy, and grape. Nice quick bitter on the back. Warms belly with no burn. Sweet!!! Excellent brew. Very enjoyable and worth the money.

Rich browns, mahogany, and glints of amber gaze endearingly at me from their resting place in my glass while a khaki head bubbles and burbles its way into a firm collar. She swirls with lace and a decadent nose. Sweet and vinous, pumpernickel bread heavy and rich emerges from the bakers oven even as candied fruit bring to mind fruitcake. Why is that fruitcake tastes so horrible and yet the aroma of fruitcake in beer is so enticing? This is obviously one of the great mysteries of life to which we will never be privy. Red and black licorice waft in and out while a plate of fresh prunes, dates, raisins, black cherries and plums are lain out before me. There is a delicate port quality to the Abt. 12 which only matures with age; do be sure to cellar a few bottles. Treacle and tobacco leaf wrap up her nose and I am ready to move into the quaffing stage. In fact, I was born ready to drink this beer. As with most St. Bernardus beers, her mouthfeel is rich and frothy with a boisterous bubbliness which settles down some with time in the bottle and/or in your glass. Prunes, raisins, and pumpernickel great me first, adding to her full and slightly chewy mouthfeel. Ah... just as good as I remember. Fruitcake and candied fruit bring a smile to my lips even as her fermentable sugar sweetness leads into the more earthy richness of licorice and tobacco leaf. Cinnamon sprinkles hither and fro as a rosy glow permeates my chest thanks to her lofty ABV. She slowly grows dry in her finish which is enhanced by further notes of cinnamon, wood, and tobacco leaf lingering long in my breath. Each quaff leaves a luscious coating of treacle-dipped raisin and prune on my lips for a truly smacking occasion. St. Bernardus Abt. 12 is best enjoyed at cellar temperature, each quaff a palatial revelation, and so I cede pen and paper to pure selfish enjoyment.


Dont believe me? Wait not and grab a bottle. Many may wax lofty poetic praise on the Chimay Blue, but for me, the St. Bernardus Abt. 12 is the Belgian Quadrupel where all Belgian Quadrupels are at. Always great. Always humble. Always mine.

I have tried before, but this review is from an 11.2 oz bottle.  I forgot just how good this really is, and Im not a huge fan of Belgian beers.  Aroma is alcoholic and sweet, rather fruity with yeast.  Very nice aroma, not too demanding but not stale at all.  Nice caramel appearance, the head is rather large but thats alright.  Taste wise, this is truly something special.  Theres a ton going on and all the tastes compliment each other instead of fight each other.  Its carbonated but smooth, very complex fruit characteristics, has a slight tang for a finish.  Theres a lot to be impressed with, and at $3.99 for a 12 oz bottle its intended for special occasions.

Sweet with loads of malt and sherry-like character.  Stone fruits and dried fruits are highly prevalent.  Easy-drinking and very smooth finish.  slight woody and anise flavor characteristics are present.  Slight bottle bomb.

Bottle from Crown Liquors #6 - Pours brown with a half-finger tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, grain, brown sugar, and spruce. Taste is bready malt, dark fruit, and some piny/spruce hop character. Mouthfeel is dry and soft.
Very sweet and tasty abbey ale. Brownish pour. Nose and taste of molasses, brown sugar, caramel, spruce, cedar and dough. Rated 5/24/04
Nose is of dry fruit, grape and plum.  Amber/brown color with off white head.  Dry with a hints of grape/plum with a slight earthy finish.

Ive had this one before but just getting around to reviewing it now...

Pours a nice deep cloudy dark brown with a beautiful foamy tan head.  Very little lacing.  Aroma is amazing and the flavors match - malty yeasty goodness.

Ive had better Quads, but this one is up there towards the top.  Would drink again.

Very foamy beer. The overly foamy nature detracted from te overall appearance. Poured down brown with a frothy, off-white head. The most notable aromas were caramel, raisins, andgrapes with grassy and earthy hints. The balance of caramel malts, fruit and hop notes help disguise the overall high abv level. I felt that the malts were a little over-powering. Overall, this was a full-bodies, well balanced beer. The expert combination of flavors masks the alcohol. This is a silently strong beer that should be enjoyed slowly.

great abt quadrupel. dark red cloured with dark white persistent head.incredible aroma consisting of mixes of nuts,chocolate, red wine and berries. proununced hpppy flavours and medium bitterness. despite being highly alcoholic it seems really easy to drink

Pours out with a white head that settles over hazy reddish-brown liquid. The nose is spicy, with notes of chocolate and light hints of dark fruits & a "horse blanket" aroma. Mouthfeel is effervescent, with notes of nuts, chocolate, fruitiness and a healthy amount of hops. The finish drys out to a perfect balance of hoppiness and malt sweetness...the high alcohol in this beer is hardly noticeable until late finish. A remarkable beer, you find it..buy it!
sample taster, the alcohol hides very well , had alot of fruity notes to it, pours out light brown color with lively head with some bready notes as well

Bottle, Way too foamy, frothed out of the bottle and i had to hurry it into the glass. Dark brown body with off white head.  Aroma is caramel,fresh bread and raisins.  Full bodied.  Caramelly taste with some toasty notes.  Smooth bodied, does not taste as strong as it is.  Lasting sweet finish.  Sip it and confine yourself to one or two.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 25, 2010 (bottle: bb 02.08.2012) Pours murky dark brown foaming so agressively it comes out of the bottle on its own; aroma is dominated by dried fruits like plums and raisins, it also has slight earthy tones and - surely coming unexpected - butter; flavor is also dried fruity with toffeish caramel notes, much spicier than the aroma drying the mouth and keeping the sweetness well in place; medium to full-bodied with smooth carbonation. Although it didnt quite hit the spot for me, I throughoutly enjoyed it.

Pours dark brown, hazy (fine sediment visible) with a frothy off-white mostly lasting head.  Aroma is quite complex of yeasty dough and sweet malts. dried fruit (raisins). Flavour is a complex mix of sweet malts with notes of dried fruit especially raisins. Full body with soft carbonation. Dryness and a noticable bitterness emerges in a long and memorable finish. This is an excellent Abt.

Classic belgian aroma right out of the bottle.  Plenty of malt, yeast, fruit, and brown sugar.  Huge lasting head.  Pours a deep, dark amber.  Flavor is dark fruit, bubble gum, yeast, booze, ginger bread.  Very complex.  Smooth, chewy mouthfeel.  Great belgian beer, almost as good as Rochefort.  A classic.

Bottle from Beverages and More.  Pours dark soil in color with a tall hansom head.  Fruits and caramel and strong yeasts permeate from the glass while brown sugar and wet hey mix with the strong balance of alcohol.  This is a very complex beautiful ABT, dried fruits and nuts, caramel and yeast and a long warm finish.

33cl bottlre. Pours a coffee head and brown color. Aroma: cherry and nuts. Flavor has some nutty notes in it, with elements of raisins, toffee and sweet chocolate. The alcohol is very well hidden.  Thick and creamy mouthfeel. Great abbey ale!

33 cl bottle. Pours a cloudy brown color with a thick layer of creamy, ivory head. Pleasantly thick, rich aromas of raisin, fig, and caramel malts. .Full bodied, rich mouthfeel with a touch of vanilla and clove spice accompaning the smoky, meaty spice that characterizes this brew. The finish is a bit astringent with some alcohol burn.

This beers look beautiful out of the bottle and in the glass. Its got a slightly cloudy, deep brown tone. But the taste wasnt what I was looking for. It was awfully bitter and malty. Not my favorite from this very fine brewery.

My first quad, and I fear I could be spoiled.  Aromas are yeast, brown sugar, dried fruits, alcohol.  Appearance is a dark ruby reddish brown with a nice smoky tan head and beautiful lacing.  The flavor and palate are so complex I fear I cant do them justice.  My favorite brew to date.

Aroma: Has a sweet smell with with notes of caramel, citrus, and fruit. There is the distinct indicators of its higher alcohol content as well.

Appearance: Has a tall, frothy head. The beer itself is a cloudy dark amber.

Taste: definitely a good bit of alcohol in the taste, but still quite pleasant.  Has the typical complexity of a Belgian beer.  Dried fruits, caramel, and strong malt all abound in the taste of this delightful beverage.

Palate: given how robust the bold taste of this beer is, the feel on the palate is surprisingly thin.  This is an aspect of the beer that should not go unappreciated.  The carbonation is a flatter experience; a long enjoyable bitter ending finishes out this beer.

On tap.  Pours a dark brown with a light head.  Nose is fruity - raisins and cherries, with a slight sourness - but overall weaker than I expected.  Palate is smooth and very nice.  Tastes of lightly roasted malts, sweet fruitiness, and more slight sourness (in a good way).  Finishes fairly sweet.  Very good beer.

Wow! What a great quad. One of the best Ive ever had.  Bottle tasting at work, this 12oz bottle was traded to me by one of my favorite rbers BelgianBeerGal.  Aroma, taste, palate... all so perfectly reflecting the style, and yet still sets itself apart from other beers of the same style.  I strongly recommend giving this bad boy a try!

Slightly opaque medium brown with 3 fingers of off-white head. Aroma is sharp, of raisins and sugar. Extremely high carbonation makes this really bite. Flavors of rum and raisin, finishing very sweet.

Pours a dark brown with a off white head that has great retention.  Aroma is raisins, malt and sweet carbonation.  Taste is just a pleasure for the palate.  So many different flavours come out with the playing of this in the mouth.  Good carbonation livens up the palate to accept flavours of raisins, malts, caramel and a little metallic taste.  Just a nice beer, thanks to gotoguns for this.  Will put the other one away for a while and see how it ages.
Dark, full color, strong flavor. Careful when uncorking the bottle, the beer has a tendency to overflow.
A tall corked bomber murky brown pour- tall lite tan head- taste of fruit,nuts,roasty, dough, -not my favorie style of beer but really good

Pours dark brown with a decent size lighter beige head. Aromas of dark fruit, slight sweetness, spices and yeast as well. Start out with dark fruit on the palate, nice sweetness,  and get the yeast on the end. Nice smooth mouthfeel to it and do not notice the alcohol too much.

Shared this w/ SkyCop32.  Pours a deep dark reddish brown color. Aromas of dark fruit, caramel, and some spice. Flavors are dark cherries, plums, and some spice. Alcohol is really hidden in the deep flavors.

Pours dark prune color with a lively beige head. Dark fruity aroma with lots of spritzy carbonation on the palate.  noticeable alcohol increases as it warms.   Liquid bread in a glass.  Filling finish.

A great beer with a wonderful Belgian flavor. Its spicy and bready and incredible. Theres a lot of aroma, sweet caramel and spiced nuts. The flavors adds in raisins and smoke. Theres a lot of carbonation sizzling the flavors throughout the mouth. I could drink this beer for a long period of time, like a fortnight or so.

Dark brown color with a tan, lacing head. Chestnut, molasses, honey, ripe fruits, alcohol in the aroma. Medium sweetness in a dense, characteristic body. Just the right amount of carbonation. If you can get yours hand on this one, its a must.

Pours a dark golden brown. Massive, thick offwhite head that lasts forever. Nose of apples, bread and banana. Very complex. Sweet malts. Amazing flavor. Heavy malt like candy sugar. Very cidery. So complex, its hard to pick out flavors. Not even a hint of alcohol. Palate is surprisingly thick. Coats the mouth well. Low carbonation levels leave a silky smooth texture. Overall, the best Belgian Ive had to date. Id compare it to an Imperial Chimay, if they made one. Im in love.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2010 Corked 750 ml Bottle. Appearance is light reddish brown with tiny seed fragments and an inch of whipped head. Aroma is spiced bread, pears, sour apples and burnt sugar. Taste begins with intense brown sugar and caramel malt sweetness. It follows with doughy yeast, toffee, raisins and candied dates. The finish is toasty and boozy with a very pleasant candied sugar aftertaste. The overall mouthfeel is silky and creamy with a wonderful balance of dried fruit and dark sugar flavors along with that classic Belgian style doughy yeastiness. Exceptionally complex and flavorful Quad with an ABV that creeps up on you.

this is really good. intense, but not cloying, rum and raisiny aromas and flavours. big but dry mouthfeel. very disguised touch of alcohol. phenols galore without being overpowering. floaties are very hard to avoid though.
Its a really great beer. I really enjoyed the fruity flavor but I always envy those people that are able to distinguish the kind of fruit that is used. Beautifull color.
I love this beer. Bitterness is as I wish, medium bitter, has full body, finish is long. Excellent.
bread, hoppy,amber, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, lively, bitter.
Cloudy, milk-chocolate brown. Alcohol and banana (?) come through strongly in aroma. Mouthfeel is even, not sticky. Finish is sticky, has some burn due to high alcohol content.

Bottle.

A - Deep hazy brown with a red hue. Good sized creamy, and tan head. Good amount of lacing left over.

S - Sweet bready malt paired with dark sugar and molasses. Dark fruit (plum, raisin, date, cherry) and licorice. Also a good amount of spice, specifically clove.

T - Similar to smell, with a lot of dark bready malts and dark sugar along with the above mentioned fruit make up a large amount of the taste. Also the spices (clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, anise) are quite prevalent. Alcohol is quite hidden, although there is a hint of it.

M - Full to medium body with adequate carbonation. Really creamy and smooth.

D - Really nice to sip. Smooth creamy and full, and provides a warming, but not necessarily all from the alcohol. Sweet but not cloying, really complex and a new flavor every sip provides a new mix of flavors.

Notes: Really nice beer with lots of complex flavors. A lot of spice in this beer. Good example of the style and a good example of craft beer in general.

I expected a small differense with westvleteren , but it wasnt.
nice beer but i missed some bitternes.

Bottle pours dark reddish slightly cloudy brown with nice two finger head that hangs around a while.  Aroma fruity with slight alcohol.  Tastes plums, raisins,currants, berries.  Palate very smooth and gentle.  Aftertaste of berries and fruits, very pleasant and not overwhelming.

Overall great beer.

I found this beer to be a bit disappointing, given the ratings and the description. Its a beautiful beer, with complex colors ranging from burnt orange to copper to mocha and lots of points in-between. Aroma is certainly soft and genuine -- it smells quite similar to the way it tastes -- but theres something abstract missing from it. Its tasty, for sure -- earthy fruits (raisins for sure), barnyard-esque (in an open-air pastoral sort of way -- idyllic Irish or something), perhaps too focused on the sweetness, and some hints of bitterness. It coats the tongue and lingers, but the mass produced caramel candy aftertaste cheapens the experience. Still really great -- but the slight let down weighs more than it should . . .

Dark reddish brown with a tan head that leaves a good lacing. Smells like plums and spices. Meduim body, the caramel malts really hit you with this one, followed by a slight bitter finish. Masks the alcohol really well . Yum.
UPDATED: JAN 31, 2011 Less talented cousin of Westvleteren. A solid brown caramelized which is drunk without penalty. A sure bet Trappist

1 pint, 9.4oz bottle.  Poured dark amber that was cloudy with huge white head.  Aroma of raisins and fruit.  Taste is huge!  Bursts forth of fruits galore with touches of spice all around.  Great great beer.

Bottle - Poured a dark brown color with a nice foamy head.  Aroma is very raisin like, malty and yeasty with hint of alcohol. Taste of dark fruits, yeasty, bready and malty - just as one would expect from the nose. Medium carbonation with smooth finish. Tasty.

Già vedendola nel bicchiere è bella! Scura, con una bella schiuma cremosa. Lolfattiva è seducente. Complessa. In bocca è piena, grande struttura per questa belga che non delude le aspettative. Equilibrata.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2013 Small bottle. Murky brown with a creamy light tan head. Aroma has no treble, just bass: leather, earth, decaying wood, dried blackberries, molasses, old malt whisky. Unctuous mouthfeel. Taste is mainly sweet with a little spice and a bare hint of sourness - a little bit of a let down after the aroma. Dark fruits give way to fresher berries and a little cleansing bitterness at the finish. Alcohol is certainly there, but well-integrated. Great. [4.3] 1/11 Fresher bottle. Fruits and spices a little more vibrant. The finish is boozy but lovely with plums and dark sugars giving way to spices. [4.4] Just bumped appearance to 5 on a "what am I saving that point for?" basis. Big, boozy, complex, but remains just a fun thing to drink.

Pours brown with some reddish tints and a tan head. The aroma is lots of dark fruit, brown sugar, yeast, and spices. The flavor is very nice with a complex malt blend. Lots of dark fruits, coconut, brown sugar, and spices. Strong alcohol presence with a warming finish. A good Belgian, but slightly overrated in my opinion.

either one tap, or in a bottle this beer is almost without equal, dark brown with a thick white foam with  rich taste thats e sweet and bitter, goes down smooth and one can savor all the flavors that they put into the beer

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2014 Sampled at Vineyards in Ottawa, from their 330ml brown bottle. Poured a deep brown, non-see-through, with red highlights. The creamy tanned head has extra long retention. On top of it are found extremely tiny sediment of spices, here and there, but lightly. A miniature fizz comes up to surface. Thick lacing is left. The aroma at first is very light. Slight vinegar, but as the brew gets warmer (suggested), it starts having a nutty scent with hints of bread. The taste mostly of dark fruits like plums, raisins, grapes mixed in with some toffee. The nuts are found in it, as well as minimal molasses. A beautiful apple aftertaste is left and the finish is very smooth. The mouthfeel is creamy and mildly tarty. Overall.... Wowwy, Wow ! Wow ! Very nicely brewed, and will definitely try again.

From a 750 ml corked and caged bottle. This  poured a dark brown color and raised a big brown creamy head with good lacing. Beautiful pour.  The nose is ripe fruit with plums and berries, with a whiff of  alcohol,   Rich heavy body and a creamy mouthfeel.  The flavor is belgian yeasts with fruit and malts.  The finish is amazing, with a long lasting aftertaste that rounds off one of the better beers in the world.

questa birra risulta veramente una "specialità"!
molto corposa e forte alcolicamente ma risulta decisamente bilanciata tra il dolce del malto e laroma della frutta!!!
speciale è il finale davvero persistente!!!!

330mL bottle.  Pours a hazy nut brown with a small head that settles to a thin covering of large bubbles.  Aroma of red wine, toast, maple syrup and yeast.  Not as much in the flavour, a bit of caramel, fruit and very slight bitterness with a slight sourness coming in late.  The alcohol is well masked.  Soft carbonation, medium-full bodied and slick with a slightly sour and astringent finish.

Pour from 750 ml bottle.  Moderate head which fades quickly.  Dark dirty brown with visible sediment.  Aroma restrained with discernible alcohol.  Full body, tastes of brown sugar, dried dates/figs with breadiness and a surprising bitter background that holds everything together.  Alcohol is noticable but not overpowering.  Fantastic.
Dark pour from bottle.  Pillowy head, with a distinctive taste of bitter fruits.  Warm alcohol finish.  Very decent beer, but certainly not worthy of a 100 rating, IMO.

A: The pour is a cloudy dark mahogany color without much head to speak of.

S: Good but not great aromas of sweet malt, caramel, and yeast. There might be a touch of alcohol as well.

T: I was a bit let down by the aroma, but the flavor does quite well to redeem itself. A slight warming feel of alcohol goes well with some dark fruits and sweet, caramel malt. The yeast is not as quite prominent as many other Belgian beers.

M: Even with the high level of carbonation, the body is still quite full.

D: The alcohol makes itself known more in terms of the subtle warmth it provides the beer but isnt aggressive by any means. The flavors are sweet but balanced and are helped out by the carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2010 Everyone seems to enjoy this one a whole lot, maybe the ABV hits them hard in the end. A very dark brew serve in a goblet at Yard House. Subtle lacing at the top. Tastes of very bitter fruit and prunes. Not an offensive taste, but it does not go down as smooth as I would hope. Tasty, but not a favorite.
Murky brown with a brown head. Aroma of caramels, sweet fruits. It has a nice sweet to bitter, creamy taste. Like it!

Pours a hazy dark brown, bubbly head is sticky like glue. Aroma of raisins, figs, Sweet malt, and a bit of spice. Dark fruits up front in the mouth, yeast and spice back it up. Bit of warming alcohol at the end.
Pours murky brown with a brown head.  Wonderful aroma of dark fruit, caramel and yeast.  Flavor is raisins, prunes, caramel, some spice, dark malt.  Smooth mouthfeel. Truly delicious.

Bottle. Brownish with tanned head. Aroma of caramel, fruit, sweet liquorice, somewhat clinical.
Full bitter to sweet evolving flavour with fruit, raisin, smoke and liquorice.

Pours a dark chocolate haze with some life, thin head.  Aroma of grapefruit, with hints of caramel and banana.  Has a creamy, doughy, bitter taste.  A yeasty feel.  Medium body that thickens nicely as it warms.  Tasty brew.

bottle - hazy orange brownish beer with a nice beige white head. Aroma is thinner than expected. Some faint caramel and cardboard notes. Flavour is more complex. Right maltiness to balance the high alcohol. Medium to low bitterness.

[bottle from bierkompass.de]
Complex, spicy aroma with some musty, powdery character. Lots of spices and some herbs, but hard to pinpoint any single accents. Cloudy orange-brown under a lasting, beige blanket. Sugary, woody bitter, alcoholic flavour that is slightly vinous with some white grape. Appropriate bitterness for the medium sweet flavour. Some brown sugar. Medium body, medium carbonation, sweet, spicy finish.

Great beer.  All the normal stuff youd expect-baking spices, banana, bready Belgian yeast.  But after being open for about 90 minutes (but still chilled) I was getting great bitterness in the end that reminded me a lot of tea tannins that combined with great soft orange aromas and was not unlike Earl Grey.
Tap. Dark brown body with a small white head. Sweet, brown sugar, caramel. Silky, smooth and well balanced.  A very nice beer.

Medium dark amber, relatively clear with a small head... Aroma of big dark fruits with yeast, belgian candi sugar, and sweet malts... Flavor of big fruits dark yeast very flavorful warming... full bodied huge flavors excellent...
Draft at the Mellow Mushroom Mobile. Dark brown with a small white head. Sweet, sugary nose. Taste of candi sugar, malts, sweetness. Body is silky smooth and easily drinkable. Well done.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 18, 2010 750mL Bottle -- Pours opaque brown with a reddish hue and a light tan head.  Aromas of caramel, mild chocolate, jam, fig, toast, soy, and yeast.  Full bodied, slightly sticky sweetness, some tartness, and average to lively carbonation.

In bottle
Dark brown head with light lacing.  Lots of malt flavors, spices and yeast. You can feel the alcohol.  One of the best Belgian Trappists, up there with Westmalle.
Poured out dark with a distinct but gentle aroma of yeast and fruit.  Very smooth drink tasting brown sugar sweet.  For me this beer loses to Rochforte 10 by a hair.  A nice beer.

Pours a fairly dark brown colour, in the light a little red with a nice tan head. The aroma is malty with some fruits present; raisins mostly, there is also some yeast and spice too. The taste is fairly sweet, again there are some darker fruits present, the finish was also fairly sweet not much bitterness in this beer. Medium bodied, creamy in the mouth, quite nice. Overall a very good beer.

¨Murky red/brown colour, big beige head, light lacing.
Candied sugar, yeast, alcohol, dried fruits in the nose.
The same flavours are found, rich and fruity, yeasty and a warming finish accompanied by a light bite.
The carbonation is rather sharp but mellows out eventually, the liquid is slightly sticky.

Bottle. Was shocked to see that ive never rated this so here goes. Poured a rich dark beige with a wisper thin off white head. Nose is yeasty with candied sugars and dark fruits and some sweetness. Flavor is rich and complex.  This is so smooth, with a medium mouthful. Its loaded with dark fruits and carries a buttery sweetness to it but still finishes very dry. Nicely carbonated with a hint of the abv this a delicious classic.

My bro offered me a beer and it was either this or coors light.

I wasnt sure what to expect with this beer. Blue moon is an ok but drinkable beer. I expected the same from this.

Looks almost like a marzen when poured but a shade or two darker. A thin 1 finger head on top.

Smells a little sweet with a small bit of spice and candied dark fruit. A bit of herbs and some sour apple too.

Light but sweet flavor. Some roasted sugary pear like flavor. I think this beers biggest downfall is calling itself a A dubble. It falls way short of that namesake and because of that becomes a disappointment. Like someone else stated somewhere, its a macros attempt at a craft beer and it comes up short imo.

Mouthfeel is watery albeit somewhat smooth and not hard to drink.

Probably not a beer i would ever drink or even want to drink again.
It smells potent and malty-perfumey. It is dark brown with some maroon color and a ton of sediment floating in this thick brew. It tastes sweet, and very malty and boozy as in the Belgian tradition.

Bottle served in a tulip. Sediment rich cloudy brown in color with a huge, swelling light brown head. Good retention and decent lacing. Aroma is raisins, pit fruit, spice, alcohol, and malty sweet. Complex and very aromatic. Changing all the time. Medium-full body. thick texture, and oily. Sweet flavor and a touch salty. Alcohol is very evident. The finish is long and oily with minimal sweetness. Impressive.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2011 11.2 oz bottle, pours a deep amber brown with a thick beige head. Aroma is caramel malts, raisins, various other dried fruits and spices - very complex. Flavour is extremely complex - caramel malt, raisins, figs, slightly sweet, very alcoholic, hints of toffee. Full-bodied mouthful, with an alcoholic finish. Outstanding beer.

750-ml bottle Whole Foods, Baton Rouge, LA - Aroma: malty sweet, raisins, dates, slight peppery; Appearance: hazy, deep brown in color, huge persistent light tan head, some laces; Flavor: malty sweet, salty, caramel, raisin, date; Mouthfeel: medium to full bodied, creamy texture, lively carbonation; Overall: a dark, very rich, complex, smooth, malty, fruity, and strong alcohol Belgian Abbey style beer with a dry-alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2012 Bottle. Both aroma and taste are very complex. Very dark brown color, big head, but the foam disappears pretty quick. There is some weird thing inside, I only can describe as "candy", maybe a bit like some kind of bubblegum. As well with smelling as tasting this "candy" comes accros. Very decent beer for special occasions. Edit: blindtasted on 8 july 2010 with Westvleteren 12 (both about 9 months), I prefer this one... Taste was close, something different inside, but I should give both same points. Also for the looks. But the smell of this one I prefered above the Westy... Retasted both blind after 2.5 years aging. The Westy is better sligthly.

Big Bomber. Pours a dark chocolate brown with ample thick frothy head.  Aroma is roasted malt and slight chocolate hint. Dark fruit and sweet malt taste, hints of toffee. Thick feel on the tongue, slighty alcohol finish....a great sipping beer on a cold winters evening. Well worth the price!!!
At vonk slijterij in zaandam,  bottle 330ml, hazy brown, full fluffy head, lots of spices and parfumery flowers, grainy heavy bottom.

Appearance: Pours a murky deep brown (borderline black). An inch or so of off-white, foamy head lasts a good while, so long in fact that it was a bit annoying. The head is quite dense and frothy.

Aroma: Not very aromatic due to the massive, thick head. With some swirling and settling I caught a little bit of the dark fruit notes. Smells a bit like dry champagne to me, maybe a touch of alcohol.

Taste: What a complex beer we have here! First hit with dark fruit flavors, reminded me of red wine so I thought maybe grapes, currants, cherries or plums. I get a slight taste of some malts in there but the carbonation really brings out the fruit above all else. Not much bitterness if any. Aftertaste dominated by a dry alcoholic taste.

Palate: Good effervescence makes for a crisp, dry finish but overall the beer goes down smooth and is perfectly balanced in the mouth.

Overall: Definitely a new favorite, excellent Belgian ale in every way. The interesting esters and hints of malt combined with the ability to hide an ABV of 10% make this a deceptively drinkable brew. By all means grab a bottle and find out for yourself, a glass or two later and youll be damn satisfied- and DRUNK!
sweet, molasses, malt and bold...I could belly up to the bar and drink me a few of these...

Poured from the bottle.  Very nice hazy dark copper with perfect head.  Highly carbonated, full bodied sweet and fizzy palate full of fig and raisin.  Very complex beer with a sneaky kick.  The alcohol is silent in this quad.  Overall, I am very impressed, lacking a bit in aroma, but this beer is top notch.

Bottle. Pour is very bubbly deep brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is lots of dark fruit, christmas spice, rich caramel malt, cocoa, and lightly nutty.  Flavor is true to nose with quite a bit of effervescence.  This is great stuff.

St Bernardus ABT 12
On tap at Pangaea Café in Sacramento. Thanks to Rob for having this. Pours medium hazy brown with a thin tan head. Minimal lacing on the glass. Subdued aroma of alcohol, bread dough and caramel with some yeastiness. Aroma gets stronger as the beer warms Flavor is much the same with a rich caramel and Belgian funk flavor. Sublime on tap with a warming finish. Darn well balanced, but I honestly like something with slightly less balance.
bottiglia. i profumi sono molto prepotenti con sentori di frutta a polpa rossa tostatura e carammello.il gusto forse è troppo aggressivo nel carammellato e fruttato cuasi ad arrivare al bubblegum.
on tap: Pours dark brown/ red. Sweet caramel and toffee and candy-like sweetness., some nuts and dark fruit and foamy white head. Some mildew notes in the finish. All around a solid beer.

Bottle, pours brown with a cream head.  Aroma of dark fruits and malts.  Complex flavor or dark fruits and caramel.  Delicious smooth mouthfeel and this beer hides the alcohol well.  These are easy to find and always great.

Extremely dark brown/not quite black, with an large off-white head that has good life and lacing. The smells are of dark fruits (plums, grapes, figs), caramel mats, and a hint of chocolate. Although the aroma of fruits is quite strong the alcohol shines through as well, this brew does not hide the fact that is ABV is so high (10.5%). Even so the taste does not disappoint and has the overwhelming flavor of dark fruits and dark malts with a hint of alcohol at the end. Smoother than Tucker Max at a bar.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2013 this is a great beer, definitely not for beginners though. I made the mistake of trying this brew too early before I was really into quads and belgian strongs and it was just too much for me. That being said, this beer is awrsome. Lots of dried fruit and brown sugar aromad and flavors. Complex, warming, and just tasty in general. A classic.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 On draft at the Demervallei. Pours a nice darkbrown beer with an even more beautiful beige head which leaves lots of lacing behind. Aroma is full of fruit. Taste is even more fruit and is very smooth with a nice bitterness on the end. Mouthfeel is excellent and very soft. I didnt liked the bottle version, but this draft version is just perfect.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2016 Refrigerated big bottle with a cork.  Pours a medium brown with dark amber highlights and small beige head.  Lacing is excellent and palate is wonderful.  Taste is malty fruit (mostly fig), some toffee and caramel, and a hint of alcohol.  Good, but I prefer Rochefort 10.

Bottle.  Pours brown with a creamy tan head that coats the glass.  Malt and spicy Belgian yeast aromas.  Malt, sugar, spicy fruit, and alcohol flavors.  Creamy mouthfeel with a warming alcohol finish.  Nice sipping beer on a cold winter night.

This one spouted foam from the bottle for several minutes before I poured it into my glass. Decent head that fades rather soon, but leaves a good film and decent lacing. The color is a deep brown with ruby tints. Nose is toffee and deep fruits with hints of chocolate and some sweet apple and even some banana. The taste is initially bitter, quickly giving way to candied fruits, molasses and hints of chocolate. Lingering sweetness in the finish is a bit overpowering. The mouthfeel is medium light with plenty of carbonation and warming alcohol in the finish though balanced by the sweetness. As the beer warms, the bitterness fades and the deep fruits become more pronounced. This tastes young, like it would improve with some aging...

11.2 oz.,  drink by 18 11 13.  Dark brown/red beer with nice head that will last the entire sipping session. Pours out some clumpy yeast. Probably the richest smelling beer Ive known, caramel/toffee and cloves, mostly. Those are also on the tongue, plus some fruits (but maybe as much apples and berries as plums and figs). Slightly boozy. Lots of bubbles, but theyre all small. Vaguely rustic, very rich and very, very good.
Pours a dark reddish brown with nice frothy tan head. Aroma consists of orange, caramel, spice and malt.  A favorite of mine.   Great all around, as close to perfect as can be.
Playful. Jubilant. Smooth. Caramel? Toffee tones? Nuts? Deliciously subtle palate seeks deeper inquiry.

Pours with a three-finger light tan head that fades slowly leaving a good lace.  Cloudy brown/amber color.  Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Nose is raisin/caramel. Starts sweet has a raisin/caramel flavor, mellow finish; better as it warms, hints of alcohol. Part of a gift 4-pak that was $17.00 from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, ME. Best before date of Aug 13, 2014 - I couldnt wait!

Dark reddish brown with a medium-sized tanned head. Great head retention and lots of lacings.

The smell is full of fruit esters - blackberries, figs, plums and apples. Very impressive. Sweet dark malts and notes of fudge, grass and yeast.

The taste is very balanced and complex. Sweet dark malts and fruity flavors (figs, plums, apples) up front. Caramel, gentle spices, dry wood and a hint of yeast. A hint of chocolate. The finish has a nice bitter twist to it with plenty of malt aromas, lingering fruit esters and warming and well integrated alcohol. A very tasty brew.

Medium to full bodied, very smooth texture despite generous amounts of carbonation.

This is one of those Belgians that are just unbelievably balanced and tasty. Although Ive had lots of beers I like better, theres something about a beer like this that makes them come out almost as perfection in a bottle - everything is at its place and I wouldnt want to change a thing.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Poured from a 22oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a dark black with about two fingers of brownish foamy head. some lacing of the glass.

The smell is sweet but a bit musky, gives me visions of trees or leaves falling. A hard core flavor apple and a little bit of clove.

The taste is malty with some dried fruits. There is some pear flavor mixed with a bit of a creamy/sugary flavor that gives out a great kiss the the senses.

The feel gives a great Belgian flavor beer. Its hard to really say more than that it just gives off a great flavor and it is full bodied beer with some great flavor and is easy drinking.

From 750 ml. bottle into tulip on January 1, 2010.  Pours a dark brown with moderate tan head, which lingers along with substantial lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits (fig, raisin) with caramel malt, yeast, and a bit of spice.  Taste is very well-balanced, not too sweet, very smooth and a bit oily.  Typical of the abt/quad style.  Alcohol warms along the way.  A very enjoyable bottle on a cold winters night - well worth the price.  Cheers!

one of my favorite beers.  Real nice rich brown color in the pour.  Has a real nice creamy head.  It bursts with aromas of fruit.  The taste is extremely fruity and smooth also.  So smooth you dont even realize its 10.5% which can be a problem.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2010 11 oz. bottle- pours dark brown with a nice thin head that congregates near the rim. Aroma is yeast and sugar, the flavor is a perfect Belgian Abbey, sweet and some kind of spice, delicious. Next up Delerium Noel.
This was great! Pour is with a thick tan head that lingers for a while. Aroma is fruity and flavor matches, masking the taste of 10.5% alcohol. Not terribly expensive either.
alcohol-y, yeast-y, pretty bitter and caramel-y. A bender in the making. Its a bit heavy and alcohol-y for my tastes.

It poured a hazy brown-amber liquid with a small beige foam that left very little lacing.

It had a smell of figs, wood and nuts.

It had a semi-smooth mouthfeel, medium body and low bitternes. Tasted of red wine, figs, druid fruit and nuts.

Also a very nice beer but the triple was better.

never been a fan of this style, but i tried this for dessert and was very impressed. big chocolatey and estery flavors and a delicious creamy texture. better on tap because i dont like the heavy sediment in the bottled St Bernardus beers.

Poured from .33l bottle into a St. Bernardus chalice, shared with SamGamgee.  Darker brown, a bit hazy,  with medium tan head.  Nose of sweet malt, bread, raisins.  Taste was on the sweet side, just slightly bitter.  Very smooth to the palate, medium bodied with an oily feel.  Excellent beer!
