Bottle.  Very pleasant aroma from afar, prickles the nose up close, very rich, toffee, blackberry, dough, minor alcohol.   Massive fizzing head, darker cream color, minor lacing, very opaque and cloudy, dark rust-brown in color.  This is a large but smooth malt dominated beverage, almost sugary sweet candy at the start, flavor becomes very rich and heavy on the sweetness spectrum (probably too rich for my personal liking) soon after, some mixed spices and light alcohol in the finish, I do enjoy the aftertaste though.  Not as memorable as I was expecting, maybe too heavy on the rich fruit, though it is definitely a well crafted drink.

33cl bottle from Systembolaget. It poured a dark brown, almost black colour with a medium big beige head that settles down fast in the glass. The aroma is fruity and smells of raisins, roasted malts and sweet caramel. The flavour is bitter-sweet and tastes of fruits, raisins, banana, malts and alcohol. It has a long aftertaste.

Fruity/plum like aroma that is fairly weak.  This is fairly acidic with some malts and is almost wine like in its palate.  Not much bitterness, just sugary sweet like a good wine.  This is in a class by itself as most beers don’t have such a strong fruit presence.  This one grows on you though, and is of very high quality.  The only negatives about this beer is the somewhat weak aroma and the overbearing fruitiness.

Belgium comes through again! Without question I enjoy the deep brown color and off white head but the aroma , and taste of  roasty malt, caramel, and deep fruit tones are marvelous. I like the alcoholic tone because it is in balance with the smooth sweet tones in this quad.

[1562-20080802] 330mL bottle. Fresh raisin malt and boozy fruit aroma. Murky, dark brown red body with a long-lasting foamy light tan head and lots of dark floaties. Hard fruity booze flavour has a bit of raisin malt. Medium-full body. Fresh.
(c/o HogTownHarry, w/ jerc)
This beer had a very sweet aroma, poured dark brown. It had a very large white head. I liked the taste at first, but the after taste was far to bitter for my taste.
nice aroma, dark brown with some black debris in it, flavor is suiper balanced sweet built by lots of components.

Dark Golden Brown pour, Yeasty, spicy, malty aromas.  Mouthfeel is like but hearty with a complex mix of spice and yeast with some subtle fig and and maybe raisin or grape.  Warming alcohol finish is touched with banana.  Excellent
Driied fruit, sweetly malty, raisins... A very good belgian once again but doesn’t quite end up in the top tier.

This beer looks absolutely beautiful.  Dark brown in color with a very large, long lasting, foamy head.  Looks almost too good to drink.  Aroma is malty, sweet, and slightly alcoholic.  The taste is so complex.  So well-balanced with flavors of raisins, figs, caramel, slight chocolate and traces of alcohol.  The alcohol is well hidden, though.  Medium body, feels a little thick in the mouth.  Overall, a fantastic beer!

Pour a dark ruby brown in color with a nice two inches of head.  Smell is belgian candy sugars, some plum and some light yeast.  Taste is more of the plums and dark fruits.  Incredibly creamy and big on the mouthfeel.  A hint of spice in the taste at the end of each sip.  Very good beer.  Luxurious in the mouthfeel.  Great beer, but not as complex as the Rochefort 10, which is still my fav.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 Pours dark, deep red with a fizzy, active head. Smells like dark fruit. Tastes of plums, grapes, other dark fruits. Fizzy, malty mouthfeel with a biting alcoholic finish, below average to on my palate. Flavor gets better as it warms and it becomes easier to drink as you get used to the bite. Very complex beer.

Bottle: Dark red colour, with a nice creamy head. Aroma of grapes, fruits, flowers,caramel and some sournes in the end. Flavor has a nice maltymouth feeling, medium body, som alcy medium finish. Werry Nice!

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 Aroma smells of ripen fruits, yeast, and chocolate.  The taste is sweet, but not overbearing.  Very balanced with sweetness and roasted malts.  Goes down easy, but a little carbonated.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2008 ONE OF THE BEST BEERS IN THE WORLD AND  ITS SO COMPLEX.IT HAS A  SLIGHTLY FRUITY SMELL AND TASTE. I ALWAYS HAVE TO HAVE A 750ML BOTTLE IN MY HOUSE FOR RESERVE.

Bottle & tap on several occasions @ Café Gollem. Dark brown, beige head. Aroma of dark fruits, mouldy yeast (typical of St.Bernardus beers), chocolate. Taste is very sweet, almost cloying, but perfectly balanced by the dark fruits, roasted malts and dark chocolate flavours. Thick and creamy mouthfeel. Very good when bottled, superb from tap.
[Archive] Sweet syrupy aroma but not that much. Alcohol, chocolate, lots of carbonation and it’s quite heavy.

Pours dark brown with redish hue.  Rather large foamy tan head that doesn’t last real long.  Aroma of bread and alcohol.  Great palate.  Light carbanation.  Hints of spice and caramel.  Light alcohol burn to the finish.  Alchohol is hidden very well in this one.  Great beer.

Pours a dark brown, with a foamy cream head. Looks almost like coca-cola. Smells very malty. Nice. Flavor is....incredible. Lots of malty, nice hop bitterness too. Balance. Good and fruity too. Plum, figs, maybe some citrus. Smooth. Delicious.
Crushed with Dadbra.  One hell of a bouquet.  Looks great, complex and sexy as hell.  Definitely a top brew.

Poured a cloudy brownm color with decent sized head. I could detect a banana and vanilla scent. Flavor is much like it smells and leaves you with a alcohol burn and aftertaste. A good brew but not in the same league as the Rochefort Trappistes 10 that I had recently.

No 700, why not have something good Murky brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is complex, to say the least.  Nuts, fruit, alcohol, toasted malt, sweet malt, yeast, raison, toffee, sugar.  Taste is equally complex with sweet malt, sugar, banana, nuts, raison, alcohol, brown sugar, fruit, etc.  A little alcohol burn to go with the fruity/nutty finish.  Good stuff here.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2009 After some more beers, I find this one fine but something in its flavor becomes too medicinic for my taste.  I have decided to drop 1 point from Its flavor and aroma.
Old rating:
Great beer, Dark reddish color with tan head that diminish slowly, nice plum-raisin aroma with sweet fruity flavor where alcohol is hidden well. Great balance of sweetness and bitterness. Yet my favorite.

Aroma was fruity vanilla malts and alcohol.  The pour was nice hazy brown with a thick light tan head.  The head takes some time to settle down and leaves a nice thin layer on top until the end.  Flavor was a complex mixture of fruits, syrup, malts and hints of vanilla and alcohol.  Palate was incredible.  Carbonation from beginning to end that finished almost frothy.  Leaves my tongue tingling.  Not a big carbonation man myself, but it is well implemented here.

330mL bottle from an in person trade. I was excited to get to try this one. Pours a dark, murky brown with plenty of yeast sediment floating around, and a huge beige head. The aroma is very yeasty, not all that complex, just the usual dark fruity esters and a touch of booze, but still pretty nice. The flavour is sort of a mixed bag every sip I take. Sometimes more harsh than others, but generally gets better as it goes along.  Yeasty and boozy, but also some nice prune and date notes. Very smooth and silky feel to it, which I like. Very sweet and malty, but I wouldnt call it terribly complex, but thats not to say it isnt good. Gets much better as it warms, and the warming feeling from the alcohol isnt harsh at all, but very much evident. Im not really sure what else to say about it, its well done, but I guess it only really gains any major complexity with significant age. All in all a good one Im glad to have, and one worth trying.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2009 Re-rate 6/21/09: Pours dark dark hazy brown with two finger beige head. Aroma is bursting with ripe fruits such as plum, cherry, and apricot. Lots of sweetness in the aroma- brown sugar and molasses. Flavor is sweet with dark fruit notes quite prevalent. Malt character is robust and complex with fruity notes and lots of dark fruits: plum raisin and fig abound. Some alcohol in there as well, but not overwhelming. Palate is thick yet drinkable...robust but refreshing and crisp. Finish is dry. Quite the bold charactered brew.
Lovely aroma of chocolate, sweetness.  Dark coffee color.  Amazing enjoyable flavor with roasty maltiness, dark fruits, very complex.  One of my favorties!
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 Bottle. Pours a dark coke color, nice full tan head. Very complex, nice and enjoyable flavor; long-lasting finish.

I can’t believe it took me so long to try this beer.   Pours a dark hazy brown with thick white/light tan head.  Nice sweet aroma.  Good flavor, nice dark fruit.  It isn’t as good as the Westy 12...but since it is so readily available, it will have a place in my fridge.  Good stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 Pours dark hazy brown with a foamy off white head.
Aroma is fairly light. Plum and apple fruity tones. Dark roast 
Flavour is so so smooth!!
Roasty malt dominates in the early palate, plum and dark fruit tones, sweet in the finish.
Alc is assertive but not overpowering.
UPDATED: SEP 22, 2008 33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex brew, sweet, cloudy, good head, very good brew

Pours dark brown and very cloudy. Nice medium frothy head. Sweet smelling with alcohol present. reminds me of a confit of "frutos del bosque". Alcohol ever present but not overpowering. Sweet taste with molasses, some christmass spices. In short, the flavor is extremely complex. It will takea few more of these until I can get an accurate description. A beer to be enjoyed with strong cheese or by itself. Not the kinda stuff you want to drink all night at a bar, this is something you make time for and savor.

An excellent beer.  Probably the best-smelling one I’ve ever had.  The aroma fails to betray the fruitiness of the beer’s smooth taste.  Has an okay head, but not as thick as I’d like.  Again, it’s remarkably smooth and complex.  The bottom of the glass has a significantly more pronounced bite.  Fantastic beer.

Bottle. Pours dark, dark brown with hints of cola coloring around the edges.  The head is massive, off-white and lasts quite a while leaving good lacing.  All kinds of doughy stuff floating around in this one as well.

Big sweet and massively complex aromas.  There’s belgian yeast, sugar, plums, bubble gum, nuts...extremely pleasing to the nose.

Taste is just as complex as the nose with sweet malts, yeast, dark fruits and even a little chocolate.  The layers of flavors just keep coming and leave a wonderfully sweet aftertaste that lingers pleasantly on the tongue.

Mouthfeel is truly exceptional.  Perfect medium to full body with high carbonation that tickles the tongue with the myriad of flavors.  Creamy and delightful.

This is the beer that got me started on craft beers and so I’m always going to have a couple of these on hand.  One of my absolute favorites.
Looks and smells fantastic.  Nice, thick head and aromas of fruit and barley.  The flavor decent and is smooth in the begining but bites ya in the end.

Pours a dark brown color with an off white medium head that dissipates slowly. Lots of sediment, even for a bottle conditioned Quad. Full bodied. Amazing aroma of brown sugar, cinnamon, butter (diacetyl) and dust. Tastes sweet with a short burst of coffee like bitterness followed by taste of fruit, raisins and a thick bready finish of pumpernickel. Think of this as liquid bread - it’s very filling. I would suggest pairing this with some very sharp cheese. The more I taste the more I like. I will try it again and modify my rating in the near future.

bottle thanks to metzlers in denton, tx.  appearance very impressive with this one.  poured a rich amber/copper with an off-white head that lasted forever.  last the glass from top to bottom.  aroma was banana, spice, and fruit.  flavor was fruity with spice and alcohol was present.  carbonation was med-high.  this was good but not a session beer at all.  this was my first quadrupel.

1pt 9.4oz Btl. Nice dark brown pour with a perfect medium fluffy white head that lasted forever. Aroma is very aromatic, with lots of spices and lots of clove. Some banana and other fruits like figs or dates as well. Taste is wonderful and smooth with lots of spice and dark fruit, as well as a nice burn on the way down. Very, very good.

Dark brown with a light tan head that stays for the entire pour. Bitter taste, stronger aftertaste of alcohol than I care for (maybe it was an older bottle?) Not a bad brew, but definitely not a session beer.

Bottle--a gusher.  Dark muddy brown pour with smallish bubbly light tan head.  Aromas and tastes of bitter chocolate, figs, raisins, dates, plums.  Notes of coriander, clove, cinnamon, and nutmeg.  Great beer.  One of the best beers that’s relatively easy to find.

Thanks to kiefdog for sharing!  Dark brown, pour. Decent head without going away much through the beer. It was a little heavy on the sugar and alcohol, but that’s in comparison to a Westvleteren 12. A good solid brew, that if you can’t get the Westvleteren, makes a great substitute.
very impressed.  nice amber color with a large white/ tan head.  nice smooth beer without the strong alcohol taste.  Very happy to try this beer

Olyan mint ha ez lenne a sörök "Tokaija"!Sűrű,testes és édes,tele rafinált aromákkal.Nagyon összetett,egyszerre csak egyet és azt is nagyon lassan és figyelmesen!Bár ha kaptam volna többet belőle,biztos nem állom meg a tovább kóstolgatást!Minden újabb kortynál előjön egy újabb íz,zamat.Fantasztikus!
750 bottle purchased at vintage in Ballantyne.  Pours to dark body with an off white head.  Flavor is excellent with little hint of alcohol.  Top notch beer

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2009 .25L in trappist glass @ Brick Store. Surprisingly this only cost 6 bucks. Huge, frothy, brown head and a deep caramel color. I honestly wasnt expecting this to be so strong. Complex aromas and tastes, including sweet bread, spices and dark fruits. Left ornate lacing on my glass. Sweet with a creamy mouth feel, a good beer for sipping. Astringent finish, almost like drinking a fine wine. Ill have to try another one of these before making the final judgement.

Pours a fizzy cloudy dark ivory with a frothy light brown head. Has the aroma of dark fruits(cherry/plum/pumpkin), zing of spice, bread, and a hint of alcohol. The flavor is very balanced with the fruit coming through from beginning to end with a little bread, spice(cinnamon) and little alcohol showing though but almost completely hidden. Sweet, very smooth/creamy, and rich. This just my be my favorite Belgian style brew. I think this is better than its competitors like rochefort 10, 8, and struise pannepot. Awsome!

Bottle, Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. OOweee ! This is truly a classic. Hadn’t tried this in years, and have I been missing out ! Very dense dark brown with a lingering biege head. Corking aroma loaded with fruit, caramel and spice. Flavour is awesome...sweetish with lots of fruit, spice, vanilla and hop.
A real treat.
Love this beer.  Brown and cloudy, huge head.  Raisins, brown sugar, candied fruit, and bananas.  Syrupy and smooth finish.  One of the best I’ve ever tried.
750 bottle. Very nice dark reddish/brown color. Smelled kind of metalic on first smell, then turned to sweet malty.Slightly acidic but not too bad. Was expecting more, kind of let down.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Great intro to the Belgium family of beers. Very interesting aroma and creamy flavor with a hint of licorice. So far one of the best beers I’ve ever had!

Usually when I pay $10 per bottle for a beer, I expect to be let down.  This beer was great though.  They did a great job hiding the alcohol taste.  Head that wouldn’t quit, and flavor that you’d sell your soul for.  Definitely one of the best beers I’ve had.

Pours a dark cloudy brown with a thick, frothy eggshell colored head. The nose is complex and alluring, caramel malt, belgian yeast, and dark fruits in the aroma, with a touch of spice and candi sugar. The flavor of this beer is amazing. Nuts, honey, cloves, cinnamon and other spices, fruit and belgian yeast. The mouthfeel is dense and creamy, the finish is well-balanced with both the sweet malts and candi sugar shining through. Hides the alcohol very well. Overall, a pleasure to drink, one of the best beers I’ve ever had.
Bottle. Cloudy dark amber. Aroma of malt, yeast, candy and sweet fruit. Tastes of sweet fruit, cherries and almond. Slight dry finish makes it well balanced. Very nice and easy to find.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2016 Appearance: Cloudy, dark brown. Lots of thick, darkish head.
Aroma: Dark fruit and malt. Alcohol, metallic. Biscuits.
Taste: Quite alcoholic. Malty, some bitterness. Tongue-tingling.
Info: 330ml bottle, 10/6-2007, 17/300M

2016 re-rate (2.8->4.3):
Appearance: Dark brown, hint of red. Lots of light tan head. Lots of sediments, a bit too much to be honest.
Aroma: Malt, sweetness, some dark fruit. Raisins.
Taste: Malt, dark fruit, sweet, toasted. Hides alcohol well. Prunes. Hides alcohol very well.
Bought: Saveur-Biere.com, 330 ml, 2.80
Info: 27/2-2016, BB: 14/12-2018

On tap at Redlight and poured in a snifter. Deep amber pour with a thin white head. Big malty sweet, orange candy sugar aroma. Nice medium body. Malty sweet, candy sugar and a nice spiciness that make this such a beautifully tasting beer. Finishes very clean and hides its strength very well. This beer just blends everything together so well and is a real joy to drink.

750 ml bottle-Pours a hazy brown body with a huge head and a cork that popped out of the bottle and started overflowing. Aroma of belgian yeast, candy, and sweetness. Taste of belgian yeast, malt, caramel, sweetness, and some fruits. This full bodied brew is really smooth and drinkable. Nice job.

Bottled at El Irlandés, Valparaiso Pours a deep dark cloudy brown color with orange hues. Head is perfect, medium to big, cream colored. It lasts for long and leaves a film of 1 cm thick.
Aroma shows dense malty layers with pleasant alcoholic nuances. Spicy touches come when it warms a little. Hazelnuts, nougat, caramel, dark honey, palm syrup, brown sugar and tons of molasses. Cognac, clove, christmas cookies. I could keep listing all day. Amazing.
Flavor is sweet with nutty bitterness. Extremely intense, complex and layered tastes. Liquorish, whiskey, cognac, molasses, all kinds of nuts. Hints of belgian chocolate, dulce de leche and choclate covered orange peel. It finishes with orgasmic mousse texture and a touch of Kahlúa and Whiskey or Amarula Cream. Absolutely incredible.
Dense, thick, creamy mouthfeel. Warming alcoholic punch. Medium carbonation. Complex and overwhelming aftertaste that lasts for hours. This is definitely a world-class beer worthy of all the praise it gets.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2009 V - vibrant poofy head leaving lots of lace. dark dark brown color

A - strong aroma of fruits and spice, malt

T - dark fruits, spice, a tinge of alcohol, and a deep roastiness without being heavy.

P - well balanced with a tingling/bitter sour feeling.

On tap @ Yard-House Irvine. Pours dark brown, deep reddish amber with small white head.  Slight aroma of hops with powerful sense of spice and alcohol.  Flavor of spice, pepper and sweet plums.  Finishes with a slight ting of alcohol.  Very enjoyable!

On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Pours a medium to darker brown. Aromas of sweet & dried sticky dark fruit. Plums, raisins, figs etc. Medium to lighter bodied but lots of complexity. Some caramelization sweetness & spiciness. Alcohol gives a slight notice towards the end. Remarkably smooth for a beer of its magnitude. Enjoyed this with a Westy 8 & Westy 12

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2011 The bottle exploded upon opening leaving me with only one half of the beer! Other than that this was a great experience. The aroma is huge, sweet and malty with a complex dark fruit, a mixture of plums raisins and figs. The flavour is big and moreish, estery, more dark fruit with plums becoming more obvious, and little caramel. The alcohol is well restrained and gives the beer a pleasant warmth. Full rounded body with a gorgeous lively carbonation. I cant help comparing this to Rocherfort 10, my highest rated beer up until now, although I find Rocherfort has a more complex flavour, St. Bernadus wonderful aroma, coupled with its slightly bigger, tasty though perhaps less refined flavour makes this my new number one. Although I do think a side by side comparison is now called for.
Rerate, new scores, notes the same
My first quad. Pours dark brown with an off white head. Smells malty and fruity. No alcohol detected. Really great.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2009 Full hop, spice and malty profile. Sweet malt profile balanced by a hop profile.  Brown sugars balance the small hop profile. Raisins and dried fruits dominate this one. Pure complexity. SECOND ANALYSIS: Got one of these in the 12oz and its really dry. I like it, but not as sweet as it was before. Interesting.

I was really looking forward to this beer and it gracefully turned out even better than expected. Theres not much to criticize here, as it is strong in all categories. Sweet, perfumy aroma with a great complex flavor of maple, brown sugar, spoiled cream, wheat bread, all kinds of funky flavors end up in a soulful elixir. Booze is well hidden on the palate but hits you in the face, chest, breast, neck, and head areas moments thereafter. The remaining aspects of this beer are just too much for a novice like myself to describe at this point, but after all is said and done, its damn fuckin good. Easily in my top 5 thus far. Bravo, Saint Bernardus.

Pour was dark brown with a fizzy light tan head.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit, sweetness, and a lot of yeast.  Flavor was thick and real sweet with a strong floral character.  Alcohol was hidden pretty well.  Smooth brew.  Would probably buy again and let age for a while.
Bottle: Pours amber with a fairly thick head.  Aroma of yeast and fruits.  Flavor of fruits, malt and hops.  Very good.

I normally dont go for belguim style beers but maybe Ive been trying the wrong ones because this one was great.  Dark fruit and malty goodness, with an almost wine-like character.   solid mouthfeel with a hint of warming alcohol.  great beer.

scent is of fermented fruit and malts.  very dense beer with some sediment on the bottom of the glass.  taste is very smooth.  finish is smooth as well.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden as well.  I would purchase this again.

My first quad. And I picked a good one. I really didnt  know what to expect from this style. But I was instantly delighted by it. Poured a dark brown, with a light tan head. Sweet with ah int of dark fruit, and malty. Not hoppy at all.
Poured dark red with a bubble head , short lived.  Taste malty with a carmel falvour.

~Pours a dark reddish brown with nice sized brownish head. Some chunks floating in the beer.
~Aroma of fruits, mainly banana and fresh apples. Some yeast spiciness. Smells fresh.
~Sweet flavor. Fruits definitely present, some raisin and plums. Sugary caramel and alcohol. Somewhat salty.
~A nice feel on the tongue. Quick and crisp. Finish has a sweet bitterness to it.
~This is a good beer. Probably wont buy again. Its a little sweet for me to really enjoy. Im glad I got the opportunity to try this famous beer though.

nice looking overall but the head was not very good when you consider the body and carbonation of the beer. Nose and flavor match, conserves of blueberry and straberry rubarb pie. The beer did have a touch of refreshing bittering. Nice ballance leaving just a touch of the %10.5 in the back.  World class with deep roots.

Subtle raisin/fig/fruit scent. Deep, dark, opaque reddish-brown with a bubbly, off-white head that leaves some lacing, but not as much as I expected. Some carbonation, but it doesnt hit you too hard. Taste is malty, fruity and alcoholic with no bitterness. Subtle finish. Ive tasted many dubbels, and although its not my favourite style this one is quite good.

The beer pours an amber red thats so deep it is almost brown it has a good rocky head with large bubbles that settles slowly and leaves little lacing. The nose is light with a mix of caramel, some yeast, dark fruit and malts. The taste is rich; mixing sweet malts and dark fruit with alcohol and some bitterness. The beer is very tight in both flavor and palate making it rich but still balanced. A very good deep dark beer.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2009 33cl bottle from Total Wine (Tampa). Pours a dark brown to black with a one finger head that is retained throughout consumption. Aroma: malt, candy sugar, alcohol, molasses, spice. Tastes sweet, malty, and sugary with hints of maple syrup. Full-bodied ale with a sweet, lingering finish. We tasted this bottle with a 33cl bottle of Westvleteren 12. The St. Bernardus had a creamier mouthfeel and was somewhat lighter in color than the Westy 12. The Westvleteren 12, however, was slightly better balanced than the St. Bernardus with a fuller-bodied mouthfeel, less sugar, and well-hidden alcohol. Given the history between these two beers, it is no wonder they are very similar. Both are exceptional ales.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2008 Must let this beer warm up for all of the flavors and aromas to come out.

Aroma:Sweet dark fruits, sweet slight alcohol

Appearance:brown, cloudy

Flavor:Complex, fruity, plum

Palate:Full body,thick

Overall, this beer is a must have and complex flavors hide the alcohol well.

had this many times which for me says a lot for a beer, many i havent returned to. This pours a very dark murky brown color, the aroma smells very fruity, i get mostly figs when i give it a good sniff. The Flavor is not as potent as the aroma unfortunately but it is damn good, it has heavy carbonation which i think masks the alcohol well, very easy to drink this one down.
A dark amber brown pour with lots of sweet dark fruits.  Spectacular warming feel going down.  Awesome.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2009 Bottle:  One of my favorite beers of all time.  I had to revisit this one.  Pouring this beer is an experience in itself.  It has a dark brown color with a sweet alcohol aroma.  There are raisins and other dark fruits.  It is perfectly carbonated and feels amazing on the tongue.  Extremely gratifying to drink.  An excellent Abt/Quad.  An essential beer.

Bottle.  Pours a murky brown with a super thick tan head.  Ah, gorgeous.  Aroma of grapes, champagne, raisins, dark fruit.  Flavor of sweet dark fruits, Belgian yeast.  A well-crafted beer, extremely well-balanced.  The palate is superb - creamy, thick mouthfeel, almost as if you were drinking a milkshake.  This quad is hard to beat.

11.2 oz bottle, a gusher- head fades back to a thin film. Smells like fresh banana bread soaked in dark rum topped with toasted marshmallow cream- or maybe pineapple upside down cake covered in caramel. This beer is dessert- such a smooth mixture of fruity flavors and mild hoppiness- alcohol is not at all hot, quite masked in fact. Dangerous beer- top notch.

Bottle pours a rich, opaque, dark brown color with a tan head.  Nice thin sheet of lacing along the side of the glass.  Looks delicious as it sits in the glass.  Lots of yeast, dried fruits and roasted malts in the aroma.  Flavor is very complex,  initial sweetness of dried fruits, a hefty dose of yeast, lots of spices, and a slightly dry wine-like finish.  Alcohol is fairly noticeable, but not overpowering.  I really enjoyed this one!
Excellent beer that only takes one to get the night going.  Great flavor of fruits caramel and a hint of oaky chocolate.

really nice quad.  Thick head and body, the pour was a dark brown with sediment.  The aroma was a complex mix of dark fruits, malt, and caramel.  The flavor was full of many different things including fruit, malts, and banana.  Just an amazing complex beer that really hits the right spot. Amazing indeed.

Bottle. Pours deep amber-brown, cloudy with a large frothy head. The aroma for me is mainly of spices (cloves) and fruit, and the taste comes through in that order, with a lasting impression of fruit and a fairly heavy alcohol finish. Nice fall/winter evening beer.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2008 Bottle,  tastes of earth fruitcake with over ripe plum finish.  The balance is a little off, a little too much alcohol for the flavor. A decent head that does not last very long with little to no lacing.  Huge particles floating in the mix.  Dark reddish brown beer.  Moderately sweet flavor.  Soft carbonation that has a great palate feel.  This is an excellent beer but not the best value for the money.

11.2 fl oz, best buy? 12/07/12 pours a deep dark brown full of dark fruit and yeasty flavor... not my favorite but easy to sip on.. alcohol listed as 10% as opposed to 10.5%, A huge head formed when i poured this... not a bad beer, easy to drink and typical of the style.

When i poor my drink a strong "heavy" aroma off fruit and something i cant put my finger on (i mean that in a good way) while drinking it i taste the fruit that i initialy smelled with a strong feeling in the back off my mouth. a bit off a dry end-taste. This is most defo family off the other barley type beers (i mean rochforts 10 and westvleteren 12) and it scores high at my personal top 20

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2010 Pours very dark red with a thick, full head. Fruity aroma. Tastes of banana and dark fruit, very fruity. The alcohol really comes through on this one, which I think detracts from the taste a little bit. Good beer, very strong.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with full white head, with fizzy lacing on the glass.  The aroma is of dark fruits, caramel, bananas, vanilla, and spices.  The flavor is full of dark fruits, roasted malts, figs, spice, and an alcoholic touch at the finish.  Very well made beer.

11.2 oz bottle from a gift pack which included the official St. Bernardus chalice. Pours a solid mahoganey with a large fluffy off white head that leaves some impressive lace in its wake. Complex aroma with lots of hidden nuiances, banana, dark fruit, dough, alcohol, vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, some winey notes as well. Medium to slightly full bodied with average carbonation that finishes with a good amount of alcohol warming on the back the throat and only the slightest hint of dryness in your mouth. Flavor of rotting banana, vanilla extract, some dark fruit, red wine and sherry from the alcohol. As nice and enjoyable as this was the alcohol was still very up front and needs some time to mellow. Oh well I guess I should grab a case of the 750 ml bottles and drink one every six to twelve months till I find out what the perfect age for this quad is.

On tap @ stardust. Brown with a tan head, leaves nice lacing on the sides of the glass. Very complex. On the nose caramel, bananas, doughy yeasts, dark fruits, a hint of alcohol, vanilla, spiciness. Huge toasted malts, sweet, doughy, touch of alcohol mid-palate, dark fruits, dried figs, touch of spiciness. As it warms, it stays well-bodied. Smooth and drying at the end. Even at almost room-temperature alcohol doesnt dominate or become overbearing. Greatly enjoyed this.
Best beer in the world! Full flavor which gets more pronounced as the beer warms up.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 (Belgium) This was the winner at the last Knights of the Devonshire tasting. The color was a warm brown with a med tan head. The aroma was wonderful, spices, caramel, dark fruit, with  a fruity / vanilla / zesty taste. Great carbonation here !!! This brew was a delight, Do yourself a favor and get some .

Poured a nice nut brown with little to no head.

Smelled of caramel malts, fruits, and nuts.

Tasted of caramel malts, nuts, fig, and some underlying fruityness. Really a marvelous taste.

It was a little dry in the mouth, but otherwise splendid; great carbonation balance and everything.

Very drinkable, I want to have many many more of these.

Serving type: on-tap
Awesome...What is great about this beer is that it is available in most states.  Its good to drink when your not sipping your westy 12...
I had this beer in a pub in Tongeren (Tongers) Belgium one year ago, and then recently discovered a source locally in the States.  It was good.

Large bottle - popped the top and savored, the Devonshire Knights ruled this to be number one in our latest tasting!  Well rounded and very drinkable. Nice solid off white head, dark mellow amber.  A fruit and roasted character with light spice which blended so well with the alcohol.  Texture and taste were all there.  A show piece indeed!
330 ml bottle. nice brown amber colour.  BIG white/creme head.  strong complex taste, fruit and chocolat.

winner of last Devonshire tasting and my fav of the night. Bottle. Nice off brown color. smelled of dark fruit and spice. very warm mouth feel. Left me throat and stomach warm also. Left me wanting more. Another Belgian with a high ABV% but masked VERY well by the complexe flavors in this bottle. One of the Devonshire guys said this doesnt really taste like a beer and it is more wine like and I have to agree with that but it is a beer and it is amazing!
Very nice. Solid flavors all around. Pours light brown with a thick head. Flavors are very hearty and show they are well crafted as they go down uber smooth. Very fruity. Well positioned brew.

Awesome. Very dense and complex. Dark fruit flavor, mainly raisins. Some spices as well. Lightly sweet, but not too much so. Excellent drinkability for such a strong beer. Lightly carbonated and full bodied.

Poured a dark orange with an immediate scent of apples and raisins to me.  Alcohol pretty stong in the taste, along with a taste of plums, vanilla, anis.  Sort of heavy on the palate and very carbonated.
Descents Belgian beer, the more I drink them the more I like them, and this I an pretty good one.

Pours a very cloudy dark brown with a nice even tan head.  Aroma of yeast, peach,  and over ripe apples.  Alcohol is clearly present in the taste.  It is a complex fruit and yeast flavor with plenty of sugars and some spice.   Some hop is felt on the tongue more than tasted.  It mixes with the spice to provide a nice zest.  A beer to sip around a roaring fire with the one you love.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2009 Bottle, pours a dark brown color.  Wonderful aroma of prune, fig molasses and tropical fruit.  Taste very similar, this is so nice.  Strongest flavors are that of prune, fig, molasses and dark fruit.  High carbonation with a thick vinous feel.  Slightly dry.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2009 Smaller bottle. Pours a dark brown body with little head. The aroma is dark fruits - raisins. The taste is extremely drinkable considering the 10.5% abv. It had some notes of sweetness as well as the dark fruit.

Bottle 0.75 l. Bought Kvickly Hilleroed. Colour deep red-brown with very high soft beige head. Aroma sweet fruity - plums and cherries. Complex spicy taste - more liquorice/anis than fruit. Pleasant bitterness. Soft carbonation. Long lasting a bt dry aftertaste

dark honey brown with nice off-white, dirty head.  Not very impressive aroma (but I did serve it kind of cold which probably froze up some of the aromas).  Aromas of booze, wine, and port.  Flavors of vanilla, hickory, liquorice - very unique - grapes (wine/port), malt, whiskey.  Heavy, smooth and sticky on the palate (the alcohol leads to an ultimately dry finish).  Overall - great beer.

On tap at The Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, IL into Trappist glass.  (This was beer #2 from a night of enjoying real rarities on tap.  It took a Tyroler Schnitzel and lots of rye bread to get me back on track for the ride home!)
A raisiny, ruby-brown with a chunky, lacy white head.  Aroma is heavy on dark fruits like raisin, cherry, etc., plus a slight alcohol tingle and some nice balancing maltiness.  A wonderful aroma!  Flavor was a tart, sweet, rich fruity and malty joy.  Blew out whatwas left of my taste buds after drinking the De Dolle "Mad Bitch" earlier in the evening.  Alcohol was evident, but not so much as to make one think it was a 10.5% beast.  The alcohol evident was more of a reminder of the fermented goodness that was present.  Palate was thick but clean.  Wonderful flavors lingered.  In a way this almost reminded me of a Central or Eastern European cordial.  Overall, another great beer that I was lucky enough to try on tap.  Wow, Ill have this again, I suspect.  Just great.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2009 Pours with a foamy cream/tan head, very thick dark brown ale.  

Very rich, thick malty taste, almost meaty flavour with lots of raisens/figs/prunes and oak, grains, yeast, and spices, quite sweet and viscous. The alcohol is well hidden, an excellent slow drinking beer.

(Bottle 0.33l, BBE271212, at Poirotti on 2008-04-25) Dark amber colour. Medium a bit tan-coloured head. Fruity and malty nose. Full and bit acidic palate. Lots of malts in taste. Liquorice and chocolate flavours. Would improve when aged, now too young.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2009 Glass: Trappist
Purchased at: Circle Liquors Super Saver, Pennington, NJ and Canals Lawrenceville, NJ
Price: $4.25 or less
Size: 11.2 fl oz
ABV: 10%
Estimated Calories: 200 C

Aroma: Intensity: Strong
Balance: between Sweet and Sharp
Impression: very Nice

Malt Flavor: toasted Grains Bread Toast Nuts Caramel Toffee
Hops Flavor:Floral Jungle Spice
Other:Fruit and lots of it
Notes: This is beautifully aromatic - one of the finest aromas Ive ever had the pleasure to enjoy in a beer.

Appearance:
Color: brown
Clarity: Cloudy
Head Retention: Very, very good.
Notes: My original tasting was a gusher, but my subsequent tasting gave no such issue. An absolute standard for the type. Dark fully opaque body, with a long lasting, consistent bright white head.

Flavor:
Intensity: Middle
Balance: More sweet than bitter, but fairly well balanced.
Impression: Nice
Malt Flavor: Grain Bread Toast Nut Tea
Hops Flavor: Earth Herbal Citrus
Other: Fruit and lots of it
Notes:  The flavor is nice, and the fruity backdrop is a well balanced and delicious setting.

Palate:
Mouthfeel
Sensation: Warming
Body: Medium
Carbonation: Faint
Finish
Length: Long
Intensity: Medium
Balance: more Sweet
Notes: This is quite enjoyable as a standard of the Belgian Abbey Trappist style.

General Impression:
Craftmanship: Very, very good.
Freshness: I think that this second tasting was fairly fresh.
Personal Taste: Liked, quite abit.
Notes: A lesson  always enjoy a beer well within its intended tasting period, or suffer the consequences of enjoying at a later date.
originally posted at: <a href="http://beercritic.wordpress.com/2008/05

Pours dark alcoholy brown with hardly any head. Aroma of clean dark sugar, mild malt and a small amount of hops. Taste is smooth, bears no semblance to 10.50% and has notes of dark fruit, clean water and rich malt. This beer is a bit dry in the mouth, but full. Finish is very rich and flavors linger.
Bottle. Reminds me a lot of westvleteren with a complex character. Dark brown with a creamy lasting head. Sweetness from malts, yeast & dried fruits. Full body. Alcohol well hidden. Long end!

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2008 75 cl Bottle. Pours a hazy brown/red color. Raisans and som spicy yeast can be found in the aroma. Flavor is sweet and spicy with plenty of fruity notes and candi sugar. The finish is sweet with an alcohol burn.

rating #200 for me. 330ml bottle into a trappist glass. pours a cola colored brown with a one inch tan head. smells of dark fruits, candi sugar, and a bit of spicy yeast. deep rich flavor of dried fruits and yeast. finishes with some fruity esters, sour grapes, spice, and a bit of an alcohol burn. mouthfeel is smooth with some foamy character to it. absolutely wonderful stuff, and what a beer to hit a milestone with!

This one will knock your socks off. Rich and complex. Fruit and spice come through in the nose, heady mouthfeel too. A bit of an alcohol burn on the back end reminds you its 10 point. Overall, very good, though a bit frothier than I like.

Very tasty overall. The mouthfeel is not quite as impressive as Rochefort 10 but I enjoy the flavor a bit more.  Rich fruity flavors come out along with some light sugar.  The dark fruits are brilliantly complex.  A beer I will always come back to

[bottle] Pours a deep, caramelly brown with a huge, rocky off white head. Aroma is sweet with candi sugar, dark fruits, bready yeast. Flavor is sweet and spicy, there is some alcohol, raisins, and spices. Mouthfeel is rich, but highly carbonated.
Smells of spice and brown sugar. Tastes almost identical to its aroma. Slightly alcoholic on the backend, warming. Subtle tastes of dried fruits and spices. Superb.
UPDATED: MAY 14, 2008 Bottled.  Pours dark, aroma is caramel, raisins, syrupy taste.  Really quite delicious.

Draft at Bier Garden, Portsmouth.  Much darker than Id expected, deep, dark brown, with a thin top.  Thick and syrupy with a flavor profile that is so syrupy it almost makes me believe theres maple in it.  Chewy malt, almost raisiny.  Quite nice, as to be expected for a 100-score beer.  (#3451, 5/4/2008)

330ml bottle.  Pours a nice deep brown color with a large frothy, light brown head which sticks around for a good while.  Aroma is roasted malt, maybe a little bit of coffee/chocolate, and some fruits (pear?).  Flavor is better than the smell fruity and sweet.  It packs a decent punch, the finish reminds you that its a relatively high alcohol content.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2009 05/03/08 - Nose has malt roasts but stronger in sweet fruits and caramel.  Dark reddish brown beer, head gone rather quickly. Sweet flavor with fruits and malt. The alcohol is detectable in flavor and palate, which it boosts. Maybe a little too sweet to justify its glowing praise. 848415
11/22/09 - Rather shoddy looking brown body, floaties galore and a very weak thin head. Aroma is watery tea, nut, raisin, and wood. Flavor is similar, but the palate blasts with spice and overrides most of the profile, which then gets alcoholic with warmth. Too sugary and carbonated. A lot weaker than I previously thought, mainly a large mess. 7373714

750mL bottle. Poured reddish brown with a big frothy tan head. Aroma is fairly sweet, with overripe banana, yeast, caramel, toffee and salt. Huge malty backbone with lots of dark fruit. Flavor is nicely complimented by yeast, liquorice, cantaloupe, and warming alcohol. Big malty finish with warming alcohol. Alcohol overwhelms the palate a bit.

An excellent example of malts in action.  This beer pours a nice brown color with a massive tan head.  Smell is very much malt and fruit.  Reminded me of dark fruits, plums, raisins.  Smelled great.  A lot going on in the flavor too.  Some great malt sweetness and the fruit is still present.  Nice and smooth, very easy to drink.  Great beer.

A- Huge chunky oatmeal colored head that leaves a massive amount of lacing. Very dark brown in color, hard to see through.

S- Sweet apricot aromas folowed by orange mixed with a slight coffee and alcohol tinge in the nose.

T- Taste is very complex; coffee, sweet dark fruits, roasted malts.

M- Mouthfeel is fairly viscous but not very carbonated.

D- This is definitely a sipper. I cant see anyone saying its very drinkable but the flavor makes me want to come back to it every once in a while.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2009 Outstanding bouquet of pear, baby food, banana, and oats. Pours cloudy brown with a thick tan lasting head, good lacing. Tastes of candy, chocolate malt, and a little bit of raisins, dirty. Moss finish. Alcohol content deceptive. Great balance and complexity, sweet, tart, and earthy. Truly outstanding. Hard to find any faults with this one. Perhaps too sweet for some.

750ml bottle, enjoyed lightly chilled.  beauty of a pour - Dark brown, off white frothy head, plenty of particles getting knocked around by the lively carbonation. Strong spices, raisins, fruits, and alcohol apparent in the nose.  Taste is raisins, sweet malts, grapes, brown sugar.  Palate is probably the best aspect, ripe carbonation that turns to fluff in the mouth.  Ub3r. Nice alc %

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2009 Pours a deep ruby brown - nearly black - with a huge tan head. Aroma of sweet malts, raisins, apples, brown sugar and cloves. Flavor starts out big and just keeps getting bigger, sticking around for a good long while. Incredibly complex flavor - so much so that its tough to pick any single notes out of it. Sweet malts and raisins, bubble gum, cloves, molasses and a touch of black licorice at the very end. Mouthfeel is wonderful - it manages to leave the flavor in your mouth for a while without making it seem like it left a syrupy coat. This is an utterly fantastic beer - one I fall in love with more every time I try it.

1/3 l.  bottle.  Dark brown pour with a nearly white foamy head.  The aroma is brown sugar, raisins - very sweet - with a touch of alcohol.  The taste is more of the same, caramel and raisins and the alcohol supplies a good amount of warmth, just below the surface.  Rather enjoyable.

Nice frothy head and rich color. A little alcohol in the nose, yet pleasant aroma.
A little caramel on the palate. 
One of the best brews available locally. Great choice for good friends or special occasions.
Wonderful aroma. It pours a dark murky brown with a lot of particles. Big head if youre not careful. Taste is very good with a nice alcohol burn. Made for sipping.

Very, very dark carmel color if viewed in good light.  Beautiful creamy tan head.  Aroma of homemade sweet maple wheat bread.  Without eyes, it might be hard to tell it is a beer.  Flavor is well matched.  Smooth and soft, dark fruit and grain, well balanced with little alcohol flavor or aftertaste.  It also has a curiously bright highlight that makes this a very interesting and complex beer.  One to keep on hand for special occasions.
Great fruity nose.  Excellent color and slight tan head.  Dark esters dominate and nice malt sweetness.  Excellent trappist.

Bottle from Carringtons. Dark brown wth tan head and surprisingly little lace. Not as full as you might expect in the mouth. Aroma of fruit, spice, banana and some bubblegum. All present in the flavour along with bread, caramel and cherries wrapped in a big boozy hit. People rave about this, I find it reliable but its never blown me away.

750mL magnum.  Cork pops with much less explosion than some of the other Belgiums Ive had.  Pours a deep chestnut with a large, rocky head, much larger than I expected when it opened so calmly.  The aroma is very light and smooth with a sweet, fruity, yeasty character.  The taste starts sweet and fruity, like raisins or dates.  It quickly turns into a nice, malty mouthful with whiskey notes.  The alcohol comes through strong in the finish and leaves a dry aftertaste.  Very good.
Having tried both in the same day, the st. bernardus 12 does not compare to the westy 12 in my opinion.  But still very good.
Looked muddy, didnt smell that great - but what a great tasty mouthfull. Malty, grapes, carob nuts, herbs (sort of). Easy to find and a good beer, a winning combo.

One of the quintessential Belgian beers.  Pours from the 11.2oz bottle a nearly opaque deep maple brown color with a frothy, lacing dirty tan head.  One of a kind aroma that has a strong sweet, candy aroma mixed with some sour yeastiness, with fruity aromas like grape and plum.  Flavor is very similar with a strong sweet malt flavor that is a mix of hard candy and brown sugar.  Flavor has more grain than I had imagined with a bit of barnyard funk to round things out.  Medium mouthfeel with a lasting sweetness that hides the alcohol well.  This brew is a lesson in balance all while maintaining its complexity.

11.2 oz. bottle at Flat Rock Saloon.  Poured deep brown with fizzy off-white head.  Flavor is complex with dark fruits, chocolate, caramel, and spices all present.  Sweet and even a bit chewy.  Alcohol unnoticeable.  St. Bernardus monks are rad.
An infamous brown beer; with an intricate robust taste that packs a punch, the best high test beer Ive had.  Caution...a few of these and your standards are sure to drop.

Bottle. Dark brown witha cream-colored head. Lots of lace. Smells like figs and raisins. Alcohol is well covered by the malt and spices with a touch of fruit on the palate. Dry on the finish but not bad. Overall, a pleasant beer.

[Bottle, thanks Joebrew!] Pours deep reddish-brown with a light tan head. Aroma is quite sweet with yeast, banana, alcohol, a little raisin and maltiness (a little barley possibly?).   Taste is alcohol, vinous, a little chocolate and malt. Medium-thick mouthfeel, quite smooth. Good, fairly dry finish. It was still a very well done beer, but was a little hot on the alcohol and I wasnt blown away by it.

(bottle thanks Joebrew) Pours out a muddy brown with an off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, light raisin, cookie, toasty malt, alcohol, red wine, and yeast.  Taste is somewhat sweet with caramel, spices, light toasty malt, and a really long yeasty finish.  Mouthfeel is medium.  Not too bad of a beer, but the aroma was far more complex than the flavor itself.

Bringing heavenly nectar within reach. This is a quote from the back of the bottle. Indeed this wonderful ale is out of this world. It pours dark brown and is very opaque. The head is thick and creamy, with a tan color that leaves good lacing. The aroma is full of cherries, earthy yeast and dried fruits, as well as intoxicating liquor smell. The warming alcohol is bold and up front with roasted malts and some bitter hops. As you continue to sip the dark fruits come out. Black cherries, prune and dried apricot mingle with a caramel like sweetness on the on the tongue. The palate is thick and velvety smooth with a long finish and lively carbonation.
One of my favourits of dark beer. A strong one, but soft fullmouthy beer.Has a little fruity taste. Ends sweet.

Drink by 10-9-12: Pours a dark hazy brown/copper color with a tall off-white cream head. Strong aroma of caramel bananas and other fruits and spices. Initial taste is a little fruity and caramel flavored, with the strong spices taking over as you swallow. Belgian yeast doesnt surface until a little bit the finish. As it lingers the finish is a little dry and earthy. Body is extremely smooth.

Bottle, drink by 10-9-12. Pours dark brown with a creamy off-white head. Aroma is dark fruits and berries with a hint of alcohol.  Perfect amount of carbonation. Nice dark fruity flavor, prune is the most distinct. Hides the alcohol well. A bit of spice on the finish.  Very good beer.

Head descends but leaves a permanently thick lacing covering everything. Unfiltered dark brown look to it. Sugary and fruity smell to it. Really sweet, but not too much. Really fruity, but with enough room for the malts and hops. Alcohol is invisible. Thick palate. Aftertaste decidedly unoffensive. Somebody called this beer velvet. It is.

Bottles, taps, ... etc. A pantheon beer. Stands up to the Westvleteren 12 or any great quad/dark Belgian. Dark reddish brown pour, thick head; smooth texture and thick mouthfeel. A lot of depth in dark fruits, sweet breads (not sweetbreads!), and spices in the aroma; Christmas dark fruit cakes. Not sure who wouldnt like this, really.

I see why this beer is rated so highly! Pours a beautiful brownish red with THICK tan head. Aroma is of dark fruits and bread.  Taste is of dark fruit with some peppery notes.  There is alcohol in here?  This beer is like velvet on the tongue with a very crisp finish.  Would drink again and again!

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2008 Pours a dark brown with a light tan head.  Big aromas of dark fruits, brown sugar, and spices like clove and cinnamon.  Almost chewy heaviness in the mouthfeel.   Not as dry of mouth feel as the ABV would have you believe.  Good balance of sweetness and bitterness.  Artisan bread in a bottle.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2008 330ml bottle from importer Esprit. Dark reddish brown bubbly with thin creamy tan head. Excellent Belgian dry fruity berry, fruitcake yeast aroma. Bubbly berry, dry fruitcake taste, not too sweet as some Belgians are, but not too dry either. Clean berry after-taste. The blend hides the alcohol and only the warm feeling reminds you of it. No wonder the monk on the label has a big smile on his face. My favourite Belgian and the perfect winter beer. Hope to get another 24 soon.

330 ml bottle. Dark brown with a ruby red hue. Very tall off-white head that clings to the glass leaving a merengue-like formation. Very high carbonation level. Strong aromatic nose with plums and pepper. The alcohol is obvious. Crisp yeasty sensation at first, then rich münchenermalt flavours. Slightly spicy with black pepper and cinnamon. The carbonation is very lively. Excellent beer that is very soothing.
Pours a deeply hued ruby with a bit of foamy head. Aroma is of plum and is slightly floral. Flavor is raisin, prune and highly chewy malts. Alcohol is warming without becoming overbearing.

WOW......

I cannot believe that this is my first time having this. Its incredible. 

Pours with a nice one finger head in a deep brown color. Its huge flavor and hints of fig, raisin, malt and complexity. I find it VERY smooth for a 10.5%er.....

I think I have found a new regular for my rotations!!

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2010 Pours a brownish body, slightly hazy, with a huge foamy head that leaves a lot of lacing. Malty and sugary, slightly tart, ripe dark fruits, strong Belgian yeast, and a rush of alcohol. Good beer. For a beer with this much alcohol in it (10%) I found it to be quite smooth and easy to drink.  A relaxing sipper Quad.  Need to revisit and do a side by side with Rochefort one of these days.

Wow!  I had been breezing past this one in the store a few times, then looked it up here, and thought I should try it.  Poured a deep burgundy brown with thick rocky light tan lasting head (all the way thru the beer).  Great lacing.  Aroma of dark fruit, malt, and alcohol.  Body was a little thinner than nose lead in, but very nicely balanced bitterness and some dark malt, candi sugar, and light chocolate.  Yummy!

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2008 just like the others under their belt, the ABT 12 is again very dark for its style. delicious malt speaks of rasins perhaps...very dry. little aroma, amazing this is anywhere near 10%, much less beyond it. lacing is everlasting, sharp sizzling aftertaste reminds you why this is one of the best beers in the world even after its gone.
beautiful head, smoothest beer ive ever had. Tastes good, but not fantastic. However, overall it rocks my world.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2008 Tastes like a symphony enveloping my senses. Whispers of a great love from long ago. And yet, there is a grievous wrong to be made right. The gentleness of the initial alcohol cleanses the palate, leaving room for the dry sweet remains. The aroma captivates yet leaves deep desires for more. Finally, the flavor leaves nothing more but pure satisfaction.
Really great beer.  Hides its alcohol content very well and is a delicious beer readily available in the US.

Im really kicking myself in the butt for not buying this when I originally saw it...I was later able to sample it at Nikos Restaurant, Lebanon, PA...12oz bottle pours raisiny-brown with sudsy off-white head...scents of dark fruit, malts...flavor has the same, raisins, malt, brown sugar, with a tinge of alcohol...really really good...and on my last trip to my NJ beer store of choice, they were all out!  Ahh...next time.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2011 11.2 oz bottle (bought a 4-pack today for $11.99, great price!)  Poured dark brown with very big frothy head.  Smelled very sweet, with aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar and alcohol, and slight hops.  Taste was initially sweet, with very smooth and creamy mouthfeel, finishes dry.  Comparable to Rochefort, but I have to say I like it better!

Bottle. A very dark red almost brown beer with a good head. The aroma is of over ripe fruit and malt sweetness. The flavor is very powerful of a great malt blend with strong notes of caramel as well as hints of the alcohol, which also tickles the tongue. It ends with a good bitterness - all in all a really great flavor and therefore a really good beer.

Bottle...poured into a trappist glass with copious amounts of white foam. Nose was spicy, roasty and had a hint of hopiness. Fizzy and light in the mouthfeel...very drinkable. Caramel notes present among the spicy and floral character with a perfect amount of alcohol in the flavor. Great balance and just enough bitterness in the back of my palate.  Had a finish that made me feel cozy and content. Awesome ale.
Bottle. Pours deep brown with foamy tan head. Nice clear floral aroma with some spice. Complex roast taste. Great.

Pours a deep brown with a substantial tan foamy head.  Smells of alcohol, coffee beans and spices.  The alcohol really comes through in the taste, but doesnt overwhelm the beer.  There are some light fruit flavors, and a mild bitter end.  Carbonation is high and the body is very smooth.  A great tasting beer.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 Beautiful ale!
To quote a good friend "more beer per square inch than anything Ive ever tasted" Aroma is floral up front, yet includes strong notes of roasted malt, as well as faint scents of yeast & brown sugar. Looks gorgeous, massive head deep cloudy brown. Taste is very complex with flavors ranging from nuts & dry fruit to doughy yeasty flavors, with licorice & a none too overpowering sweetness . An excellent ale.

Muddy dark brown. Slightly sour nose with dates, dried apples, pears, and yeast. Livelier carbonation than the 8, more vinous and alcoholic too. A slight tang the 8 doesnt have. Flavors mellow when brought to room temperature, cold kills it. Great but I prefer the 8 overall.

Bottle 75 cl. Average size creamy, off-white head, excellent lacing, cloudy body, brown/ruby colour. Aroma of coffee, burnt malt, nutty. Yeasty aroma of earth and leaves. Heavy aroma of alcohol, and also nice aroma of raisin and plums. It has a full body, a creamy texture and lively carbonation. The flavor has a long duration, is heavy sweet and moderate bitter. Very nice beer.

750 ml. Red brown color, carbonation is high and sustains a 2 inch frothy head. Aroma first hits me with blue grape bubllegum then some kiwi notes, a touch of iron, vanilla and pepper. The blue grape comes to mind in the flavor as well, since it is sweet, a little acidic and it finishes on tannic and alcohol bitterness. Very fruiy indeed. Heavy carbonation gives it a medium body with a silky soft mouthfeel. While I usually prefer beers that hide their alcohol content, I find that for St. Bernardus 12, it makes it more hefty and impressive, not a lot of finesse, but it assumes it with ease.

Nice roasty malt aroma with some fruit sweetness.  Taste was right on the aroma with the dark malt and sugars. Very smooth and this is one of my favorites. I always try to have this around and a bottle is being aged to see how it does in a year or two.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2008 (Sample from August 25, 2006 Beer Club Meeting; On draft at Draught House on March 23, 2008) Served in St Bernardus snifter for full effect.  Poured a huge, creamy, frothy white head with incredibly excellent lacing.  A solidly dark, but clean beer with a ruby-red/brown color.  Had a hard time with the aroma after just drinking two other well-nosed Belgians.  Definitely caramel, but lightly fruity.  Body was medium, gently alcoholic with a somewhat bitter finish.  Great lasting flavor, lightly sweet.  Its alcohol content was very well masked for a 10%+, but peeked its head out just enough to make it fun.  Fun - yes, very fun to drink.
Den er for sprittet, det bryder jeg mig ikke om, men ellers er øllen jeg meget kompetent

Beau collet collant en vague avec de pauvre reflet rouge. Arome dalcool, pain, raisins, dates, caramel chocolat blanc, prune, soupcon de vanille, sucre brun et cerise. Vraiment cremeux en bouche, vraiment tres bien balancer. Ce qui ressortais en arome ressort également en bouche.
33cl bottle (bb 12-07-12) at Rover 2008-02-08. Dark reddish coulour, pours plenty of fizzy head. Berries and yeast in nose, sweet flavour with more berries and alcohol. Dry mouthfeel. I loved it!

750 ml bottle.  Pours a deep murkey brown with a 1-2 finger fizzy tan head. A great looking trappist beer.  Aroma is not too pungent but has a strong yeast and malt component with notes of alcohol, dried fruit and carmelized sugars.  Taste is much the same.  A very delicate and balanced blend of rich toasty and carmely malts, dried fruit notes, soft/doughy yet a little tart yeastiness and a touch of alcohol in the finish.  Malt and yeast really take over when you first sip followed by the fruits and the alcohol in the (dry) finish.  However, for 10% the alcohol is suprisingly faint.  A very drinkable, big belgian ale.  Mouthfeel is nice a frothy, feels like the murkey liquid it is.  Medium to heavy body. Carbonation is right on point. A great beer. Now lets see if I can get my hands on some Rochefort or some Westvleteren to compare.

Draught:  Aroma of ripe dark fruits, yeast, sweet malts, alcohol, and toffee.  Essentially, it smells like a Quad.  Poured dark brown in color with a small, off-white head that diminished over time.  Hazy.  Not sparkling.  Flavor was sweet.  Tastes of malts, smarties, alcohol, bubblegum, dark fruits, and chocolate.  Medium to full body.  Dry, tingly texture.  Average carbonation.  Dry, sweet finish.

750 ml shared w/ hop-smoker...Poured a Florida swamp-water brown w/ a great two finger fizzy tannish colored head. The nose was a powerful yeast, dough, candied fruits, sweet dark fruits. Tasted like candied figs, dates, dark caramel, a teensy bit of chocolate...Medium bodied, warming, slightly fizzy mouthfeel. Great sweet/dry finish. Best quad that Ive had...Terrific!

Courtesy of dpjuart. Pours a deep burgundy with a creamy, fluffy off-white head. Smells of dates, prunes, raisins, molasses and brown sugar. Phenomenal, almost indescribable taste. Bourbon oak flavors meld with sweet brown sugar on top, followed by alcohol heat, with a long, grainy, fruity, and sweet finish. One of the worlds more perfect Quads.

Bottle. Pours a reddish brown with a large frothy off white head. The aroma has hits of strae, molasses, chocolate smoke. Lots going on and all the better for it. The Taste is sweet to start but the bitterness comes out towards the end. Finishes with a nice bitterness and a creamy texture. This is a wonderful beer.
Brown color with a thick, creamy head. Aromas of raisins, brown sugar, and dates. Flavors are pecan, caramel, prunes, dates with a light yeastiness.

3/15/08 - Part of Christmas BeerClub Haul, shared with Naka and santoslhalper.  Pours beautiful flat brown with small, off-white head.  Nose is brown sugar and molasses with prunes, dates, figs and raisin.  Great brown sugar, caramel, and toffee taste with fruit (see above).  Alcohol warmth throughout and into finish and after.  Just great.  Gives Westy 12 a run, and is easier to get ahold of.
A flawless Belgian quad. Dark root beer body with heavy yeast sediment. Massive cream head.

This is a really good beer.  Nice foamy, cream colored head that lasts.  The mouthfeel is warm, smooth and rich.  A phenomenal beer.  If you cant find the Westvleteren, try this one.  You wont be sorry.
Better, cheaper and much easier to buy than Westvleteren 12! Very tastefull Belgian abbey ale.

Courtesy of Juart.  Pours a slightly translucent brown color with a creamy frothy off-white head.  Nose of a really fruity fig apple mixture and a wallop of alcohol and spice.  A good dose of rich caramel and toffee in the flavor.  Lots of layers to this beer.  Has the dark fig and raisin with some spice background and ginger candy.  A creamy oily body.  This is an outstanding beer.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2009 The initial aroma made me say "oooh" out loud. This beer is amazing, the flavor and aroma mixed with the pleasant after taste as well as how it makes your mouth feel is truly unique.
Bottle. Pours out dark with a medium head. Has a sweet yeast taste. Good beer.
Fabulous beer.  Nice yeasty, sweet aroma.  A dark brown pour with frothy, rocky head.  The flavor is incredibly complex with lots of malt, yeast, dark fruits.  Clean and complex.  Pour me another!

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2009 11.2 oz bottle.  Picked it up at Belmont Station in Portland.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a huge frothy head.  Hangs around for the duration and leaves a very nice lacing.  Aroma is earthy with nice fruit notes.  Flavor is incredible...very yeasty, with dark fruits and brown sugar.  Alcohol is detectable as you would expect from 10.5 abv, but no burn.  Fair amount of carbonation.  Overall very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2008 Bottle, 750. Gorgeously murky with a super creamy head. When cold, aroma that was very fruity but overly sweet, a bland, almost soda flavor, and a palate wrecked with way too much carbonation. However, upon warming, all awesomeness ensues. The nose was a blend of all that fruitiness along with notes of honey, toffee, coffee (these latter two being gentle but making their presence well known at the same time), and less sweet notes of dried fruits in the area of figs and dates. The flavor and palate were simply perfect. Everything came together in perfect harmony, the absurd carbonation had mellowed, the alcohol was absolutely non-existent, and I got the distinct sense that if any one flavor were added or subtracted the beer would be ruined. Well, not ruined, just its perfection would be ruined. Spectacular.
Not what I expected.  Pours a dark brown with a way big frothy head.  Not thick enough though.  Yeasty with dark fruits.  A metallic finish ruined it for me.

on tap at The Victory in SE Portland, OR pours a reddish brown with a frothy head. Smells sweet and like your typical Belgian tripel or, in this case quadruple, yeasty raisiny and even a hit of banana. It tastes pretty awesome, bit yeasty hit with plums and raisins. The mouth-feel is incredible, its thick almost syrupy, but that thickness is quickly cut through by the carbonation and the alcohol. This is truly a standout beer. I usually find quadruples completely overwhelming, but this was excellent.

Pours dark brown with a light brown head that disappears quickly. Aromas of yeast, raisins, plums, dark fruits. Flavors are the same. Flavor is sweet and fruity with a slight touch of alcohol. Meduim body, lively carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Very smooth. I love it! This is one of my favorite brews.

This beer is another dark belgian beer, but it has a lot of amber undertones.  The head is bubbly and frothy, but it fizzles out quickly.  The smell is sweet, similar to an apple cider.  It tastes a little bit like apples too, but more like the apples that you dont use for eating or making juice, more like the dryer apples that people have traditionally used for making booze.  The mouthfeel is a little thin and I can feel the heat from the alcohol.  I think this beer would pair well with something creamy and sweet--maybe apple pie a la mode.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2009 Pours a dark brown with a generous creamy head. Aromas of fermented apples and cola. Beautiful mouthfeel and warming sweet finish. Superb.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 Thanks to Dave for this beer. Pours a dark brown with a beige head that clumps together in lily pad like bits. The aroma is mostly yeasty and dark fruit. The taste is really rich, with a strong raisin and plum element. Also a sweet candy and roasted malt taste. A really creamy easy to drink body and also a good alcohol warmth round it out. A really good beer that could go well with any situation.

this beer is extremely dark brown with just a little white head. Smells a bit rainy and nutty with a bit of burnt caramel. The taste is very smooth, no hops and a sweet belgian candy syrup taste with a bit of raisin. Delicious, one of my favorites. on tap at jose pistolas Philadelphia
The commercial, description doesnt do justice, pours a dark bronze color with a slight tan head. Sweet fruit malt flavor with a spiced finish and no hint of 10% alcohol.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2012 Bottle with a brown cloudy pour with a nice thick tan head.  Aroma of caramel, apples and sugar.  Taste of apples, spices and caramel malt and very little alcohol despite its almost 11%.  Nice lacing, and a great finish.

Bottle pours a very dark brown color.  Head is a tan color and retention is very long.  Smells like yeast and alcohol.  Tastes like alcohol with some mild fruit flavors.  Very smooth on the palate which makes it easy to drink.

A dark caramel color with bubbly white head.  Very dark and vinous aroma.  The flavor is quite raisin-y with a definite presence of alcohol.  But the alcohol and fruity flavors are definitely balanced here.  The palate is fully of carbonation is pleasantly lively, but the mouthfeel just isnt quite thick enough to be what Id desire.  Good belgian though.

Pours a nice big frothy off white head. Aroma: Lemon juice acidity mixed w/ yeastiness. Some sweet malt mixed w/ fruit (strawberry/cherry). Taste: Raisins and plums, slightly acidic. Finish is very nice; very fruity; pretty dry. Mouthfeel is very nice; pretty silky, carbonation is still pretty lively though. Yeast is kinda spiciness, and slight horse blanket.

Pours a very nice dark reddish brown, with a beautiful off-white head that will not die. The aroma is pleasant, but very reserved - a bit fruity and malty with some subtle citrus notes. The flavor is a very complex mix of fruits and malt sweetness with a tongue tingling alcoholic bite. Although the alcohol is noticeable, it  is well balanced with the other flavors. The palate is very smooth. Overall a very nice brew, maybe the best Belgian Ive had.

Bottle. Poured deep copper brown with a creamy off-white head that slowly dissipated leaving a nice lace. Yeast, bread, caramel and dark fruit on the nose follow through in the mouth. Full bodied. Coats the mouth. Alchohol is detectable, but not overbearing. Nice.

Bottle at home.
Brown with a large light brown head, beautiful lacings. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, brown sugar, dark fruits, roasted). Flavor moderate/heavy sweet, light/moderate bitter, good balance. Full body.

Dark amber pour with a malty head. Nutty fruit aroma that comes at at you wonderfully. Flavors composed of cherry,figs and roasted malts. Just outstanding. Hides the high alcohol nicely. Dreamy creamy is all I can say. Slightly behind Rochefort, but not far.

To date, the best beer I have had. Fresh fruit aroma, raisin, caramel, fruit flavor. The finish is remarkably smooth for this extremely flavorful 10% abv. beer. Highly recommended and worth the price!

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2009  A nice nutty sugar-plum aroma with cinnamony Christmas spices, and hints of Belgian yeast, apples, and pears in the background. Lacing like a wedding dress. Mouthfeel medium to sticky. Flavor is slightly more subtle. Clean apple highlights the fruit basket, candy, caramel, and raisin. Alcohol is fairly present, but not enough to detract for me. Its a situation thing though. We had a tasting one night where we came off some goldens and triples into this and the alcohol bite was staggering. I would think aging this beer would make it an almost perfect beer. I would put the nose higher than any Trappist other than Orval, and an equal to the LaTrappe and Achel Quads. Classic.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 Had a mini quad tasting in April 07. Had this one first.

Picked up this 12 oz bottle at Champanes in Warren MI.

Appearance: Pours a nice and clear brown color with a 1 finger tan head. There is a little bit of lacing on my snifter.

Aroma: Starts with some nice malts and a slight alcohol burn. This is followed by dark fruits, figs, roasted malts, and slight cherry. The aroma on this was a little more pronounced than the Westy12 and less than the Rochefort 10. Very nice and inviting.

Flavor: The tastes are similar to the aroma, but not a noticable. Cherry and dark fruits from the start followed by warming alcohol and some spicy hops.

Palate: The dark fruit and malt flavors hang for a bit. This is pretty creamy too and also goes down too smooth for 10%. A 4 pack of this would be no problem, but splitting this bottle is nice too.

Overall. This finished behind the Rochefort 10 and Westy 12 in this tasting and slightly above the Chimay Blue. I aged a 750ml of this for a few years and it was incredible. It was probably all 5s or damn close if I rated it. The 750s are quite a bit better than the 12 oz bottles IMO. In other tastings, this finished ahead of the Rochefort 10, but not this time. Truely a world-class beer (as were the others). Definitely pick some up....and age a few.
33 cl. bottle , off white head with dark amber color, fruity nose, excellent body and flavor

One of the best beers Ive ever had the opportunity to taste.  Appearance is amber brown and cloudy.  Nose is sweet, airy and yeast.  Taste is dark fruit, plum, raisin and candied fruit.  Finishes sweet over alcohol.  Wonderful beer.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2008 St. Bernardus Abt 12 is a very enjoyable ale. A dark amber color with a good head and rich aroma or malt and sweet make this ale very inticing. A strong and smooth flavor with a great finish do not dissapoint.

Tasted 2008-02-23. 3 years old, 75cl bottle. Pours very lively, unclear, dark brown with beige head. Aroma: Dust/cellar (in a good way!), honney, very sweet without being cloying, freshly baked buns with butter, yeasty. Flavours: Fruity, very well balanced between the sweet and the bitter. Very round and complex. Love it!

E bravi i St. Bernardus che si riscattano dal loro nome di operai dellombra di St Sixtus con uno dei prodotti più notevoli che mi sia capitato di assaggiare nel genere così detto Quadrupel che poi è semplicemente una denominazione di comodo. E quindi sto comodo. E bello stare comodi quando si beve una birra del genere perché così ce la si gode bene peccato che dura poco. 100 a.C. Secondo tribunato della plebe di Appuleio Saturnino, che propone una nuova legge agraria, appoggiato dal pretore Caio Servilio Glaucia, anchegli di parte popolare. Fa approvare inoltre una clausola che obbliga i senatori a giiurare di osservare la legge; Quinto Cecilio Metello Numidico (campione della guerra giugurtina) preferisce lesilio. Ciò forse è allorigine di una serie di tumulti scoppiati durante le elezioni (sia Glaucia che Saturnino si erano ricandidati per lanno successivo, in modo da sviluppare il loro programma) che spingono il Senato a ricorrere al senatus consultum ultimum. Mario, in quanto console, si vede costretto a far uccidere i suoi protetti: la sua reputazione ne viene fortemente scossa e preferisce allontanarsi da Roma per qualche tempo, andando in missione diplomatica presso Mitridate. Viene domata la seconda rivolta servile in Sicilia.

Dark chocolate brown with a thick two finger reddish-brown head. Aroma is both earthy and sweet. Falvour is similar with saccarine sweetnes mixed with more mellow hints of chocolate, dark fruit and a very nutty finish. Alcohol is very well hidden, which was a surprise compared to similar brews (ie Rochefort 10). Extremely drinkable for such a weighty beer.

Its hard to know what to say about this beer,  superlatives dont do it justice.  Out of the bottle it pours a reddish brown, with complex aromatic notes.  The depth of taste is both bold and multivalent, with notes of several fruits and spices.  All told a top 5 tasting experience.

On Tap @ Bier Markt W.25th Street in Cleveland. I noted many of the same flavors that were described. The dry, somewhat malty finish is what prevents me from giving the beer a higher rating, as well as drinking more than two or three at a time.

The jolly prior smiles from his sky blue label as I pour this murky raisin colored marvel from its bottle. A small bubbled off white head vigorously aproaches the rim of the glass, quickly settling down soon after to a beautiful ring of froth. Small bits of yeast dance in the nectar as I wait for it to warm a bit. Aromas of alcohol and perfume rise from the glass. Raisins bathe in a mahogony booze. Hot alcohol fills the mouth like a fine scotch. Soon the alcohol dissipates leaving flavors of chocolate covered raisins and sweet dried cherries. The finish is somewhat dry leaving a hints of licorice on the palate and a wonderful warmiong feeling in my belly. Grade A to be sure.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2008 Poured a dark brown color with a huge off white head. The smell was very sweel to the nose. The high alcohol content it not noticable in the taste. Like other in the genre of beer dark fruits such as fig and raisins were present. A great beer deserving of such a high rating.

Bottle from Monument Liq in Concord.  This brew was similar to others of its genre, namely the Rochefort 10.  I found it to taste much like dried-dark fruits, especially cherries and raisins.  Its unfiltered look, innumerable head, rich flavor, and masterful palate pull in a top-10 tasting for me.  Excellent.  I could drink this one on a deserted isle.

what a beer.  color is hard to decipher as the bar is rather dark tonight.looks a dark amber, nice frothy acing.  aroma of berries and other fruits, caramel but not really, just sweet really.  perfect balance of malt and hops. thank you watou.
on tap @ the map room

0.33L bottle, quite small but dense head, brown colour with some deep red taints, a bit murky. Strong aroma of vanila with some earthy notes, carbonation is quite strong but not offensive, flavour is sweet and alcoholic with some mild coffe notes. Mouthfeel is pleasantly creamy and so is  the aftertaste which is mildly sweet.

Simply delicious! Thanks for the sample CollinTikianus! Poured a hazy orange with a skinny full lacing. Smelt of berries and bananas and went down and tasted in what words can that can not describe. I hope we meet again St. Bernardus!

Bottle from the downtown wine shop.  Poures a light tan frosty head and dark color.  Taste of fruit and cream.  Very suprised, the carbonation is very powerful with a awesome head.  I like this very much.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2008 abt 12 is a very fruity beer that is very smooth and well balanced. Holds a nice thick creamy head when srved at cellar temperature. I feel that drinking at cellar or a little above really brings out the characters in this beer
On tap at Maxs.  Brown with a red tint and a white head.  Fruity aroma with grapes.  Bitter alcohol taste.  Not much flavor.  Didnt like it.

On tap. Has a beautiful deep reddish brown colour. Very warm and malty on the nose - dried fruits, caramel and some herbs. Flavour is sweet and relatively complex and very malty. Dried fruits, spices (made me think of Rochefort) and powdered sugar. Ther finish is sweet. The alcohol is extremely well integrated! Really good!

Bottle, nice dark brown color. Good sized head. Smelled sweet, but just the right amount. No lacing on the glass. Taste is super smooth.  Raisons, sweet dates, spicy apple. Really good. I like the high alcohol content. Over all an awesome brew!
I tasted this beer before I got my account with ratebeer, so I cant really remember all the flavors.

Malty raisins, tropical dates, and spicy apples on the nose.  Deep brown, nice head.  Sour and sweet with a solid slow alcohol burn to cut through.  Excellent carbonation.   Rich, complex, an amazing beer.
