Great drinkability, even the girlfriend enjoyed it. One of my first Belgians, which could come back to haunt me since I doubt Ill like many as much as this.

Bottle at the Hopdevil... only Deus and  Gouden Carolus Cuvee van de Keizer left.   Poured an extremely dark red,  almost black colour. Vinuous and  sourish nose with raisins and alcohol. The taste has a beautiful smooth malt profile, a bit chocolatey, that merges perfectly with the warming alcohol finish... dark fruit, prunes dipped  in alcohol, somewhat spicey, herbal,  nutty, dry...  The aftertaste is a bit light and  gone quickly. Complex and  obviously a great beer but I expected more.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2007 Dark mahogany pour with reclusive ruby hues, very obviously bottle conditioned. A big off-white head forms, fading very slowly, never fully. Thick lacing clings to the glass the whole way down as the liquid is drained away. The aroma is very earthy and upon first nosing, its plain to see where this beers origins lie. Notes of wood grain, classic Belgian yeast, spices, soft hops, raisins, figs, dates, plums, lightly roasted malts, bitter chocolates, carob, apples and other mellow fruit scents. Very complex and always engaging. Caramel seems to compose an intricate backbone, structured in a way as to provide steady sweetness that doesnt interfere with the enjoyable process of dissecting subtle nuances. Alcohol is noticeable but never bothersome, though the flavor would score one point higher were it less noticeable. The flavor is a dynamic mosaic of fruits, yeast spiciness, chcocolates and roast. Candi sugar sweetness parades around the woody notes and seems to seep into the furthest recesses of the mouth. The sweetness level is medium-high, bitterness is mild, acidity low to mild. Carbonation throughout is medium-high and soft. Prickly spicing is a fine counterpart to sticky caramel notes. The finish is very sweet initially, then dries signifigantly and leaves fruit and sugar notes alone to battle for supremacy until the next sip. A very elegant palate, a sort of modest full body with plenty of excitement for all the senses. Light vinous and alcohol notes throughout. Very good. Although this doesnt share the complexity of some notable Abt beers, it stands strong and deserves regognition for consistency, great aroma and taste and a lively spirit. Seems serene and reserved while still knocking over the tastebuds like a wrecking ball of sweet flavors.

Cloudy mahogany pour with a solid off-white head.  Yeast, darker fruits, baked apples, sugar, and spice.  Subtle, vinuous flavor with figs, anise, and faint cocoa.  Some sweet yeast esters and a bit of bubble gum.  Very nice.

Flaske. Mudret med et forsvindende hoved. 2 år gammel flaske hvilket kan ses på bundfaldet, som er med til at få øllen til at ligne noget hentet fra årets Roskildefesival. Tilgengæld er resten helt i top. Fantastisk smag der minder en smule om portvin.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 I dont have a whole lot of experience with belgians, and perhaps they are not my favorite.  But, I was able to appreciate this for what it was.  Taste of yeasts, dark fruits.  Very carbonated, easy to drink.  Sweet.

The pour is perfect. Nice dark amber that is slightly murky. Forms a nice looking tan head that lingers and lingers. Smell is sweet, and malty.Flavor is full of caramel and a touch of hops. What a smooth drinker for 10%, or any % for that matter. Awesome brew.
very hoppy aroma, salty and sweet at the same time, with fruit and a nicely smooth texture... i prefer the westvleteren and rochefort 10 to this but its still good

This beer is bloody close to Westvleteren Abt 12. The only major difference is in sweetness. Of course it is much easier to buy and therefore perhaps has less mystery surrounding it. If you want a Wv12 but can find one this is the closest thing to it.

Really nice mahogny towards deep red look, with a bubbling brown head. Aroma is very rich, with different esters comming through. But the dominating aroma seems to be very nice sweet alchoholic port scent, that brings promise of something nice to come. The flavor is just soo smooth and delicious. Complex palate, and a very warming alchohol, thats only felt. The palate is quite exploding, which helps bring all the different aromas forth in the mouth. Very enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours amber, a little muddy, with a thick brownish head. Aroma is nice. though it doesnt stand out. Taste is fruity at first, then malty. Leaves a pleasant finish that doesnt last for very long. Very nice to drink.
From bottle at the pours dark amber color with a good amount of head.  Nice smooth flavor with a pleasant lingering aftertaste.

bottle w/ cork. pours deep red/brown. light tan/creamy white head. The smell is the best I have experienced thus far. Very drinkable. Tastes of various fruits, some caramel.  The aftertaste is amazing too: leaves the mouth tasting of grapes.  Overall, my favorite beer tasted thus far.
i love this one to death. a beer snob friend of mine told me to get it, the price tag was a bit for a pizza shop workin college boy who lives with his parents, but the beer was so darn good :D

Dark brown pour, thick off-white head.  Nice lace.  Smells of fruit, spice, yeast, and a hint of alcohol.  Tastes of fruit, sweet malt, and a bit of caramel.  Alcohol is muted for 10.5%.  Very light in body and flavor for this style.  Clean and dry finish.  Very good beer, but I was expecting a little more.

Bottle. A very nice beer and deserved top 50. Dark brown with huge long lasting pale brown head. Aroma of fruits and flowers also some dried fruits, but both in aroma and taste lighter than Westvletern and Rochefort. Taste raisins on bottle, very soft dried fruits.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2007 11.2 oz bottle... pours extremely well with a nice 1/2" head.  smells wonderful... i smell apricot and a touch of cinnamon.  spicy on the tip of the tongue and full of body on the sides.  Great aftertaste, slight caramel taste.  One of the best beers in the world.

Update :: recently tasted this on tap at the Brick Store Pub and was blown away at the difference in tap vs. bottle.  Out of the tap it is much creamier and a bit mellowed out.  Absolutely excellent.  Out of the bottle it is more alive with flavor and carbonation on the palate.

A surprisingly refreshing and excellent tasting beer. It has a very rich creamy texture and maintains a foamy top until the glass is empty. It is strong and yet sweet. The mildly bitter herbs are soothed by a deep caramel flavor. There is a light fruit and nut taste mixed in to round it off. The first impression is wow! It only gets better from there. The flavor further builds and evolves. It lingers for a pleasurably long long time. A great nightcap to bring sweet dreams to anyone who appreciates a superior trappist.
No this is a good quadrupel/abt.  If only I knew what ABT stood for.  Does anyone know?  Let me know.  Dark brown/black, malty flavor, delicious!

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2007 Dark brown to almost black in appearance.  The head is slightly off-white with some wonderful lacing thrown in.  The flavor is slightly malty but lingers wonderfully, changing as it dances across the tongue.  This is a fabulous beer.

This is a great sipping beer. It pours a rich dark coffee color with a light head that doesnt seem to go away. It smells malty and sweet with a hint of fruit. The beer is very smooth in the mouth, but has a rich texture to it. It is a malty sweet flavor, but has a slightly sour or acidic taste somewhere in the background. You can definitely taste the hints of fruit. A very complex beer that is worth a try.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 750 mL cork bottle conditioned.  Pours dary ruby with big foamy head.  Flowery and yeasty on the nose.  Full bodied... there is a lot going on in this beer.  Figs and raisins are evident and it graduates into a carmel/toffee sweetness, roasted sugars?  There is a bit of medicinal warmness from the high Abv.  A lot of depth and a good entry.  The monk on the bottle certainly has something to smile about
Pours a rich mahogony color with a bubbly tan head. Smells of fruit and yeast. Tastes extrelmy yeasty with a little bit of hops. Not very smooth, and has a very acidic mouthfeel. Not that great.

Bottle pour at Pier 32.  Poured a beautiful, cloudy dark brown color with a sizable tan head.  Aroma was of raisins, plums, malt, figs, and wood.  Very smooth on the tongue.  Tasted just like it smelled, with some candied sugary sweetness to round it out.  Nice alcohol finish to it.  One of my faves.

Pours a deep reddish brown into the glass with a nice off white head that has some lasting power.  The aroma is very nice and has what I might call a banana runt aroma.  The taste is big and deep with a sharp dry finish.  The alcohol is pretty well hidden but this beer is definitely a sipper.  This beer goes in big and coats the mouth with a really excellent flavor.  Cheers St. Bernardus!

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy mahogany with a dense tan head.  Figs and plum in the nose with a hint of alcohol.  Wildly complex body with fruit and spice at the front.  Highly carbonated sharp mouth with a slight alcohol burn at the finish.  Wonderful.

Pours a delicious looking hazy dark brown with a medium layer of froathy creamy looking offwhite head...a little wisp of dark yeast sediment too that almost gives it a cappuccino look on top.  Aroma is perfect balance of sweet and spices, not too powerful, rather subdued yet all encompasing.  smells of dates, burbon, earth, and a lot more, just so complex and beautiful.  Mouthfeel is medium, slight abrasive finish.  flavor is alcohol, berries, malt, pine, and figs.  overall, deliicous.

Second taste, first rating 6/15/07.  Draft at Eola Wine Company in Winter Park, FL.  Lucked out and got a massive double pour for $7!  Very dark brownish cola color with a medium off-white head and excellent lacing.  Aroma is rich dark fruit.  Flavor is excellent....cherries, figs, raisons, dark fruit.  Nice body with a very smooth finish.  Alcohol comes through about 30 seconds into the finish.  Outstanding beer!
Dark color, thick head that lingers and leaves a lot of lacing.  Sweet flavor - cherry, fig, raisin - but not too sweet.  High ABV more noticeable as the beer slowly warms.

bottled- very dark and malty flavor. with accents of fruit and raisins. the head was a thick light light brown color. by far the best mouth feel and rich tasting beer that i have experienced. will enjoy again soon

pours deep brown with a rich, creamy thick offwhite head with a few brown flecks.  fruit and malts dominate the nose. tastes include malt, rasins, dates maybe, and many others i cannot describe. nice full bodied mouthfeel and smooth all the way down. this is the best beer i have had the pleasure of drinking up to this point.
Bottle - Probably one of the best beers I have had to date.  Was tasting with others that I had heard more hype and this blew them away.  Great color and complex taste start to finish.

Wow. This is my first beer like this, i dont evn know how to describe the experience.  I dont even feel ready or experienced enough to describe.  The aroma is of alcohol, a light berry, and nuts.  The taste is so complex its like that gum in Willy Wonka with a 3 course meal, it changes continually and each sip i find something else.  The taste is slightly alcoholic with pine, nuts, figs, yeast, malt, berry, and pretty much every other flavor imagineable.  Truly a ride with a long aftertase .  The appearance is also quite beautiful with the hazy brown with speks of what reminds me of little seeds.  Well rounded, exciting.

Pours a deep reddish-brown with garnet highlights and a fluffy, beige head. Quite pretty. The initial aroma was a bit musty and horsey but quickly faded to a fruit medley of  apples, grapes, prunes and pears. The fruit cake notes that many detect in this beer are present, but I felt the overall aroma was "lighter" than that descriptor. The mouthfeel is medium-full bodied, creamy, sticky-sweet and lightly effervescent with a hint of alcohol at the end. Pears, apples and plums front a warm alcohol finish. This is a great beer and one that I wouldnt hesitate to recommend.
Awsome. Pours a dark brown with a white, fluffy, grwing head. Tons of fruit with stong rasins and figs. Sweet. A syrup like feel on the tounge with a strong finish.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2009 WOW, what a beer! 330ml bottle poured into a tulip.  It poured a dark chestnut color completely opaque and very effervescent.  The aroma was very complex of fruitcake and sweet malt.  This was my first Abbey Ale and from the color I expected a Porter or a Stout.  Boy was I wrong, the flavor is much lighter.  The flavor is somewhat nutty with some dark fruits.  Its mildly hoppy with a sweet, creamy, malty taste.  It is very smooth almost velvety in my mouth.  It reminds me a great deal of Champagne What a treat this one was!

330 mL bottle.  Hazy brown with creamy white head.  Aroma of raisin, dates, and yeast.  Velvety slightly bright palate.  Initial taste sweet and malty transitioning to a raisin bread taste and finishing slightly bitter with an alcoholic warmth.

330ml bottle.  Rich nutty and caramel aroma.  Pours with a dark copper/brown hue and a good sized off white head.  Well laced.  Rich, fruity and nutty flavour.  The finish is bitter and the beer leaves a warming sensation.

My review: wonderful fruity, chocolate aroma. Pours a dark opaque brown with an off-white head with good retention and some lace. Flavour of sweet milk chocolate with indiscernably complex fruit flavours. Minimal hops, nice fruity aftertaste, wonderful malt taste. Thick, creamy body. Astoundingly good beer

My wifes review (beer-hater): Pours a swampy sewery brown, which reflects the flavour. Sharp cockroachy aftertaste. I spat it out! [ed: truly the sign of a good beer!]

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 12 oz bottle. A classic beer. Pours dark brown, with a finger width of light fluffy beige head. Aroma is bountiful. Raisins, caramel, molasses, apples...you name it. This is the kind of beer that you can come back and smell every 10 minutes and get something unique and beautiful each time around. Flavor is exceptional, too: sweet candies, brown sugar, various spices (cinnamon? ginger? paprika??), ripe apples, raisins, pears...you name it. Complex. Very warming and very easy to drink. Its remarkable to think that a beer this good and this special is so easily accessible as well.
Very nice dark beer with a hint of sweet malt flavor. One of my favorite beers of all time by far.
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2007 Plenty of long lasting head and carbination in this brown colored ale.  Very bold with a smooth nutty finish. Very Easy to drink this, alcohol is concealed well
Bottle pictured, dark brown, fluffy lasting head, malty aroma, fruits and moderate alcohol presence at the end.  Complex and balanced flavor.  The best non-trappist beer for the trappist-lover.
Great beer.  Colour was brown/amber, but a bit cloudy.  Aroma was malty.  Head was full and tasty.  Taste was extraordinary.

Maltyness in the aroma (alergies so I cant smell much). Dark brown/red with big tan rootbeer head. Wow, that was complex. I cant name half the shit I tasted there. Some reason I tasted sweetness on the back of my tongue. It was bittersweet, slightly icecreamish (?). Ill stop before I embarrass myself further. It was alittle sweet for me but the rush of flavors more than made up for it. Thick heavy mouth feel.
Clean pour and smooth delivery to the palate.  Very impressed with the boldness of the flavor.

Tasted during blind quad tasing 07 with Holdenn and Drewbeerme.  Poured dark and murky.  Aroma was toasted malt, raisin, some alc.  Flavor is is pretty heavy sweet all the way through, with some of that alc that was in the nose in the finish.  The only problem is that I really thought it was too thin and watery for my liking moderate alc burn.

carbonation must have been intense, pulling the cork gave loud pop even after standing still for at least a day. pouring revealed extermly dark red, maybe maroon. the foam was crazy. mountains no matter how slow and even i poured. not that it was bad being as it was entertaining in how creamy and thick it was. the aroma was sweet with spice and maybe some fruit. the flavor was so complex i dont know how to explain it. not as sweet as it smelled rather some kind of spices and herbs that i couldnt name. maybe liquorice.  the complex taste of fruit and spice hides the 10% alcohol completly. i fantastic beer.

Bottle as pictured. Screenprinted label states "10% alc/vol" twice, and also describes the beer as a "classic dubbel." High carbonation... the cork levitates into my hand with hardly any prompting. Pours murky smoldering red, nearly opaque. The friggin huge ecru head resembles the jello blob in Sleeper. Rather tame aromas of anise, bubblegum, and faint spice. Flavor echos the nose- more spice with some cherry, metallic, and herbal notes. A combination of hoisin sauce and pomegranate juice comes to mind. Very short on fruit. Flash-bang fizzy palate. Dry, tingly finish. As the beer warms and carbonation subsides, flavors skew even more toward peppery and licoricey. The muddy bitterness of unsweetened chocolate competes with an alcoholic burn in the aftertaste. Just an okay beer... I thought it was pretty bland and timid overall.
Robe brune foncée voilée surmontée dune mousse beige épaisse qui persiste. Arômes de levures et de liège. Saveurs de fruits rouges, de caramel, de torréfié, de liège et de levures. À regouter...
very nice in the style. complex...smooth and creamy, yet thin and just a bit foamy. bready with rindfruits of plum raisin and licorice. genuine and pure malt character. real cherry hint.

On tap.  Pour is a rish dark brown.  Flavor of toffee and chocolate covered raisins, with a touch of caramel emerging as the beer breathes.  Nice lingering palate, nice floral element which blooms in the aftertone.  Beautifully well balanced.

Grainy brown colour with an off-white head. Spicey-sweet aroma dominated by yeast and dried fruit with slight aroma of alcohol. Taste desciption i would say very much like the aroma.  I enjoyed it, especially because of the 10.5% didnt hurt the flavor IMO.

This is by far my favorite Belgian style ale. Opaque, very deep reddish brown color, with a lasting, creamy head. The first taste revealed that it was not as sweet as I was expecting nor was the taste very high in alcohol either.

bottle from Le Bon in Miami Beach - dark brown pretty thick head - as someone said earlier the finish is what draws people in to this beer and I couldnt agree more - what a smoothie - excelent - im sure the atmosphere I drank it in helped as well.  Man I cant get enough from this brewery

I may have drank a bit of heaven. Deep dark brown beer with a tan head that never fully leaves the beer. Aroma is light, but fruity. Flavors of raisons and spices, nothing overpowers in this beer including the alcohol. The palate is silky smooth, with no alcohol burn.
Sweet fruity aroma..Dark brown with average tan head.  Full body palate and very smooth masking the high alcohol content well.  Fruity raisin flavor.  Excellent beer.
Bottle. Dark brown with lots of head.  Very sweet aroma.  Alcohol is quite hidden.  Maybe a little too sweet but an exceptional brew.

Bottle @ pub. Pours a dark ruby with thick head. Yeasty aroma of plum. Fresh and creamy, fruity flavours of dark berry with a very sweet finish of plum/raisins/sherry with prominent alcohol. Maybe too far a bit on the sweet side.

It is tough to say something original about a beer that has sooooo many ratings.  I was astonished how big the white head and how difficult it was to place the aroma.  The flavor is big, but not unexpected considering the alcohol content.  However I am certain that It is the finish that draws people to this beer.  The taste in the mouth after drinking is quite astonishing.  Remarkable for such a strong beer.  I am not convinced this beer is 4+, but it is absolutely 100% worth-trying.  Cheers
Brown Sugar color and light off-white head.  Very sweet aroma, slightly carbonated with a very smooth finish.  I truely enjoyed this beer.

750ml Bottle.  Pour is brownish amber with a medium sized off white head.  Aroma is fruity, yeasty and a bit of earthiness.  Taste is very layered with several different tastes coming through.  I get the sweet fruit, bright yeast, big malt and at the end some hot alcohol.  The after taste has some banana and spice as well.  At different points of warming, the flavors changed orders further leading to the complexity.  Overall, great stuff.

Bottle, 750 ml. Pours dark amber/ruby color. Huge long lasting tan colored head. Pungent aroma of spice, malt, toffee, bubblegum. Full bodied, highly carbed and with huge flavor; very complex: spicy, cloves, banana, raisins notes of rum; very warming and relaxing.

First bottle consumed at the Académie de la Bière here in Paris, which Ill review as well to help any fellow ex-pats looking for quality beer and eatins here in Paris.
As for the substance itself... confronted with a powerfully large beverage menu with some fairly incredible inebriantations to select from, I opted for this stalwart intoxicant.. in small part because I had heard satisfactory things, in greater part because the wry old smiley man on the vessel itself looks as if hes an elderly pederast, attempting to entice an innocent wide eyed little boy into his parlor.. and this makes me giggle (with alarm!).
If i were that little boy, I may well have skipped (or sauntered, depending on a variety of factors) right into that parlor, provided he handed me this beer first. Extremely complex and yet indefatigably smooth, deep and dark, almost like a river containing deep and dark liquid, if this river were made of beer resembling St. Bernardus Abt 12. A slight sour/bitter bite at the end, yet there is a sweet aftertaste as well, combined with a hint of roasty and toasty - ness.. so the aftertaste ends up being simultaneously bitter and sweet, and it seems to work advantageously. The ABV % was extremely well incorporated.
Most importantly, however, was the domineering nature of the ghosty quality of this beer.. a trait so rare that I cant even begin to describe it. Ive tried, on numerous occasions.. though language itself has proved woefully inadequate for the task. I have developed a hand signal that, in part, helps paint a mental picture of the quality of Ghostiness.. and I will leave you with this, which you will keep between yourself and myself and NOT DIVULGE, for any reason or price, even if your life is threatened.. by reading the previous sentence, you are now bound to this agreement. It is as follows:

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with hints of red-orange. Fantastic lacing from a slightly off white thin head. Nose is bananas, citrus, cherries, and some strong general sweetness. Flavor is much of the same, but more pronounced. The alcohol makes itself known but not overbearingly so. The palate is smooth and enjoyable throughout.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2015 thin black/brown, slightly lamvbic sour high maly nose, ruch spirity malt, touch of sprit like evaporation, tinge of sour in the malt  Tk 2 Very malty quite sweet nicly balanced... at endof a 10 top 10 night .3->3.8

Bottle at home ... with 4 vintages of Westvletern .. bbf 2009 ... dark copper .. thin tan lacing ... soft toffee fruit ... light blackcurrant roast nose ... soft dull toffee fruit ... soft malts .. soft toffee fruit ... 3.7
Dark brown with a thin beige head.  Starts with fruit and malt.  Finishes with bitter carmel and alcohol.  AHH, I love the quadrupel.

One of my favorite beers. I love its dark, complex and nutty flavor.
A beer can´t get much better than this.

Excellent Abt/Quad.  It is as smooth as silk with a nice licorice finish.  The malt overpowers the hops with this quad, but its complexity forgives the slight imbalance with a masterful blend of dark fruit to make a bold flavorful beer.

Now this is what were talking about!! Pours to a dark orange brown color with a nice off-white head that lingers for the entire glass, and leaves very good lacing. Aroama is a bold mixture of dark fruit (plums, grapes, raisins) and malt, with the scent of alcohol creeping in as it warms. Flavor is predominantly these fruits, with a touch of malty sweetness, offset nicely by just enough alcohol. All of this leads to a long, smooth warm finish.

I purposely took about 45 minutes to drink beer, and must say that this beer was as good, if not better, as it warmed to room temperature as it was early on.

A most excellent beer!!!

12oz bottle. Here it is, the crown jewel of my 100th rating get together. Imp Stouts may be my favorite style, but I was anticipating this one the most. Ive said it time and again, that cheery fat monk wouldnt lead me to a bad beer. Pour is lovely - a dark plum colored body with a fizzy, lasting white head. Resolves to a swirly ring that stays with you the entire beer. Excellent lacing. Aromas of dark fruits, yeast, cherries, figs, and some spice. Flavor is the same with some breadiness and plum notes as well. Finish is long and mesmerizing. Not boozy, hides the 10.5% masterfully. 

I never thought I would say it, but when you take money into account, this is better than Westy 12. A brewing master class.

Trappist glass.  Dark brown with slight red tinge and thick/rich head.  Fruity/yeasty aroma.  Malt dominates upon tasting.  Sweet caramel, raisin and prune.  Alcohol fizz at the end.  But otherwise a thick, soft, and smooth palate.

Dark brown brew under a huge beige persistent lacing head. Very carbonated and full bodied. Alchol is the dominant note, but theres a lot of fruity (pears, apples, berries), nutty and obv tons of dark malt sensations (honey, a slight toasted note). As it warms in my trapp glass i can perceive a light suffering yeast note and a vinous hint, but i bet my sample suffered a little on shelf. The bitterness is well hidden but i guess theres a lot to get the good balance of this wintry brew.

Pours a dark brown with a big, fluffy, well retained light tan head.  Very bubbly.  Lovely smell of dark fruit, dark malts, cinnamon, and berries.  Really pleasant.  This is a wonderfully done quad.  Perfectly balanced, and quite easy drinking for a big beer.  Big dark fruity taste, but the finish is all sweet cinnamon, which just went so well together.  No bitterness whatsoever, just all big flavor.  Just a great brew all around.  I dont drink this brew enough.

Bottled 33cl at Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty and fruity. Flavor is very comlex. Notes of caramel, dry fruits. Notes of alcohol and licorice. Well balanced.

Beer sampled at Cellars Wine & Spirits Friday evening beer tasting. Pours a cherry cola caramel with a thick head and nice lacing. Lots of aroma such as dark cherries, smoky toffee, chocolate, raisins and a little yeast. Taste is very soft and smooth. A bit high on the alcohol.

Nice beer, if you like belians. Not my first choice of beers, but when in the mood, is usually among the top three belgians I would choose. Good flavor, smooth and easy to drink. Too easy, with the high alcohol content, you can get in trouble.
Not much for repetition. If you ever get the chance, its worth a taste.

11.2 oz bottle from Whole Foods in Hillcrest. I poured this one to fast and gave me a huge head. After that dissapated I was left with a nice greyish white head. Good lacing left on the glass after my first swallow. Tastes of raisin, sour grape, and mollasses. The alcohol is well hidden and I enjoyed this.
What a tasty treat.  Not up with the Trappists ... but if you like that style, youll like this one.

On draft at Isaac Newtons in Newtown, PA. I was surprised to find this one on tap, poured into a Chimay glass. Deep brown with garnet red hues. Little to no head, just a perfect white ring encircling this beer. Aroma of dried fruits, molasses, plums, and malts. Flavor was a masterful blend of malts, mild spice, dark fruit, toffee, molasses and a mild hop presence. What a great blend of flavors to entice the taste buds. The alcohol was barely noticeable. Very delicious and paired well with my London broil. Excellent brew.

Bottle. Ive had this beer on tap in the past but I waited till I tried it out of the big bottle before I rated it. After pouring two glasses I did notice sharper aromas from the second pour due to, I assumed, the sediments from the bottom. Smells of molasses, light coffee, milk chocolate, herbs and perfume, doughy yeast, and raisin, dates, brown sugar and a little alcohol. Head was rocky, white, fully lasting and had excellent lacing. Color was a hazy brown. Flavor was moderately sweet, lightly acidic and finished lightly bitter. On the palate it was a chewy, medium to full, creamy with lively carbonation. There is not a thing offensive about this beer and Id say the taste is just about perfect. A bit better from a bottle than a tap. More please.

750 ml bottle.  Cloudy brown with a red hue, big frothy head and high carbonation.  Sweet fruity aroma with dark fruit flavors and rich malty taste.  Nice long finish and literally no alochol burning sensational.  Considering its high rating, I thought it might be a bit more complex.  Regardless, still a damn good beer.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 1.59 pint bottle, $9.99.  Solid malty aroma with moderate amount of sweat yeast.  Big fruity champagne bouquet, OMG (very sexy aroma).  Huge frothy off-white head that never fully diminished.  Murky dark amber brew with  an average amount of medium sized particles.  Flavor starts off moderately sweet and salty and finishes the same but with a little bitterness.  Duration is average.  Palate is medium/light with a watery texture and lively carbonation.  Loved it loved it loved it.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2007 I really enjoyed this beer, one of my first true quads...looked forward to each sip and especially liked it as it warmed up revealing its large complexity.  Excellent from start to finish, def a favorite.  This is what changed my impression of belgian beer!
Tap and Bottle... Tap a little smoother, but not that noticeably.  Great color and head.  Very easy to drink.  Weirdly, always reminded me of a hint cotton candy.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 On tap at Map Room in Chicago.  One of the best Belgian quads Ive tried.  Amazingly smooth and easy to drink for the high alcohol content.  I really enjoyed the dark color and head.  Served in a nice big trappist glass-- it was a nice beer to finish off a nice Monday night with my buddies.

Pours a dark earthy brown with a huge fluffy biege head. Aroma is of mild fruit and spice. Nice full and creamy mouthfeel. Dark fruits like plums on the tongue. This was truly a great beer. It was just so smooth and silky. I could drink this beer all day long. the next day too

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2007 I first had this beer when the LCBO was selling a St. Bernardus assorted gift set at Christmas 2005. This beer really stood out as the best St. Bernardus offering. I recently did a blind taste test along with Rochefort 10 and Westvleteren 12, and St. Bernardus 12 didnt really stand up. Definitely a great beer, but didnt quite reach the sublime level of the other two. The beer pours with a nice red-brown colour with white head. Is rich with raisin and port flavours, but with much lower intensity compared to the other two.

From the bottle it poured a deep rich brown.Aroma of fruit and sweet malt. Ever so smooth on the palate with flavors of deep complex fruit. Full body with a low alcohol taste. a superlative Belgian Abt.

Pours dark brown, with a decent head.  Smells nice of dark fruit and malt.  Taste is much of the same, dark fruits, malty, some spice, very smooth mouthfeel with quite a bit of carbonation.  A real pleasure to drink.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2007 Pours a dark almost tea like color with a thick creamy head.  Has the smell of dark fruits with fruits and spices in the taste as well.  Has very little carbonation and tastes kind of grapey.  Has a good mouthfeel and finshes smooth.  I just had this on tap and it is just great.  All the spices and fruit blend perfectly for an outstanding beer.

Very dark red in colour with a decent head.  The aroma is very ripe fruit, malty sweetness, and strong alcohol.  The flavour hits you like a ton of bricks.  Sweet and strong.  Very alcoholic, attacks the mouth.  Hints of caramel with a bitter aftertaste.  A decent beer in its own right, but 2 bottles and Im done for the night!

Bottle @ Chauccers Pub.   Poured into a Trappist glass.  Dissapointing head considering my expectations.  Dark, murky brown in colour (with a hint of orange).  Sweet aroma and an amazing mouth feel with great carbonation.  Taste was sweet, with the alcohol hidden nicely.  Could not put my finger exactly on the taste but I would say some sort of dried fruit.

Overall, a VERY enjoyable experience.  Served the way it should be, I left a happy man.

I have been waiting awhile to try this mother.  This beer pours a murky copper/dark amber color.  The head on the beer was very frothy with large bubbles that stuck to the edge of the glass for a good deal of time.  I smelled raisins and malt.  The taste was of the classic Abt/Quad style.  The taste is dried fruit, carmel with carbonation and alcohol.  The mouthfeel is tremendous as the beer really coats your whole mouth and warms you up as it goes down.  The beer got better with each sip, as I think it was a little to cold on the first few sips.  This is a tremendous beer and is in my top five beers of all time.  I have a bottle of the special edition aging in the basement.  I am extremely excited to try that one next.

11.2 oz. bottle. Sweet, classic Belgian aroma. Cinnamon and sugar scents. The smell is disappointingly weak. Pours a sparkling brown with a large amount of suspended particulate and a large amount of beige head. Produces limited lacing. Sweetness and alcohol dominate the flavor, which is similar to that of a barleywine. Thats unfortunate, as I am not a big fan of the barleywine style. Chocolatey. Bitter, English-style hops noticeable. Lacks the complexity and spicyness that make so many Belgian beers special. Bland. Little aftertaste. Full-bodied. Smooth and lively in the palate; very good texture. Easy to drink, which is impressive for a beer with such a high alcohol content. Light alcohol burn. I found St. Bernardus Abt 12 to be remarkably disappointing. I had heard great things about this beer, and it completely failed to live up to the hype. Sure, its drinkable, but its just boring.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2008 This beer is not the greatest beer in the world despite what people say.

Brown color, decent head.  Noticed the bubbles, going, and going, and going... if I wanted champaigne, I would have bought that.  Good taste, but became bloated only an hour into the drinking of the bottle, which at the time I had only consumed half.  

Dont piss on my leg and tell me its raining.  UPDATE (4-27-08)- resampled very early this morning- EXACTLY that same results as previously experienced- the score remains that same.

Bottle at Cervecería Oldemburg, March 07. Yeasty aroma, with a spicy touch. Deep rich brown color with a medium beige head. Plums, a touch of dried fruits and some yeasty phenollics. Satisfying MF, a bit flat. Rich, flavorfull but a bit flat belgian strong dark ale. I expected more.

Brown hue with diminishing off white head, mininal lacing, alcoholic smell not overpowering taste but can feel the effects, closer to water than oil, medium body, molassas malt, dried fruit particularly prune tang, as it warmed it became very chocolatey, delicious and probably somehow nutritious.
Pours an opaque mahogany with a nice head. Velvety mouthfeel. Sweet with some spice and dried fruits in the background. Very smooth despite the 10% alcohol content. Caramel-taste. Almost like flan.

Bottle, 33cl. Hazy brown colour with a tan head. Complex flavour with fruits, grapes & candy. Perhaps a wee bit alcoholic smell. Fuity flavour with plums, figs and candy. The taste isnt alcoholic at all despite 10% ABV. Top-notch beer.

For the availability and price of this beer compared to rochefort 10 or for that matter westy 12...it is a phenomenal beer that is a fantastic abbey quadruple that is great bang for your buck.  Very lively and carbonated body that has excellent head retention.  The palate is velvety smooth with a nice prickly presence from the carbonation.  Lots of yeast characteristics to this beers aroma as well as some candied sugar and fruits.  The flavor is very refined with some of the yeast coming through, some belgian candied sugars, some alcohol comes through too, but it is very welcoming in this big abbey beer.  A great quadruple that is a perfect way to introduce people to this style of beer.

Fruity estery aroma with nice spec. B character. Quite direct and cockey. The flavour is figs, prunes, almonds and alcohol with a nice sweet finish. The palate is nicely carbonated which makes this beer very easy to drink.
Great abt, but it could use some more complexity.

Bottle. Deep red pour with an off white head. Aromas of candied fruit, orange zest, malt, yeast and some light booze. Light citrus oin the flavor along with more candied fruit, lemon and lemon zest. Lively carbonation with dry sweetness throughout...dry, somehwta boozey finish. For a style I dont care for , this was rather exceptional.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2007 Light tan head upon the pour, nice froth and lace on the edges of my Trappist glass. Dark mohogany color with lots of yeast. Notes of citrus and heavy fruits on the nose, I love the aroma on this beer. Plenty of raisin, cinnamon, nutmeg, caramel, pear and banana under the malt tones. Chewy palate, malty taste finishing with dry alcohol, Belgian yeast and candy sugar. Finishes smooth on the tongue. This is right up there as one of my favorite Belgian brews, next to the Trappist Rochefort and Westvleteren beers.
Great Beer. One of the best Ive had. Nice alcohol warming.  Beautiful color and aroma. Very deep falvors.  Mild finish.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 Dark ruby red with a dense head and nice lacing, its a shame about the hideous bottle/label. Complex malty aroma with dark fruits, candy sugar, vanilla, nutmeg, cinnamon, alcohol, liqourice, and much more. A well balanced yet very complex flavor, with an extremely detailed malty long finish in which the instantly recognizable St. Bernardus yeast was prominent, as well as some spicy hoppiness. Medium/thick mouthfeel, low carbonation. Lush, one of the best.

One of my favorites.  Pours a dark reddish-brown with a small head, and lots of yeast sediment floating around.  Amazing aroma.  Great quad flavor - sweet and malty with some malt and fruity flavors.  Very smooth drink with a long finish.  Alchohol well hidden considering the high content.  Highly recommended.

The beer that started the addiction.  Had one of these on a whim at a Taco Mac in Suwanee GA.   Felt like I hit the lottery.  I cried when the bottle runnethed over.  Will always have available in my home when entertaining guests.   Dark, smooth, flavorful....didnt know beer could be this good.  If you can find it, try it.  My first Trappist beer, but happily, not my last.
Very potent and sweet with a smoothness that was well apprecitated.  A great quadripel.
Pours dark red/brown. Nice typical Quad nose, sweet malt, candied sugar and yeast. Great flavor, port like characters - raisins, spice. Nice long finish.
Can barely taste the alcohol, pours a dark reddish/brown with a light head and plenty of fruit on the palate.  Excellent.

Fills my trappist glass as a dark and dense leather brown. Small layer of film develops across the liquid. Aroma is a very sweet malt character and also displays alcohol and yeast. Very strong and very potent. I wish i had a 750 mL of this quad.
Pours a dark color, with alot of head. Hints of fruit and spices. Alot of sugar makes this sweet, which is very tasty for me. Finishes pretty nice.
Tons of dark dried fruits in the aroma and flavor. Plum and raisin. Some spice, lots of dark sugars. Great palate, a bit on the sweet side. Some alcohol. Not blown away, but its my first bottle.

Bottle. 1Pt. 9.4 Fl. Oz. Appealing, thick, off-white head with great longevity and lacing.  Scents of malts and fruits fill the nose.  Great mouthfeel. Perfect carbonation.  Satisfying flavor. I will definitely be drinking this beer again.

Unfortunately I cant really smell this beer right now due to a cold. But WOW. Appearance is basically perfect - a coffee/mahogany colored body with an ivory head that leaves beautiful lacing. The flavor is phenomenal, with strong maltiness; notes of chocolate, caramel, and molasses; heavy fruitiness. Palate is perfect. The best part, however, is this tingly warming feeling in my tummy as Im drinking this. Highly recommended!
Rather commercial, but not so well known (within my group of friends). I just love it. Its the perfect abt-beer as a surrogate for the finest trappist-beers.

Poured from fridge into cold tulip glass an foam nearly overflowed glass.  Had to spoon it out.  Light malt, light hops, and earthy smell.  Off white, lasting head with good lacing.  Deep reddish brown color.  Little bitterness, Moderate sweet finish.  Dreamy creamy soft texture. Full body and moderate alchohol.  Great Belgian Abbey beer.  I bought a case of it at $3.59/bottle.  Interesting history.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 Draft @ Monks Cafe - I have a couple of bottles that I havent had the chance to crack open yet, but I think a draft of this stacks up well.  Nice, dark brown color with a light head.  Sweet aroma with dark fruit abundance - cherry, plum, grape.  Sweet, malty taste makes this one all worth it - on taste alone, its one of the best beers Ive tried.  Magnificently smooth & a real treat.

Deep rich dark ruby colour with a thick tan head. Nose is dark fruit, cherry, plum, maltiness and some freshness. Very complex. Taste is slightly fizzy and warming, dark fruit, a little alcohol, perhaps a touch of banana. Palate is slightly fizzy still, smooth, bold, lasting warm malt and dark fruit. Just a hint of alcohol, but dry.

This is an extremely substantial beer, and a rather unique one, but satisfied me as a wine would rather than as a beer due to its grape and fruit character.

This beer is a cloudy red-brown (more red than brown) with very solid head formation.  Aroma is very fruity with a lot of plum and raisin aroma.  Flavor is very grape-y, with a big puckery finish like a cabernet wine would have.  It is extremely dry, and a bit fruitier than I would have preferred.  Mouthfeel is very dry and astringent, but pretty good.  

I had this on-tap at Landmark 1850 in Milwaukee, served in a tulip glass several degrees too cold.

33 cl bottle, best before 24/05/10 courtesy radiomgb. Cloudy dark brown amber colour with a mostly lasting frothy off-white head. Raisin, chocolate, plum, yeasty, and light alcohol aroma. Raisin, chocolate, plummy, and yeasty flavours with noticeable alcohol and a light citrus pith and yeasty bitter finish. Full bodied, very warming mouthfeel. Very good, but much preferred the Prior 8 to the Abt.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2007 Bottle, 330ml. A dark brown colour with a red tint and a small off-white head. A strong yeasty, fruity peach aroma with some malt and caramel evident. The taste is dominated by malt, with some bread and dark chocolate. Perhaps a little plum or blackberry in there as well. An almost syrupy mouthfeel. A noticeable alcohol burn in the fairly sweet, malty finish. High carbonation. Good lacing. Oh yes, this beer is deserving of its high rating.
Delicious.  I was referred to this by a friend who lived in Belgium for years. Despite high alcohol content, its never as overpowering as some Trappist varieties.  Deserves its 100 rating.

The "12" is the mack-daddy of Belgian beers.  Served in a traditional goblet, its taste, strength, and smoothness all work together to provide a great beer experience.  If youre switching from US beers and want to try a true staple, this is the one.  Available at the best liquor stores and tap rooms.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2007 Poured from a 11.2 ounce bottle into a snifter, deep ruby red with a medium beige head. The aroma was sweet, fruity and full of malt. The taste was sweet and creamy with notes of dark fruits and malt. Very smooth and well balanced. There is very little alcohol present at the start, but it becomes more noticeable as it warms. For my money one of the best beers in the world.

F*cking Brilliant!!  I just want to sit and smell this.  The maple, alcohol, apples, raisins, blackberry & currant.  The look is all dark chocolate with a wussy (fast disappearing) ecru colored head.  Very Pretty.  The flavor (if I can stop sniffing long enough to taste...) is raisin, alcohol, maple, brown sugar, and just F*ck Me!.  If I may get all girly, I want to have this beers children.

Wow!  I am enjoying this beer.  Lovely aroma of flowers, yeast, and fruit combine to be a wonderful part of this beer, making it a complete brew.  No real head, just a tan film.    This beer is fairly close to being perfect.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Tried this back to back with Rochefort 10 and this lost by a....dare I say....smidgeion? Pour was a medium brown with a huge puffy head. Aroma was very grainy with yeast and alcohol. Taste was some prune and raisin with yeast and malt undertones. Creamy mouthfeel with a little carbonation. Not as strong as the Rochefort but easier drinking.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Delicious, bread like, yeasty aroma with lots of fruity (and some slightly roasted) notes. Huge lasting head. Dark reddish colour. Lots of small bubbled carbonation. Fantastic taste dominated by dark malts but also rather sweet/spicy and liberal amounts of hops. Mouth feel is great and it feels a little more fresh then Westvleteren 12 and Rochfort 10 because of the high carbonation. One of the greatest beers in the world.

Poured a dark brown/red/purple with huge head. Very slowly dissipating head as well. Nose of candied sugars, grape soda, raisins. First sip was very smooth. Something (maybe the yeasts?) gave it a very carbonated feel on my tongue. The alcohol is very well-hidden. Although some peeks through early on, the beer becomes much more balanced once it warms. This was really an awesome beer overall. Respect it, and you will come out a better person for the experience.
Pours a nice dark color with a big chunky head. Nice aromas of raisin, fruit, yeast. Nice sweetness and bitterness, great balance. Light burn. Very good.

Big bottle. Lovely hazy dark brown colour with a long lasting light brown creamy head. Nice round sweet spiced malty, nutty and fruity flavour with some yeast to it. Great complex mouthfeel! Yummy spicy, sweet and bit bitter long lasting aftertaste. A very very great tasting Belgian abt!

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2007 Garrafa, em Utrecht (HOL), em novembro de 2007. Coloração marrom turva, com creme bege. Carbonatação alta. Amarga e seca. Notas de frutas vermelhas, torrefação e nozes. Harmônica.
Wow.  Unreal beer.  Matly, Fruity,  Caramel.  A cornucopia of flavours.  Nice head that lasts. Drink at a warmer temperature.  Thanks to Piscator
Bottle - Dark red/brown.  Malty, fruity nose.  Carmel, wine-like alcohol, hints of fruit, raisin rum maybe, strong.  Drink all of its own.  For any food pairings Im all ears - message me.
Pours dark brown with a thick foamy tan head. As soon as I openned the bottle the aroma was present. Malty and fruity. Tastes sweet, maybe banania, caramel. malt. Very very nice.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 10% ABV 330ml bottle. Dark brown pour swimming with sediment. Thin off-white head resolving into a slick of swirling clumps. Headily orange-fruity snout with boozy suggestions of port and licorice. Caramel-smooth maltiness with a hint of medicinal woody spice and a generous slug of licorice-yeasty bitterness in the finish.  (Re-rate) Aroma distinctly oaky, soapy, sweet but hopped. Garden herb/ noble hints in there. Would never have picked that up before I went to Munich. Almost pitch and creamily collared. BLOOD, liquorice, soap and sugar in the mouth with a nibble of roasted barley. Herbally hops apparent. Smoke and alcohol aftertaste. Its a decent enough big dark Belgian ale no doubt, but excessively sugared and too boozy for my liking, and lacks the elegance and complexity of its Trappist brothers. Digging those delicate noble hop notes, however.(8/4/7/4/15) (Re-rate) Wildly incongruous waft of noble hops- herbal, unfiltered helles germanic, chick pea. Singular, pure, uncomplicated, un-’Quad’- like. Apparently v.dark ruby tints. Liquorice black but copper vs lightbulb. Immovable narrow cappccino collar like a floating layer of cream. Herbal Hop-driven without bitterness. Chick pea, kidney bean notes merging into soft whispering booze, sweet peppery coriander-like spice never tasted in a beer this dark and big. Drifting towards the numbing caramel silk of Chimay. Saved by those hops, but standard liquorice finish.. mixed bean salad dowsed in marzipan/palinka alcohol. Tasty slick sessions but nowhere near worthy of Trappist comparisons. No yeast, roast, edge or bite. Just mellow caramel and hops. 15 is too generous.
Pours dark brown with a thin head.  Aroma is very malty with some fruity notes as well.  Taste is malty, sweet, and with some fruity tastes as well as a small alcohol warming.  Very nice to drink.
Brown pour with thick creamy head. Fruity, malty, and sweet with a creamy yeasty finish. Warming and very plesant. A favorite.

Bottle:  A true brown pour with lots of bubbles and a large, creamy beige head.  Nose is fruity with yeast, malt, and some breadiness.  Taste is light with fruit notes, little yeast, plenty of malty sweetness, and some hints of more fruit in the tail.  A very creamy (at the same time silky) mouthful and warming in the end.  Excellent.
Dark brown pour with light tan head that lasts.  Aroma and flavor were similar; malty, bready and light fruit.  Very smooth/creamy beer that masks the high alcohol content well.

Beautiful pour, on tap, nice ruby colored with a fluffy white head.  Aroma and flavor are both somewhat fruity, yeasty, and with mild alcohol.  The mouthfeel was amazing though.  Very silky . . . Nice beer.  Im usually an All-American guy, but those Belgians sure get it together sometimes.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown color with a longlasting off-white head. Sweet malty fruity aroma with lots of dark fruit. Sweet malty yeasty flavor with lots of dark fruits. Malty yeasty finish with some hints of alcohol.

Draft. Brown in the glass with a creamy off-white head that slowly settles but renews with a twirl of the glass. Leaves light lacing rings after each sip. Nice fruity aroma. Sweet flavor of fruits with a malt background and hints of wood and spices. Medium body and a creamy texture. Very enjoyable as an after dinner treat.

Thoroughly enjoyed this quad with Skibumphishead.  Pours with a frothy one inch head that never fully dissapears.  Nice lacing and warm brunette color.  The aroma is intriguing with citrus undertones.  The taste is slightly citrusy, but has a richer more robust flavor. Hints of raisin, brown sugar, cinnamon and chocolate with a burst of grapefruit aftertaste. mmmmmm....me likey.

OK, I simply LOVE my American micro breweries.  BUT, I have purposely waited to have this particular beer due to its high rating and hype.  So here I am....Pours out dark red/brown, dark ruby like.  Aroma is heavenly, sweet malts (somewhat typical of other abbey ales that Ive tried)  Formed a white foamy head.  Flavor is of a smooth malty taste that says "take another drink".  Very good beer.  Does taste similar to some other Belgium ales, but much smoother and refined.  I would love to try this on tap or cask.  Yes, I still adore my American brews, but this Belgium beer is pretty damn great.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Poured dark red/brown.  The aroma was mostly fruit, overripe pears  Body was very rich with malts, with even more fruit, caramel, and sweet candy.  Some woody overtones linger.  The finish is a bit strong on alcohol.  I"m a bit surprised to see this beer rated so high.  The balance is not exceptional, and the sweet, alcoholic finish was not great.  I think the Rochefort Trappistes 8 and 10 are both far better than this beer.

Pours caramel brown with fairly large off-white head.  Strong aroma of fig, plum, raisin, port, and caramel malts with a slight alcohol pungency.  Extremely smooth for 10.5 abv with great malt character.  A little bitter in the finish makes this an extremely well rounded beer.

rbesg, bottle at haket. very deep shade of brown with a lingering beige head. i always figured this beer must be over-rated and never sought it out before but it blew me away. big salty aroma of bbq shapes, vegemite (the first time ive liked the smell of vegemite), salted licorice. heady alcohol bite but plenty of other flavours to save it - spiced liqueur, marzipan, hazelnut, brown sugar, whipped cream, vanilla cake dough. anyways.
A dark brown pour with a lot of off white head.  This beer had a sweet malty flavor with hints of molasses.

Bouteille de 750 ml avec bouchon de liège obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de cassonade, dépices et de petits fruits foncés. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée brunâtre avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col crémeux beige avec une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de malt rôtis, de caramel et de petits fruits foncées avec une pointe dalcool. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de caramel légèrement alcoolisé en arrière goût. (Rating #868)

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2007 Dark murky brown body, full creamy beige head, nutty aroma with lots of dark fruits. Rich creamy smooth palate with medium carbonation. Taste is quite sweet: plums, figs, candi sugar, and a little Dr. Pepper? Very expressive in its flavors, unlike Rocheforts 8 and 10 which I find more reserved (but thats not to say they are any less big). Spiciness kicks in halfway through, strong alcohol presence though Im not sure I would guess 10.5%. Has a lot of good stuff going on, a really enjoyable beer. For what it is, and not what it might be compared to, this definitely lives up to its reputation.

[Bottle, February 2007] Deep ruby pour with medium stagnant bubbly head. Aroma is fruity with berries. Flavor is fruity with apples and some banana. Mouthfeel is wet yet crisp. Finish has medium alcohol burn and more berries. Great beer but it lacks a little something that jumps out at me and grabs my attention.
Ive always been a fan of the Trappist-style beers and this beer reinforces that opinion.  It was dark and sweet (brown sugar or molasses) with fruit essences.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 I love the fact that you can age this beer. If you were to age a beer such as Heineken you would go blind after drinking it. Anyways, the first taste I had of this I knew I had tasted a special beer. The smell of old raisins was present throughout the entire experience. The color was awesome, a Coca-Cola appearance if you will. The taste was a mouthful. This beer was thick and also smooth at the same time. The monk on on the label looks happy to be drinking it. Thank God for Belgium!

pours dark brown with some tints of red and it has about an inch off-white head.  Nose of dark fruit, with some sweet banana like malt and a bit of spicy yeast character. The taste is very sweet, just like it smells but with some brown sugar along with the malt and dark fruit. Mouthfeel is nice and full and creamy with a good amount of carbonation. Its nice and smooth, and very drinkable.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: A great beer, fruity, sweet, nutty, herbal, and malty aroma. Taste is roasted malt, herbs, liqorich, toffee, coffee, caramell, fruits and hops.
Meget god (og billig) stærk belgisk ale. Dog kraftig smagbar alkoholstyrke, men dejlig karamel-, rosin-, ?-noter. Duft og eftersmag ikke så varieret som smag
This is my favorite beer. First thing after work every friday, I pick up one of these badboys. It pours very dark brown with a normally thick tan head.

This is one of the best Belgians I have enjoyed.  I have had the entire line of St. Bernardus (8, 10, 12, Prior, Abt, etc.) on tap while I travel to Stockholm.  It is definitely better on tap than in the bottle here.

Aroma: Sweet apples
Appearance: red, brown, not enough head
Flavor: heavy sweetness, lightly bitter, I felt the alcohol too much
Palate: 
full body, creamy, thick feel, lively, 
Overall - I felt the alcohol (Not good), but I want more from that beer. The best company to blue cheese

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2007 Bottle.  Hazy dark brown color, fizzy khaki head.  Pretty strong alcohol aroma, some plum and spice.  Taste is tangy, spicy, a little hoppy at times.  Great beer but I cant t see myself drinking it all of the time -- perfect time/place seems like after-meal drinks at a dinner party.
spiritually deep aroma.  full tasting and tangy with a well appreciated aftertaste of bitterness.  a revelation.

Pours murky dark brown with a creamy brown head.  Aroma is complex, cookies, bananas, dark fruits, and apples.  Flavor starts balanced twards the sweet side, carmel, toffie, and finishes more well balanced and short.  Medium to full bodies, creamy and softly carbonated.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 Re-rate 1/5/14: Bottle from my cellar shared at a tasting at Orens place. 2006 bottle. Murky dark brown. Aroma full of dark fruits, somewhat oxidized with port, caramel, a bit of chocolate and a bit of nutty hints. Sweetish flavor with chocolate, dark fruits, oxidized vinous notes and a finish with a light alcoholic touch. Medium-bodied. Aged pretty nicely. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4

(Re-rated on 7/15/07. Took a point from the aroma and a point from overall impression. Changed the description a bit).
Bottle. Color is very dark brown, with a lovely beige-brown head that lasts long. Aroma of malt, yeast, dark fruits, caramel and a bit of alcohol. Flavor is sweet with malt, raisins, carmael and some yeast. A nice full body with a spicy, alcoholic and a bit bitter finish. A great beer. 7/4/8/4/16=3.9
Richer and stronger than the 8. Pure quality. I dont need to get poetic. This is an excellent beer.

25.4 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy light brown with an off-white one finger head. Very appealing sweet aroma of molasses, plums and caramel.  The flavor is dominated by carbonation, follwed by cherries, plums and caramel.  Nice warming on the finish. Great beer!

Murky brown body with a big, foamy tan head. LOTS of stuff in the aroma, very pleasing. After one whiff I had to smile, undoubtedly resembling the monk on the label. Flavor mirrors the aroma with fruity notes of plum, cherries, caramel, brown sugar, and molasses. Wonderful flavors coaxed from the yeast, the brewing experience is overwhelmingly evident as I sip it. As it moves down the pipes, I feel a warming sensation that is no doubt caused by the 10.5% alcohol. The alcohol is masked in the flavor, but not hidden. A very nice brew and genuinely worthy of its high rating.

Bottle at St. Veronus. Poured in a Trappist Glass with a white head. The smell on this beer is gorgeous. The aroma is very inviting and the best of any beer that I have smelled. Unfortunately, the taste didnt hold up to its promise. Flavour is of cherries, molasses, brown sugar, plums, and a small hint of grapes and caramel. Creamy mouthfeel and a well-bodied brew. Tastes great, but the aroma makes it out to be bigger than it truly is. Pleasant experience, pleasant beer.

Pours deep opaque brown with large tan head with good retention and good lacing. Aroma of plums, raisons, alcohol and caramel. Flavor is the same with the alcohol not being to over whelming. Even with the 10% ABV this beer is very drinkable.

What more needs to be said about this beer? A rich mohagony color with a puter head. Sweet with a hint of some fruit (raisin/figs), but not overbearing. Beautiful balance of hop and spice to back up that sweet entrance. The finish is as consistent as the rest. A medium carbonation finish leaves a malty flavor in tandem with just the right amount of hop. Its called beer. It tastes good. Give me more. Oh, and its 10.5%. Who the hell wouldve known? 2 mangled thumbs up.

Pours a nice deep mahogany color with a bubbly light tan head.  A somewhat extreme level of carbonation detracted somewhat from this beer, which had a distinct alcohol flavor.  Somewhat sugary flavor was evident with a mashing of fruit flavor, though nothing stood out.  Although this was an excellent beer, I had higher expectations.  Would definitely buy again, but enjoyed the Rochefort Trappistes 10 much more than this beer...bottle wins points for artwork, however!

Pours dark with a light brown head. Head holds pretty good. Aroma of fruits. Tastes inclube roasted malts and fruits. Great full mouth. This could be my fav Quad. It also has the coolest label Ive ever seen.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2008 I sampled this beer poured from the bottle into a belgian ale glass.  It poured a very dark brown color that was somewhat cloudy, with a good bit of foamy off-white head.  A sweet, malty aroma full of fruit notes, some raisin, and a touch of caramel malts, with the presence of alcohol noticeable; there may have been some toasty hops too.  However, the beer was only slightly sweet in taste; it was mostly bitter with some sour touches too.  The beer had a medium-high level of carbonation, and a dry finish with a crisp alcohol bite that warmed my throat.  A very good Belgian ale!

beautiful dark brown color with a off white foamy head. gotta admit that my taste buds might be off a bit since im congested, so i couldnt quite get all of the aroma i wouldve liked. flavor was sweet...a little caramel, some fruit, and enough alcohol to know its there, but in no way overpowering.  its a solid beer, but i must admit...it just doesnt wow me like the rochefort 10 does....i would take that beer 10 out of 10 times over this one. cant say ive ever had the westvleteren, so i cant compare with that.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2007 Pours a really large, foamy head. Dark brown color. Aromas of alcohol and fruit. Some honey in there. Strong malty flavor that consists of honey, fruit, and cork. Really excellent!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2007 Bottle.  Pours a very dark red/brown with a bunch of carbonation.  Bubbles sticking to the side of the glass like soda.  Has a medium size foamy white head that disappears pretty quickly.  Strong and complex aroma of dark fruits and malts.  Great smooth flavor that is refreshing and very complex.  No complaints.
Draft at Eulogy.  Dark brown, almost raisin in color.  Creamy head that never faded.  One of the best Abts. I have ever had.  The aroma is almost as amazing as the taste,

The color was grape/orange with brown hues.  The head was off-white, creamy, and lasted forever.  The aroma was not very pungent at first.  There was a sour/yeasty smell.  The alcohol and fruit were stronger after having had a bit to drink.  The flavor was alcohol, yeast.  It burned the nose slightly.  The palate was alcohol and was a bit harsh.  The finihs was warm and lingered in the back of the throat.

Finally tried this one, I feel like its a staple that I should have had a long time ago. Poured a murkey brown that showed some red in the light, bottle had sediment that remained stirred up after sitting. The head was profuse, tannish white, and frothy. The aroma was typical belgian, some spicy aromas, ripe fruit, alcohol, and musty notes. The flavor showed the alcohol but in a mature way (it wasnt over the top but it let you know it was there), spicy, mature fruit, and a sweet caramely taste. Nice. The palate was very dry and had a small bubble carbonation feel to it. The finish was very warm and I noticed the alcohol very much. Not as great as I had expected, but still a good Belgian.

Great beer with which you cant go wrong. Im drinking one now. This is one of the twelve or so beers I currently have in rotation. Its not overly sweet to me like Achel, it seems to be a good balance, hops are present so it has a good blend of hoppiness, malt and alcohol with chocolate & coffee overtones. The bottom line is you wont regret giving it a try and there is a good chance it may become a regular for you if you do.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2008 11.2oz bottle, part of our blind "Better Know a Style: Abt/Quadrupel" tasting, pours deep murky brown with nice white head. nose is molasses, prune, plum, toffee, brown sugar, maple syrup, and mostly raisin. taste is rather sweet with rainsin and plum notes. mouthfeel is slightly watery with alcohol and dry finish. finished #3 out of 9 quads.

2005 vintage, 33cl bottle. i wouldnt say this improved, mellowed a bit. still tasty but not better.3.8.
as my co-worker put it tonight - "perfect" - this is what belgians should taste like - malty sweetness with hints of fruit - great color with a nice solid head

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2010 On tap at Ölrepubliken in Göteborg, Sweden. Pours a nice reddish brown colour with a generous beige head. Superbly balanced fruity and nutty aromas with dry yeasty and hoppy notes, and nicely integrated alcohol (is it really 10.5 abv?). Medium to full bodied, extremely smooth mouthfeel, with a vivid carbonation. 
Wonderful. Perfect.

Pours a darkish brew with head that looks pretty carbonated, thank you very much. As things simmer down, the head becomes more delicate with every passing minute. Absolutely gorgeous. And fruity, so fruity and delicate all the way around. Very, very good thing this isnt sold at my corner store. I can just imagine the damage that would wreak on my personal finances.

Just had my second bottle of this beer. Had my first on Christmas eve as the fourth bottle of Westy 12, Westy 10 and Rochefort 10 sampling. It held up incredibly well that night and tastes great on its own. The monk is smiling for a good reason.

Carbonation doesnt seem overkill but this really makes you need to burp-- more than any beer Ive tried.  Still the best Belgian brew Ive tried. Beautiful look and lacing. Nice nose, great finish and aftertaste. Pit fruits, grapes, carmel malt balanced with mild spice/herbs and hops.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2007 Poured a reddish amber; medium head.  Aroma of yeast, alcohol, plum, pit fruit, light malt.  Creamy palate, slight warming at the end.  Slightly sweet; alcohol fairly present.  Flavor of pit fruit, brown sugar, yeast, caramel, alcohol.  Complex.
Good trappist brew.  Deep red with a tan hear.  Alcohol very evident but a very drinkable beer. For me the brown sugar tones stood out.

Bottle from Wilburs poured into trappist glass @ 58 degrees - Pours a beautiful deep red with a 1 finger tan head; a very beautiful beer to look at; plums, alcohol, malt, a little yeast, red wine, and tart grapes to the nose; alcohol, plums, apples, raisins, malt, bread, faint chocolate and brown sugar on the initial taste; Sweet malts, grapes, and a light bitterness of barley in the aftertaste; a smooth, full body; Nice carbonation with alight sharpness; A nice warming feeling when it goes down. This was an absolute pleasure to taste. Easily the most complex beer Ive tasted to date. I just wish I could get my hands on it more easily!

Its a nice beer I drink it often because its even hard to get the Westvleteren in Belgium and this one is available in lots of local shops

It has a sharp flavor a bit sweet in the beginning, a black clear appearance  with a nice brown head
I bought this since I cant get the Westvleteren here in the US.  16 bucks for a four pack?  Worth it.  It is everything an amber should be- too bad its an Abt.   Drank it right from the bottle.

Fruit, figs, citrus, caramel, metal, brown sugar in the aroma.  Pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Sharp flavor, sweet upfront, caramel, brown sugar, some fruit, with a spicy character i cant place, and i can taste the alcohol.  very nice though.

Pours a dark brown color with an overabundance of thick creamy tan foam. The head dies down to a more normal 2" in several minutes. Excellent, stick-to-the-glass lacing throughout the glass. I first get the aroma when the cap is lifted, and it is very prominent while pouring the beer. I smell this wonderful, still-rising bread dough aroma. Very yeasty. This is followed by a very potent alcohol scent.

The beer is sweet for sure, but absolutely not cloying. It is full of brown sugar and dried dark fruit, and there is a thick caramel maltiness to it, followed by a touch of raisin and rum. Faint spice in the finish - cloves or herbal/spicy hops, maybe. Fantastic full body, gently carbonated

Pours dark brown with a fairly thick, foamy, tan head. Banana, yeast, lightly sweet malt, and mild hop aroma. Flavor matches the aroma with a little more bitterness in the finish than expected. Palate is medium, a bit creamy, and bitter-sweet. A little unbalanced, but the flavors present are enjoyable none the less.

[Tasted in 2004, DK-ITA: 0-0 with Troels.]

A truely very strong beer with alcoholic presence. Therefore it is a hardkicker for many. Sometimes its good, othertimes its less good. But lots of ingredients such as notes of fruit, sweetness, caramel. Heavy stuff!

A very good belgian beer.  It lacks a lot of the estery quality of some belgian beers, which is actually a plus to me.  I am not a fan of the banana taste in my beer.  That said, it is very resiny, dark fruit and candy and complex with a nice finish.

Brown-amber pour with a off-white head that lingers.   Aroma was sweet and fruity...figs I would say.  Flavor is also sweet and  complex, with fruit and a almost bubble gum character.  An overall good but not great beer.
wow.......if you cant get westy 12, this is just as good. excellent! aroma of dried fruit, and caramel. nice big fat frothy head. absolutely a piece of heaven.

Bottle.  Poured into a St. Bernardus Tulip.  My favorite Belgium which makes it my favorite beer.  A wonderful pour, Frothy white head.  Dark amber in color.  Fruity smell.  Wonderful complex taste.  I like this better than the Westvlederin because I think it tastes "cleaner", and is much more available.  That being said, the Westi is the original.(for those who do not know the story, westvlederin used to sale its recipe to St. Bernardus for mass production, in 1992 the trappists started selling for themselves (to retain the trappist "logo) and St. Bernardus carried on the "formula" note it is not a trappist, but the same basic stuff as a Westvlederin Abt. 12)

Awesome.  Very bready and fruity nose.  Can smell the alcohol, but it doesnt detrace.  Very murky in the glass.  More effervescent than I expected.  Tastes like heaven.  Lots of malt and esters.  Sweet and bitter hops all at the same time.  Alcohol in the finish, but not hot, just present.  Awesome.

Bottle. Dark reddsih brown with off-white lasting head. Heavy malt and pretty high level of hoppy bitterenss. Some orangecid is also detected. Malt and a high level of carbonation on the  palate. Average finish, with nice hoppiness. Certainly a well made and tasty beer.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2014 Bottle; 33 cl Deep brown with off-white head. Aroma very yeasty/bready, with dark fruit notes and some alcohol. Dark fruits again in the mouth, with a  yeastiness as well, and the warming alcohol, though that is very well-integrated considering the abv%. Soft and delicate, but packed with flavour, a truly, outstanding beer.
Poured from bottle. Dark reddish brown...Slight head, good lacing...VERY fruity, yeasty aroma...Taste was fruit fruit fruit...Apple, figs, plums...Very pleasing after taste...Very easy to drink.
Dark red pour, fruity aroma. flavor of caramel, malts and alcohol which combines for a nice flavor profile, though not extraordinarily complex. nice bitter finish

12 oz bottle . dark brown pour , beige head ,good lacing. yeasty,sweet malt , figs/pear aromas . Sweet , fruity flavors ,figs -plum -banana .. medium  mouthfeel . alcohol shows up more as it warms .very dry finish . smooth , great abby

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2010 Bottles of various ages. Just a classic quad thats accessible. Awesome how they produce the larger volume but keep such good quality. "Similar" to Westy 12 but maybe a touch thinner and the alcohol a little more raw.
The best Abby ale I have ever had. Smooth, low tannin, slightly sweet caramel flavor due to the execptional hops.

12oz bottle.  Pours a very dark, murky brown with a white head.  Aroma is sweet, with brown sugar, hints of alcohol, figs, malts, and some yeast.    Flavor is sweet malts, with dark fruits, yeast, and brown sugar.  Mouthfeel smoothes out as you sip.

From bottle: dark brown-red with large staying head, malty, fruity, yeasty, some chocolate, caramel, apples, some sour notes, the alcohol is pretty present in the flavor which is not too plesent, banana, dark dried fruits, some spicyness, weak bitterness, not as rich and full bodied as some of the better strong belgian ales, the finish is a bit sour and dry, overall a good beer to start the new year.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2008 Pours a murky dark brown with lots of visible sediment despite a careful pour. Big, fluffy, inch-thick white head. Aroma of caramel, candy sugar, wood, figs. Flavor is sweet and lightly fruity: big malt up front, figs, plums, s fairly huge alcohol presence that fades into a mild dry finish. Full mouthfeel, lightly astringent. Great lacing. Very complex and earthy. A wonderful beer.

Pours a dark brown with a nice brownish head.  Aroma is a bit nutty, sweet, and very full.  Taste is silky sweet, with some dark fruit and caramel/toffee undertones.  Quite complex, the best of the brewery.
I love my belgiuns.  This had a nice veggie and hoppy flavor with all the usual complexities.  2 Finger head - beuatiful.

Aroma of apple that is unique and pleasing to the nose.  Pours a big frothy head that mostly fades.  Flavor is fruity and very easy going down.  Its Definetly not my favorite thing to drink, but how refreshing! Quality is evident in every sip.
Excellent beer. Out of 750 bottle into chalice. Nice head, retained throughout drinking. Medium amber color. Flavors abound.

Merry Christmas!  Pours garnet brown with a very fizzy orangey head.  Aroma is pears, caramel, and much malt.  Dark fruity flavor with some banana.  Very understated and soft on the palate.  A velvet drink of subtle density and substance.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2006 12/30: Rerated 11.2 oz bottle, BB date 26.08.10.  Served in a trappist goblet.  Color is a dark amber with a thick one-finger, lumpy tan head that diminishes slowly then constantly replenishes itself.   Intense initial aroma of caramel, malts with a subtle fruitiness that quickly disperses.  Each swallow results in a thick and foamy mouthfeel that has to be chewed through only to find a delicious coating on the tongue.  The flavor is  rich, malty and well blended, with a balanced, elegantly bitter finish.  A slight warming is evident from the alcohol, which is otherwise hidden.  Strong lacing left on the glass.  Im not picking up the broader set of flavors described - could just be me.  Bumping up appearance 1 point - a full glass and a single pour makes all the difference.

Paper notes from the Falls Tasting / 2006 YeHA!.  Sampled next to the Westy 8 and 12.  Minimal head.  Clear maple color.  Sweet malty start, balanced malt-bitterness in the body.  Finish is creamily succulent, and lightly bitter.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 12/23/06: Cloudy caramel brown in color with good lasting head. Aroma is very sweet and strong. Flavor is amazing, sweet and fruity with a taste of apples and raisins. High alcohol but didnt taste like it.

Re-Rate, Vintage July 2002 bottle, batch 467:  
Found two of these bottles at a local bottle shop for $3.50! Dark brown color with very small off-white head and no lacing. Extreme caramel flavor, taste like candy. Light fruit and slightly sweet. A little woody and roasty. Its like a good strong cigar. Cant taste the alcohol at all but still has a warm feeling. Aroma is all malty caramel. This is like nothing Ive ever had before and truly unique from a fresh bottle.

Pours dark reddish brown with frothy tan head.  Aroma of mashed oranges, caramel, spice, malt, yeast, dark fruits, fig, plum, prune and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor is an outstanding combination of all of the above.  Great palate and smooth as can be. Hmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm... fantastico!
a complex malty  taste, a sweet aroma that give you a real idea of the taste, and a wonderful dark brown color. this is a wonderful beer but a serious palate is need to get the best out of it.

beautiful, inviting body...dark reddish brown app. with medium frothy, brown head..aroma is full of dark fruits, caramels, figs, spice, milk, and yeast...flavor is huge in figs, plum, and prune..nice palate

Presents a gorgeous nutty deep brown color with an off white head that wants to stick around. 
Aroma  fresh hops, licorice, honey, charred caramel, oak. 
The 10% ABV is brilliantly masked. Along with the bursting malts you get a sweet sensation that lingers far beyond finishing your drink. However answering the big question as to how this compares to its Trappist (Quadrupel) cousins - well its different, quite different. When compared to the Rocheford 10, while the Trappist ale is warm and highly complex, the St. Bernardus is an easy drink and not as overwhelming. Im in no way suggesting that this is a better brew than the Rocheford 10, well come to think about its probably not, however there is still much to appreciate here when judged on its on accord.

Cloudy brown pour with a decent sized tan head that melted down to a thin layer that stayed on top of the beer while I was drinking it.  Sweet malty, fruity smell and taste.  The aroma didnt capture all of the flavor, but it had a great fruitiness to it and a smooth finish.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown, with a huge beige head. Sweet smell, yeasty, caramel.  Wow, now that is balanced, wheres the alcohol??  Flavors similar to the smells, and is quite fantastic. Crazy lacing on my glass, like a piece of art.

Bottle.   Pours a murky dark brown color, with a rocky beige colored head, huge lacing.   Aroma is bread, caramel, dried fruit, brown sugar.   Flavor is brown sugar, honey, caramel, bread dough, chocolate, dried cherries, prunes.   Palate is medium bodied, very smooth, no hints of alcohol, surprising easy to drink, resinous, doughy finish.   World class!!
Head dissipated a little quickly but the lacing was phenomenal.  The mouthfeel was velevetly smooth.  A tatsy ale with a complex yet well balanced flover profile.   Sweet yet hoppy.

Bottle.  Pours a nice dark brown with an off white lasting head.  Lots of carbonation, sweet smelling of fruits, sugar, caramel.  Taste is sharp from carbonation, with hints of honey, sugar, caramel, fruits.  Easily drinkable, filling, and quite satisfying.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2009 11.2 oz bottle-Date code 12 07 11. Poured a murky brownish cream color w/a moderate foamy head. Floral, fruity nose, very fragarent. Sweet fruity flavor w/ a bit of spice-very complex, very hard to describe, & very good. Lots of carbination & lacing. Incredibly smooth, dont taste the alcohol at all, very long finish-Excellent beer!
