As its warming up, taste is getting stronger, in a good way. And it warms the belly slightly with the alcohol. Im enjoying this one, this is what beer sampling is all about.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: The last in our "Weekend at Bernies" sampling.  What more can I add to this beer by trying to explain it in words?  I think it was summed up best by one of our tasters, a friend of mine who is atheist.  He looked at the bottle, with the monk smiling happily at him, and said "Youre trying to convert me, arent you?"  This has got to be one of the best beers on the planet.
UPDATED: AUG 6, 2005 caramel, chocolate, brown, light sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, thick feel, long finish,

Love the happy Saint on the bottle.  Deep dark brown, looks almost like a stout.  Thick foamy light tan head.  Verry friuty and spicy scent.  Bitter fuity taste that veries greatly.  A bit rich but very pleasant.

Taster @ PIB.  Pours a deep rich toffee color.  Smells of yeast, spices, and strong malts.  A wonderful taste of dates, oak, cloves, and spices.  A truly magnificant beer worthy of drinking some more.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 Small re-rate - repeated tastings of this incline me to add a few points. I prefer it very lightly cooled down from room temperature. I like the whole line actually - the Pater and Prior are well worth trying, as are the Watou an St. B Tripels. Does the Abt. 12 rule? Yes, but it has a worthy court of subjects.

Small tulip poured from 33cl on BeerBistro patio. (Awesome place.) Small sips of strong, deep rich flavor delivers what the dark colour promises. Bigness. Not exceptionally powerfiul or detailed aroma, but nice dark / mixed dried fruit (pear fig plum rasin) aroma and flavor with austere sweet-baked spicings. Alcohol shows a bit. Elegant and not bad. Might prefer a Koningshoeven Quad though - I must try both again (and Fin Du Monde to see if it hits the spot these days.) St.B12 is very good if not indispensible at first try, but when the expectation is so built up like this Id better try a few more StB12s to rate more objectively.

The server took away my bottle before I was done (hey I paid 13 bucks just to stare at it!).

75 cl Bottle. Dark brown colour, with a nice big rocky head. Lovely aroma of some complexity and notes of medicin. A wonderful flavour, notes of spice and dried fruit, and some sweetness. The alcohol is very good hidden, and the beer ends up in a very delicate way. Absolute the best beer I ever try from this brewery.

330ml brown bottle shared with Gilvanblight and PandoraGreen, Pub Italia, Ottawa. Dark brown pour, small tan head. Almond, nutty, chocolate malt aroma. Flavour is deeply choclately. Alcohol blended in nicely. Carbonation seemed light and restrained. A big but not overpowering beer.

Aroma of spicy yeast, port, chocolate. Pours a murky brown, huge foamy off-tan head that sticks around. Fruit sweetness up front. Tingly palate on the tongue. A blunt chocolate finish with a strong alcohol taste that I found off-putting. Hops are definitely there as well. 100th percentile? Bah!
This is really a quality brew. A very nice aroma with a very malty, a bit chocolate, caramel like taste. Nice palate. Very tasty!

Bottle - 330ml Nice opaque muddy brown body with more than decent head. Complex is the appropriate word to describe this splendid monster: caramel, malt, a bit of roast, fruit, spices and alcohol. Warm finish.

got a mug on draft with a big, thick, creamy, textured head  that lasts and lasts. Very malty, estery, fragrant, and volatile nose. Mouth filling body with just the right amount of carbonation. Not too sweet with a very complex taste. Goes down satisfyingly. Finish is medium. Lots of lace on the glass. Dark brown, copper color. Had it on draft, but theres bottles too at the Bodega downtown.
pours a dark brown with a thick off white head .  first aroma of fruit and alcohol . has a nice alcohol sting to it at first taste along with carmel and fruits at the finish. very malty.. good stuff

Beautiful color and full round taste of butter and alcohol.  Slightly dissapointing/dull nose, perhaps I shouldnt have read that review that compared this to Westleveren.  Oh well.  Incredible beer nonetheless.
Nice fruity/malty aroma. Pours a nice rich brown with a rich long lasting head.  A hint of fruit with a strong maltiness.  Pleasant on the palate.

This beer poured a cloudy deep brown color w/ orange highlights; thick lasting head and lacing.  The aroma had dark fruit, malts, coriander, and a slight spice note.  The flavor was sweet w/ malts and dark fermented fruit, and coriander.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied and creamy.

Exceptinally similar to Westy 12.  Dried fruits arent as distinct in the flavor -- theres quite a bit of malt in front of the yeast esters, but theyre still immense.  The aroma is fruity esters and alcohol with some sweet malt behind it.  The flavor is very similar: yeast esters, caramel malt, some bittering hops in the background and a little alcohol -- not as much alcohol flavor as Westy 12, though.  Very very good, especially for the price and availability.

Doughy Smell.  Candy dark Brown color. A little alcoholic but smooth.

Available at Downtown Wine & Spirits in Somerville, MA

Slightly sweet aroma with a hint of alcohol. Pours dark reddish brown with off white head. Thick full mouthfeel with strong presence of malt and dark fruit. The alcohol detracts from the fruit somewhat, but isnt overpowering. Id love to spend more time searching for adjectives, but this is a complex beer and I think Ill just go enjoy it.

when i first poured the beer it had a sweet aroma of burnt caramel, the also had a bit of an alcohol smell to it as well.
The head of the beer was frothy and white.  The beer had bitter taste but not overly bitter, it also had slight alcohol taste to it as well with hints of sweetness. overall pretty good beer , i would have given it  a better rating but quads have never been my favorite.
Lovely dark, brownish red colour. Heavy malty aroma, very full body and flavors to rival even the heaviest Trappists.

burnt orange/dark brown, depending on what angle you look at it.  this is pretty decent.  very very creamy and very thickk white head.  really carbonated.  lots of plum, almonds, walnuts, and some peanuts in the flavor.  almost like a thai seasoning taste to the beer... wierd.  some hints of apricots and peach.  enjoyed this at home with mikes.  there is a weird creamy taste/palate, like a baileys or something... yummers

brownish color with a hint of orange.  nice light tan head, very huge and creamy.  Banana bread, strawberries, nuts and irish cream in the aroma, very nice indeed.  Big time alchohol in the taste with dried dark fruits and nuts. Very thick and a nice subtle bitterness shows up at the begining and at the end.

Bottle.  A little dissapointed compared to the abt 8.  Beautiful pour though.  Deep rich black with an awesome brown head.  Excellent appearance.  Taste is a bit off with the alcohol really showing.  Spices with hints of oak and malt.

St. Bernardus Abt 12.  22 June 2005.  Small bottle.  Deep walnut brown with an uber-creamy cappuccino head.  In my Chimay glass theres a cool effect: the bubble stream that comes up the center of the glass makes a little poofy pillow under the head.  Aroma of apricots, banana, cinnamon.  I can taste nuts, cinnamon, brown sugar, and lots of yeast.  One of the best, and a nice treat for my anniversary.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2005 Very sour smelling, with a bit of grape. Dark amber coloring, with a fluffy tan head. Very wine-like qualities, deep flavor, almost a carbonated wine. Seriously. The mouthfeel is deep and dense, with a bitterness at the finish. Overall, not my style, but you appreciate class when you come across it.

HUGE rocky khaki head over a deep brown body, tart grapey nose, cherries, sweet fruity flavor, complex, syrupy warming mouthfeel, little bit of a throat burn, ,malty rich and roasty, mmmmmmmm this is dank

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2005 Slight little rerate based on a new batch sampled.  Most of the original traits rated still stand, but there was a slight metallic zing on the end and resonnating in the finish, which causes me to knock the palate and overall rating each down by one.  Nevertheless, the original rating...Beautiful murky, rusty chocolate in color with a fluffy, 1/3" thick head that looks like moss.  Head and lacing are the most beautiful Ive ever seen, and they retain their timeless character throughout the tasting.  Aroma is chocolate, anise, bananas, cloves, cackled pepper, chocolate éclairs, brown sugar and sugar brazed walnuts.  You can actually feel it slide through the nasal passage.  Flavor is sudden bliss.  So complex.  Subtle yet leading cocoa joins a bakery fresh yeastinesss to concoct a flavorful and rich chocolatey pound cake.  Rolls over the tongue so seductively and is accentuated with the most expertly crafted spices, primarily cloves, pepper and nutmeg.  Effervescent but smooth and full-bodied.  Chewy, lip-smacking malts.  Finish is defined by chocolate liqueur-filled truffles and a scarce trace of earthy, mild tobacco.  Utterly fantastic.

amazing beer.  Pours dark amber with a nice staying head.  The aroma is malty goodness, with a hint of banana.  The alcohol is slightly  present, but in a good way.  The flavor is malts, chocolate/toffee, and fruit.  Well crafted beer.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2005 Re-rate. My my i cant beleive i had this so low before, what a beer, appearance is something to watch forever. Aroma and flavour have the great dark fruit, yeasty, sweet, malty, general amazing goodness that i love about belgiun beers. I like this the way it is and ppl say its one to age so maybe if i can contol myself it is one to age for a while. But give me more first!

Bottle:  Pours a deep amber color with a large rocky sustaining tan head.  Aroma is all over the place with lots of dark dried fruits, earthiness, and some candy notes.  Flavor is very big, chocolate and faint roasted malts, sweet sugary malts (caramel and toffee) and raisens.  A lighter mouthfeel, and still the alcohol is barely recognizable.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 Bottle (330ml) At Volo.  Very fine slightly mocha looking head - quite lively, dark specks like fine-ground cinnamon.  Not much lacing.  Light but very appealing aroma with cloves, some alcohol, sweet malt, bar chocolate.  Colour is cloudy medium copper.  Taste is ... mild but complex, follows the nose, but not at all alcohol-overwhelming - its there, but under control.  Refreshing and slightly sweet.  One of the best ABT 12s Ive had - not quite to Westvlerteren 12 or the Rochefort 10, but close.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2005 Great, full bodied, fruity belgian beer. Lots of things all going on at once with this beer, very enjoyable. I have since had this on tap at Mahars. All I can say is wow, unbelievable.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2006 Delicious but very complex and difficult to analyze. It poured a rich brown with reddish highlights and a large frothy head. The nose was spicy and floral but not nearly as powerful as its mouthfeel. The high alcohol content (10%) came through very clearly to me. The flavor was malty and tart with undertones of caramel and plums. The finish was amazing, starting with a harsh bitterness that slowly mellows out into a very smooth creamy and sweet taste on the back of your tongue. I took long breaks between each sip to really appreciate that final evolution.

Nice dark brown color with a contrasting white head.  It gives off a wonderful fruity aroma.  Fruits and caramel are the flavors that come through.  No alcohol flavor in this beer despite the hight alcohol content.  One of my favorite Quads.
Bottle. Pours dark caramel color with large off white head. Nose is sweet plums and caramel. Mouth is medium body, bitter, with an alcohol warmth delay.

Bottle.  Nice opaque brown/black pour with a think white head.  Nice fruity spicy aroma,  with some spicy yeast.  Big mouth full of dark sweet malts and lots of dark druits - dates, plums, prunes, and surprisingly little peppery alcohol (well hidden).  Very nice quad

Bottle. Pours an opaque brown with a thick off white head. The head dissolved nicely leaving good lacing. I also picked up on a fair ammount of carbonation. Aromas were of yeast, floral notes and a hint of pineapple/ fruit. Flavor was malty and sweet up front, with fruity sugar flavors lingering on. I thought the mouthfeel was suprisingly full, and the alcohol was masked quite well. Overall very enjoyable.

Very dark, with a good head with some belgian lace.  The aroma has overwhelming variety, with spices, lavender, soap, coriander, and various others I cant identify.  

The taste is surprisingly tart, with some lingering sweetness - sour with some hints of vodka, with well masked alcohol.  Nice, but not exceptional.

#271009 printed on the back of the bottle.  Very murky brown body with a medium, creamy tan head.  Creamy-sweet aroma: orange zest, brown sugar, nutmegy custard, with a fluffy yeast that sort of ties it all together.  Big, sweet malty flavor: candi sugar, orange zest, rum, and that unifying yeast.  Bits of green bitter hops, too.  The usual big, sweet intense Belgian-y flavor.  Fun but not terribly interesting.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2013 The goofy guy gets it done. Poured a massive head in my St. Bernardus glass. Typical quadrupel color - dark red/brown. Aroma is overpowering with raisins, but theres also malt, alcohol, yeast, and some fruityness. Flavor is very strong, alcoholic and sweet. Raisins and alcohol dominate everything initially. As it warms it becomes more complex but remains overwhelmingly sweet.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 nice dark brown color w/ a frothy off white thick head that laced very well.  The first thing I smelled was a good bit of yeast then an odd dark fruit element smelled a light tart hop.  Palate is richly creamy a bit warming in the swallow and some decent carbonation.  The taste definatelly has a touch of alcohol hints of brown sugar and plums raisens and a hint of some other sweet fruits a definate carmel malt kick too.  Some very good stuff.

330 ml bottle purchased in the fall 2002. "Best Before" date expired in 2004, so I was anxious to see how well it had held up. Pours dark mahogany brown with a big, firm and lasting slightly brownish head. The aroma is dominated by dried fruit (figs, dates and prunes), fresh plums, chocolate and fresh cream. On the palate the beer is massive! Extremely full-bodied, soft and velvety, with the dried fruit element and the chocolate notes at the forefront. There is a nice warming sensation from the alcohol at the end, and the aftertaste hangs in the mouth for several minutes. A fantastic beer! I have had it several times, but always in relatively freshly bottled examples. From now on, I think I will lay down my bottles for a few years, as this transforms a normally very, very good beer into a sensational one.

When the body of this beer finally revealed itself from under its massive, rocky head, it was a particle-rich, copper/amber, holding dense texture. Potent aromas were heavily malted, starting woody, with caramel, nuts, banana and a metallic overtone that continued through to the taste. Flavor was thick and sweet with light acidity and a long finish. Full bodied and mellow with a syrupy texture. Very rich and  tasty, but dont drink too many consecutively.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Countryside, IL<font size=-1>

11.2 oz. bottle.  Best before:  October 5, 2009.  Deep, hazy ruby pour with a thick, sandy head.  Some effervescence.  Full aroma with some dark, sour fruits.  Creamy, medium to full body.  Goes down smooth, yet crisp.  Almost champagne-like in its sparkling crispness.  Warming alcohol is present throughout, especially at the end.  Thats really a distraction, as it takes away from the taste quite heavily.  A good amount of malts with hints of sour apples, bananas and figs.  The overwhelming presence of alcohol makes it hard to distinguish many flavors.  There is a lingering bitter perfumed quality that lasts long after each sip.  I had hoped for more than this.

Deep red with  a tan head. Clear. Rich, strong and fruity aroma with yeast and some perfume. Alcohol and dark caramel noticable. Is somewhat oxidized. Big bouquet of dark fruit in the flavor. Finishes with a well balanced alcohol presence and a lingering date and plum flavor. I like this one better on draught,  though having got this today off the unrefridgerated truck which got it from a container that shipped in May, it might not be a fair comparison. I have had a bottle of Chimay White that sat in my bar at room temp. for 8 years and had to have the cigarette stains washed off it before drinking, that was friggin amazing though. So go figure.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours to a lasting fizzy creamy looking off-white head atop a fizzy dark brown clear body.  Decent lacing.  The aroma hits with raisins and fresh cracked american walnuts, red apple peel, light bourbon.  Deliciously mixed aroma.  The flavor has banana, caramel, raisins, plums, apples, spices, vanilla, lots of malts.  The flavor is very strong and in your face.  The palate is very carbonated, almost too much so.  Fairly full bodied and creamy.  Overall, a good beer but not as good as Westy...  :).  I put in rating #555, a magical # for us Subaru guys...

Cloudy, murky brown, with a decent tan head. Fruity aroma, with notes of plum and raisin, then hints of walnut, whiskey and pine. The aroma is echoed in the taste - earthy pine, very faint hints of bourbon, caramel malt, and an alcohol burn at the finish. Cahampigne-like carbonation. Much, much tastier as it warms, I mustve poured it too cold. subtle hint of dark bread and a hint of blackberry. Alcohol burn is more muted, as well. More than the sum of its parts, well made and tasty. Thanks to Springslicker for this one!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2006 Bottle from Belgium.  Dark brown beer. with lots of flavours on the nose, not least raisins and chocolate.  For such a strong beer where you would expect lots of sweet alcohol, this has good drying tangy hops on the end.  An exceptionally good beer.
Deep reddish brown body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of cherries and green apples mixed with some caramel. Cherry, spices, blend of apples and malty alcohol flavor.  Full body.  Sweet finish.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 Smell is very relaxing like orange peels. i enjoy this beer year round very citrousy, the first sip numbs your taste buds. color is very complex very dark with a light redish look. Very important that you let it warm up and sip it slow to enjoy it. I actually brought a six pack to mexico and traded it for some good tequilla. Great mix. Bad hangover.

Smells like spring bloom at the Keukenhof.  Shared bottle number 200709 with my fiance at the Het Elfde Gebod bar in Amsterdam.  Complex as all hell taste with things like flowers and fruits leaping out at me.  Wow.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2007 Rerate 5-18-07
Very elegant with a brown fruity flavor and a bubbly palate to be enjoyed. Yes,l the finish draws me to this beer but there is more to be said. The taste has a certain exuberance to it as it is very well balanced with floral, fruit and a very yeasty accented tone.
Previous rating:
This one rocked my world as well as my buds who tasted it tonight. It started with a flowery smell. Aroma-wise it wasnt too striking but it made up for this in taste. I had a bottle aged from 1999. It had a very refined character that was smooth on my tongue with a flowery overtone, some malty tones underneath and some sweet carbonation. The alcohol was definately noticeable. One of my buds had a bottle of Chimay Blue and we noted that while this beer isnt as overpowering taste wise, its finer in many ways. I could drink the foam of this one! I gave it the Max dog test and he sniffed it and tried to sip it!

Another thank you to rich, seemed to be a dark cherry or ruby color, definitive like a soda pop.  Nice tan head that seems to keep a lid on whats in store.  Apple/yeast taste to it, banana hints in the finish. Im not a big abt fan yet but this helped me keep an open mind.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2005 appearance of a coke, dark brown but the head is creamy tan and never fades away.  aroma is of apples and bourbon. taste is excellent, with hints of yeast, tons of spices, and hints of apple and banana.  aftertaste holds the spicyness and is nice and sweet.  took me awhile to get to this, and im not disappointed.

Bottled:
Sweet nose with candy aroma. Fruity like apples, malty  and winey like a long stored red wine. Flavor is quite spicy, full bodied and warming. Light to medium sweet but good balanced astringent. Notes of plums, raisins, alcohol and malt.  Balancing bitterness. A real pleasure.
bottle. Dark red / burgundy appearance.  Fruity aroma with some bready features.  Tastes of fuits and hints of bannas and cloves.  Went down like candy. A good beer

Dark burgundy colour with a large mocha coloured head. Rich aroma with the expected yeast notes along with dried fruit (dates, apricot), caramel & wood. Flavour isnt quite as complex as I was expecting, but is still very good - moare dark fruit and caramel, malt and molasses, a bit of chocolate, and some coffee and smoke in the finish along with warm booze in the throat. I lingered over a 33 cl bottle for almost two hours, and it improved with every sip.

Belgian wheat aroma with some faint sweet, candy notes evident upon deeper inhale. Pours a nice big off-white head. Brownish red in color with large particalia. Muddy and almost opaque. Very nice lace. Head lasts. Why is it that so many brews just cannot get a long lasting head? My first impression is that of high carbonation. I followed a La Fin Du Monde with this brew and this is clearly better. When I had this for the 1st time a few weeks ago at an in store tasting at Cellars Minnetonka, it seemed overly carbonated and airy and was perhaps served too warm. I am enjoying this go around much better. Caramel notes. This is a little overly carbonated for my tastes, otherwise, a beer of exceptional quality and perfect sweetness.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 (Bottle 33 cl) Very dark with a beautiful and stable head. Lots of malty flavours, caramel, dried fruits - all the best to find in a top-Belgian. Very full-bodied with awarming alcohol. Amazing average of this beer through no less than 541 ratings.... 260993

My bottle is warming and is almost ready for its uncorking. This is my first caged, capped and corked beer. Im anxious. I must admit that I have fears about this bottle, as with other top end Belgians I bought from the store. They spent time in a continously lighted cooler, potential months. The Orval and Rochefort 10 were lucious, the Traquair and Founders Imperial Stout were not. Im hoping this falls on the right side of the spectrum. The cork ejects quickly, with vicious power. Carbonation is rising. I sniff the cork. A vinous winy typical cork aroma seeps up my nostrils. Slowly into the Tulip glass goes the beer, it develops a healthy, yet uneven head. Its a pearlescent ivory tone, with fine bubbles and a clearing center. So far so good. To the nose: cherries, plum and a swirling reminsicense of an overdone scotch ale with port and currants. Honey and wine bring back the airy thoughts of a fresh flower field and a dose of potpourri. Savory tones creep in from the sides, with aged oak, balsamic, and juniper berries. The aroma is complex, but not glowing. Brought to the light, this beer glows of deep dark cranberry juice, flecked with yeast like a fresh robins egg. The yeast stays well suspended in a clear blood beer. The beer is opalescent, running from amber to golden to deep red. The carbonation is fine like Champagne. This should be good. Unfortunately on the palate, Im let down. Its a scotch ale, with sherry. Theres more, but first, Im dissapointed. This is one dimensional. When the beer is in my mouth, it bursts into a fury of carbonation and turns into foam. Its not clingy, oily, or sugary. Just a slightly sweet beer, with some water to wash it down. The beer really expands and foams in the mouth, which isnt really a desirable trait for me, since it doesnt give my tounge a chance to participate, instead it just hints at a touch of its taste and then leaves an aftertaste. The flavor is dominated by brandy, apples, and plum pudding. That rich, lucious deep wheat and yeast are most omnipresent, really showing strongly in the middle. The alcohol bursts on the back end, adding a nice growing warmth to the profile. Raisins, sherry and port make flash apperanaces, but dont detract from the quality. I dont think this beer has suffered any age or light damage, it just is what it is. The aftertaste is dominated by green apples and butter diacetyls. The palate is average, with a drying trend. The complexity is pretty good, but the texture and depth seem one dimensional. As the beer has warmed some more, its starting to show more nuances and unveil subtlties, but nothing jumps out at me, the beer just gains more body, tone and depth. The texture gains some chewiness and fullness. A fruit swirl laced on top of a rich yeast and sugar base, with some deeper notes. Overall, Im somewhat let down, but generally pleased with the way the beer has gone, although it leaves me longing for more. Ive enjoyed my time with it, but look forward to new horizons down the road. How fitting for how this past semester of school has gone and my thoughts of a friend I wish I could be closer to. This beer is a true tribute of the evening.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2005 Terrific.  I bought this at Michaels Bistro to celebrate my last exam of college  and it rose to the occasion.  Strong flavor and aroma, yet so smooth and easy to drink.  I look forward to trying it again.  Cloudy hazel brown color with a hint of amber.  Diminishing tan head.  Good lacing entire time.  Strong, sweet aroma smelling of apple and grape covered with chocolate or caramel.  	Definitely smooth.  Bubbles dance on your tounge the whole way down.  Very well balanced.  Tastes of nuts and sweet fruit.  Also coffee and toffee.

Pours a dark, hazy brown with a huge, dense, tan head. Very lacy. Aroma is very fruity. Tart apples with a light alcohol smell. Some raisin and winey aromas as well.

Taste is very fruity. Spiced apples and white raisins. Some port flavors hanging around, dancing in and out of the alcohol. Caramel and molasses. Part of this flavor profile reminds me of mulled wine.
Mouth is sweet and sticky. Really smooth for 10% ABV. This is excellent but could be aged just a bit to blend the alcohol flavors better. Lived up to the hype for me...

(bottle) Murky brown colour with a foamy tanned head. Yeasty nose with dried fruits and caramel. Soft sweet flavour and a complex taste rounded up with elements of spicy liquorice, nuts and plums on a toastmalty bed with a bittersweet finish. The alcohol is good embedded.

From a 750 mL. Pours a deep brown color with a thick and lasting white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with hints of caramel and toffee. Rich and sweet flavor with hints of caramel and brown sugar along with a roasted nut taste. Some alcohol burn near the end of the bottle but not offensive. Great beer.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2005 Poured a deep reddish-amber with about 1" creamy ivory head. Some sediment noted.  Excellent head retention.  Floral and fruity aroma with grapes, apples, and oak coming through.  Full-bodied, and powerfully complex flavor, but the fruit and oak were very well balanced.  Mouthfeel was creamy, yet well-carbonated.  Fruity aftertaste was very pleasant, and the beer warmed the stomach well.  I am assuming that this is a recent vintage (expiry date 7.20.09), so I will put the rest of these away for a few years, and re-rate at that point.

pours a dark, dark red/brown. nice lasting off-white, fizzy head.  yeasty, fruity aroma. bready, sweet taste, somewhat fruity, and a little alcohol in there too, but it is well balanced, for 10%. medium/full bodied, with crisp carboation. good, complex beer.

What a great beer.  Pours a nice dark amber with quite a bit of sediment.  Aroma is what you would expect from a great belgian.  Its sweet, malty and slightly caramelly as well.  Flavor is well balanced and you really cant tell this is 10% .  Its malty, and caramelly, and belly warming all at once.  Truly deserving of its high rating.
Poured a mostly clear amber color.   Aroma and flavors of  fruit with sugar and alcohol and a touch of cherry.  Semi-dry.  Not too sweet and nicely balanced.  Slightly smokey.

Very complex strong Belgian.  Head stays with the drink the entire time just about. The alcohol taste was a little too up front and not very well hidden. At times was almost coming across as having wine like characteristics.  I actually like some of the other St. Bernardus beers better, but this is still a solid beer.

Poured iced tea brown with an off white head. Noticable yeast floating in the body with a good amount of carbonation.  Sweet malty aroma with hints of fruits. Flavor was sweet bread with a variety of fruits: apple, pear, strawberry, and plum. Creamy texture with a huge malt body. Finishes dry and is a little on the sweet side.

On tap at the Publick House. Dark brown with a large foamy head. Largely malty aroma, spiced brown bread, pears, raisins. Incedibly well-balanced, soft, rich and sweet, all kinds of fruits swirling around, some alcohol burn. A beautiful and delicious beer.

bottle at ciros. interesting aroma: large yeast component, pear among other fruits, rich complex maltiness, some tartness, and a bit of cheese funkiness. burgundy body, generous foamy tan head. big malty body, yeasty, fruity sweetness, warm alcohol. very complex. lively carbonation. very nice.

Cloudy brown colour with an off-white head.
Sweet aroma dominated by yeast and dried fruit with notes of alcohol and spices.
Sweet aroma of yeast, chocolate, liquorice and dried fruit.
Nice, but not the best quadrupel Ive had.

Dark nut brown with a thick tan/brown head that hangs around for a long time.  Aroma is fruity like grape soda.  Flavor is malty with hints of plums and raisins.  The palate creamy and smooth with a strong alcohol warmth on the backside and a somewhat bitter yet sweet taste left in your mouth.  Very complex and worthwhile to be in the top 50.  The more I drank it the more I liked it...  The head hangs around the whole way down the glass.  My first Abt/Quadrupel..  And I think it was a good choice..  It wont be my last!

Bottled (BB 10/2009)
My 1000th rating, also nice to reach place 50 in  "the most ratings from Belgium RB TOP50 list" with this beer. 
Dark hazy nut brown, tight brown head. Aroma of licorice, grapefruit, Pernod, sweet plums and apricot. Flavor has raisins, licorice, roasted malts and lots of alcohol - palate is more rude than in Westy12. Funny beer: same time creamy smooth mouthfeel and whiskey-like alcoholic burn. Very long alcoholic bitter aftertaste. Complex beer and worth of its fame but not par with Westy12.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2006 Its possible that this Belgian quadrupel improves with age, but this sample disappointed. Poured a dark chocolate brown colour with a huge rocky head that receded fairly quickly but barely laced. The aroma was phenolic, with an unusual gingery quality, hints of a raw leathery merlot and a splash of paint, whisky barrel and distant bitter chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel, medium-bodied rather than "full". Initial flavour profile includes raisins, dark malt and baked apples. The alcohol is well integrated but the finish has the phenolic quality of the aroma. Theres a lot to like here but I dont think it bears comparison to the Rochefort 10. Bugger - I was really looking forward to this one.... (Bottle, best before 12/8/09)
Rerate 1/2/05: had a couple of these since that have been far superior to the first. Its fast becoming a favourite.

This beer is as brown as they come. Also has a head that lasts to the bottom of the glass -- not many beers other than Belgians can do this. Very fruity bubblegum aroma. Flavor is rather complex, with a strong malt element and a surprising amount of hops, of all things, showing through in a 10% beer in which the alcohol is so well hidden! Flavor also carries strong elements of walnut, ruby port and nutmeg. Nice beer .. courtesy of potbelly monks. Kings and Queens of the earth surely drink this in their vomitoria!

The aroma is sweet and has a definite cheese and roasted malt presence along with floral hops. It is an orange-brown color with a big fluffy white beautiful head that I have come to expect on a St. Bernardus. The Flavor is like toasted, sweet malt with a hint of plum and allspice. Medium bitterness and despite the 10% alcohol content it is not overly strong. Complex aftertaste that has all the elements of the drink itself.

Sampled at Brewtopia 2005.  Poured light brown with a thick creamy off-white head.  Strong dark fruit aroma.  Tasted of dark fruits and alcohol.  A good strong belgian, but I didnt find it to be as layered, sweet, or as complex as Westy 12.  Theres been a lot of debate as to whether this beer can be considered an inexpensive alternative to Westy, but I think theres no replacing #1.
Bottle.  Very dark red, almost black in color.  Glad I saved this one for last.  It has a very sweet malty aroma and a taste that is smooth, warming and eqallly sweet.  A real good drink.
dark brown. thick creamy off white tan head. leaves some nice lacing in the glass. has a malty and fruity aroma. taste is fruity and malty has a smooth creamy mouthfeel. awsome.
on tap at the maproom, served st bernardus chalice,  huge rocky head.  creamy mouthfeel, some apple, warming alcohol sensation.
Tap at Maprom-Deep dark brown with a big brown head. Nutty with characters like nutbread. Bold yeast flavors with some very subtle fruit notes.
Murky dark brown with an off white head.  Apples, alcohol, and nuts in the aroma.  Taste is apples, grapes, some chocolate and raisins.  NIce alcohol warmth in the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2006 Bottle, dark brown, creamy off-white head, moderate lacing, aroma of malt and alcohol with a twinge of sweetness, taste is much better...get molasses, raisins and a very sweet fruitiness thats not overpowering but smooth,  I could drink one of these everyday.

One of the best beers ive had yet. This Belgian is very creamy and silky. Pours a dark brown with a monstrous head. Head retention is incredible as well. Has dark-fruit flavors such as raisins. Will buy many times!
Another nut brown colored ale from Belgium for me to try. A more sour brew than the Leute Bokbier it had a more floral aroma. Unfortunately wasnt one that I enjoyed drinking.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2005 Pours an off white, frotthy head. Already when smeling the beer you can smell the high alcohol contend. Has a strong taste of prunes and port. A little too much of alcohol in the taste for my liking. Personally, I prefer the St. Bernardus Prior 8

750 ml.  River green/brown color with an ever-present cap of lace.  Apple, spice, and yeasty alcohol dominate the nose.  Great malty mouthfeel with excellent balance of balance with the alcohol.   Finishes  a little short with some sour bitterness.

Dark hazelnut brown with a airy tan head.  Good head retention for a while and died down to a thin crown that lasted for the duration.  Some small sediment pieces.  I really like the look on this one.  Very complex nose...caramel covered peaches, heavy on the malt, apples, sugar and alcohol.  Good appetizing aroma.  Flavor is smooth.  Again, very heavy on the malt, fruity, sugary and sweet, caramel, vanilla, peaches and apples.  Creamy with a good body.  Finishes peppery, not surprising with 10% alc.

From the tap.  Huge malty aroma with light fruit.  This beer looks great.  There is a huge brown head that lasts almost too long as you wait to drink it.  It slowly dies down to a rocky head, and finally leaves a thick lace on the glass.  Flavor of medium-sweet malt.  There is fruit and minor spice qualities.  After taste is also light fruit.  Very heavy palate.  Definitely a sipper; it is a beer to take your time with.

Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  The head is long-lasting.  Quite a bit of sedimentation to see in there too.  This was a very tasty beer.  Very smooth.  You would never know it contained %10abv.  Great beer.

Tap at Blue Nile, Minneapolis.  Pours tasty walnutty amber with attractive foam.  Malty, sweet yet balanced, tender mouthfeel, with traces of hazelnut (or sometimes pistachio gelato with a drip of raspberry).  Uber tasty.
Strange style of beer altogether.  Incredible soft body for such strong alcohol, and well hidden at that.  Shows what a true craft beer making can be.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2005 Perfect 5 points on the appearance b/c of the constant lacing as well as the constant head. Malty dark fruit aroma. Slight alcohol flavor. Rich, smooth and very drinkable like all St. Bernardus ales. Flavor is malty and fruity(prunes?). Somewhat chewy to the palate. Dont know if its worthy of a 99 rating but its definitely a nice ale.
This beer is Gods gift to us.  Simply amazing!!!  How a beer with this much Alcohol content can taste so good is genious!

750 mL bottle.  Had to crack this one to mark the beginning of March Madness.  Dark brown and murky.  Good head that leaves a great lacing.  The first thing I noticed was the initial aroma burst, banana, sweet bread, plums, figs, and malts.  Flavor was very vinous, very winelike.  Alcohol was masked pretty well.  When chilled, its very malty, a little chocolate.  As it warms, it picks up dark fruits (figs, raisins, plums)  Dry finish, but not bitter in the least.  Overall, its pretty decent

Opaque dark brown w/ lots of sediment. Lasting, creamy, rocky beige foam. Very nice lace. Aroma is richly malty (dark bread, cookie dough, caramel), fruity (plums, raisins), chocolaty, & yeasty (bubble gum). Silky, full-bodied feel. Complex, malty, yeasty flavour w/ a slightly sour edge.

Bottle at the Alex P Keaton in London, Ontario. Pours a dark brown body, with a being head that is huge and frothy. Look at all of this sedimentation here, awesome! Aromas are corriander,raisins, alcohol. Taste is raisns, alcohol, malts, other fruits, bread. Finish is nice, warming, sweet alcoholish prune taste. Nice example of the style!

The brewery that used to make the westy beers. World class stuff. Berries and plums with pears and raisins, soft cocoa and brownsugar. Full bodied great mouthfeel. Some candy sugar and apple notes, with mild anise. Incredible finish that makes you grab for the next exquisite sip.

Big ass bottle.  this got a red brown color with a nice tan head. smell sweet like a cookie, sugary..sweet malty  rasiny, fig kida flava.really a rich beer,chewy kida, . MO flavas of friut , caramel slightly. alcohol is not  really present  very good one

Cellar Temp. Fantastic aromas of sweetbreads, sugarplums, and coffeecake. Dark burgundy with a true, sustaining head. Remarkable progression of flavors. Somewhat sweet with rich, highly complex maltiness. Dark molasses, soft caramel, prunes with hints of strawberrys and cherries. The sip is then transformed by the effevesence into a holy symphony of alcohol light vinous notes and dark fruits backed  chorus of Bing cherries (not cherry flavor). Proves that Franklin was correct; He does love us.
On tap, Map Room Chicago. Deep brown-red. Tight off-white head. Soft mouthfeel. Nice slate-ish and raisin-fig-date fruit sweet flavors.  Drier finish than I was expecting. Outstanding.

Pours cloudy dark brown with a thick off-white head. Aroma of pears, banana, yeast, pizza dough, and earthiness. Taste has notes of caramel, toffee, roasted/toasted malts, figs/dark fruits, chocolate, yeast, apple, molasses and spiciness on the back end. Pretty sweet. Alcohol content very well hidden. Body is full, round and very smooth with subtle carbonation. Good head retention. Really nice stuff.

Pours  a cloudy orange/brown color with a small offi-white tiny bubble head. The aroma is complex, with raisins, plums, amd fruity yeast esters (and some alcohol).  The flavor is just as complex, both smooth and spicy, with the same array of flavors as in the aroma. It does not finish sweet, but slightly malty and spicy. Outstanding.

A hugely flavorful and richly complex Belgian Quad. Pours a cloudy reddish brown color beneath a thick, dense enduring off-white head. Presents rich aromas of yeast rolls, figs, raisins, brown sugar and black licorice or anise. The palate is full, smooth and quite chewy; especially as the ale warms. The flavors are a myriad of dark fruitcake, toffee, caramel, malt and spices. This Quads obvious sweetness is perfectly balanced by the 10% alcohol and just a hint of hops in the finish. This Belgian treat would be hard to beat. Worth every $!

pours a cloudy reddish-brown with a ton of sediment floating around. Nice sized, tan head. Aroma is raisins, malt, salt, and dark fruit. Wouldnt exactly call this creamy, although it does seem to get more so as it warms.. Very bubbly and has some sour spice in the finish. Rest of the taste is caramel, dark cherries, raisins, yeast, liquorice. Noticeable alcohol taste.

Bottle- At the Alex P. Keaton in London, Ontario. Poured a dark brown body, medium beige head. HUGE sediment visible....almost syrup looking. Nice lacing, and the head seems to form rings in the middle of the body, very distinct. Perfect. Aromas are black licorice, rasins and prunes, saltiness, and some floral spiceyness. Taste is floral, spicy, rasins and prunes , sweet an salty, licorice too. Nice! Finish is alcohol, bitter sour aftertaste too. Great example of the style! Watch out Westy!

this is one i just never have had....its been sitting in the cellar forever. almost forgot i had it.  not going to bore you with the huge chunky sandy brown head that enveloped into my glass or the dark brown murky nectar that lurked below,  it was the nose that got my attention.... probably a little too cold at first but a huge yeasty fresh bread feel  notes of brown sugar and cinammon.  fuckn insane in the nose, different and fantastic.  palate was a silky smooth malty delight of dark fig flavor, toffee, rock candy, tobacco, more spices.  not way over the top, trying to be too big or cloying but just right...couldnt taste the alcohol at all, even as it warmed. good stuff!!  i wanna taste this side by side with a westy for comparison?

330ml bottle. Thanks Sammy...finally got around to quaffing this bad boy. Pours murky in my goblet... redish- brown highlights when held to the light...lots of sediment in suspension and on the bottom of the bottle. Fat meringue like tan head, which lasts until the last gulp....excellent lacing. Light carbonation...  aroma of dark fruits, rum, wine, alcohol and bready malts. Effervescent up front, followed with a complex array of flavors...dried dark fruits, nuts, red grape wine and  spicey yeast.... Long finish bread dough, yeasty, almonds and rum in the after taste. As the ale warms in the goblet the malts become cookie dough sweet, spicer and more intoxicating...what a whallop...all ale should be like this.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2013 Aroma of malt mixed with oaky, agricultural smells. Pours dark brown, decent head that disappears around the edges but stays thick in the middle and lasts to the end leaving decent lacing. Taste is a pleasantly bitter maltiness at first and then sweet malt with hints of oak, caramel and spices. The alcohol content, 10%, is noticeable. Excellent balance its very easy drinking and overall a highly recommended beer.

Thanks to slikwily for this one.  Pours dark brown with an average light brown head with fair lacing and a small dollop remaining in the center.  Aroma is oak nose, caramel malt and yeast.  Flavor is warm caramel with alcohol and creamy malt.  Full-bodied and  dark palate.

Thanks to Jim for sharing this gem. Poured amber/brown, with a small head. Sweet malt aroma with some yeast in the background. Lots of tiny fizzy bubbles to spread the cheer. This was malty, with a dry creamy finish. Very warming also, must be the utter smoothness in this 10% brew. Excellent.

Murky brown reddish brown.Some floaties.so what?? I am drinking them down.Heaven.Pure heaven,that wonderful Belgian yeast sweet dark exotic fruits.Ahhh,the good life.I wonder what the BMC drinkers are doing now??
Rich malts and some coriander.makes me wonder:what do you find interesting in Bud Light?? sweet and fruity.Did I mention heaven?? Great mouthfeel.Thank you God.

Very bold aroma...pours very dark with a light brown head that lasts. Flavor consists of malts, maple syrup, and yeast. Alcohol is present but does not dominate. Thick and rich on the way down with a surprisingly light and sweet aftertaste.

Creamy and adherent foam; optimal persistence. Color dark brown, not excessive dense but very bubbly. Optimal aspect. Determined scent and much alcoholic one; strongly in the nose. Much flowery with liquorice notes. Good persistence. I believed was better seen the great publicity.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2007 Bottle. Aroma is mostly yeasty with a hint of brown sugar. Dark reddish brown colour, semi-stable brown head. Suspended yeast. Peppery flavour. Warming alcohol. Flavour of dark malts with a hint of bitter aftertaste. Some sweetness, but well-hidden by the alcohol. Very peppery and beautifully bready. Thick, creamy mouthfeel that almost tickles, perhaps due to the alcohol. Hm, there IS a lot of alcohol in this, isn’t there?

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2005 750ml btl. Dark, nutty brown beer with a moderate head, nice lacing, and a brief release of gasses. Taste is well balanced: nuts, chocolate, overripe fruit, malts, cinnamon, anise, and alcohol are all noticable flavours. Amazingly creamy, smooth mouthfeel, especially when swished around. A damn fine beer for the price and availability. Its my fourth fave beer, after westy 12 and rochefort 10 and 8. DRINK SOME NOW!
WOW...strong stuff! Almost a honey mead, yet creamy and smooth. Almost too sweet, but I enjoyed it. Definitly worth the price and lived up to the hype.

330 ml. bottle. Pours a gorgeous thick, dark brown with some yeast detritus evident and a large, creamy beige head that lasted and lasted.  Aroma is molasses, brown sugar, dark brown bread, spices - coriander and clove most noticibly - with rich sweet malts.  Flavor is smooth and sweet and complex with cinnamon, nutmeg, molasses, mellow oak and raisin leaving an astringent finish.  High alcohol content is well hidden in the rich flavors.  Full body, smooth and light, creamy carbonation.  My favorite of the abbey ales so far I think.

I tried the Abt 12 from St. Bernardus last night. I drank it with dinner, in a goblet, from a 750mL bottle. It was purchased at Harrys in Marietta. I kept it in the refrigerator, but let it cool to just under room temperature. I might have let it warm too much. 

AROMA- Very nutty with distinct hops and slightly smokey-caramel aroma. A big, dense head that kept growing and growing 

TASTE- Big, chewy mouth-feel. Tastes of cardamom, caramel, raisins, bourbon. It also seemed slightly salty to me in an odd sort of way. Distinctive flavor of alcohol. Very abbey-y (abbeyish?) I had expected more of a dry hopiness, but it was actually quite sweet. Not overly carbonated, impressive head production aside. 

AFTERTASTE- lingering raisin and malt.

Warm brown beer with beige creamy head. Powerfull aroma of dark malts, caramel, spice, sweet cakes and dry fruits like raisins. Dens mouthfeel with a sexy fizziness. Taste is malty, chocolate, nuty and light fruity. Wow this is good stuff.

Bottle. Dark brown beer with a huge beige head. Fruity, malty, yeasty, alcoholic aroma that draws you in for more. Warming full body. Alcohol definately present. Date/raisin/plum flavors. Despite alcohol presence its easy to drink and otherwise well balanced and complex. Alcohol just dominates. If you like an alcohol presence, youll like this over a Rochefort 10, but otherwise it pulls you attention away from everything else.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2009 Upgraded 3/12.  Had this with avec fromage de chevre.  Enjoyable.


My bias is towards hops (sickening amounts of them), so my reaction to a yeasty-bubbly-carbonationy presentation is slightly short of euphoric.  Sweet, slightly sticky, airy-bubbly body, some head at first but dies off.  Ends up like an Arrogant Bastard in appearance in color and transparency, abstracted from everything else including head or foam retention.  Fruity in a general sort of way.  Ive got a 4-pack of the stuff, so my rating could change on subsequent attempts at joyful consumption.
I think Ive got some stunted scent-receptors, because I just dont detect the complexity in this much less many other of the beers.  I seem to go on intensity more than anything, hence little variance in my scores on this component.  Is it fig in this one?  Alright already, just punch me in the nose with a fistful of hops and Ill be back in my element.

11.3oz bottle. 63.5°. NB worthy glass. Poured  dark chocolate brown with a 1 1/2" billowy head. Lots of sediment floating at the bottom of the glass. The foam makes it home all over the sides of the glass.  I am a foot or so away from the glass and the aroma is wafting up to me.  When I bend down to smell it, the smell is malty, plums, raisins,  bananas and yeast. The smell is wonderful. The taste is very similar to the aroma, with some breadiness to go along with all the dark ripe fruits and wonderful esters along with a big dose of dark brown sugar.  Maybe it is because of the higher temp that I am enjoying this at, but the alcohol is noticeable, in fact it is a bit detracting.  The finish is fruity and spicy with that alcohol coming through as well.  The beer has a nutty, sweetish aftertaste. The mouthfeel is outstanding, it feels really full in the mouth, especially before the head dies down.  This is a fine beer, it is more forward than Westys 12, which I found to be good, but restrained.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2013 nice aroma and decent body.  very drinkable for its strength.  sweet and fruity, a nice quad overall. 2/8/2005

2009 (4 yr old) vintage.  massive caramel aroma with toasty chocolate flavor.  much smoother and chewier than a new bottle.  4/2/2013

33cl  bottle BB end 0f 2004, I carried it back from Belgium in early 2003.  THis one was very excited to get out of the bottle!  Big aroma with somewhat rancid dimensions, meaning medicine, phenols.  Stale rasins, prunes, leather, maybe plums too, why not?  All of that carries in the sweet malty body.  I step outside on a crisp 2*C Nebraska eve to let the pug puppy out. A neighbor has a fire burning and smoke lingers in the air on this still eve...ah, how nice a rauch abt would be!  The negative aroma comments fade, the beer highlights chocolate and honey of the dark sort.  Some decent bitterness helps add some finesse.  A fine fruit-laden beer.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2005 A very good quadruple, very much taste and the most important, for me, not too much taste of the alcohol.

Bottle from the Offie, Leicester. Very dark, verging on black, with a big ice creamy head. Tasty, strong aroma, laced with thick berries and wine. Some good elements here: smooth, insistent choc towards the finish; with a hint of raisin in the mouth. However I was put off a little by the icey, vodka wave of strength which hits almost immediatly. A little too overpowering for me, but I can see why its so well regarded.

Ten years ago I picked up a gift pack containg four different of the Bernardus beers. At the time, I thought the 12 okay but the 8 the star of the show.  Nobody agreed with me.  It looks like people still dont, but my preference is towards the middle versions of these similar lineups (Bernardus, Westvleteren, Rochefort).  This is a dark murky brown with a thick foam.  The aroma is unbalanced - all yeast (dust mainly, but some funk too), with hints of figs, plums and toffee.  The flavour is better with chewy malt depths, more dates, a little bit of chocolate and a sturdy alcohol backbone.  Actually, that alcohol is a little too sturdy.  Fruitcake notes appear as well.  The finish is quite alcoholic and sweet, with not nearly enough nuances to justify a rave.  Its rich, but not all that complex.  Now, where can I buy that Prior?

Pours a gorgeous muddy brown color with ruby highlights and a thick light brown head. Mind blowing aroma of fruits, caramel, liquorice, alcohol, peppermint, spices and yeast ... well, I guess the aroma is kind of complex... Excellent flavor of fruits, caramel, liquorice, peppermint, spices and alcohol with a sweet finish. Medium body, very creamy and smooth texture, soft carbonation. This is Belgian heaven and the clouds are made of heavy dark malt.

33cl. bottle:  I finally got around to trying one of these.  It pours a cloudy, brown color.  There was some off-white head to it, which died down fairly rapidly.  The aroma was not quite as strong as I would have expected.  Very pleasant, but a hair lighter.  The aroma is rich and complicated.  There are many kinds of fruits in the mix, but the  complexity is making it hard for determining individual notes.  The taste is superb.  A complicated sweetness, with a tart underlying flavor.  Fruits, caramel, heaven.  Superb.

This is by far the best beer Ive tried.  To me its taste is perfection in every way. I feel like Im in heaven (or heaven is in my mouth) when I drink this.  The colour is dark brown with a nice frothy tan head that lasts and laces the glass.  The aroma is so inviting you just wanna dive in.  The taste is molasses, yeast, banana, figs and brown sugar...sweet aftertaste the alcohol is very well hidden. If this stuff were regularly available here Id turn into an alcoholic.

Something about the taste reminds me of gulden drak, but its appealing brown shades and off white fizzy head make this one a strong ale keeper.  Very good flavour of oranges and citrus.  A tad strong on the body, but ever so smooth.

Pours dark brown with a pillowy off-white body. Gorgeous appearance. Winelike aroma, with ripe fruits and a definite zestyness to spice up the bouquet. Very thick, smooth and sweet. Warm flavours, raisins, plums, a hint of almonds; even a bit smoky. Full bodied. Finish is rather hoppy, bitter, and dry. Nice beer.

dark amber color with nice fluffy off white head. Aroma has candi sugar, raisens, figs, caramel apples, with subtle vanilla, a hint of coffee. Flavor is round, dry, sweet and malty, nutty, brown sugar and a touch of maple, with a faint alcoholic bitterness in the finish. Could have been a bit less carbonated. A fantastic brew. Im actually surprised it took me this long to try it.

At first i thought this is terrible.  Then I read the bottle and allowed it to warm a bit and it was wonderful.  Pours kind of like a cloudy coke with a nice tan head.  Smelled like a yeast roll but the flavor was very nice with hints of nuts vinilla and maybe some brown sugar.  Either way this is a very nice quad indeed.

33cl bottle.  Pours a lovely cloudy red (blood red when held to a candle).  White head was there, but then petered out to a sort of glazing.  Quite an excellent aroma..bananas and peaches.  Of course the yeast was ever-present.  Tastes almost like a wine, perhaps a merlot, with ample carbonation in the first sip, but a wee bit less as the drink went on.  Excellent taste and very appetizing beer.  A wee bit expensive, but worth it for a rare occasion!

Dark murky brown in color with large, light brown head.  Aroma was yeasty, but not all that pronounced. Perhaps it is the food cooking in the kitchen throwing me off.  Great taste, moderatly sweet light brown sugar, butterscotch, nutty and a hint of vanilla.  Like it says on the bottle, very well balanced.  Tasty... I will have it again.

Bottled. Cloudy brown/red coloured. Big head, which leaves very fine lace. Aroma is malty, caramelly, alcoholic in a vineous sense and some hints of what reminded a bit of camembert. Taste is yeasty, fruity (banana) with notes of cloves and choclate. Full-bodied and very smooth. This beer leaves a warming sensation and I felt the alcohol rather strongly. A very nice and complex beer.

A murky brew for sure, almost swirling in the glass after a gentle pour from the bottle.  Aromas of wine, mustiness, slight alcohol and apples.  Full bodied, wonderful complex taste with each sip.  This is BEER.  A strong ale for sure as one small beer has me buzzin.
For 10% ABV, this one sure hides it well.  Sweet, malty, hoppy- an all around good drink.  Sip this one slowly and enjoy it as it warms.  Yummy.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: 12oz bottle. Part of the gift pack that came with the neat glass. Nice dark amber/brown pour with a small, uneven coca head.  Taste fuses vanilla and roasted nut/toffee flavour but well balanced and smooth. Palate follows suit. Alchohol well hidden, almost defined.  enjoyable all around

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2015 Rerate at Ölrepubliken 150701. Tried it several times the last few years. Either I have changed or the beer have changed. But this is definately bot a 5.0-beer in My book anymore. 
RERATE 060624. I loved this beer the very first time I had it. Since then I have tried it several times on both bottle and tap. And I just like it more and more each time. Simply wonderful, I just cant get enough of it. 

(Old rating: 10/4/9/5/17)
Dark amber, nice lasting offwhite head. Great malty aroma with hazelnuts and other nuts, along with vanilla and malt. Malty dry and nutty flavor with vanilla and cream. Very complex and with a great body. Alcohol is well hidden.
UPDATED: DEC 16, 2016 From a bottle.Dried blood in colour,small head,sweet malt,chocolate biscuits with your coffee flavours.Big and warm.

Bottle, Cafe Volo.  Dark Brown pour.  I had a bit of a cold, but I didnt get a strong aroma - more of a muted mixture of sweet malt and a little spiciness.  Tan head that was pretty active - lots of bubbles.  This transferred over to the mouthfeel - very active and bubbly as well.  Strong malt character to taste, a very assertive beer featuring lots of sweetness (a hint of chocolate, but not as predominant as others have made it out to be) and certainly some alcohol, but not overpowering.  This is a perfectly balanced beer.  Heaven in a glass was my final verdict; it is hard to describe but this beer, combined with a wonderful setting of a corner table at Volo with the welcoming company of the owner Ralph on a cold windy night outside, made this one of my best beer drinking experiences in Toronto ever.

Pours hazy red brown with a big lasting off white sudsy head. Aroma is a little barnyard and funky with musty yeast and crusty malts. Lots of stale brown bread in the flavours with berries and a smidgen of citrus hop bitters. Predominated by earth, roasted chocolate and biscuity malts. Alcohol extremely well hidden. More ripe red berry flavour than fig/plum/raisin  I would expect from and Quadrupel. Good.
An excellent tasting beer with a noticeable taste of alcohol.  Chocalate tasting and full of spices.

11.2oz bottle from gift pack with glass.  Muddy brown with a big tan head and lacing everywhere.  Very nice aroma of sweet malt, fruit, and alcohol.  First sip is a bit of a shock.. since the other beers in the gift pack were mild and understated, the big flavors here were unexpected..  This one is big, with intense flavors of dark fuitcake and rum, sweet malt, and a slight bitter finish.  Some warming alcohol on the way down, but its well hidden in the excellent flavor.  Even though the flavors are intense, they come through smooth and pleasant, almost too easy to drink.  Well deserving of its 4.13 average rating, its pretty close to awesome.  Easily the best quad I have tasted.  It gets better with each sip, and I like that!

A little sweet, but I found it to be very smooth and well-blended. Definitely an ale that I enjoy drinking. Light carbonation. The flavors are mostly in the malt range.  Subtle aroma... hard to define. Worth trying, for sure. I found the alcohol to be barely detectable.

Dark brown with ruby highlights.  Small tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt, fruit and alcohol.  Body is a bit lighter than expected.  Vineous sweet malt flavor.  Alcohol evident in the flavor.  Very nice, and certainly an effective winter warmer after shoveling the snow, but does not quite hit the high marks that other raters have given it.

Nr. 100!! Yes! Darkish color, nice big white bobble head. Hoppy/sweet aroma. Flavor, powerfull sweet/smokey/alcohol start, the extreme tasty start melting in your mouth, and turn into a sweet smokey toffee finish! NICE!!!!

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [33 cl. bottle] Very dark and muddy brown color with a thick and fluffy white head. Very thick and complex aroma of sweet malts, dark fruit and alcohol. The flavor is extremely fruity and sweet. Mainly dark fruits like cherries or plums with a nice, sweet malt body and a sweet and warming alcohol finish. Very smooth and creamy.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2011 23-11-10 bottle. Aroma is perfect blend of all kinds of dark fruit, raisin, plum, faint banana, candied fruit sweetness in the background. Flavor on par with aroma. Tons of dark fruit. Plums, fig, raisin, candied fruits, faintest hint of alcohol. While highly carbonated, still has a soft/billowy mouthfeel. Notes from tap at Barley Johns, huge fruit, banana, prune, raisins. 9/5/8/5/18.

Marzipan and nut nose.
Dark brown.
Vineous almost grappa-like notes, some sugar, ok complexity.
Medium body.
Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2007 Draught: Pours a deep dark mahogany color, with a creamy beige head. Very fruity aroma apples and pears, and same with the taste apples, pears, and dark fruits, belgian sugars and cant even taste the alcohol, damn good quad.

Draft, at the <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Tree Inn, Blue Island, IL. Redolent of candi sugar and caramel malts. A smooth blend of smells that I still cant separate into its components. All I know is that its very heady with alcohol and I will want another.

Muddy brown body with a soft medium-size, light brown head. Smooth taste of rich fruit, malts, cocoa. Aroma of raisins and alcohol also a sort of burnt rubber/grain. I was really pleased with this beer it was medium bodied, well balanced, smooth and the alcohol was warming. I knocked this down very quickly so it must have been very much to my liking.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2005 poured just like muddy water into my rochefort glass.gave off little head that stuck around until the last drop.the smell gave off  sents of rasins,bubblegum,candy and a little earth.the flavor was an outstanding balance of all the flavors from the aroma,along with malts,belgian yeast,and fruits.this is awsome!!!
re-rate:im am becomming a huge st. b. fan.this time around i noticed when the head evaporated a huge web was left behind.its very smooth,very complex,and wonderful!
re-rate number 2:you really cant get a better looking brew than this.looks stunning right when a 330ml bottle is poured into a trappist glass.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2005 Pours a very dark brown/red color body with a bit of yeast resting on the bottom and a cliingy, foamy, off-white head.  Aroma is bread, raisins, walnuts, prunes, plums, oranges, cinnamin, and light carmel.  Taste is a refined blend of bananas, apples, walnuts, vanilla extract,  raisins, and blackberries.  Oh Yeah...thats good.
A wonderful chewy dark ale.  It has a complex yeasty nose, a beautiful jewled color, a nice tan head, and the taste is incredible.
Citrus, spice, and chocolate.... raisins and malt as well. Nice head but dissapated quickly, however, a thin film remained throughout the entire glass. Would highly recommend!!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2006 In the 0.33L bottle from Dirty Johns. Freakin Amazing! Very dark cloudy pour with a light brown head. Head starts big, but then dissolves pretty quickly to leave a slim blanket over the glass for the rest of the beer. Aroma of gooseberries. GOOSEBERRIES! This is packed with so much O.G. that  This is as close to a barleywine that I have ever had in a Belgian Ale. Sweet, but a nice hop balance to the sweetness. Total tongue coater. I would die a happy man if all my homebrew turned out like this. UPDATE 2/18/6: On tap at the Red Monk during the 2006 Crescent Moon Beer Bus Trip. Served ridiculously cold. Strong and satisfying, but is not worse in the bottle.
Intens dark color with not much foam. Great nose of coffee, caramel and dried fruits. Very rich taste with smooth mouthfeel. Intens afthertaste with some sweetness and complex burned aromas.

Slightly hazy brown body. Suprisingly small, though long lasting light brown head. Initial aroma of prunes and rasins, with light chocolate, apples, port and pears following. Some light spicy notes uncovered as it warmed too. Suprisingly only medium bodied, not as smooth as i was expecting. Sweet caramel and raisins start, with some chocolate notes and other dark fruits coming through. Alcohol warming feeling down the throat. Nice beer.

12.15.04  330ml bottle, Ommegang goblet.  Deep ruby pour with tall and creamy khaki head that nitrogen injected brews dream of having.  Gorgeous complexity in layers of aroma.  A whole box of raisins soaked in fresh apple cider and spritzed with cherry brandy.  More layers peel away to reveal caramelized pear, warm scone, chocolate pudding.  Divine.  The flavor is a miracle.  Dark and sweet, Ive sold my soul for less.  Reduction of pear brandy and soaked raisins, soft cocoa, cherry touches, brown sugar burnt in cream.  The palate is velvet soft with the lightest eff tingle fully coating and exploring the entire palate.  The beer, as it finishes, becomes wine-like with plenty more raisin to linger over exquisite warmth.

#1200!  Thanks to npdempse for this one.  This is the first top 50 beer Ive had for awhile.  Pours very turbid orangish amber.  Aroma of malt, fruit, hops, spice, barnyard.  Slightly more intense aroma than the St. Berny 8.  Tastes very fruity, creamy, smooth, with finishing figs, spice, fruit, and bandaid.  Very nice complexity.  Id love to do a side-by-side with this and Westy 12.  Are monks allowed to get laid?  If so, maybe Ill join up.  I think Id make a great Dalai Lama.
dark brown with creamy beige head that lasts.  Dark fruits, spice,..smooth finish. excellent palate.

It poured a dark brown color and a really nice thick and creamy head. Also had a sweet aroma that reminds me a bit of brown sugar. From the first few sips I could tell that it had not quite warmed up enough even though I let it sit for several minutes. Then when it warmed the flavor was tremendous. It had the usual Belgian spicy taste, but with a faint smokey or roasted flavor. This "smokey" flavor is not something Ive tasted in any other Quadrupels and gave it a very original character. Ill definitely say that this one ranks up there with the Trappistes.
Complex and lighter tasting than expected.  10%?  Doesnt feel like it.  Huge head that dissipates fairly quickly.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2006 I dont remember much of drinking this beer but i remember it being super malty. i have to admit i dont understand these belgiun beers so sorry for wasting your time.  (Rerate)  I had this on tap and it is a pretty damn good quad.  nutty, sweet, woody, yeasty.  excellent.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 A delicious beer with a full body and just the right amount of carbonation.  There are hints of fruit and blended spices in just the right balance.  This is one of my favorite beers available to me.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2005 Cloudy brown with a considerable off white head.  Very lively aromas of prunes, raisins and maybe even a hint of cherries.  It is creamy with the dark fruits in the taste as well. I also taste chocolate and butter.  This is great!
smooth, fruity,  and complex... Its belgium in a bottle....  Probably the finest defination fo a quad I have had so far.

Again, this one was not as good as I thought it would be.  Not as smooth or as flavorful as most, average compared to others of the genre.  The sweet malt and spiced tastes are there, on my palate they never lingered enough or materialized into an enjoyable flavor.  I am not sure why it seemed stagnant from start to finish.  A bad bottle perhaps?  The dude on the bottle hyped me up too much I guess, should have been better.

This poured out a dark thick opaque brown color with a good sized beige head that has great retention. This also left a wonderful coating of lace around the glass as it was consumed. Big complex aroma here with dark sweet fruit malts standing out the most with notes of alcohol, some spice and yeast. There is more going on than that but I am unable to tell exactly what the wonderful scents are, I will defiantly need to get a few more of these to enjoy and analyze. Up front with the taste is sweet fruity malt flavors mingling with a bit of spice. The taste is very smooth and it defiantly warms you up a good deal. Mouthfeel is full and creamy with excellent carbonation and a dry finish, basically perfect. Drinkability is only hindered by ones tolerance for 10% beers besides that its so smooth and delicious I could try and drink this all day. Excellent beer that is recommended to everyone.

Brownish red color, aroma that is very complex, full of abbey type malts and the smell of wine casks, thick texture, so many things going on in the taste, fig cherry chocolate banana, alcohol sneaks up on you. On my top 20 list
Bottled 750ml and 11.2 oz. Mahogany wth a large off white creamy head.  Toffee aroma. Full creamy mouthfeel. Nice longlasting fruity bitter taste. excellent. well balanced. multiple tastings.

Pours a dark brown with reddish highlights and a thick tan head that lasted for the duration of the sampling (1hr.). Rich pungent aromas of plums, rasins, toffee, alcohol, and bready yeasts. The flavour was rich as well with rasins, plums, spices (clove, cinnamon, nutmeg) belgian yeast with some alcohol burn in the finish. All in all a deicious brew.

Deep brown with ruby highlights supporting a creamy tall mocha head.
Rich sweet alcoholic aroma carries a nutty caramel with cookie dough and spicy pepper. Sweet complex flavor. No hops. A bit of tart wine with a nice long finish.

330ml bottle. A dark beer, with a surprisingly foamy head. Loads of yeast in the bottle. A fruity, sweet aroma. Perhaps banana, and definitely raisin. Big raisin flavour, and some liquorice. Cant taste the alcohol, just feel the warming effect in the throat. Slightly plain taste in comparison to other beers of this stature. I was a bit dissapointed, but I had been building my expectation for a while.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005  This is great.  It is very strong in the ways it hits the body.  The taste hides the alcohol well though.  The aroma is very spicy and the taste is fruity.  A little sweet but still good.  I cant put my finger on which fruit exactly.  It gives you a spicy sensation when you sip it too.  Good stuff.  Fantastic on tap.  It knocked my socks off.  Wonderful beer. Bravo.

This was incredible. I dont feel worthy to describe its flavour. Wonderful dark brown colour. The flavour is the usual dark fruit and malty spicesm but the way it all comes to gether is mouth watering.

Pours a deep brown color...Huge,rocky tan head that lingers for most of the glass...Aromas of sweet fruits...candied rasins...Faint presence of alcohol and some spices...Flavor follows siut with huge malt flavor giving way to dark fruit...Flavors intensify and become more complex as the beer warms...Finish is crisp but slightly metallic...Very full through the midddle...A very nice beer
What exactly is supposed to differentiate this beer from other Belgian strongs? Too sweet, too yeasty. Dont like it.
Beautiful beer from a tap.  Slightly dark in colour.  Strong hints of fruit and crisp finish.
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2014 One of the best barley wines of the world, also available of draught. Will keep for years. Very complex in flavours/aromas. Very hartwarming beer.
Small bottle. Wow. Pours very dark with a big, dark, rocky head. Smells wonderfully fruity and spicy. Very Belgian flavor (makes sense), a little alcohol burn. Dry finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2006 Very rich and creamy belgian, the belgian yeast balances with the hops with a slightly moist yellow cakey sweetness and a touch of spice. Complex to say the least. Consistency is thick for beer and best described as slightly syrupy.

Poured a surprisingly dark brown, capped by an abundant creamy tan head.  Complex aroma of dark fruit (raisins), spices (cinnamon), sweet maltiness, and alcohol.  Flavor is delicious:  sweet, fruity, spicy, and floral, with only the slightest alcohol burn in the finish.  Very well balanced; the sweetness is countered excellently by a slight bitterness from the alcohol as well as some of the spicyness.  An awesome thick nectar in the mouth.  Fantastic concoction!

Pours dark reddish brown. Aroma is raisin with apparent alcohol. Flavor is sweet, dried fruit with a nice finish that hides the alcohol better than the aroma. Very nice mouthfeel and aftertaste. A great beer.
UPDATED: MAR 26, 2007 Dark brown color, heavy sweet malty aroma and taste, full body, long sweet light alcoholic finish.

Very dark amber brown w/thick off white head. Toffee, carmel, chocolate and malt nose. Heavey mouthfeel with foaminess and a sweet lingering finish. Molasses, toffee, chocolate, cherry and light sourness. Great beer!!

25.4 ounce bottle with cork and basket stopper purchased from Wilburs Wine and Spirits in Ft. Collins, CO, for $8.99. Happy birthday to me.   What a beer! Really very unique. The appearance is nothing exceptional -- kind of cloudy like you would expect a BCA to be, but a rich thick head and lots of lacing!  Incredible aroma! Mix chocolate, raisins  & rye bread rising just before it goes in the oven. Wow!  Amazing taste. Very unexpected! Not the flavor I had expected from the color. Raisin, plum, yeast, a ripe banana note, high note of pineapple, but not overly sweet. My friend, who shared part of this bottle said, "Like baked raisins with all the sugar turned into alcohol." Not much of the toasted malt or chocolate tastes I had been expecting -- just a total and wonderful surprise!  What a rich, round feel! The bottle said to serve this at 52 to 56 degrees F., and that was right! Smooth without being syrupy -- I hardly wanted to swallow this, it was so nice in the mouth.  Cant believe they sell this at the brewery for about 1 Euro a bottle!
This beer is for special occasions, and worth it. Enjoy!

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2004 bottle.  opened in honor of RED SOX game 2 win in the World Series... color of hot fudge with a fluffy tan head... aroma of syrupy ripe fruits, port, toffee.... flavor of rum cake heavy on the liquor, spice notes... bitter chocolate... smooth, slick, and oh so warming me up on this Boston night.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2014 Murky dark brown. Sweet, enticing nose. Smoothly effervescent, soft and syrupy. Rich malts, with toffee, cake and brown sugar. Lesser notes of chocolate, raisins, bananas, pears, toasted caramel, and herbs. Finishes a bit sticky. Balancing bitterness. Warming, cozy and a pleasure to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2005 Dark brown, large, longlasting head. Fantastic aroma! Fruity, malty, and....mushrooms...! Very very interesting...
The alcohol is well present in this pleasant and rich beer.
Reminds me of Westvleteren, but then less sweet. Which isnt a bad thing.

This one like all the Bernardus beers really need to age.
This is what I like, It is malty and rich. Niiiice.
Dark brown with tan head. Flavor is subdued with a slight fruity malt flavor. Very pleasant to drink, look forward to having again

This dark brown abbey ale pours with an attractive tan head and elicits a very pleasant fruity malt aroma. The flavor gives only a hint of the high specific gravity, and is every bit as tasty and satisfying as the good trappist ales. Goes well with Chimay cheese.

Its got a large bubble head, tan. The bubbles are standing one on top of another like a cheerleaders half-time routine. And its holding, holding, holding....Damnit! I couldnt wait. I took a snoot and got foam on my nose. HaHA!

Nose: Caught wind of a bakers spice rack. Vanilla extract. Sea side smells. 

Taste: Spicy with an alcohol bite. Sour cherries cloaked in brandy. Tastes like a ripe yellow fruitcake with dried sour cherries and almonds, and almond extract, and candied citrus peels. Nice chewy semolina cake flavors, soaked in lite-brown sugar simple syrup, and a touch of brandy. I shouldnt be allowed to drink this bottle this fast.

Wow!  This was a truly remarkable ale!  Slightly sweet at first but it becomes dryer and better as it warms, mellow alcohol flavor and yet warming all the way down.  Nice rich deep brown color, with even hints of currants?  As other raters have also noted, it does have notes of plums and raisins, with a creamy toffee like quality as well.  Hands down one of the best trappist ale I have ever drank to date.
This must be one of the best beers that I have ever tried.  Dark, full of flavor, small but thick.  Alcohol is hard to taste despite the large amount.  Good taste.

11.2 oz bottle:  Deep, dark, thick brown with a small, rocky, tan head.  Opaque and cloudy, this beer has a ton of yeast, including what I left in the bottle.  The aroma coming from this beer is rich.  Theres chocolate, brown sugar, toast, port, vanilla, plum, raisin, nutmeg, cinnamon, molasses, maple syrup, coriander and toffee - all in the nose.  Very complex, as is the flavor that follows.  I can taste coriander, chocolate, apple, cinnamon, yeast, raisin, currants, grapes, honey, earth, and some spices like a sweet rum bun.  This beer manages to be rich, complex, alcoholic and still very creamy.  This is a great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2006 smells a little intimidating, pours a mysterious dark brown with a small head, but delivers beyond expectations.  rich, malty, but with a range of subtle flavors hiding in the corners, with the 10% alcohol not readily apparent.

dont have a trappist glass?!?! darn...but wow this aroma is incredible fruity and merry.
quite. sweet and a little bit bitter.fizzy palate...not as smooth as I expected.

Deep auburn-red and a thick off white head.  Aroma is very thick, with a rich boquet of floral notes and has a sweet, malty character. Hints of brown sugar here.  Flavor is sweet and huge. Notes of coriander, brown sugar, honey, currant, sweet fruit and is very earthy. Very well balanced.  Palate is rich and full bodied. This tastes better as it warms. Finish is slightly dry.  A world class beer.

11.2 oz bottle (age unknown).  pours a deep cloudy brown hue with huge rocky tan head.  looks like cola almost.  Amazing complex aroma of brown sugar, candy sugar, spices, vanilla, dark fruits, and a multitude of others.  This is a huge beer.  lots of spice that tingles your tongue like cinammon gum.  the beer has an apple note that mixes well with the cinnamon bite.  This is definately a sipper.  It took me like 1 1/2 hours to finish this small bottle.  Alcohol was not well covered IMO.  This beer has awesome aging potential.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2005 Rerate June 2005. Rich fruits and soft esters, come out of the deep ruby body and glorious head. Hints of figs, chocolate, ripe dark fruit and brandy soaked malts in the nose.
