Sweet with cotton-candy on the finish accented by banana and licorice. Beer turns kind of gross and ice-tea like as this one warms though. Pretty good beer, just don't let it warm up or lose carbonation.

Dark and murky red/brown color, creamy tan head that coats the side of the glass as it recedes. Has characteristic tiny bubbles forming on the surface. To me it smells all the world like chocolate milk, with a nip of whiskey in it maybe. Tingly mouthfeel, citrus and sinus warming. Silky maltiness, not all that sweet, more chocolate than caramel. Lingering finish on the sweet side.

Deep brown pour with a slightly copper tinge to it.  Huge amounts of head, aroma is nice but there is a lot of noticeable alcohol.  More malt than I was expecting, the alcohol in the mouth is not nearly as overwhelming as it is in the aroma.  I preferred the Prior 8 I had last night.
Great big head and wonderful reddish tint.  It has a nice fruity aroma but the alcohol smell is a bit overwhelming.  Yeasty, ripe fruits, bread... nice complexity.
UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 Bottle - best around the end of 2005.  Nice creamy head and a good and fruity smell.  Complex and malty.  I don't think it's  better than the Prior 8 I had earlier this month.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2003 I was a little bit let down by this beer.. Looked stunning while poured into my Westy glas, surprisingly little head but a very thick head. Aroma was also a let down.. Somewhat malty, but you could smell that you were about to drink something alcaholic. Taste was sweet, raisins,chocolate,malt on the tip of the tongue. Much better then Chimay blue but not as great as I was hoping....

Gorgeous deep scotch colored, red tinged, with a fine head.  This had an august malt backbone with a fluttering of aromatic sweetness in the wings.  Slight yeastiness in the bouquet reminiscent of a german wheat.  Fairly smooth and luscious, rolls over the mouth with a fair yeasty flavor as well. Alcohol is incorporated well into this beer--no spikes. The tongue has a delightfully macerated numbness. A slight sourness. A solid beligian brew.
I've had better. I've had worse. Quite drinkable, a bit maltier than I had expected. Good not great.

wow, look at that head, its gotta be ¾" thick,and creamy white, the color is a cloudy chocolate/ruby color,
it is raisin and rootbeer scented, just simply delicious, rich creamy toffee/raisin/clove flavored with some bananas lingering, a little yeast flavor comes through, but is well balanced, this beer is very rich, the best beer in the universe, westy 12 needs to get on its knees to this mad man!

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2012 2012-05-15, bottle at La Cervezateca, Torremolinos, bb 25.10.16, 7-5-8-3-15=38Malt and caramel aroma, sweet but with austerity. Full bodied, with good malt and caramel flavor, but also a metallic character. Too young.2012-04-01, draught at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen, 7-5-8-3-15=38Cloudy dark amber color, with generous creamy head. Moderate malt aroma, with very light dark fruit, honey and smoke. Full bodied, with good malt flavor, caramel, hint of dark fruits and chocolate, ordinary bitterness; there is a warm alcohol feeling; solid, but overall not exciting, and weak in the final. Good, but seemingly young.2003-07-08, bottle, 7-5-9-4-15Deep amber color; huge rocky head. Strange spicy aroma, alcohol, light liquorice, carbonation. Very good malty body, a pleasant sweet liquorice. Quite long final, but not enough bitter/aromatic.

Dense dark mocha/ruby color with a picture perfect "khaki" head, vergeing on brown as well; huge aroma of raisins, sultanas and peardrop candy. Truly classic flavor, with cola/rootbeer notes followed by a tangy molasses, brown sugar  and (a little) soy sauce, drying out a bit from substantial alcohol on the finish. Great interplay of flavors here, St. Bernardus is proud of the local brewing water and if it helps the various highlights of this beer shine the way they do, then I think they should build a spa...is Spa close to Watou? Anyway, this dark fruited giant is a world classic, GET SOME.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2003 Who cares about looks.  Everyone else has covered that!  Aroma of dark ripe fruits with a hint of mustiness, bread and yeast, caramel, and toffee.  Flavors are about the same with a nice creamy body.  Very complex and rich (like butt-ah).  Awesome stuff. Rivals Westy 12 and Rochefort 10 at least IMO.  A Belgium beer fan must try.

This beer is very similar to the Westy 12 in complexity and taste.  It is however, much creamier and about half the price.  An outstanding beer.Dark with rich aroma and complex flavors that dance in the mouth.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 Ok aroma, with a brownish foam . Beautiful brown color. Nice flavor with a nice balanced alcoholic taste. The alcohol gives it a pleasant feel even though it gets a little to much after a few. Had this on tap and is going to drink it again.

My lable is a little different, but that might have something to do with labling in the US as opposed to everywhere else.  First off, upon popping the top, there was severe bubble-over.  Fairly dark mahogoney in color.  Creamy, mostly diminishing head.  Sweet aroma of yeast and cloves.  The alcohol is noticable, but not overwhelming, warming on the back of the throat.  Cloves and spice are predominant on the tongue.  Another great Belgian Strong.  Also, more accesible, at least for me, than Westy.

Murky dark brown with a hint of red. Big, long-lasting tan head. Tons of lacing. Awesome aroma of sweet (apples, raisins, plum) and spice (clove, liquorice). Some butterscotch and toffee in the flavor to go a long with the above mentioned things. Very creamy with a big body. Alcohol is well-masked, but with a slight warm feeling going down. Very complex.

Dark reddish brown color with a small but persistent beige head. The aroma contained raisins, plums, brown sugar, alcohol, sweet apples, and some spices. The flavor was very similar to the aroma, but with more emphasis on the alcohol...some toffee tones are present as well. Bubbly feel with a semi-dry finish...mainly alcohol. Very good.

Dark bread,fruit, caramel and spicey nose. Burgundy colour, with a very large, toffee coloured, meringue like head. Most lace I've witnessed. Butterscotch, caramel toffee, hint of chocolate, treacle, and raisins are all in the flavour! Complex, smooth, creamy, even the foam is creamy and rich, alcohol lends a soft, dry burn. An extremely fine rendition of the style!

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2005 Lasting beige head. Dark brown body. Sweet and dough in the aroma. Thick and creamy body. Taste is sweet, slightly spicy, rum, liquorice. Finish is a little bitter-sweet. The high ABV gives a pleasent warmth but is otherwise well hidden. Nice.

Muddy brown colour with a slightly tan head which is about 1 inch tall in my goblet. Slightly yeastie aroma with a very faint sweet smell as well. Trillions of small bubbles rising on the side of the glass the way a good belgie should. The first taste is great, very complex and very malty. Definate chocolate and malt undertones with some fruit and yeast flavours hitting in the very back of my palate. This is less malty than the Westy 8 and Rochefort 10 (which I prefer) and I would say is more complex because it isn't overriden by malt. I would rank this one lower than Westy 12 (still the best beer ever in my book) but higher than both Rochefort 10 and Westy 8. A great beer for a great price. Definately try to get your hands on this beer if you don't want to spend the money on those earlier named beers or if you've tried all three of them.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2004 Thick, redish pour, with a bubbly, creamy tan head.  Aroma of yeast and dough, with a slight wine scent.  First taste is delightfully spiced.  Flavors ot malt, fruit, chocolate, and bread dance on your tongue.  Oh man.  This is one fabulous Belgian Quad ale. I know that Westvleteren 12 gets higher marks from most people, but this beer is such a great price in comparison.  This is definately a favorite of mine.  I'm vey impressed. Purists may ignore it because it isn't a "real" Trappist ale, but it definately up there with the best.  I'd certainly rank it up a notch above Chimay Bleu.  It has at least the complexity of Rochefort, and the alcohol taste is better masked.  It's especially important to note that this beer costs HALF of the price of Rochefort 10.  I LOVE this beer.  This beer really is the little brother of Westvleteren Abt 12.  There is some good information about this beer on:

http://www.beerhunter.com/documents/19133-0014 />
Evidently, the brewery in Watou produced similar beers for St. Sixtus in Westvleteren, for commercial distribution, until the monastery upgraded their brewery in the early 1990s.  So, while it's not an "official" Trappist beer, it certainly stands up just as well to the best of the best.

Pours a dark reddish-brown with a very thick beige head. Thin lacing. Aroma is pleasantly fruity, with some malt, spice and alcohol as well. Medium-bodied and sweet, with flavors of malt, licorice, cherry and raisins. Flavor became more rich and easier to drink as it warmed. Pretty good Belgian.

Pours out a dark chocolate color, with lots of bubbles.  A strong spicy aroma.  First sip you can taste a banana and clove taste...then get a fruity sweet taste.  So many tastes and flavors which makes this very complex.  The smooth creamy taste seems to make you not even taste the alcohol.

Pours a dark brown, with some ruby tinges in it.  Head is large, big-bubbled tan, slowly diminishes to some decent lacing.  Body has lots of carbonation, and lots of yeasty bits swirling around in it.  Aroma is huge, yeasty, vinous, fruity, grapes, raisin, some doughiness, and hints of honey.  Flavor is equally huge and complex, lots of fruitiness and sweetness, and changes over time as the brew comes up to room temp.  Very full bodied, massively complex flavors and aromas.  Very similar to the Westy 12, but seemed to have more lively and lasting carbonation.
Smells like a wine and has a slightly fruity (also reminds me of a wine). Nice color and head. A rather interesting beer. But then again, I haven't tried too many Belgians yet.
Smells heavenly.  Looks dark brown, but there's a hint of red in the color as well.  I taste at least 4 different flavors in the taste.

Dark brown, smooth creamy head that diminishes into a thin blanket. . . Spicy, banana, clove aroma - hints of alcohol.  Great malt complexity - starts fairly sweet candy, then moves into a spicy herbal treat.  Good woody finish with plenty of nuts.  Well done, but I liked the triple better.

This beer pours a murky brown like many of the other Belgian strongs.  The aroma was very malty with hints of caramel - almost like brandy.  The flavor was fairly smooth for the level of alcohol, but too strong in my opinion.  For the abv and price for the taste, I'd go with one of the other Belgians.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2004 Pours into the glass with a burgundy body topped by a thick natural longlasting head with a good amount of lace left behind.  Sweet fruity malt aroma with caramel notes.  Brandylike aroma.  Sweet caramel malt flavor with fruity notes and a good spiciness. The finish si nutty and slightly spicy.  Full bodied, tingly from the carbonation and warming.

A foggy dark brown with a frothy light tan head that hangs on the sides of my glass.  Bready chocolate nose with notes of alcohol drifting up.  Lots of rich malt flavors here.  Very complex.  I detect milk chocolate and vanilla in the taste.  Sweet but not too.  I can chew this stuff.  Very full silky smooth finish.  This is a bargain at $3.79 a bottle, I pd $10.99 for a West 12.  This on my top ten list.
UPDATED: MAY 28, 2003 Very dark ale with huge head.Many different flavors involved but overall very sweet and smooth. Raisin or plum seems to mix well with the malt. Very nice
Full bodied dark ale with huge head. Sweet spicy aroma. Flavors abound of complex fruit and malt. Smooth.
Had this on draft at the Split thy Skull event at Sugarmoms is Phila. Nice solid Belgian beer. Good malty flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2003 Great looking beer. Big, lasting head and amber, cloudy. A fresh acid in the aroma, some fruit not classifibly. Sweet nice taste, some rye in the finish.
Re-rate: Store it for some years, open it and let it rest for an hour and you will get something near Westy 8, lots of bread, heavy.

Deep dark brown with reddish shine. Thick brown head, lacey. Nose of flambéed banana, Baba au rhum or Sachertorte, later also a bit rubbery, and chocolate. Taste is sweet, flavours of liquorice, sweet (Belgian) chocolate, overripe bananas, plum pudding. Some people talk about figs  fresh AND sugary, Id say yes. Very heavy mouthfeel, nearly fit enough to chew. Also an impression as from walnut oil. Keeps going for a long time. No new aftertaste, unless a fleeting cigar-ash impression. Impressive. One of Belgiums classics.

On tap for Belgian Beer Month at Toronado.  Dark caramel pour with strong cream head.  Tastes like a spicy molasses syrup - not to be confused with sporty spice.  The strong chocolate reminds me of a sweet chocolate mole.  Undertone of plums or figs.  Very smooth on the palate.  May have to go back for more of this.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2007 ***The re-re-rate... 750 ml bottle... This beer rocks!...  Murky, very dark brown brew which reveals burnt orange highlights when held up to a lamp. Large, frothy, khaki head. Excellent retention. The nose is fruity and malty with notes of dark fruit, apple, fuzzy fruit, pear and chocolate. The flavor is malty and rich, but has excellent balance. Dark fruit, light bitterness, chocolate. Medium to full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Chocolatey, balanced finish. The high ABV is very well-hidden. A beautifully constructed beer! World Class!
***The re-rate***...  I tried another 12 oz. bottle at Monks Cafe in Philly. My following rating holds. I really dig this brew! 
This beer rocks! Whats not to like about this beer? The appearance is murky and forbidding with a deep orange/red color that Ive not seen before. Very large creamy, khaki-colored head. The head diminishes slightly, but is everlasting and leaves very strong lacework on the glassware.
The aroma is very rich and complex with all kinds of Belgian malt and Belgian yeast induced fragrances. Russian Black Bread dough, dark chocolate, Chanel No 5, lime, alcohol, dark grapes, overripe plums, dates, French oak, brown sugar, nutmeg, chalk and yes, a fresh, unused Band-Aid brand bandage. Ok, that about covers it. The flavor is of warm, sweet Belgian rum, caramel, molasses, prunes, alcohol and cola up front. Nicely balanced Belgian ale as my mouth was enveloped by dizzingly pleasant hop bitterness, orange blossom honey sweetness and a woodsy, grassy, straw-laden earthiness on the backside.
Full-bodied with a buttery and syrupy mouthfeel and lively carbonation.
A lengthy, flavorful, dry, alcoholic and astringent finish. ***Original rating... Bottle...This beer rocks!...  What a brew! Personally, I might like this one as much or more than Westy 12... I MIGHT!
Ill defintely have to try this one again with my good friend Scraff.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2003 deep brown, creamy, nice Belgain Ale.Sweet with candy fruits, yeasty, complex finish, a nice Ale,re-rate aroma of raisins, candy belgian sugar,rich and extremely complex. A "drinkable" ale very refreshing for 10 ABv as it is well hidden, roasted molasses malts, complex, this Ale is a Winner
Another one that smells and taste like soy sauce. Also taste licorice. Nice thick head.
Dark brown. Creamy. Nice head. Plum/raisin flavors. Nice banana esters. Yeasty. A lot less hoppy than Westy 12.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2004 Rerate 4/23/2004: best by 2004 bottle.  Pours a nice medium to dark brown with a beautiful off-white thick lacing head.  Aroma is rich, malty and full of bready Belgian yeast.  Flavor is much to suit, sweet, complex, and smooth.  Not quite Westy, but a great beer for its price. 

3/21/2003: Thick dark murky body with a good layer of foam on top.  Sweet bready Belgian yeast aroma with no alcoholic notes.  Highly carbonated mouthfeel that when fading reveals the sweet, complex malty goodness lying beneath.  Decent fruit and wood flavors are evident.  This is a very good, respectable Belgian ale with a pleasant, dry, candi-sugar finish.
Color was dark carmel w/visible carbonation and little floaties. Aroma was sweet and yeasty. The taste was woody, sweet and musky. Nutty with a yeasty bitter finish. Very dry.
Dark amber with large off white head. Aroma is alcohol with some malt and fruits trying to come out.  Taste is mainly of alcohol, no subtly here, very unbalanced, same as drinking a shot.

Deep dark brown colour with a nice head. I had a hard time finding the right words for this, but I really liked it! Keywords could be rum, plums, malts, and spices (vanilla?). I loved the very full palate and warming alcohol sensation.

Very dark brown, almost opaque, with a gigantic neverending head; I could've poured this fridge-cold and it would have been warm enough by the time the head faded.  Yeasty/malty banana nose with hints of cherry is disappointingly weak to my shnozz.  Flavor definitely stronger and more memorable, bananas and creamy sweet malt at the front, strawberries raisins and rum stand out in the middle.  Awesome creamy cherry/vanilla/Dr. Pepper middle, smooth but long finish.  I'm glad I have a 2nd bottle, I suspect I'll like it more a second time.  As it is, doesn't seem QUITE a masterpiece, but certainly I'm glad its Top 50 status brought it to my attention.

Sweet dark bread aroma.Chestnut appearance with no particles.Very smooth for 10%.Fruity,brown sugar, raisan, fig,cherry  
yeasty bread and  caramel flavors.Very mild hops at the finish.

I had this on draught. It was a dark beer with a nice large rocky head that continues throughout the whole taste. A big alcohol taste with bitterness and yeast. The palate was quite oily. Some malts as well. Overall a very strong flavor.
This beer is like Trappist-beers. The alcohol 10%, is well camuflaged by a round flavour.(Bottle)

Had on draught at The 12 Hour Belgian Beer Party at Pizza Port Carlsbad on March 8, 2003#39 on the Beer Fest program.  This was a true treat - a sweet aroma wafts up with slight maltiness.  The beer is drawn from the tap with a light brown head that lasts throughout with a creamy, dark brown color.  The beer itself is quite nice - slightly sweet with a hint of acidity.  The aftertaste is not the best, but definitely not the worst - slightly sweet, but not too overdone.  Need to find in bottle now...

Dark brown color. Medium head. Aroma is malty and sweet. Nice smooth malty beer. Malts are richly sweet and slightly nutty. Touch of barnyard. Herbal hops. Well balanced. VERY NICE beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter
My favorite belgian beer.  Malty, flavorful, explodes on your palate.  High alcohol content doesnt overpower the beer.  Warmer the better.  Better in the bottle than the tap.

Tap.  Served in a small 8 oz belgian-style glass.  Very deep amber/brown color with modest carbonation and a light thinnish cream colored head.  Very good lacing as well.  Filled with lots of malty flavors with some hops- but most of the flavor and mouthfeel comes from malt with lots of plum, fig, and caramel like qualites.   Mouthfeel is extremely full with a nice balance and has a great finish.  Lots of great yeasty aromas and flavors with a nice subtle alcohol finish as it warmed.  One of the best belgian dark strong ales.

Despite the great reviews of this beer, my bottle is a little sour.  The finish is very dry, and there is too much carbonation - it is biting, and this not a smooth, frothy beer, as I expected from its appearance.  Yeasty aroma, the flavor is dominated by raisins and plums.

Pours a nearly opaque brown, black. Held to the light, millions of tiny bubbles can be seen interspersed with fine yeast particles. Thick, foamy, mostly lasting head with nice sheets of lace. A strong plummy/fruity aroma hits as soon as the bottle is opened. Raisns, wine, apples, yeast, alcohol, and citrus are present as well. Dark, malty, raisiny flavor. Hints of black cherry and bannana. Caramel and brown-sugar flavors become slightly more pronounced as the beer warms. Overall, pleasantly sweet in flavor. This is complimented greatly by a rich, creamy mouthfeel. The 10% ABV comes out mostly in the finish but has a nice evaporative cooling quality. Some nice, tart acidic notes come out as well keeping the malty sweetness from overwhelming the palate.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2006 [re-rate - its been a while since Ive had this, and it seems a lot more astrigent than it used to be - the flavors are also a little less balanced, with sweetness bordering on cloying - still a tasty belgian, but not great] Dark, dark ruby in color, with a frothy, cappuchino-like head and lovely yeasty aroma, with hints of chocolate and raisins.  Heavy carbonation with fine suspended particles.  Medium to full body, nice creamy mouthfeel dispite the high carbonation.  The flavor has some spice to it, with fruity flavors from apples to bananas.  Lots of malts come through near the end, which serve to cut the alcohol presense that manifests after having the beer in your mouth for a few seconds.  Malts dominate the finish, with a nice caramel and toffee flavor.  Some of the banana flavor sticks around at the end as well.  A nice Belgian, Trois Pistoles meets Westy 8.

Draught at De Zolder, Brugge. Magnificent dark red brown hued with a doughy thick head. I found the draught to more flavoursome than previous bottles, there was whiskey like malt, oak, late tobacco and some banana. Luckily it wasn't carbonated and when it had warmed somewhat it gave out a delightful alcohol glow. Great beer.

Has a very cloudy amber color with quite a few "floaties" in it and quite a bit of carbonation.  Smells of fruit and alcohol.  Taste is of spicey alcohol and finishes kind of fizzy with alcohol flavors.  Overall I am just not into the Belgian styles, it was pretty good, better then most, but the fizz/carbonation is what kills it for me.
Deep brown. Fluffy white head. Smells like fresh bread dough. Tastes like orange and spice with just a hint of lemon. Alcohol comes through clear on the finish.

Pours a slightly hazy copper w/a  verly light beige head, which collapsed very quickly to larger bubbles.  Interesting array of aromas; bananas, green apple, alcohol, slight raisin, and a little bready.  Flavor is well balanced and clovey; fruity and alcoholic.  Maltiness is overtaken by hop flavor and bitterness in the finish.  The raisin and green apple aromas don't come through to the flavor though, but you do get some banana in the aftertaste.  The body seems medium, which might be affected by the high carbonation level.  Although the alcohol is very noticeable and has a slight burning as opposed to warming.  Very good beer, but not one of my favorites.

Good head on the deep brown/black liquid. Overipe bananas can be detected in the aroma. Licorice and bubblegum flavors along with caramel and toffee in the aftertaste. Sweet spicyness coats the mouth and the alcohol clears the sinuses. A bit too sweet for just one person on the bottle, best to shared with another.

Pours a very dark, cloudy brown color with a small, off-white lingering head. Strong aroma of fruits, yeast, spices, and alcohol that is very similar to the Abt 8 though slightly stronger in the alcohol department. This beer is very complex, full bodied with lower carbonation than the Abt 8. The flavor is chocolatey, fruity, yeasty, and bready. Very smooth and worthy of praise, this beer is one of the better non-trappist Abbey ales I have had.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2003 Dark amber colour, with a thin, creamy and persistent head. Strong and intense cherry aroma. The flavour is complex, but a bit unbalanced: a little bit too sweet, with strong taste of cherry and traces of caramel and banana. Huge alcoholic aftertaste. Really good, but far from the perfection of a Rochefort 10...

Okay, supposedly this is made to the same recipe at Westvleteren 12, but I'm not seeing it. Huge, meringue head is appropriate to the style. Very sticky and I saw caves forming in the head along the sides of the glass as smaller bubbles became large but were unable to move because of the viscosity of the rest of the foam. The body is a very dark brown, cloudy. The nose is earthy, similar to some of the smells of a vegetable garden towards the end of harvest. The first flavor that hit me was cotton candy but this was while I was getting nothing but foam. It also seemed a little hot then. There's a butteriness to it that blends nicely into the chocolate and toffee malts. Ripe bananas over peaches a bit past their prime meld in nicely as well. Very low bitterness and the alcohol is covered extremely well. There's also a slight vinous character to it and there's something there that reminds me of the homemade wine my church uses for Communion. The mouth feel is very slick and creamy. This beer forces you to drink it slowly whether you want to or not. Since I'm enjoying it, I want to do so.
Cloudy lighter brown color, spicy apple and cherry-like nose. Creamy smooth and round on the palate. Sweet alcoholic finish.
Very full Belgian beer.  Not one of the best that I have ever tasted, but well worth a pour.
Yet another good Belgian ale.  Very enjoyable.

Not as potent as I would have hoped. Pours a dark brown with a light tan to off-white head. The head quickly disappeared. The aroma was bittersweet but seemed somewhat dry. The first taste revealed that it was not as sweet as I was expecting nor was the taste very high in alcohol either. Finished a little dry but had a tang or zip in the end. The alcohol was noticeable but not overwhelming considering it was 10%. Recommended

Good round taste that fills the mouth well, but I was expecting more. Came off with too much alcohol and astringent tastes. Still a very managable and drinkable beer, but I don't think I'll buy this again.

This beer poured a dark amber color and formed an off white sudsy head that left circular lace. A good deal of carbonation was present. It had an aroma of malt, caramel and fruit. A flavor of malt, caramel and spicy fruit. A very strong flavor element and finish going on with this beer. A very impressive beer.

Looks just like the Prior 6, coffee-brown w. creamy head. However, the aromatics of the 6 are significantly offset by the vodka-like vapors streaming out of this one. The flavor as well, is alcohol saturated, though it certainly is warming. Full, sweet, fruity with a nice roasted malt richness, some coffeeish element. Pretty good but I liked the 6 better.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2003 Bottled. Deep amber/brown coloured. Light brown head. Might be something wrong with this bottle. Maybe excess yeast, because lots of foam burst out of the bottle. Nothing wrong with the aroma, though. Fruits, spices, malts and slightly notes of alcahol. Flavour is very fruity. Plums and raisins is present, an some vague alcahol burn. This is not as well balanced as other top-notch belgian strong ales. Has to give it another try. Rerate draught: Not much to add. Seemed a lot more balanced in the flavours, and more distinct in the aroma, why I uprate it by. Original rate 8-4-7-4-16-3,9.

Dark ruby brown, cloudy (yeast), tan head leaves excellent lacing on my glass.  Wonderful aroma of yeast, raisins, dried cherries, and malt.  Well-balanced complex flavor - everything from the aroma and then some.  Dry finish.  As good as Westvleteren 12 for less than half the price.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2007 I wish I had a Westy #12 right now to compare this with.  My memory of the Westy is that it very similar to this beer.  This beer is fruity and complex.  I do get some alcohol taste in the flavor.  I bought this bottle for 3 dollars and the westy for 8.5.  There is no way for me to justify the difference.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2015 Brown,light tan lasting.head.Light metallic salty nose.Complex palate of light fruit,earthy malt. Mild hop finish with light alcohol heat

Darker cloudy copper body with a well formed thick head.  Aroma of ripe fruits, spices and alcohol.  first sensation is alcohol, but then a nice smooth, fruity mild, yet complex and well rounded.  A great, probably new beer for most freinds to enjoy.

Westy 12s long lost brother, almost as complex and elegant. Pours deep reddish brown with a massive creamy head that doesnt quit. Aroma is very strong, like sherry and plums. First taste is very reminiscent of West 12, very sherryish and fruity, with hints of chocolate and figs, and dries off nicely. The difference here is that this has more of an alcoholic finish than Westy. For being almost identical to Westy, its a great value at half the price.

Excellent Belgain abbey-style beer, deep brownish color with a redish tint, the huge foamy head didnt last all that long which gave way to just a few bubbles around the edge of the glass, the aromas were filled with different kinds of fruits including apricots and maybe even a pear-like smell, sweet maltiness also included in the nose, lots of different fruity notes in the flavors as well as a defined sweetness, the body was very full & almost syrup-like, heavy aftertaste that hangs around for a while, the finish included more fruitiness & malty sweetness, this was pretty damn close to a Rochefort or Westy, I think I may have to give those beers another try & see how they stack up again this gem of a beer

Quite lovely.  Deep red color with a surprisingly huge head.  Has a wondrous mixing of scents in the nose, dancing between apricot and pear fruitiness, butterscotchy maltiness, and hints of sweetness.  Excellent flavor, again full of lots of fruits (peaches, figs, apricots) balanced beautiful with a yummy chewiness of malts.  Finish has a bit of residual sugariness, but its far from unpleasant.  The berw simply hangs in your mouth for minutes afterward, tasting quite lovely the entire time.  If Westy 12 is better than this, I just may have to crack that bottle open pretty darn soon.
Very dark colour with a beautiful head. Excellent aroma (banana?). Too sweet but well-balanced.

Pours a dark, but clear, brown with long lasting, lacing head.  Slightly alcoholic with hints of chocolate, nuts, raisins, toffee, caramel, sugar, and brandy.  While it doesnt match up with its supposed brother, it is still one hell of a beer.
browner than westy with more stringent alcohol aroma and watery malt, lots of raisins, I cant help but compare  this "generic westy" to the real thing I drank at the same time

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2005 Ok head from the pour.  Great carbonation keeps a thin head on the surface.  Color of watery milk chocolate.  Slightly sour dark fruit aroma with some grapes and yeast.  Rather full bodied with many flavors hidden inside.  Some port, more dark fruit, grapes and a nice alcohol warming to go along with a large alcohol presence (which I like).  Decent malt backbone.  Finishes quite smooth and alcoholic. Slightly sour and crisp.  Quite a good/complex beer that is well worth the time.  Wow even better the second time.

Deep ruby color with a large tan head.  There is a fruity and wine-ish nose apparent.  Great taste for Belgian Strong--alcohol perfectly concealed and there are spices and fruits abundant.  Especially cloves and pears.  Very moderate--well balanced and nothing too extreme.
what a great beer at a great price quite nice on draft and bottle

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2004 Strong complex aroma of malts, sweet fruits and hints of spices. Cloudy darkbrown coloured, thick head. Good so far. Taste is complex; nuts, sweet, fruits and hints of spices. Alcohol is well hidden. palate is good; moderate bitter; moderate sweet and fruity. Thick mouthfeel. Great! rerate feb, 8th 2004. Very unbalanced beer. I'm interested in this one after some aging.

Bottle conditioned. It was new years eve and the bottle label said best before end of 2002, so fearing a massive deterioration in the beer overnight I settled down to see in the new year. Deep chestnut colour with a small but thick collar of foam and good condition. Complex aromas of pear drops nuts and malt, More peardrops in the mouth with some fruit notes and a hint of mouldy cork. Finish was alcoholic and warming with a roast malt bitterness. Not as complex as a Westy 12 but still a good way to finish off a year.
This was very similar to Westvleteren 12.  Not quite as sweet and the alcoholic taste is toned down a bit.  Very good.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2003 a swedish pillow lay atop the brownness which let in hints of orange every so often..the aroma was a tart grape, musty and dusty, with chocolate and white wine..the flavors were chocolatey, vinious..notes of grapes, chocolate cake, creamy chocolate frosting, licorice, and bitter chocolate..very warming with a thick and chocolate yet tart mouthfeel...I was looking forward to this for along time..and i was not let down
Brilliant dark color. Full bodied, creamy. Smells fruity, bready dough. Yeasty doughy taste. Malts, sweetness, alcohol is present. Palate is full, until only the alcohol remains.
Bubblegum and clove in aroma and flavor.  Poured with tall bubbly head, brown/gray color.  As it warmed, some chocolate and roasted notes came through.  Too sweet and bubblegum flavored for me.
A complex ale fruity, spicy, sweet and yeasty what a combo  Abv well hidden. Recommended
Big tan head.  Very rich but clean tasting.  Strong chocolate flavor with a slightly bitter finish. Comparable to Roch 10

Nose lasts forever, with lingering sweet malt and plums and currants.  I could sniff this guy for an hour or two without even taking a sip.  Malt flavor is dark and sweet with a finish that I am still tasting 15 seconds after the end of the sip.  Excellent, Excellent stuff, that I will need to sample several times to get my head around the flavors I detect. (and at $3.99 a bottle, its hard to go wrong)  Superb.
Black currant, slightly chocolatey aroma.  Similar to Westy 12, but fruitier and more vinous.  I think I might like this better than westy 12.

Deep brown color with a beautiful head. Intense fruity sweet flavor that would make it perfect for an after-dinner drink. Spicy alcoholic aftertaste which makes a very interesting pairing with the sweet raisin-like beginning. Wonderful.

hazy, deep amber brown woth a beautiful lacy head.  this beer threatened to explode on me from the minute it opened.  raisiny, nutty, sweet aroma.  very complex, buttery, rummy, raisiny, spicy, flavour with slightly tart and alcoholic hints.  a very rich and satisfying ale.  lovely.
Dark reddish brown w/ a tan head. Aroma of toffee & rum. soft textured w/ a slightly sweet finish

Deep mahogony brown with a fluffy off-white head that lasts.  Aromas of vanilla, some yeasty sourness, dark fruits and creamy chocolate.  Very aromatic.  Vanilla, creme and dark chocolate making an appearance in the flavor profile with dark fruits in the background.  A little hot - alcohol - in the finish.  Seemed a little thin bodied, which is my only complaint.  Complex, beautiful and aromatic.

Terribly similar to Westvleteren 12.  Grapes, molasses, spice and a touch of booze in the nose.  Flavor is of hard candy, banana, molasses and spice.  Perfectly balanced beer.  Alcohol well-cloaked.  I have to give this the edge over Westy 12, which I had last night.
UPDATED: SEP 3, 2004 Dark brown/ruby color, big beige head. Sweet fruity aroma. Flavor is sweet, acidic, toffee, hint of raisons and banana

The monk on the bottle would have to be the Nelly of monks.  Strong fruity aroma, a bit more intense then the westy 12 I had just before this but not nearly as enjoyable.  Syrupy rasberry, vinous with some mellow nutmeg.   A bit bitter, little sign of its strength.  Thank you Kaya
This beer is a deep brown color with a big giant foam on top. Fruits and malts present in this beers smell, in the taste it is a sweet, vanilla, and hints of bananas. A great beer.

Pours with a decent golden head with mix of larg and small bubbles.  Aroma is great, grapes, bananas and port. Not as chocolatly aroma as Westvlteren 12.  Definately a banana flavor pretty sweet but a little thin and not a complex as Westy.  I have 4 bottles of Westvleteren 12 aging in my cellar and cannot wait to to do a side by side taste test after this ages a liitle.

Strong tropical fruit flavors. Maybe a bit too sweet. Very nice dessert offering. Maybe slightly overbearing compared with the triple. Re-rate: Had another one and it was really just delicious. Drank it warmer. Have to up the overall impression and palate.

The Westvleteren brewery in the abbey of St Sixtus decided to contract the brewing of its commercial product to the St Bernardus brewery at Watou from the end of WWII until 1992 when it took back the rights to the term Trappist and now brews the commercial brands itself. Until that date in 1992, this was a Trappist beer, after that date it became an Abbey beer. When it lost its Trappist status the name St Sixtus was removed from the label. It would be interesting to drink this with a bottle of Westvleteren 12 to see who really does make a better job of the recipe. From what I understand St Bernardus has the original yeast so Westvleteren had to get their yeast from Westmalle. The alcohol is well used to add depth and flavour to a very creamy, smooth, sweet and fruity brew. Quite delicious.
Now your getting into my taste of beer. I really enjoyed this one. very sweet and tart it really is a full mouth.
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2004 the malts are just luscious on this one - plummy, raisin, chocolate toffee, some spices - cinamon, etc.  smooth and thick.  very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2006 I had this beer way underrated. Its one of the very best beers in the world, and its widely available to boot. Id say this is the quintessential Belgian--exotic Asian fruits in a rich toffee cream. Spicy and yeasty. Westvleteren is better, but I can drink St. Bernardus on tap in two locations...Westvleteren I cant even find in bottles these days.

Adamantly disagree with the big 3 on this one. Very strong notes of plum, grape and raisin in the malt. Chocolate flavor begins to dominate as the beer warms. Amazing complexity of flavors, smooth finish for such a huge beer. World class.

Buttery, spicey and sweet nose. Brown body with hints of red and a medium head. Wonderful flavor: plums, raisons, alcohol, coffee and caramel. Warms you up with its fullmouth taste. Good balanced beer.

Yeasty nose, cloudy brown-red color, spongy tan head with small bubbles. Chocolate and caramel flavors predominate with hints of spices and raisins. Slightly dry finish. Complex with an impeccable balance. Wonderful stuff.

Huge over-carbonated fizzing,leaves only half the bottle.Dark,muddy,brown with med-sized bubbles,with decent retiton.Aroma is bready,alcoholic,fruity and slightly spicy.Flavor is big and non-restrained. Fruity,rummy-dates,and nuts with a bready,doughy(similar to west.)finish.Overall,the over carbonation was a turn-off and the flavor didnt make up for it.

Murky red/brown. Fine head and lace. Delectable nose of banana, chocolate, pear, doughy malts,rummy alcohol and others. Almost medium bodied, moderate carbonation and slightly creamy. Bananas, doughy malts and dark fruits invade palate with a touch of spice throughout. Finish is a nice alcoholic warmth and a candy like sweetness. Could be a little thicker but this is tasty as hell. Developes a dry yeast character and thickens a bit as it warms.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2006 A very dark red almost brown beer with a good head. The aroma is of over ripe fruit and malt sweetness. The flavor is very powerful of a great malt blend with strong notes of caramel as well as hints of the alcohol, which also tickles the tongue. It ends with a good bitterness - all in all a really great flavor and therefore a really good beer.

Malty, sour aroma.
Very carbonated but smooth on the tongue.
Damn good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2016 Rating reflects aged sample. Re-rate: Bottled BB 2004, sampled end 2009 (about 9 years old). Dark brown colored, small brown head. Complex, but not very strong nose of malts, raisins, dried fruit, molasses, port-notes. Fantastic flavor, all complex components of the aroma, wonderfully balanced, sweet and bitter. Extremely long-lasting finish, dry and bittersweet. One of the most well-balanced brews i know. And it doesnt even taste like it peaks at this age, it might even get better when older.... Fantastic brew, and well worth aging. Original rating: This is a very nice one! One of the best aromas out there, strong, fruity, sourness and some caramel. Appearance is nearly perfect: cloudy dark-brown with a thick long-lasting head. Very malty flavor, full and a bit fruity. Nice smooth and long lasting finish. Alcohol is very well hidden. The only flaw of this beer is perhaps that its a bit too sweet, but aging could make this better. Ill keep the second bottle in my cellar for a few years. If i can wait... ;-).
Additional note: appears to peak after 5 years of aging (0.75 L at 12 degrees Celcius).

Plenty of apple on the nose; well-rounded flavors converge on palate; fruit, malt, honey; high drinkability factor for 10%.  Complexity becomes apparent with each sip.  A large beer that could be enjoyed in some quantity.
UPDATED: NOV 15, 2003 Bready, cracker, fruit and a malty carmel richness in flavor and a full mushy texture. Easy drinking for this ABV and yet totally lush. Best part about this -- only 3 euros!

WOW I had no idea how much I was 
going to enjoy this beer when I happened
to see it at Monks in Philly.
Tremendous explosive after taste.
I must try this again.

John

While this is supposed to be a Westy 12 knockoff, it definitely doesnt look like the Westy in the bottle (i.e., no magnificent yeast floaties throughout the beer). The brown body is opaque rather than cloudy, and the head is light tan and only medium thick. Nose is malty, with a doughy sweetness. First sip is mostly cookie dough, medium sweet. Alcohol is noticeable in the finish, although inoffensive. Continuing... I know Westy 12; Ive tasted Westy 12; Ive rated Westy 12, and, Senator, you are no Westy 12. Im surprised that this is in the top 50; my example was a middle-of-the-road dubbel. Certainly this lacks the complexity and the surprising flavor changes of its inspiration.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2007 Dig the lush monk on the label. The aroma was like goddamn cookie dough, i almost disgraced my pants. Tastes of bananas and figs, all sorts of fruit race throughout with a sweet, candy like finish. Definitely unlike any belgian ive had before. The downfall is the overt carbonation. Its fizzy beyond belief and almost stings your tongue. Im thoroughly impressed.

Overall its a got a strange secondary taste to it that makes less enjoyable to drink.
Not as good as some of the real Trappist beers.

Dark brown with a medium beige head that dissipates fairly quickly.  Aroma is rich, raisin and rum, with a hint of banana.  Flavor is fruity (mostly raisin, perhaps date &/or plum), malty and quite sweet (near bubble gum), with significant alcohol presence (though its hard to guess its at 10%).  Altogether a very enjoyable beer, though Id appreciate it even more if it werent quite as sweet.

Almost perfect.
Im sure.

Do you know that when the abbey of Vleteren or Rochefort hasnt enough beer, they ask each other?
It is reality! I know it from a brewer.

I didnt know much about this one, but I was impressed.  A dark brown copper color with a medium head.  Complex and thick with malt, chocolate, grapes, pears, and spices.  The alcohol is noticable, but interacts with everything to balance out.  Ill have another, please.
Dark beer with an impressive head.  This has strong banana and caramel notes.  Pleasant warming alcohol, too.  Excellent.

Dark cola-like in color with a big tan head.  Nose is amazing mix of doughy yeast, spices, bubblegum, and the clear presence of alcohol.  Banana, my dads home-made pizza crust, and oaky alcohol flavors. Highly complex and captivating.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 Rerate: Very deep brown - almost black colour. Slightly brownish head. Spicy aroma. A complex, spicy and malty flavour. The flavour starts quite neutral, and finishes bittery.

Malt aroma, very dark color. Very nice beer, drinks quite easy.
I love this. Floral nose, sweet raisiny, dates? Dark muddy color. well balanced. What else would you expect from those Belgians
Ive had this from tap as well as bottled. Very delicious. Raisins and malt in the aroma. Great complexity in the flavour. Strange carbonation. Some westyness.

really nice strong.  muddy brown in color.  robust malt presence, ample spice and fruit - especially on the finish.  just a little bit of sourness - definitely can smell it.  very well balanced.  havent seen this local to seattle - mom brought back from belgium.

Re-Rate 10/09/02: Deep brown color on the pour the head is prodigious, the lace husky, beige and long lasting. Nose is sumptuous, nutty sweet, bubble gummy, rasin like, a most Sniffable beer. Front is ambrosial, the top is light, the finish is congenially dry, magisterially hopped, notably acidic. A treasure not to be missed if your into Belgian Ales, and one of only a few to get a Perfect 5 from this Olde Gusler. Ranks or I should say is tied for #1 on my current 1000 beer master list with Westvleteren Abt 12, and Abbaye des Rocs.
Malty with chocolate and fruit notes.  Wonderful aroma. Nice warming from alcohol.  Dry finish.

Re-Rate: I had to re-rate this after finishing my four bottles.  I initially gave it a 4.1, but it is better than that.  I actually grew to like the alcohol heat on this one, it has a warming quality whereas most are just astringent.  Plus it is offset by the nice creamy malt and a background of wine.  One of the best.
Very much like the Westvleteren 12, the same great taste, flavor and malt.  Until 1992 St Bernardus brewed for Westvleteren.
Lots of alcohol and roasted fruit.  Tastes l;ike a real trappist ale.  Well balanced chocolate and fruit...yum!
Dark amber appearance, head depending on the pour and glass.  Smells a lot like a Westy 8: roasty pears, smoke, woodiness.  Prominent alcohol.

Wow! This is a funny beer to open. When ever the top is removed the brew starts to fload out immediately! Such a big pressure inside. Nevertheless, this brew is really fantastic! The same complexity as in the westvletern 12, but in a more drinkable version. Every flavour-component  in this beer is more clear and the aroma is softer and lighter. The yeasty aroma combined with the fruity notes makes it irresistable! I actually prefer this one instead of the Westvleteren 12.
Very complex. It is a little bit like Westvleteren only the alcohol is more obvious. Ive heard they should use the same recipe as the monks from St. Sixtus Abbey.

Red-brownish, medium head. Very similar to pater 6 except that a bit alcohol is shining through. Like the 6 and 8 it has the noble trappist characteristics but is a bit short on complexity. Oddly enough I found this one a wee bit flater than the 6 and 8 and the alcohol is not that well masked. Dont get me wrong, it is a good beer.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2004 Appealing, spiced aroma of fresh banana nut bread.  Opaque, very deep reddish brown color, with a lasting, creamy head.  Flavor has nice bit of malt fruitiness, some plum, raisin and spice, but the palate is surprisingly light and effervescent.  Somewhat acidic  mouthfeel along with some light, peppery bitterness in the finish and aftertaste.  Finishes more sweet than dry, though.  Quite an interesting balancing act the flavor and palate have undertaken.  Interesting and tasty.

Bottle brought to me with care from England.  A cloudy ruby brown color
with an off-white head.  A strong dark fruit aroma with raisins, banana, malty sweetness.  Somewhat bubbly with a carbonated feel.  The flavor does not disappoint and echoes the aroma.
Dark brown with a creamy head. Aroma is very similar to the Rochefort 10. Great mouthfeel.Nice flavor with malt and fruit.
very exciting nose. perfect head, stays thin the whole beer through. nice flavor, but a disappointing aftertaste. great beer, overall.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2003 Small 330ml bottle, pours a thick cloudy brownish color with a huge frothy and creamy biege lasting head that leaves clingy sheets of lace in my glass, nice malty and sweet yet spicy aroma. Sweet and fruity malty flavors, nice and smooth creamy soft mouthfeel,full body with a lively carbonation, finishes with a pleasant sweet and spicy aftertaste, alcohol very well hidden, I love this one.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2004 Wow. I must be all over the map...probably more likely than this beer being the subtle mix of styles if appears to me. First off, a Brune or a classic trappist a la Westy or Roch? More Brunelike to me, quite Bretty nose, deep malt, some alcohol, fruit like dates or something. The lack of super obvious alch. nose is a plus in my book. Then the taste: some high alcohol, like the Rochefort 10, but more malty (in fact this malt is kind of like the depth [user_ex calls it malt syrup] found in Double Enghien Brune, but without the hops to counteract). Hmmm...I like it, but I can see how others woudn't.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Well, its obvious this is highly respected, but i just didnt see it. For me the alcohol showed to much, there was quite a strong malltiness and reasonably smooth, but a little to sweet and unbalanced. Not really elegant.
Dark color, good carbonation.  Aroma of yeast, peppery vanilla and fruity notes. Very complex and a nice balance between the fruity notes, sweetness and bitterness.
Very complex. Sweet, something fruity, lots of body, good aftertaste.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 The Westy connection is obvious at first sniff...Perpetual bread, thick cookie dough, red wine allusions, roasty cigar and herbal hop bitterness...Dark caramel and earth-filled cherries in an easy going, big-bubbled, yeasty finish...Sometimes its a little too doughy and fluffy, and thus seems rough and sugary...The best bottles are 4.5s, while some others are 4s for me...Anyway, I just love this style of beer, especially when it is so well-executed...This is better executed than Westy 12...

Like an Impressionist painting, beers in this genre are pleasing to the senses even when they dont have absolute genius of composition and technique.  This is a nice beer, to be sure, but lacks some of the complexity found elsewhere.  Massive head, soon gone, yeasty notes in the aroma.  Rich, sweet, port-like flavor, with raisin, not disguising the alcohol particularly well, with bitterness (not extreme) in the finish.

Intense aroma of hops, chocolate, yeast, porto and fruit (apple, raisins). Very full bodied. Sweet, malty taste with porto, some fruitiness and a alcohol burn. A bit tart. The aroma is more intense than the flavor. Nevertheless a complex and delicious beer, well worth looking for.
Bold black beer apperance, with little forth to form the head.  Platable and plesant beer with an overridding black currant quality.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2003 very creamy, more complex and more bitter than Chimay Bleu...
re-rate 18/03/03:
I realized I had underrated this one
Very strong notes of plum, raisin, and chocolate in the malt. Chocolate begins to dominate as the beer warms. Very complex and a HUGE beer. Not quite as good as the Westy beers, but close.

Tenminste houdbaar tot eind 2003: Huge plumbs, raison, and alcohol in a sweet taste.  Aroma has too much alcohol, but it is still nice and complex with huge yeast/bread tones. I think with more time to mellow out, it could be stunningly good.  Thanks Gusler!
a very dark ale that is a full bodied beer end of story.  once you open the bottle this awesome smell rushes your senses
Dark garnet color with significant yeast/proteins.  Small diminishing head.  Yeast and caramel aromas.  Flavors of dark bread, toffee and  farm yeast.  Finishes with a dry malt.  Alcohol very hidden.
Fruity,plums/rasins,toasted malt,toffee,nice warming alcohol prescence,sweet.
Extremely sweet, liquorice taste.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2003 Dark reddish brown. Fruity aroma, with hints of banana and apples. Very sweet, raisin flavour. Some toffee. When it warms up it reveals a a deep, complex malt character with notes of salty licorice, and a finish which is reminiscent of a madeira wood single malt whiskey.
A terrifically complex belgian brew.  Enjoy.

Luxurious and hearty warming brew. Pronounced maltiness is close to chocolaty with a strong dark fruitiness. Smooth and sweet, there is a nice accomodating oakiness that just tempers things down. I preferred the Tripel, my tastebuds are still a little immature when it comes to strong ales, but this one is still nothing short of outstanding.
This is a heavy guy. Lots of tastes and flavors, very complex, maybe too complex. I could suggest this one to every one.

Murky brown meaty red colour with a intermediate lasting beige head. Wierd aroma, swish the glass and you get an immediate puff of wonderful fruit, banana and sultana, that fades to malty/yeast. Smooth senous palate firing up the full range of tastebuds and adding to those in the nasal passages. The flavour starts as slightly sweet moving to a full bodied toasted malt/yeast. The closest I could get to an overall description was marmite or vegemite, but its  well balanced with the other bitter sweet flavours all the way to the bitter end. Im going to have to get myself a few more and try them at different temperatures. Im calling this one Africa, deep, dark and mysterious and worth exploring some more.
Fruity, with a sort of medicinal aroma, I cannot say what. Very generous taste.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2014 Bottle (BB Dec 18, 2017).

Head is initially average sized, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy dark brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (walnuts/pecans, caramel), moderately yeasty (basement), with notes of brown sugar, alcohol, raisin, overripe banana.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, watery/syrupy/velvety texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

A very easy-going, straightforward quad...pleasant but simple in the nose (walnuts, sugar, and yeast dominate everything else)...drinkable but still too sweet (and somewhat watery, syrupy, and fizzy) in the mouth.  Similar to Rochefort 10 in that its without flaws but uninspiring and somewhat lacking in depth and finesse; low/mid-3s in quality.  I re-sampled fresh bottles of Westy 8 and 12 recently as well and thats still by far the pick of the Trappist (and similar pseudo-Trappist) brews (not counting Orval, since its in an odd class all its own, of course), its not even close (Westy is still 4+ as of 2013, IMHO, totally without any bias and quite a bit of skepticism to be honest).

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 I sensed a medicinal aroma, along with alcohol, custard, banana bread, chocolate chip cookies and tropical fruits; pours a sticky, creamy, large and small interwined bubbled foam;  purple haziness that reminds me of Aventinus weizen-eisbock;  palate detects hard water used in this beer which is similar to the 6 and the 8; lively carbonation hits the mouth;  I tasted musty yeast, chocolate, vanilla cake with a wonderful creaminess; initial sip was numbing to my palate; alcohol is very warming;  this beer finishes with hints of bananas and a lingering marshmallow creme taste that lasts near a minute.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Huge head.  Nice complex aroma and flavor.  A very good, complex BSA.
Ive only had the St. Sixtus version of this beer, but what a beer!!!! Phenomenol. A strong flavor, and a higher alcohol content that Deüval. Drink two and call me in the morning.

Color; a mysterious brown.  The glass I have it in refracts the light in interesting ways and creates all sorts of different shades of brown.  The center is strictly murky (this is good).  The head is monstrous and thick with the proverbial Belgian lace sticking all over the glass.  The aroma is complex with hints of mustiness, fruitiness and slight tartness.  The bubbles that are everywhere in the glass were no indication of what was to come.  The palate was very clean and not bubbly like I had anticipated.  More high marks for that feature.  Flavor: Full bodied doesnt begin to describe the complexity of the flavor.  From a sweet/sour combination up front to warm, doughy raisny middle then a bit of alcohol in the finish.  This is a great finisher and a top class beer in my book.

Actually I was somewhat disappointed with this beer.  There was just something about it that tasted off.  Maybe I had an oxidized bottle.  all I know is I have tried many other that were better.  I will re-rate.
Very nice beer indeed. Has a hint of honey, with a mild flovery palate.
Incredible.  The abbot surely has it made!!
UPDATED: MAR 8, 2007 Strong aroma of vanilla pudding and raisin. Dark brown color, beige head, good lace. Sweet, very flavorful, vanilla, raisin, light butty and some nutmeg. Full yet sparkling.

Beautiful head, cloudy brown colour. Aroma of apple and blackcurrant. The taste does not live up to the aroma: it is fruity with a slightly disgusting sweetness. The finish is long with a touch of acidity.

dark brown, nice head; aroma: banana, powerful, one-dimensional; taste: way too sweet; aftertaste: banana, long and disgusting - I was once a great fan of this beer but I have now to admit that my passion for sweet beers has dramaticaly slowed down
Clearly brewed in the style of Rochy 10 and Westy 12, this beer features a great combination of fruits, nuts and alcohol on the palate. Very hearty and characterful.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2003 Dark brown color, reddish tinge, fully foaming head.  Apples and plums in the aroma and flavor.  Incredibly smooth and rich, satisfying.  Lighter in body but truly excellent.  Lights hints of chocolate.  Strong carbonation carries fruits through the palate easily.  Top notch.  10% ABV!  Unbelievable!  I'm giving it an extra point for not even hinting at alcohol.
